webTitle: Gascoigne trips up on his first night out

fields.headline: Gascoigne trips up on his first night out
fields.trailText: Everton got everything they bargained for and more from their star new recruit last night. Paul Gascoigne, playing his first game for them since moving from Middlesbrough, was immediately embroiled in drama over an altercation with Dundee United's French midfielder Joachim Fernandez which almost came to blows.
fields.body:
Everton got everything they bargained for and more from their star new recruit last night. Paul Gascoigne, playing his first game for them since moving from Middlesbrough, was immediately embroiled in drama over an altercation with Dundee United's French midfielder Joachim Fernandez which almost came to blows.

The 33-year-old former England player was on the field for only the first half of Everton's 2-1 defeat at Tannadice, but it was more than enough to make his mark.

Fernandez, who is on trial with United, tumbled to the ground in the 20th minute when Gascoigne appeared to trip him. After receiving treatment he jumped to his feet and confronted Gascoigne but was held back by the Everton defender David Unsworth, until the referee Gary Marshall intervened and asked for Fernandez to be subsituted.

As Gascoigne comebacks go it was entirely predictable, though he deserved credit for refusing to be provoked by Fernandez. He said later that he had "clipped the back of [Fernandez's] heels and he just fell over. I talked to him in the tunnel after and there was no problem."

Gascoigne had earlier shown signs that he might be a handy acquisition, linking well with Everton's other newcomer Thomas Gravesen.

David Weir's 37th-minute goal gave Everton the lead before goals by Steven Thompson and Alex Mathie ensured a fitting result to a match which, rather than being remembered as a testimonial to Maurice Malpas, will go down as further testimony to a certain Geordie's penchant for fireworks.

fields.headline: Tricks of the trade
fields.standfirst:
How not to be a workaholic

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: How not to be a workaholic
fields.body:
Katie James, 42 project manager

Two years ago, I was promoted. My workload doubled and it had a profound effect on my life. I'm the main breadwinner in our house and I started putting work before my family, staying too late and becoming preoccupied with my job. I realised I had to change the situation, so I did three things: I cut out all non-essential meetings to improve my output, I limited myself to working only one hour beyond office hours and I asked my boss to employ an assistant for me. I gave him a detailed job description and a proposed salary for the position, and he agreed.

Mark Spencer, 50 sales manager

My last job dominated my life, to the extent that I didn't do anything else. I got over it by figuring out the most productive way of working, sorting the urgent from the important and the important from the trivial. Often, urgent things aren't urgent at all. I'd have meetings that were really just gossip sessions, but I had convinced myself I was working hard. You have to be honest with yourself. There's pressure on people to work late but if someone asks why I don't, I tell them I can close a deal twice as fast as younger managers because I have more experience. And it's true.

Alison Parker, 39 chief executive

In a previous job I worked very hard and, as my social life revolved around the organisation, I became a very boring person. If I had to make conversation that wasn't about my job, I was lost. I got so immersed in it that I even married a colleague. It was only when I changed jobs that I realised what a workaholic I had become. The way I got round it was to take up evening classes in something completely unrelated to my job, where I could meet people outside work and just get a different take on life. I still go every Thursday and those evenings are sacrosanct in my diary.

Tom Harris, 55 managing director

I'd set up my own business and worked really hard, doing 12-hour days, bringing work home and even taking my mobile on family holidays. Getting over workaholism was really difficult for me. I thought my business would collapse if I wasn't there and eventually I realised that this was because I was vain. I'd set up this business, so how could it survive without me? You have to be honest and figure out why you work so much. In my case it was self-importance, not efficiency or productivity. Realising that made it a lot easier for me to cut down on my hours.

Karen James, 28 publisher

It's hard not to be a workaholic because companies expect so much from you. I worked far too hard, was depressed and my health was suffering. I decided to get a life coach because I couldn't work out where my priorities lay and they look at the whole picture, rather than just your job or mental state. I realised that by being a workaholic, I abdicated myself of any responsibility in other areas of my life that needed my attention. Now I never work beyond 4pm on a Friday, never work at weekends and work hard at those other areas.

webTitle: Employers 'flout spirit' of minimum wage law

fields.headline: Employers 'flout spirit' of minimum wage law
fields.standfirst:
More about the minimum wage
The minimum wage explained
fields.trailText: Thousands of employers are flouting the spirit of the national minimum wage by cutting hours and making unreasonable demands on staff by increasing their workload, according to research published yesterday.
fields.body:
Thousands of employers are flouting the spirit of the national minimum wage by cutting hours and making unreasonable demands on staff by increasing their workload, according to research published yesterday.

Evidence is emerging of determined action to recover the costs of the £3.60 an hour minimum wage - shortly to be increased by 10p - through a variety of tactics including excessive charges for coffee and tea and removal of paid breaks and holiday entitlements.

The survey, based on the experiences of clients visiting Citizens Advice Bureaux in the north-east, revealed a catalogue of intimidation by employers, including the threat of dismissal. It singled out private care homes for the elderly as the main source of exploitation. Advice workers followed up a string of complaints about dismissal, "unlawful deductions from wages" and cuts in hours.

The research highlighted the case of a care assistant whose employer introduced a £9 weekly charge for drinks which had been provided free.

Another case concerned women working at a florist's shop who asked for a rise after hearing about the minimum wage. The employer told them she could not afford it and advised them "to go on the dole and ask about it". When they persisted, she said: "I can do anything I like with part-timers - finish them, cut their hours down. Basically, I can treat them like shite."

A cleaner was paid the minimum wage but told by her employer that he expected her to work a lot harder to earn it. He threatened to "make something for you to do every minute of the day from now on". The women left her job because his attitude was so aggressive.

A part-time taxi driver had her pay increased by £1 an hour to meet the minimum, only to be told to sign a form saying she was self employed. If she signed it would terminate her employment; if she refused she would be sacked.

Although research for the report by the north region of the National Association of Citizens Advice Bureaux was undertaken last year, follow-up surveys uncovered similar abuse.

From findings this year at one job centre on Tyneside, the report pointed to the emergence of a separate jobs market for the national minimum wage, with £3.60 an hour becoming the rate for the job. "In the absence of trade union organisation or other intervention to raise wages and skill levels, workers in these jobs could become further trapped and demoralised."

Both the TUC and the independent Unemployment Unit, which does detailed research on job markets, said yesterday that the research from the north-east indicated abuse of the mimumum wage agreement across the country. Although many employers were cooperating with the legislation, several thousand were probably bending the rules.

Workers are open to exploitation because many of the 1.5m people who benefited from the wage, introduced in April last year, are part time. Many are women. The government has asked its low pay commission to review wage levels further with a view to an increase beyond 10p an hour by the end of next year or early in 2002.

But the north-east survey concluded that the government needed to improve enforcement, with more raids on work premises by teams from the inland revenue, to weed out unscrupulous employers.

Grigor McClelland, trustee of the Millfield House Foundation, which funded the study, said yesterday the research provided a "disturbing insight" into the working lives of people in low-paid jobs. "In wealth and income, Britain is one of the most unequal of the advanced economies. A properly enforced minimum wage is one important instrument for correcting this."

fields.headline: Rage against the machinery
fields.trailText:
Sleater-Kinney
Cockpit, Leeds
**
fields.body:
Sleater-Kinney
Cockpit, Leeds
**

It's hard enough being a 21st-century, radical feminist post-punk band, but Sleater-Kinney have a further enemy in the sound system. "This is our fourth member," says the trio's exasperated singer/guitarist, Carrie Brownstein, "the feedback!" Seconds later, guitarist Corin Rucker complains she can't hear herself play. "Rock 'n'roll!" shouts somebody, as the band grin through gritted teeth. Suddenly, Janet Weiss's drumkit collapses, meaning the poor girl has to sit out the second number. The crowd are - as they comment - "very nice" to them, but not only are Sleater-Kinney taking on centuries of patriarchal society, but medieval percussive technology and rock'n'roll PA systems still set up for hairy men with heavy metal guitars.

Their politics are not Sleater-Kinney's only distinguishing factor. Like about five bands in the history of rock (notably the Doors and Roxy Music), they have no bassist. Weirder still is Brownstein's unique, almost operatic wail. However, take these facts away (and the cultural baggage - former Riot Grrrls and so on), and the band are suddenly left looking ordinary and even dated. At their most melodic, they reach the heights of 90s Throwing Muses and Shudder to Think, but most often recall the early 80s Au Pairs. It is a sobering thought that for all the feminist progress in society, the music has gone backwards. Where the militant Au Pairs intrinsically understood the power of funk/dance rhythms in getting a message across, if you tried to dance to Sleater-Kinney's too-trad punk you would end up with ligament damage. (Whisper it: a bassist might not be a bad idea.)

Maybe they make sense in the US, but here, Rucker's ironic Aerosmith rock poses border on the archaic. A bit of Patti Smith's sassy attitude wouldn't have gone amiss. The band come across as really nice girls but, somehow, really nice girls aren't expected from blistering modern lyrics such as "looped her death on the internet, and a woman's life got cheaper that day". After 50 minutes, Brownstein's bellow recalls the sort of thing you'd shoo away with a broom. The sound system does them no favours, but their noble intentions deserve greater support from the sound of the band.

fields.headline: Details, but no drama
fields.trailText:
The Mystery of Charles Dickens
The Lowry, Salford
***
fields.body:
The Mystery of Charles Dickens
The Lowry, Salford
***

Whenever Charles Dickens embarked on one of his extensive reading tours, he would delight huge crowds both sides of the Atlantic by performing his characters. "I was an actor and a speaker as a baby," he once declared, with all the exaggeration of genius.

Written by Peter Ackroyd, Dickens's most recent bio- grapher, and an assiduous chronicler of London, this one-man play attempts to re-create the thrill of those readings, and by providing a narrative of the author's life, we are also encouraged to ponder the exchange between autobiography and fiction that informed the great man's work. This means that an industrious Simon Callow has to switch frequently from impersonal narrator to Dickens himself and then to Dickens's characters. And it is seldom a smooth transition.

Callow sometimes spins on his heels to signal a change, or sits down on the leather swivel-chair, but his tone when resuming the role of narrator is always an apologetic one. Like the audience, he seems happiest when Dickens's misfits, paupers and urchins are allowed to speak for themselves.

Giving us, among others, Mr Micawber, Pickwick, Scrooge, Mrs Gamp, a tearful Oliver Twist, and Squeers the Yorkshire schoolmaster in Nicholas Nickleby, Callow smuggles retarded or rotund vowels out of his beard with equal aplomb, or he spits them out, his mouth side-stitched, his lips trembling. He relishes the ugly grimace and cockney leer of the market cheap-jack, the stooping gait and growl of Fagin, or the howls of a madman living at the top of his voice - all of which are rendered with eye-bulging intensity.

In between, we return to biographical details: Dickens's childhood poverty, his terrible months toiling in the Blacking warehouse, his doomed marriage. But the slightly forced, Reader's Digest tone rather smothers the comic grotesqueries that went before. With few effects and no music, there is insufficient theatre here. Dickens's affair with the young actress, Ellen Ternan, which could have added drama, is alluded to but largely unexplored.

In the end, the play - if you can call it that - only leaves the page for Callow's masterful impersonations, and while something of Dickens's restless spirit is invoked, you will have to dust down the novels to appreciate fully the mystery of the man.

fields.headline: Imagine no computer
fields.standfirst:
How long could you live without yours? An hour? A day? A week? A month? As one boss in Japan tries to separate his staff from their screens, Merope Mills examines the implications

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: How long could you live without yours? An hour? A day? A week? A month? As one boss in Japan tries to separate his staff from their screens, Merope Mills examines the implications
fields.body:
He will probably be called backward and undoubtedly labelled a Luddite, but Mitsuyasu Ota, the mayor of Hirata in Japan, doesn't care. In a bold and highly unpopular move, the boss of the town's municipal offices has just imposed a one-day-a-week ban on the use of computer equipment at work.

The move, Ota claims, is intended to show staff how to work. "Despite administration being human-contact work, there are a lot of young staff who mistakenly think that they are working by just sitting at their computers or word processors," he says.

Unsurprisingly, this has gone down like a lead balloon with the Hirata City staff who claim work will be left undone as a result. Writing by hand and communicating without email, they gripe, will be "inefficient" and waste paper. But Ota is not interested in their complaints. It was his own love of computers and his increasing reliance on them, he points out, that prompted him to impose the computer-free day.

In our hi-tech modern world, such a step seems like self-inflicted torture. To most of us, wiping out computer use at work would be inconceivable to the smooth running of the office. But perhaps Ota is right. Perhaps our computer-heavy culture actually does do more harm to our work than good. After asking a handful of people to jot down a daily computer diary at work, it is tempting to side with Ota. A database software tester who spends most of his days glued to a screen relays part of his day:

9am Ease into the day with a strong coffee before booting up and checking emails in anticipation of some funny forwards to amuse me through my first half hour.

9:30am Headphones go on. MP3 server is activated so I can listen to music while working at pace through a report document in Word.

11.30am Casual surf of the internet to find details of last-minute bargain flights for my summer hols.

2.30pm Email attachments from friends start arriving. I have my work cut out playing with them and ensuring they are forwarded to appropriate parties. Gems include a "How naughty are you in bed?" quiz, the obligatory David Beckham joke and a string of cartoons about different nationalities' willies.

And so on. This wasn't how it was supposed to be. When computers were introduced into our working lives, they were seen as the key to a hyper-productive workplace. But the promised benefits of increased IT investment have failed to materialise. Theories abound as to why what economists call the "productivity paradox" exists, but most users will admit that alongside computational privileges come distractions. Perhaps the endless technical problems or sheer irritation of being stuck in front of a monitor all day begin to take their toll.

Take a sneaky peek at some of your co-workers and you might see why Ota has chosen to veto one of his favourite office tools. Those hands deftly gliding across the mouse pad may actually be succumbing to the latest edition of computer solitaire. But be quick or you'll miss it. These days, many computer games come equipped with a "boss screen" that pops up to deter probing eyes. Such in-built paranoia is there for a reason. Accountants Accpac International estimate that American businesses lose around $100bn per year to PC gaming.

Likewise, electronic mail has proved a mixed blessing in the workplace. As well as the time-consuming replies to friends and colleagues, experts admit that email exchanges at work are rarely as productive as face-to-face conversations. "Communicating via computer doesn't require you to interact with individuals," says Ivan Robertson, an occupational psychologist at UMIST. "This means people don't interact on a social level, so it takes away the glue that keeps people bound together. The social signals of behaviour aren't seen by email, so you end up with people sending quite terse messages which are very bad for company morale."

Interacting via computer, he says, involves a completely different set of social rules since people are more blunt and honest when they are not talking face-to-face. "On the plus side, it can flatten the hierarchy and improve communication between different levels in an organisation. But there is evidence that people don't engage properly because computers take away a lot of the characteristics you need for a job to be satisfying - skill variety, control of a task and the identity people have with their work. When you are driven down this route, as call centre workers are, you end up feeling disempowered."

This feeling can bring problems of its own. Cliff Saran, technical editor of Computer Weekly magazine, describes the experience of being busy doing nothing in front of his PC. "People tend to be very reactive when sitting in front of a computer, so it's easy to find yourself just staring at it waiting for something to happen," he says. "If you deal a lot with emails, you might be avidly awaiting one, but actually doing nothing but twiddling your thumbs until it arrives."

He likens the numbness he sometimes feels in front of his computer to a sort of writer's block. "Sometimes I've got a blank document open and I just can't get started because there's nothing, no prompts on the screen."

UMIST professor Pete Makin has researched behaviour in email use and says: "When they arrive, people find reading them more pleasurable than working, so it's a good excuse to leave what they're doing. Most organisations like to keep on the little noise emails make when they arrive, but it just puts people off their work."

Robert Kling, professor of information science at Indiana University and author of Computerization and Controversy, has been debating the productivity paradox for some time. "There has been a relentless promotion of computerisation as almost guaranteeing large productivity gains at work," he says, "but the economic evidence doesn't bear that out."

As people use computers continuously and intently, he argues, it is much harder for bosses to understand how and what work is being done. "A lot of it looks the same these days - just people staring at a screen. In the days of paper mail, people walking past could see whether or not you had stuff to deal with. Now anyone casually casting an eye over your desk can't tell how much work you have to handle and what's urgent and what's not. Work has become much more privatised."

As everyone sits transfixed in front of their own screen, "go-slows" are becoming harder to check. Our distracted database software tester admits at least half his work day lies in putting on a show: "I face the people in the room I work in, so as long as I am looking at the screen and my hand is on the mouse, it looks OK."

For that reason, it is harder to detect the time-wasters or distracted. Jeff Madrick, editor of the American economic journal Challenge Magazine, points out: "People get preoccupied at work with all the different functions of their computers, partly because there are so many games to be played and so much information to be accessed, and because the office system is usually much faster than their system at home."

He argues that a lot of people are attracted to the idea of thumping away at their computers as their contribution to the New Economy, but says they are actually not achieving much in the process. "There is novelty involved in computer work - part of the interest is simply because these products are hot. A lot of the New Economy is just a big game for adults, a new, fun way of working."

These distractions have their downside, Kling adds. "Computer work can be very seductive, which isn't necessarily a good thing. In a bold and highly unpopular move, the boss of the town's municipal offices has just imposed a one-day-a-week ban on the use of computer equipment at work. The move, Ota claims, is intended to show staff how to work. "Despite administration being human-contact work, there are a lot of young staff who mistakenly think that they are working by just sitting at their computers or word processors," he says. Unsurprisingly, this has gone down like a lead balloon with the Hirata City staff who claim work will be left undone as a result. Writing by hand and communicating without email, they gripe, will be "inefficient" and waste paper. But Ota is not interested in their complaints. It was his own love of computers and his increasing reliance on them, he points out, that prompted him to impose the computer-free day. In our hi-tech modern world, such a step seems like self-inflicted torture. To most of us, wiping out computer use at work would be inconceivable to the smooth running of the office. But perhaps Ota is right. Perhaps our computer-heavy culture actually does do more harm to our work than good. After asking a handful of people to jot down a daily computer diary at work, it is tempting to side with Ota. A database software tester who spends most of his days glued to a screen relays part of his day: 9am Ease into the day with a strong coffee before booting up and checking emails in anticipation of some funny forwards to amuse me through my first half hour. 9:30am Headphones go on. MP3 server is activated so I can listen to music while working at pace through a report document in Word. 11.30am Casual surf of the internet to find details of last-minute bargain flights for my summer hols. 2.30pm Email attachments from friends start arriving. I have my work cut out playing with them and ensuring they are forwarded to appropriate parties. Gems include a "How naughty are you in bed?" quiz, the obligatory David Beckham joke and a string of cartoons about different nationalities' willies. And so on. This wasn't how it was supposed to be. When computers were introduced into our working lives, they were seen as the key to a hyper-productive workplace. But the promised benefits of increased IT investment have failed to materialise. Theories abound as to why what economists call the "productivity paradox" exists, but most users will admit that alongside computational privileges come distractions. Perhaps the endless technical problems or sheer irritation of being stuck in front of a monitor all day begin to take their toll. Take a sneaky peek at some of your co-workers and you might see why Ota has chosen to veto one of his favourite office tools. Those hands deftly gliding across the mouse pad may actually be succumbing to the latest edition of computer solitaire. But be quick or you'll miss it. These days, many computer games come equipped with a "boss screen" that pops up to deter probing eyes. Such in-built paranoia is there for a reason. Accountants Accpac International estimate that American businesses lose around $100bn per year to PC gaming. Likewise, electronic mail has proved a mixed blessing in the workplace. As well as the time-consuming replies to friends and colleagues, experts admit that email exchanges at work are rarely as productive as face-to-face conversations. "Communicating via computer doesn't require you to interact with individuals," says Ivan Robertson, an occupational psychologist at UMIST. "This means people don't interact on a social level, so it takes away the glue that keeps people bound together. The social signals of behaviour aren't seen by email, so you end up with people sending quite terse messages which are very bad for company morale." Interacting via computer, he says, involves a completely different set of social rules since people are more blunt and honest when they are not talking face-to-face. "On the plus side, it can flatten the hierarchy and improve communication between different levels in an organisation. But there is evidence that people don't engage properly because computers take away a lot of the characteristics you need for a job to be satisfying - skill variety, control of a task and the identity people have with their work. When you are driven down this route, as call centre workers are, you end up feeling disempowered." This feeling can bring problems of its own. Cliff Saran, technical editor of Computer Weekly magazine, describes the experience of being busy doing nothing in front of his PC. "People tend to be very reactive when sitting in front of a computer, so it's easy to find yourself just staring at it waiting for something to happen," he says. "If you deal a lot with emails, you might be avidly awaiting one, but actually doing nothing but twiddling your thumbs until it arrives." He likens the numbness he sometimes feels in front of his computer to a sort of writer's block. "Sometimes I've got a blank document open and I just can't get started because there's nothing, no prompts on the screen." UMIST professor Pete Makin has researched behaviour in email use and says: "When they arrive, people find reading them more pleasurable than working, so it's a good excuse to leave what they're doing. As people use computers continuously and intently, he argues, it is much harder for bosses to understand how and what work is being done. "A lot of it looks the same these days - just people staring at a screen. In the days of paper mail, people walking past could see whether or not you had stuff to deal with. Now anyone casually casting an eye over your desk can't tell how much work you have to handle and what's urgent and what's not. Work has become much more privatised." As everyone sits transfixed in front of their own screen, "go-slows" are becoming harder to check. Our distracted database software tester admits at least half his work day lies in putting on a show: "I face the people in the room I work in, so as long as I am looking at the screen and my hand is on the mouse, it looks OK." For that reason, it is harder to detect the time-wasters or distracted. webTitle: Byatt pulls plug on Kelda's mutual plan

fields.headline: Byatt pulls plug on Kelda's mutual plan
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Water regulator Sir Ian Byatt yesterday pulled the plug on a plan by Yorkshire water supplier Kelda to turn itself into a mutual business owned by its customers.
fields.body:
Water regulator Sir Ian Byatt yesterday pulled the plug on a plan by Yorkshire water supplier Kelda to turn itself into a mutual business owned by its customers.

Sir Ian said that Kelda had failed to convince him this particular £2.4bn scheme had any real advantages to the 1.9m customers. The decision could undermine plans for other potential water mutuals.

The Ofwat regulator said Kelda had failed to consult water users in Yorkshire properly. He dismissed company claims that there was little opposition to its planned restructuring. Sir Ian said the Bishop of Leeds and a 100-strong meeting in that city on July 6 had underlined the depth of feeling against the moves.

The Ofwat decision was welcomed by consumer and labour groups which feared that Kelda was trying to hand over debt from shareholders to customers.

Last night Kelda said it had dropped the plan and would not be putting forward any alternative scheme in the near future. "We will go back to running the business and see what structures others come up with," said a spokesman.

Kelda said the decision was a blow to others, such as Hyder and Anglia, looking at mutuals and expressed frustration that the regulator had failed to rule on the principle of separating asset ownership from operations.

The City had already built failure into the share price and Kelda ended the day up 2p at 318p. The stock has rallied in recent months on the back of plans to return money from the sale to shareholders but remains among the cheapest of the water stocks.

The sector has been depressed by Sir Ian's tough price controls, hence the attempts to find new ways of improving the financial position.

Turning down the Kelda plan the Ofwat chief said: "Water utilities should not become mutuals unless there are clear benefits to customers. This has still to be demonstrated; the advantages claimed could be achieved within the existing equity model."

He said the planned mutual would not have been entirely independent from Kelda because two of the mutual's most senior directors would hold shares in Kelda, leading to conflicts of interest. Sir Ian said: "Kelda seems to have been slow to recognise this."

The regulator urged water companies to look at other ways of reducing costs such as taking on more debt or further contracting out of services. He dismissed suggestions companies were being driven into the ground by price controls.

Drippy image lingers on

In the 11 years since privatisation, shareholders have been generally well served in dividends, but customers have a different experience and the image of Yorkshire Water - from fat cats to apparently hopeless hunters after leaks - has entered the joke books in permanent hardback form. Their poor image was not rescued by the name change to Kelda Group two years ago.

The drought of 1995-96 was one of the lowest points. While rain fell elsewhere in the north, the reservoirs of Scammonden, Angram and the Washburn Valley dwindled away into mud. At the same time 26% of what water remained dribbled from leaky pipes.

The late Sir Gordon Jones, who led the firm through the crisis, had a dour approach focused on making the business a financial success. His deputy Trevor Newton famously claimed to wash in a kitchen bowl although later he admitted taking baths at his mother's home in water-rich Northumbria. The road back to respectability has been hard, and dogged by the original pre-drought line of attack by critics of privatisation: that a free resource of Yorkshire had somehow been taken away and sold. This ignored such things as water rates and the undemocratic nature of the old, appointed Water Authority.

But it seemed to chime with Kelda's proposal of not-for-profit community ownership, on the lines of a mutual trust.

However, yesterday's announcement will now merely join a long line of infamous headline cuttings.

fields.headline: Animated at long last
fields.trailText:
David Sanchez
Jazz Cafe
***
fields.body:
David Sanchez
Jazz Cafe
***

David Sanchez is the young Puerto Rican saxophonist who started jazz life as a Dizzy Gillespie protege, an endorsement that opened plenty of doors. Unlike many horn- players of his generation, John Coltrane's sound hasn't filled his head (though on this week's evidence the late master's density of texture and whirling crescendos are preoccupying Sanchez more than they used to), and he often suggests an assured blend of Sonny Rollins's big tone and Joe Henderson's hauntingly mournful one.

Several influential premier-league American saxophonists have passed through the UK in recent months - Joshua Redman, Michael Brecker and James Carter among them - and Sanchez shared much of Redman's and Carter's big media welcome in the 90s. Yet the Puerto Rican's playing has sometimes seemed adept but faintly characterless compared to that of his peers, as if he were just a sideman in bands he happened to be leading. But that wasn't the case tonight. Though he complained of tiredness at the end of a long tour, Sanchez sounded particularly vigorous, and his percussion-strong band worked up a considerable heat.

As with much of his work, the set was mostly rugged, blurting postbop with a Latin tinge - the latter element growing in dominance through the show. A two-sax front line gave an attractively serpentine weave and wriggle to the ensemble melodies (Sanchez's altoist Miguel Zenon also liked a staccato strut on top of the beat, an engaging contrast with the leader's fluid rhythmic waywardness), and percussionist Pernell Santurnino's church- bell chimes against bustling congas and Indian drum sounds imparted unusual textures to the undertow. Santurnino and drummer Antonio Sanchez (often abetted by a fine regular Sanchez pianist, Edsel Gomez) stoked up increasingly stormy, heaving polyrhythms in the later stages, with the horns eagerly trading call-and-response figures over them.

It was a very animated business by comparison with David Sanchez's sometimes rather statuesque earlier London gigs, and uncovered a lot more of the promise Dizzy Gillespie must have heard a decade ago.

fields.headline: Windfalls for Axa members
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The 750,000 holders of policies of Axa Equity & Law and Axa Sun Life are to be offered windfalls averaging £400 if they back a plan to split up its £1.7bn "orphan" estate.
fields.body:
The 750,000 holders of policies of Axa Equity & Law and Axa Sun Life are to be offered windfalls averaging £400 if they back a plan to split up its £1.7bn "orphan" estate.

However, the scheme, devised after three years of negotiations with the regulators about how to handle the assets accumulated over the years through non-payment to "lost" policy holders, was immediately criticised for not giving enough money to policyholders and too much to shareholders.

The proposal prompted a fall in shares in many of the other insurance companies, including Prudential and CGNU, which remain locked in delicate and complicated discussions about how to deal with their much-larger orphan estates.

In total an estimated £20bn is tied up in such orphan estates, something not recognised in the insurers' accounts.

For the first time, the financial services authority said it was allowing an insurance company to buy out policyholders' entitlement to future distributions from the orphan estate.

The move caused confusion in the industry and led to protests from the Consumers' Association that the FSA had altered the usual split of the estate from 90% to policy holders and 10% to shareholders to 45% to shareholders and 55% to policyholders.

In a complicated arrangement, French-owned Axa is to pay £300m from its own assets to buy out policyholders' interests to future distributions from the estate, while it will divide up £250m of the £1.7bn orphan assets between policyholders and shareholders. The cash payments come from the £300m while other payments will be made in the reorganisation of the orphan estate.

At least 35% of the policyholders - one of whom stands to receive a £90,000 windfall - need to back the scheme. Those policyholders who do not back it will not qualify for payments. The payments to policyholders, who receive details of their entitlements next month, will be made next year provided they support the scheme at the vote in October. The courts will need to approve the scheme at a hearing in November.

fields.headline: England's Mike and Marcus show
fields.standfirst: West Indies face a new threat at next week's Old Trafford Test
fields.trailText: West Indies face a new threat at next week's Old Trafford Test, reports David Hopps.
fields.body:
Optimism abounds following England's magical recovery in the Lord's Test and their subsequent victory in the triangular one-day series, but a batting side that has failed to reach 200 in four tries against West Indies in Tests this summer requires serious attention, and the selectors duly provided it yesterday.

Michael Atherton's 14th opening partner in his 100th Test on Thursday week, on his home ground of Old Trafford, will be a debutant, Marcus Trescothick, a pairing which offers an intriguing contrast in both experience and approach.

It will be a new challenge for Trescothick after his NatWest one-day series exploits, but no one can accuse him of being oblivious to it. "Different ball, different bowlers, different fielding positions," he said yesterday. "Just different." That message seems to have got across, then.

A recall to the Test 13 of Graham Thorpe, and the automatic return after injury of the captain Nasser Hussain, could entail that England drop as many as three batsmen from the side at Lord's. Mark Ramprakash and Nick Knight are definitely omitted, but the third name will provide another bout of agonised conversation: Graeme Hick.

There is a fair possibility that England will duck the choice between Thorpe and Hick at No6 by fielding seven specialist batsmen, leaving Hick (a reluctant bowler) and Michael Vaughan (a little better than that) to offer up some spin tokenism, a dangerous ploy on an Old Trafford surface that traditionally encourages the slower bowlers.

David Graveney, the chairman of selectors, justified the alternative thus: "We need to get runs on the board and we can't expect to compete in a Test if we don't. We can't keep relying upon mercurial performances, such as that provided by Dominic Cork at Lord's, to keep bailing us out of trouble."

But it would be a negative strategy, which when last adopted in Australia two years ago brought heavy defeats in Perth and Adelaide. A far better balance would be achieved by fielding six batsmen and relying upon Craig White, Robert Croft and Cork to make supplementary runs in the late middle-order.

The Hick debate will resemble one of those BBC repeats, wheeled out for the umpteenth time. Nothing has changed. He is still prolific in county cricket, he still looks betrayed by limited footwork and a passive mental approach at Test level and every coach imagines he can find the key to unlock his mind. The team ethic will make Duncan Fletcher, for one, reluctant to jilt him again.

Thorpe, reunited with the Test squad for the first time since he eschewed last winter's tour of South Africa, is a class act. But before his exile he had passed 50 three times in two years, had become disenchanted and has hardly spent the summer crashing the ball against the advertising boards.

England's squad has been announced so early so that Fletcher can rule upon which England players must be rested from the next round of county matches. The introduction of central contracts, enabling England to rest key men, and a more competitive two-divisional championship, are both beneficial but potential conflict exists.

Consider this week's Roses match, which will determine whether Yorkshire or Lancashire will offer the most serious challenge to the title favourites, Surrey.

Darren Gough is busting a gut to play for Yorkshire, but he is a fast bowler who could gain from rest. Atherton could claim that batting for Lancashire will bring crucial match practice.

Fletcher must act for England's good but if he bars Gough from playing for Yorkshire, and lets Atherton bat for Lancashire, expect his head to be on a pikestaff outside Leeds town hall by the weekend.

England squad: N Hussain, MA Atherton, MP Vaughan, ME Trescothick, GA Hick, GP Thorpe, AJ Stewart, C White, DG Cork, AR Caddick, D Gough, RDB Croft, MJ Hoggard.

fields.headline: Arsenal fear Figo backlash
fields.standfirst: World's most expensive players
fields.trailText: A delegation from Barcelona will arrive in London on Thursday to open negotiations for Arsenal's Emmanuel Petit and Marc Overmars after reluctantly sanctioning Luis Figo's world-record £37m transfer to Real Madrid yesterday.
fields.body:
A delegation from Barcelona will arrive in London on Thursday to open negotiations for Arsenal's Emmanuel Petit and Marc Overmars after reluctantly sanctioning Luis Figo's world-record £37m transfer to Real Madrid yesterday.

Figo's controversial defection to Barcelona's fiercest rivals will be the catalyst for a frantic spell of transfer activity involving the Catalan club and their newly elected president Joan Gaspart has confirmed Petit and Overmars are his main targets.

In the face of intense pressure from Barcelona's disillusioned fans, Gaspart is prepared to test Arsène Wenger's resolve by making an official offer for both players, believed to be worth around £25m.

He said last night: "Everything here has stopped at the moment, but I still know who I want and I am going to England on Thursday to see what I can do. I will not let Barcelona down."

Gaspart polled 54% in a vote of Barcelona's 93,006 card-carrying members on Sunday to defeat the advertising magnate Lluis Bassat and succeed Josep Lluis Nunez as president after 22 years as his understudy.

During his election campaign the 55-year-old Gaspart promised that, should he win, he would immediately sign at least four players of proven international calibre, naming Petit and Overmars as well as the Real Betis striker Alfonso Perez and Lazio's Ivan de la Pena.

Wenger said yesterday there had been no official approach from the deposed Spanish champions but the Arsenal manager privately accepts it is only a matter of time if Gaspart honours his promise to the Barcelona fans.

It will then be a question of whether Wenger can deploy his powers of persuasion to talk two of his most influential players out of turning their backs on the club just three weeks before the season starts.

However, the Frenchman is sounding increasingly despondent after long and frank discussions with both players. "It is very difficult to stop players leaving if somebody offers them three times as much [money]," he admitted yesterday.

Considering the financial implications, the likelihood is that Arsenal will launch their attempt to wrench the Premiership title from Manchester United's vice-like grip without two of the players who have been instrumental to the club's success under Wenger.

Although Petit has often threatened to return to the continent, the 29-year-old Frenchman went on record last month to indicate he was willing to remain an Arsenal player for at least another season. Even so, the riches on offer in Spain and the chance to play for one of the world's biggest clubs will almost certainly see him ending his turbulent but nevertheless successful stay in English football.

Overmars's revelations during Euro 2000 that he was unsettled at Arsenal have given further credence to the belief that the 27-year-old winger would relish the chance to join the already considerable Dutch contingent at the Nou Camp.

Figo's transfer caused so much interest in Spain yesterday that the sports daily Marca carried minute-by-minute updates on its website.

The Portuguese winger is not the first player to move from Barcelona to Real but his popularity at the Nou Camp and the division it has caused between the two clubs provided Spanish football with one of its biggest sensations for years.

Figo, 27, can look forward to banking £3.74m a year until 2006 - double his wages at Barcelona - and his new contract incorporates a buy-out clause meaning any club that wants to sign him will have to pay £111.2m.

His transfer breaks the previous world record (£36m) set a fortnight ago when the Argentine striker Hernan Crespo moved from Parma to Lazio, but the money will be of little consolation to Barcelona's fans.

webTitle: Kapil's despair in a textbook case of humiliated heroes

fields.headline: Kapil's despair in a textbook case of humiliated heroes
fields.trailText: Kapil Dev might have been forgiven for thinking things could not get any worse. But last night, four days after income tax officials raided his home, India's fallen cricket hero suffered the indignity of having himself removed from a school textbook.
fields.body:
Kapil Dev might have been forgiven for thinking things could not get any worse. But last night, four days after income tax officials raided his home, India's fallen cricket hero suffered the indignity of having himself removed from a school textbook.

The Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI), India's equivalent of the FBI, has not yet decided whether he was involved in match-fixing. But education officials in the state of Gujarat yesterday pronounced their own verdict on the beleaguered national coach.

The state education department has decided to drop an autobiographical chapter by the cricketer, entitled the World of Kapil Dev, from an English textbook for 15- and 16-year-olds. According to the education minister Anandiben Patel, the chapter will be excluded from the syllabus and no questions asked on it in examinations this academic year. From next year it will be removed from the textbook entirely, she said.

Patel said her department would issue the damning order today. Several parents contacted her last month after India's former player Manoj Prab hakar claimed Kapil offered him a bribe to play badly in a match against Pakistan, a charge Kapil denies. Initially Patel said she told parents to wait until the government inquiry was finished. "Now I feel it is time to take a decision," she said.

The chapter gives a colourful account of Kapil's childhood in the north Indian town of Chandigarh. Describing himself as a "naughty child", he recounts how he once stole a police horse which was grazing in a field next to his home.

Before yesterday's ruling, Gujarat was filled only with pleasant associations for Kapil. His company Dev Mesco refurbished the floodlights at the cricket stadium in Ahmedabad, the state capital. It was also here that he emerged in happer times as the top wicket-taker in the world.

Kapil is not the only Indian cricketer in trouble, though. As well as rummaging through his houses in Delhi and Bombay, income tax officials last week raided properties belonging to several other players and former players, including Mohammad Azharuddin, Ajay Jadeja, the wicketkeeper Nayan Mongia, Nikhil Chopra, Navjot Sidhu and Ajay Sharma.

webTitle: Leeds to launch new Ferdinand bid

fields.headline: Leeds to launch new Ferdinand bid
fields.trailText: Leeds intend to test West Ham's resolve to hang on to Rio Ferdinand by making a second bid to lure the gifted young centre-back away from Upton Park.
fields.body:
Leeds intend to test West Ham's resolve to hang on to Rio Ferdinand by making a second bid to lure the gifted young centre-back away from Upton Park.

Less than a fortnight after having a bid of around £9m rejected, Leeds are ready to lodge an improved offer worth in excess of £10m.

The Leeds manager David O'Leary hopes to persuade his counterpart at West Ham, Harry Redknapp, to do business by offering a players-plus-cash deal which could see the defenders Michael Duberry and Danny Mills move back to London.

Leeds are not alone in coveting the 21-year-old Ferdinand. In the last few weeks Real Madrid and Barcelona have contacted West Ham to underscore their interest.

However, Redknapp and his club's board remain hopeful that they can rebuff all advances and that Ferdinand will see out the remaining four years of his West Ham contract.

"I would like to keep Rio here for the rest of his career," said the West Ham chairman Terry Brown yesterday.

The former Leeds striker Tony Yeboah, facing a tax evasion charge in a German court next month, has agreed on a settlement in which he will pay the authorities about £130,000, his lawyer said yesterday.

Thomas Kruppa said that he expected the trial, scheduled to begin on August 3, would now be cancelled.

Yeboah, who plays for Hamburg, allegedly failed to pay tax on about £730,000 the striker received after extending his contract with Eintracht Frankfurt in 1993.

Manchester City may be without their top scorer Shaun Goater for the first month of the season.

The Bermudian striker has flown back from the club's Irish tour for an exploratory knee operation after being hurt in Saturday's 4-0 win over Linfield in Belfast. Goater said a scan "revealed a slight tear in my cartilage".

The Bristol Rovers striker Jason Roberts is set to sign for West Bromwich for £2m. The fee has been agreed and now the 22-year-old must agree personal terms and pass a medical.

Burnley have signed the midfielder Kevin Ball from Fulham on a two-year contract. The 35-year-old former Sunderland player has moved to Turf Moor on a free transfer.

Sam Hammam, the former Wimbledon owner, is close to completing his takeover of Cardiff City. The Lebanese businessman said yesterday he should finalise his £3.1m deal in the next two weeks for 82.5% of the Third Division club.

 France, European champions at senior level, captured the Under-18 title yesterday when they beat Ukraine 1-0 in the final in Nuremberg.

webTitle: Everton eye Ferguson for rapid return

fields.headline: Everton eye Ferguson for rapid return
fields.trailText: Having already provided the summer recess with its major talking point by signing Paul Gascoigne, the Everton manager Walter Smith is seriously considering an even more audacious coup: the return of Duncan Ferguson to Goodison Park only 19 months after he was controversially sold to Newcastle United for £8m.
fields.body:
Having already provided the summer recess with its major talking point by signing Paul Gascoigne, the Everton manager Walter Smith is seriously considering an even more audacious coup: the return of Duncan Ferguson to Goodison Park only 19 months after he was controversially sold to Newcastle United for £8m.

That deal, brokered by the former Newcastle manager Ruud Gullit, was negotiated and sanctioned by the former Everton chairman Peter Johnson behind Smith's back, an act which ultimately precipitated major changes within the Goodison boardroom.

Ferguson will be permitted to leave Newcastle if any club formally lodge an offer of about £3.5m. However, if Smith does decide to give the Scottish striker the opportunity to return to Goodison, Ferguson's professed love for all thing Everton will be tested to the limit.

He is currently one of the highest-paid players in British football, having signed a five-year contract worth £9.5m when he left Everton in December 1998. If he wants to rejoin the Merseyside club he will have to agree to a deal which would see his weekly wage shrink from £38,000 to £20,000.

Although Bill Kenwright, Everton's vice-chairman and guardian of the purse strings, recently insisted that the re-signing of Ferguson was not on the agenda, Smith declined to concur. "Never say never," he said when asked whether fast-spreading rumour of a deal could safely be discounted.

Ferguson is currently on tour with Newcastle in the United States but did not even make the substitutes' bench at the weekend for the 3-1 defeat by DC United in Washington. His chances of an Everton return have improved as he has slipped out of the Newcastle side just as Smith's search for a striker has floundered.

With Kevin Campbell likely to miss the opening month of the season because of a knee injury, Smith has been unsuccessfully scouring Europe for a forward who can act as an old-fashioned target man for his array of new midfielders, Gascoigne, Alex Nyarko and Niclas Alexandersson.

Meanwhile, Liverpool yesterday increased to £5.5m their bid for Middlesbrough's Christian Ziege. The Liverpool manager Gérard Houllier has been searching for a left-back to replace Dominic Matteo and believes that the German international is the best available.

Even if Middlesbrough reject the new approach, Ziege is rumoured to have a clause in his contract that allows him to speak to any club bidding more than £5m for his services.

Bryan Robson, the Middlesbrough manager, spoke to Ziege last week and seemed reassured that the 28-year-old German, signed last summer from Milan for £4m, was happy to remain on Teesside. Ziege may, however, find the temptation of leaving Middlesbrough's Premiership makeweights in favour of Liverpool's championship challenge, where he would join his fellow German internationals Markus Babbel and Dietmar Hamann, impossible to resist.

webTitle: 'The Concorde crash was like a mini atomic bomb'

fields.headline: 'The Concorde crash was like a mini atomic bomb'
fields.standfirst: More about the Concorde crash
fields.trailText:
US president Bill Clinton
"I want to extend the deepest condolences of the American people to the families of those who are lost."
fields.body:
US president Bill Clinton
"I want to extend the deepest condolences of the American people to the families of those who are lost."

Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy
"This is a terrible tragedy. Our hearts and minds go out to the families of those who have lost their lives. Many questions will be asked about how such a catastrophe could have happened. At this stage it is a moment for complete sympathy."

British Airways statement
"Our thoughts and sympathies are with our colleagues at Air France, and all those involved in this tragedy. We have already been in touch with Air France and offered any assistance we can provide. We have complete confidence in our Concorde aircraft and our engineering. Nevertheless in these circumstances - and while information is still coming in - we have taken the unprecedented step of cancelling tonight's flights."

David Wiltshire, Conservative MP for the Heathrow constituency of Spelthorne
"I'm trying to contact British Airways to ask them to ground their Concordes until we get to the bottom of this. I'm not saying there is any connection between the crash and the cracks problem. But my constituents will have sleepless nights until we get some reassurances."

Gwyneth Dunwoody, chairwoman of the Commons transport sub-committee
"This is the most tragic accident, and our sympathies go to the families and friends of everyone involved. It is, however, important to remember that Concorde has an extremely high safety record. Both BA and Air France will want to take a little time to consider their responses to the accident, and to see the results of consultations with the air accident branches. But at this point I don't think it's necessary to ground Concorde."

US pilot Sid Hare, who witnessed the disaster
"[The explosion was like a] mini atomic bomb. I could see smoke from wherever it had just taken off. It was so low to the ground it was obscured by the hotels. I knew it was in trouble. The left side engine had a catastrophic failure, it was in flames, it could not gain altitude."

fields.headline: Concorde: the technical details
fields.trailText: Air France and British Airways currently operate Concorde aircraft, which remain the only supersonic passenger jets in use. At its fastest, the aircraft has crossed the Atlantic from New York to London in 2 hours 54 minutes and 45 seconds.
fields.body:

fields.headline: Concorde crash: reports from France
fields.standfirst:
More about the Concorde crash
Translations by Ros Taylor
fields.trailText:
A policeman on the scene
"The plane completely broke up when it hit the ground. All you can see now are the smoking remains of the hotel."
fields.body:
A policeman on the scene
"The plane completely broke up when it hit the ground. All you can see now are the smoking remains of the hotel."

Transport minister Jean-Claude Gayssot "Concorde has never had a major accident in which there were casualties. There have been accidents, it's true, but never a disaster like this. This is a terrible time for us - both for the civil aviation authorities and for Air France.

So far the black box flight recorder has not been found, but we imagine it will be located soon."

French interior minister Jean-Pierre Chevenement
"One of the plane's engines caught fire. It tried to turn back, but failed, and then exploded between two hotels - the Relais bleu and the Hotelissimo - which were probably empty."

TV channel TF1
"The blazing Concorde took off in front of passengers on other Air France flights, including French president Jacques Chirac, who was returning from Tokyo.

The presidential plane had just landed and was taxiing towards the terminal when the pilot told passengers that he had to make way for Concorde on the runway. According to one of Mr Chirac's party, the passengers saw smoke escaping from the engines, then flames, before Concorde took off like a fiery rocket and disappeared for a few moments before raising its nose."

French daily Liberation
"The crash was followed by a giant fireball as the thousands of tons of engine fuel caught fire and caused several explosions. Some of the cars on the nearby motorway were hit by debris from the plane, which was scattered over several tens of metres. Four people who were near the hotel died in the crash, according to emergency services.

One of the Concorde's left engines burst into flames as the plane was taking off at 50m above ground, a witness said. He described how flames between 10-15 metres long streamed from the engine."

The crashed Concorde's insurers, La Reunion Aerienne
"We have no comment to make for the moment. It's too soon."

Stephane Prevost, a manager at Roissy airport
"The plane passed very low over the offices [at Roissy], it was having trouble picking up altitude. It flew over the motorway and crashed next to Gonesse."

Roissy official
"The plane took off with the engines ablaze... I saw it take off, try to turn and fall just as it started to do so. All the runways are closed and flights from Roissy have been cancelled."

An Air France employee who witnessed the crash
"The engine caught fire. There was a big cloud of smoke which covered virtually the whole of the runway. Nonetheless the plane took off and gathered speed and a second later crashed on the hotel and restaurant behind us.... It made much more noise than usual during the take-off.

Mohamed, a resident of Gonesse
"The plane was already in flames by the time it took off. They tried to turn back to Roissy. It grazed the tops of the trees before it crashed into the middle of the Hotelissimo hotel.

"As soon as we heard the explosion, we ran towards the hotel and were among the first to reach it. We tried to get in. I broke a window with my elbow but the trees around us were on fire. Then there was another explosion."

The owner of the Relais bleu hotel
"I thought it was going to land on my office when I saw it coming towards me in flames. I dropped the phone and ran for it.

The Concorde passed a few metres away from the building and crashed on the hotel next door. The flames were 15 metres away from me. The manager of the Hotelissimo was burnt, a visitor is in shock and one of the guests jumped out of a window. Members of staff and other guests were inside. I think they must be dead."

webTitle: Concorde: pride of Britain's air fleet

fields.headline: Concorde: pride of Britain's air fleet
fields.standfirst: More about the Concorde crash
fields.trailText: Concorde has been the pride of Britain's air fleet since the first model made its maiden flight more than three decades ago.
fields.body:
Concorde has been the pride of Britain's air fleet since the first model made its maiden flight more than three decades ago.

The supersonic jet took off from the Aerospatiale airfield in Toulouse, France, in March 1969.

Since then the fleet has logged more than 900,000 flying hours, two thirds of which have been above the speed of sound. And despite the technical advances that have been achieved, the jet is still considered the premier way to travel by passengers and pilots alike.

The first Concorde, the 001 prototype, was a joint venture between Britain and France costing an estimated £950m. Britain and France started working separately towards a supersonic aircraft in 1956. They were working along such similar lines that in 1962 they decided to develop it jointly, a partnership that led to 20 aircraft being built.

The second prototype, the British-built Concorde 002, made a successful maiden voyage from Filton aerodrome, Bristol, on April 9 1969. By November 1970 both prototypes had flown at Mach 2, twice the speed of sound.

Concorde is powered by four Olympus 593 engines jointly developed by Rolls-Royce and the French company Snecma. Each engine is capable of producing 38,000lb thrust and powering Concorde at Mach 2.

Concorde's first pre-production aircraft flew in December 1971 and the first production aircraft took to the skies two years later. On January 21 1976 the first commercial Concorde services were flown simultaneously by British Airways to Bahrain and by Air France to Rio de Janeiro.

The aircraft had been subjected to 5,000 hours of testing by the time it was certificated for passenger flight.

Air France and British Airways each operate seven Concorde aeroplanes. The supersonic aeroplanes can carry 100 passengers and fly at 1,336mph and at an altitude of 55,000 feet.

But early hopes of selling the aircraft to airlines around the world came to nothing as the rising cost of oil and concerns about the amount of noise made by the plane led airlines to buy Boeing's 747 instead.

Cruising at 1,350mph - twice the speed of sound - Concorde's typical NewYork crossing takes little more than three and a half hours. The record for a transatlantic crossing stands at two hours 52 minutes 59 seconds - at an average speed of about 1,300mph.

The jet has an enviable safety record. But today's crash comes just 24 hours after it was revealed that a British Airways Concorde had been taken out of service after a crack developed in its wings. BA's other six supersonic jets also had cracks in the rear of their wings, but were been deemed "no risk to safety" by the Civil Aviation Authority and BA.

BA has repeatedly said of late that there was no reason why its Concordes should not fly well into the 21st century - possibly remaining in service until as late as 2015.

The aircraft has generally had an excellent safety record and only minor mishaps have bedevilled services until now. While BA was initially unable to comment on what future the plane now has, it is clear that serious consideration will have to be given to drastic action following today's crash.

It is possible that BA could decide to ground all its Concorde fleet until it has concluded what caused the crash. Part of Concorde's excellent safety record and apparent longevity was due to the fact that the vast speeds the aircraft maintains means that it suffers less wear and tear in terms of flying hours than the more traditional "workhorse" Boeing aircraft such as the 747, 737, 757 and 767.

fields.headline: The world's worst air disasters
fields.trailText: July 25 2000 An Air France Concorde crashes outside Paris, killing an estimated 113 people.
fields.body:
July 25 2000 An Air France Concorde crashes outside Paris, killing an estimated 113 people.

July 17 2000 An Air Alliance 737 crashes into a housing estate a mile away from Patna airport in India, killing 44 of the 51 passengers and crew and five people on the ground.

February 1 2000 All 88 passengers and crew killed when Alaska Airlines Flight 261 (MD-80) from Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, to San Francisco crashes into the Pacific off south California.

January 30 2000 Kenya Airways jet (Airbus 310) crashes into the sea shortly after take-off from Abidjan, Ivory Coast. 169 feared dead.

December 11 1999 Portuguese passenger plane crashes into mountain on Azores, killing all 35 on board.

October 31 1999 All 217 passengers and crew are killed when an EgyptAir Boeing 767 crashes into the Atlantic 60 miles off the Massachusetts coast.

September 1 1999 Sixty-four people killed when a Lineas Areas Argentina Boeing 737 crashes in flames on take-off from Buenos Aires and ploughs across a road.

August 23 1999 A China Airlines jetliner overturns while landing at Hong Kong international airport, killing two people.

June 2 1999 Nine die and 80 are injured when a plane breaks apart after skidding on a waterlogged runway while landing at Little Rock, Arkansas.

September 3 1998 Swissair flight 111 on journey from New York to Geneva crashes into sea south west of Halifax, Nova Scotia following fire in cockpit. All 229 passengers and crew killed.

August 20 1998 Four people die when twin-engined Cessna 402 plunges into sea between Stewart Island and New Zealand.

May 21 1998 A320 Charter flight carrying 180 passengers overshoots runway at Ibiza airport. Seventeen passengers suffered minor injuries.

March 24 1998 Microlight GT Global crashes into airport building at Le Touquet, France. Pilot suffered serious injuries.

March 18 1998 A Formosa Airlines plane crashed into the sea off north-west Taiwan killing 13.

February 16 1998 An China Airlines Airbus jet crashed at Taipei international airport (Taiwan) killing 205 passengers.

February 3 1998 A Nato jet cuts through the wire of a cable car in the Italian Dolomites killing 20 people.

February 2 1998 DC-9 crashed on Mount Sumagaya, Philippines, killing 104.

January 13 1998 A Taliban transport plane crashes in south-west Pakistan killing 51 people.

December 19 1997 A SilkAir Boeing 737-300 crashed on the island of Sumatra killing all 104 people on board.

December 17 1997 Ukrainian jet crashed on Mount Olympus killing all 72 on board.

December 15 1997 A Tajik Tupolev-154 airliner crashed in the desert in the United Aran Emirates killing 85 of the 86 people on board.

December 6 1997 Russian cargo plane (Antonov-124 Ruslan) crashes into a residential area of the Siberian city of Irkutsk. All 46 aboard were killed together with 80 residents.

October 12 1997 Argentinian DC-9 Austral airliner crashed in Uruguay killing all 74 people aboard.

September 26 1997 An Indonesian Airbus A300 B-4 crashed in Sumatra killing all 234 passengers and crew.

September 14 1997 A German military plane collided with a US military cargo plane killing 24 and nine respectively.

September 3 1997 A Vietnam Airlines plane plunged into a field near Cambodia's International airport killing 65 people. One child survived.

August 7 1997 A DC-8 cargo plane crashed within seconds of take-off from Miami airport killing three people.

August 5 1997 Korean Air Boeing 747 crashed at Guam killing 223 of the 254 people aboard.

July 26 1997 Nine people killed as a light aircraft belonging to the Jordanian air force crashes at an Ostend airshow.

May 9 1997 Boeing 737 crash-landed at Shenzhen airpot, southern China, killing 33 of 67 aboard.

March 18 1997 Fifty passengers and crew die as a Stavropol Airlines flight crashes 37 minutes after take-off from Stavropol to Trabzon on Trukey's northern coast.

March 13 1997 An Iranian C-130 Hercules military transport plane crashed 26 miles from the city of Mashhad killing 86 people on board.

February 2 1997 Seventy elite Israeli soldiers killed when two army helicopters collide near Kiryat Shmona, northern Israel.

February 1 1997 Jet crashes in Senegal, west Africa, killing 20 and injuring 32.

January 9 1997 ComAir flight 3272 crashed near Detroit killing all 31 passengers and crew aboard.

December 16 1996 Seventeen people are killed when a military plane crashed near the city of Pskov, north-west Russia.

November 23 1996 Hijacked Ethiopian Boeing 767 crashed off the Comoros islands in the Indian ocean killing 127.

November 13 1996 A Saudi Arabian Boeing 747 jumbo jet and Kazakhstani cargo plane collide mid-air near New Delhi, India, killing 349.

July 17 1996 All 238 people on board TWA 800 from New York to Paris are killed when the Boeing 747 explodes in mid-air shortly after departure from JFK Airport in New York and plunges into the ocean 14km south of Long Island.

January 8 1996 Some 350 die when a Russian-built Antonov-32 cargo plane crashes into a crowded market in the centre of the Zairean capital, Kinshasa.

July 2 1994 DC9 crashed in Charlotte, North Carolina

July 1 1994 Air Mauritanie Fokker-28 crashed in Tidjikja killing 94 of 101 passengers.

June 30 1994 Airbus A330 crashed on test flight in Toulouse, France. seven dead, including two Britons. Burst into flames after simulated engine failure.

May 8 1994 Zaire's foreign minister among nine dead when light aircraft crashed near Kinshasa.

June 24 1994 B-52 bomber crashed at Fairchild air base, Washington state. Four dead.

June 6 1994 Some 160 people killed as Chinese airliner crashed minutes after take-off from Xian. Russian manufactured Tu-154.

April 26 1994 Taiwanese airliner crashed at Nagoya airport, Japan. Some 264 killed in Japans second worst disaster. Airbus A300-600R.

April 4 1994 Schiphol airport, Amsterdam. Three dead, 21 injured when Dutch airlines Cityhopper crash-landed.

March 31 1994 Nine killed in south of Algeria's Sahara desert when helicopter crashed.

March 24 1994 Six from same family died when sight-seeing helicopter crashed over Transylvania, Romania. French built Alouette.

March 23 1994 Midair collision over Pope Air Force Base, Fayetteville, US. 20 dead.

March 23 1994 Aeroflot Airbus crashes into Siberian hillside. Seventy-five people dead, including four Britons.

March 18 1994 Iranian C-130 Hercules flying to Tehran, crashed over Nagorno-Karabakh. Thirty-two people killed. Iran blamed Armenia for shooting down plane.

March 14 1994 US AC-130 crashed into Indian ocean off Kenya. At least one dead.

July 1991 All 261 people on board a chartered Canadian Nationair DC-8 carrying Muslim pilgrims back to Nigeria were killed when it crashed in flames at Jeddah airport.

December 1988 Some 270 people including 11 on the ground were killed as a terrorist bomb blew apart an American-bound Pan-Am Boeing 747 over the Scottish town of Lockerbie.

July 1988 An Iranian Airbus was shot down by the US Navy ship Vincennes as it was flying across the Persian Gulf, killing 290 people with no survivors.

December 1985 DC8 crashed in Newfoundland, killing 258 US servicemen.

August 1985 A Japan Airlines Boeing 747 crashed in Japan leaving 520 dead and four survivors.

August 1980 A Saudi Arabian Tri-Star exploded during an attempted emergency landing after a fire, killing all 301 on board.

November 1979 An Air New Zealand DC-10 on a sight-seeing trip crashed on Mount Erebus in the Antarctic killing all 257 passengers and crew.

March 1977 Two Boeing 747 jumbo jets, belonging to Pan American and KLM Airlines, collided on the runway of Tenerife airport, killing 582.

March 1974 Turkish Airlines DC-10 en route to London crashed in a forest near Paris killing all 345 people on board, nearly 200 of them British.

June 1972 All 118 passengers and crew on a British European Airways Trident died when the plane crashed in Staines, Surrey, shortly after taking off from Heathrow airport.

Sources: Guardian R&I Unit and PA News

fields.headline: Previous Air France disasters
fields.standfirst:
There have been at least four air disasters involving the deaths of Air France passengers since 1970, reports Jeevan Vasagar
More about the Concorde crash
fields.trailText: There have been at least four air disasters involving the deaths of Air France passengers since 1970, reports Jeevan Vasagar.
fields.body:
April 1998 An Air France 727 crashed into a mountain three minutes after take-off from Bogota, Colombia. Although it was an Air France flight, the plane was leased from Tame airlines of Ecuador and was flown by an Ecuadorian crew. All 43 passengers and 10 crew members were killed.

September 1996 One of the airline's planes was caught up in severe turbulence near Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso. Three of the 206 passengers were seriously injured, and one later died.

January 1992 Five of the six crew and 82 of the 87 passengers died when the aircraft had a "controlled flight into terrain" near Strasbourg, France. The flight crew had incorrectly set the flight management system.

June 1988 An Air France aircraft crashed into trees during an air show manoeuvre when the plane failed to gain height. Three of the 136 passengers were killed in the crash near Mulhouse-Habsheim airport, France.

fields.trailText: Air France last night moved to allay concern over the airworthiness of its Concorde fleet after engineers detected wing cracks similar to those found in British Airways owned supersonic passenger jets in recent months.
fields.body:
Air France last night moved to allay concern over the airworthiness of its Concorde fleet after engineers detected wing cracks similar to those found in British Airways owned supersonic passenger jets in recent months.

A spokeswoman for the French national carrier said that "microcracks" had been noticed on the wings of four of the airline's six Concordes but added that this posed no risk to passengers.

"This is a phenomenon we have known about for a long time," said the spokeswoman. "It happens in other aircraft as well and we have a maintenance programme in place to deal with the problem."

The statement from Air France comes after British Airways grounded one of its seven Concordes last week when engineers discovered that small cracks in its wings had grown.

The Air France spokeswoman said that while two of its jets were grounded for unrelated routine tests, there were no plans to withdraw any with wing cracks. This was a joint decision by Air France, the French civil aviation authority, and the wing manufacturers Aerospatiale, she said.

Air France runs one flight a day from Paris to New York.

A spokeswoman for British Airways yesterday said that several months ago engineers had identified 50mm-long cracks in the wing spar - a beam that runs inside the wing structure - of all its Concordes. After ultrasonic testing and talks with British and French aviation authorities and Aerospatiale, the jets were all deemed airworthy.

"That section of the spar is not a critical safety area of the wing," the spokeswoman stressed.

But cracks in one jet, referred to as Alpha-Echo, were last week found to have grown to 66mm - over the maximum limit recommended by Aerospatiale - forcing the airline to ground it for repairs.

Engineers plan to bolt a supporting sheet of metal over the cracked area and Alpha-Echo is expected to be back in service by September.

In the meantime the other six jets will operate the daily fights to New York and the weekly to Barbados .

webTitle: Middle East peace talks end without deal

fields.headline: Middle East peace talks end without deal
fields.trailText: The Middle East peace talks at Camp David between the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, and the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, ended today without any apparent breakthrough between the two sides, the White House has confirmed.
fields.body:
The Middle East peace talks at Camp David between the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, and the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, ended today without any apparent breakthrough between the two sides, the White House has confirmed.

The US president, Bill Clinton, held a press conference following the break-up of the talks. He said the parties "will not be able to reach an agreement this time. As the parties were not making progress on their own, I thought we had no choice [but to end the negotiations]."

He added: "Both sides engaged in fundamental and complex questions which had never before been discussed. However, while we did not get an agreement here, significant progress was made."

Despite an offer earlier in the 15-day negotiations by the Israeli leader to recognise some form of Palestinian sovereignty in east Jerusalem, a deal proved elusive.

The return of Mr Clinton from the G8 summit in Okinawa was said to have briefly reinvigorated the dialogue, but the talks have yielded no reward for the US president's efforts. Yesterday, for the second night in a row, Mr Clinton held late-night talks, the session breaking up at about 3.15am local time.

The main point of dispute is Jerusalem, which both sides claim as their capital. Also under negotiation was the fate of several million Palestinian refugees and the boundaries of a future Palestinian state.

Israeli sources said the Palestinians had not been responsive to Israel's proposal for sovereignty over predominantly Arab neighbourhoods in east Jerusalem. Mr Arafat wants sovereignty over the whole of east Jerusalem, including the walled Old City. Both sides claim Jerusalem as their capital, and Israel has said it can never be divided.

Israelis had said earlier the talks were in a decisive phase. The Palestinians' spokeswoman, Hanan Ashrawi, predicted the two sides could achieve only an interim accord, "either some kind of vague framework or damage control to prevent a total breakdown".
