webTitle: No natural predators to put the bite on Tiger

fields.headline: No natural predators to put the bite on Tiger
fields.standfirst: The only threats to the Open champion, says David Davies, are time, tide and boredom
fields.trailText: Tiger Woods's sensational win in the Open championship on Sunday evening was no less so by Monday morning. Indeed, the longer the contemplation the greater the appreciation of one of sport's greatest feats: the completion of golf's career grand slam by the age of 24.
fields.body:
Tiger Woods's sensational win in the Open championship on Sunday evening was no less so by Monday morning. Indeed, the longer the contemplation the greater the appreciation of one of sport's greatest feats: the completion of golf's career grand slam by the age of 24.

Woods inspires awe and incredulity in almost equal measure. His golf is everything that anyone could ever dream of and his achievements beggar belief. To have won so much, and of such quality, so soon sets the mind racing: what can this man do before his time is up?

And when, indeed, will that be? Woods has set new standards in the game, not just in the quality of his ball-striking but in terms of physical and mental alertness, and it is tempting to say that should he desire to do so he can play to a championship-winning standard for another 20 years.

An average of only one major a year for that period would take him to 24, well past Jack Nicklaus's total of 18 as a professional. But there are a couple of points arising from such a projection: one is that it all might become a bit boring and the other that Woods, by the very fact of raising standards, might be the author of his own shortfall in the longevity stakes. If the kids now aged about 13 realise they are going to have to "stop eating the doughnuts", in Nick Faldo's words, and get really, really fit for golf, then Woods himself may be overtaken sooner than he expects.

As for boredom, it is significant that the atmosphere on the Sunday afternoon at St Andrews, and a month ago at Pebble Beach, was quiet almost to the point of somnolence. There was not the crescendo of excitement that normally attends the last day of a major because the old pros' credo of "the tournament doesn't start until the last nine holes on Sunday" was not being observed. Tiger was in the process of winning by eight shots after his 15-shot margin in California, and there is precious little in that to prompt a crowd to cheer.

The simple fact is that excellence of itself is unexciting. Massive supremacy in any sport needs to be challenged or it becomes mundane: most people would soon get fed up with watching Manchester United win 15-0 every week, or seeing Maurice Greene win every sprint by 10 yards.

Woods will not win every time because he does not sufficiently want to do so. Not that he would put it like that, but it is impossible even for him to concentrate constantly at championship levels, and subconsciously he will not be trying as hard in the routine tour events. As Jose Maria Olazabal put it when he won the 1999 US Masters almost solely on grit and determination: "It is not possible to maintain that level of intensity for very long, or produce it very often."

But Woods is certainly going to win a great many majors, and last week Nicklaus felt moved to repeat seriously a forecast he had made in jest before Tiger won his US Masters title in 1997. "Tiger will win more green jackets than Arnold Palmer and myself combined," he had said. Now he has said it again; this time he means it and that, in turn, means more than 10.

So what can be done to stop Woods? If we assume that he retains his desire then so far as the current generation of players is concerned the answer is not much, if anything at all.

There has been a lot of talk about Woods "raising the bar" and as a result everyone would in future simply have to jump higher. But that assumes that players such as Ernie Els and Colin Montgomerie, Darren Clarke and Lee Westwood have the capacity to do so, that they possess reserves of talent and ability as yet untapped. And that is a huge assumption. Certainly Clarke and Westwood are overweight but would they, by slimming down, necessarily become better golfers? The weight of evidence, so to speak, is against it.

Craig Stadler once lost 3st and found he could not play at all; David Duval has been on a demanding physical fitness campaign these past two years and not only has he not won a tournament for 15 months, he collapsed hopelessly over the last nine on Sunday, taking 43 to come home. A golf-fit torso was of no help to him then.

There are a few likely lads but how close they can get to Woods is a matter for conjecture. Adam Scott, the Australian whose build is so like that of Woods that it is uncanny, can certainly play but although he has challenged he has not yet won a tour event, let alone come close in a major. His compatriot Aaron Baddeley won the Australian Open and is also a good prospect, albeit he is in the middle of a slump before his professional career has even started.

Then there is Sergio Garcia, hugely talented but currently a victim of his own and his father's stubbornness. It is obvious to everyone but them that he has a flaw in his swing which was created out of necessity when he was a child and small for his age. In order to get length he needed to flail the club at the top of the backswing, so creating extra clubhead speed, like a whiplash.

Because of his talent he was then, and still is, capable of delivering the club face to the ball in a square position - most of the time. But no one can get away with such a basic flaw all the time and the Spaniard's collapse at St Andrews typified the problem. He was challenging after rounds of 68 and 69, only four behind Woods, but subsequent rounds of 73 and 76 dropped him to joint 36th, down among the also-rans.

He will need to acquire consistency if he is ever to put pressure on Woods with any regularity, but to ask him if he is going to modify his swing is to invite his wrath. His father, a professional, has been his only teacher and Sergio will change nothing unless Victor says so. So far there has been only silence.

It really looks as if golf is going to have to accept the Woods dominance until such time as a whole new breed of player, perhaps 13 now, allies natural talent to a physical and mental training regime designed to get him to the top. But for the moment and for the foreseeable future, Tiger reigns supreme.

fields.headline: Safety fears preceded Concorde crash
fields.standfirst: The crash of a Concorde bound for New York from France came after BA grounded one of its jets after a crack appeared in a wing, writes Julian Glover
fields.trailText: The crash of a Concorde bound for New York from France came after BA grounded one of its jets after a crack appeared in a wing, writes Julian Glover.
fields.body:
Even before today's crash two minutes from Charles de Gaulle airport, a small fault in a wing-support had led to growing concern about the safety of the ageing fleet of Concorde jets flown by Air France and British Airways.

The minute crack in an internal cross-beam was first noticed two months ago during a routine inspection, and subsequently found in all seven BA Concordes. The fault led to the grounding of one BA plane last week when inspection showed it had grown to 7cm in length.

Aerospatiale, the French company which manufactured the wings, said the crack did not affect the safety of the plane and the Civil Aviation Authority allowed the remaining planes, which appeared to be less severely affected, to continue in service.

Concorde, which crosses the Atlantic at 1,350mph, is considered to be among the world's safest planes. Its only major scare came in 1979, when a bad landing blew out a plane's tires. That incident led to a design modification.

Aviation analysts said it was too early to say whether reports of cracks in the supersonic plane's bodywork were responsible for today's crash. Speaking from the Farnborough air show, aviation analyst Paul Beaver said: "Questions are now going to be asked as to whether this is related.

"But it is too early to speculate whether the plane has crashed because of this. The crash could have happened for a raft of reasons.

"Concorde has an excellent safety record and in the last 20 years it has been doing a sterling job. It is an amazing aircraft - it still makes everyone stop and look up. It's a remarkable sight - designed to fly well and look beautiful. Its four engines ensure that it flies faster than a fighter aircraft across the Atlantic."

webTitle: Why £37m isn't too much to pay for Figo

fields.headline: Why £37m isn't too much to pay for Figo
fields.standfirst:
Football Unlimited's Sean Ingle on the deal which shook Spanish football to its foundations
Arsenal fear Figo backlash
World's most expensive players
fields.trailText: The Telegraph reckoned the deal was £37.4m. No way, blustered the Times, who put the figure at £41m. Meanwhile the Guardian announced the transfer was worth a whopping £43m (if you believed its front page) or a slightly less impressive £37m (according to its back page).
fields.body:
The Telegraph reckoned the deal was £37.4m. No way, blustered the Times, who put the figure at £41m. Meanwhile the Guardian announced the transfer was worth a whopping £43m (if you believed its front page) or a slightly less impressive £37m (according to its back page).

But despite disputing the exact size of the fee, the papers all agreed on one thing: Luis Figo is the most expensive signing in football history.

And how he will be rewarded for it. The 27 year-old Figo will get £3.74m a year until 2006 - which works out at £71,000 a week after tax. And that's before you include his reported £2m signing on bonus.

Furthermore, the transfer comes just weeks after Italian club Lazio positively garrotted the previous world record with their £36m signing of Argentinean striker Hernan Crespo.

Over the next few days we'll no doubt all get heartily sick of articles wondering whether football's summer silly season is now just a little bit too silly - with transfer figures being thrown about like confetti and players willing to toss their clubs aside like some quickly forgotten holiday romance.

So are football transfers spiralling out of control? Well yes, but what's new? And are players and their agents ruling the game with their demands? Of course they are - but they have been since the Bosman ruling.

And is Luis Figo really worth £40m? Damn right he is.

Of course £40m is an outrageous sum for any player. But in modern football, where the millions flow like lava from a viciously erupting volcano, it's not nearly as outrageous as it sounds. For a start Figo is one of few players on the planet who can turn a match in seconds (remember Portugal v England?) and has the sort of jaw-dropping ability that will make the Champions League winners even better.

But more importantly to Madrid, he will bring in money. Stacks of the stuff, in fact. Earlier this year when Real beat Valencia in the Champions League final, their bank balance bulged to the tune of 5,891m pesetas (£21m).

This year, they could make even more. Because when it comes to the Champions League, the rewards on offer from Uefa would make Nero blush. For a start, a team who qualifies for the first group stage of the Champions League will earn 3m Swiss francs (just under £1.2m). And they'll get another 3m francs if they qualify for the second stage.

If they then make it to the knockout stages, Uefa hands them another 4m - and the money increases all the way to the final, where the winners pocket a cool 10m Swiss francs. But that's not all. Because every win at every stage earns a club another half a million francs, while even a draw rakes in 250,000 francs.

In short, you don't have to be Real's president Florentino Perez to realise the potential for money making is huge.

But the millions on offer from Champions League money pales into insignificance compared to the amount to be made from pay-per-view. If it takes off - and all industry predictions are that it will do in the next five years - then Real will get crazy numbers after the current Spanish TV deal is renegotiated in 2003. And having Figo on board will help PPV sales in Portugal nicely.

Then there's the merchandising. According to Real's former president, Lorenzo Sanz, the club has sold 90,000 jerseys with Raul's name on the back. If Figo wins over the fans - and that's a bigger ask than it might be considering that last year he dyed his hair in Barcelona colours and insulted Real by chanting: "Madridistas, cry babies, hail the champions!" - the money will again roll in to Madrid's coffers.

Incredibly, Figo's transfer means that Madrid are now £200m in debt. But earlier this year Sanz insisted he was unconcerned. "I'm not worried because Real Madrid is a factory to make money. I am sure that in 2003 we'll be making 40,000m pesetas (£150m) a year."

If that's the case, then a £37m, £41m or even £43m transfer fee plus wages is be a small price to pay. Especially when you've signed one of the best players in the world.

webTitle: Ashcroft and Coldplay nominated for Mercury Music Prize

fields.headline: Ashcroft and Coldplay nominated for Mercury Music Prize
fields.standfirst: Full list and audio
fields.trailText: Sets by the former Verve singer Richard Ashcroft and the number one indie band Coldplay are among the 12 albums of the year shortlisted for the 2000 Mercury Music Prize, it was announced today.
fields.body:
Sets by the former Verve singer Richard Ashcroft and the number one indie band Coldplay are among the 12 albums of the year shortlisted for the 2000 Mercury Music Prize, it was announced today.

Dance veterans Leftfield, the ambient rock band Doves and the acclaimed experimentalist Nitin Sawhney are also in the running for the most prestigious annual British and Irish music award.

Half of this year's contenders have been shortlisted for their debut albums.

The music featured on the shortlist includes dance, pop, rock, folk, and classical music in the form of 65-year-old Nicholas Maw's Violin Concerto.

Unveiling the ninth Mercury prize shortlist today at London's Commonwealth club, the judges' chairman, Simon Frith, said: "With no obvious trends and fewer huge acts dominating the music scene, it means a wide open year for the Technics Mercury Music Prize. "Plus we have half a dozen debut albums, an unexpected swirl of guitars, strings and soulful singer/songwriters and a strong of people making exhilarating new music."

Ashcroft's inclusion in the list will come as a surprise to many critics who gave his first solo album a lukewarm reception earlier this year. The judging panel felt Ashcroft, whose talents had praise heaped upon them following the release of the Verve's best-selling album Urban Hymns, had "confirmed his status as a fine songwriter".

fields.headline: Simulation, Stimulation and Stipulation
fields.trailText: NOBEL INTENTIONS
fields.body:
NOBEL INTENTIONS

Put Kelvin Koogan, Mr Tony Blair, Trevor Brooking and Premier League chairman Dave "I love Danny Wilson, me" Richards together, and what do you get? A good opportunity for a nap maybe, but also some breathtaking sporting initiatives that could change the shape of our country for the better! If only our fat kids could be bothered to do anything about it.

This morning, the Koogster and Mr Tony indulged in a quick kickabout in the lush gardens of 10 Downing St (who knows, could be just a patio, the Fiver's never seen it) in order to commemorate the launch of the Football Foundation. Kind of like the Nobel Foundation, but with no awards for peacekeeping, the Football Foundation is to plough £60m-a-year into grassroots football from the year 2001. The Premier League will help out with £90m over the course of four years - roughly the size of the their bread roll budget over a similar period.

75% of this lovely lucre will be spunked on improving playing surfaces, indoor facilities and buying equipment for 40,000 grassroots football clubs. Which fits in nicely with Koogan's long-term plan to blame anyone but himself for the failure of the England team. "We haven't won anything since 1966," said Koogan, "but that makes you even more determined to make sure that in the future we give ourselves that chance, that we do put facilities and coaching in place and we do organise." Interesting points each one, especially the coaching bit.

If everything goes well, then, in five to ten years' time there should be a new improved generation of youngsters left to languish in the reserve sides of Premiership 3. Then again, as Brooking himself has mused, there may be absolutely no effect on a generation that would much prefer to kill each other through electronic simulation than on a muddy, hail-strewn pitch of a Sunday. "Kids need to be taught the right things in their early years when they are impressionable," said Koogan today. But who would you trust to do it: him or Sony?

ADVERTISEMENT

Win a fantasy night for you and five of your friends courtesy of www.e-street.com - the essential new service for planning your shopping, eating and drinking in the city.

A MERE TRIFLE

After a day like yesterday, when Real Madrid smashed the world transfer record in controversial circumstances by paying their bitter rivals £37m for Luis Figo, you'd think it'd be almost impossible to get excited about some minor transfer news involving Everton and Sunderland. And it is. Which is why we're going to see if a bowl of Granny Fiver's special caramelised sugar, Red Bull and crack trifle will make any difference.

Wooah! Jesus! Take a look at this! Everton have paid German club SV Hamburg £2.5m for Danish international midfielder Thomas Gravesen. That's amazing! It's taken Walter Smith's summer spending to almost £15m, as well! "I think we have replaced the lads who have left with some good players, and once they are allowed time to settle in I am sure they will all make a good impression," the Everton manager said! Today!

And have you seen this about Sunderland? Peter Reid has bought 19-year-old Argentinian left-back Julio Arca for £3.5m. Incredible! "I spotted Arca playing for Argentina under-21s against England last season," Wow! "He's an exceptional player and was possibly the best player on the field that night. I've had him watched ever since and we have been extremely impressed."

Arca, who arrives from Argentinos Juniors, the club which discovered Maradona and Redondo, sounds pretty pleased as well. Brilliant! "I am very happy to be coming to Sunderland," he said. "I hope that I can win a place in the side and that we can win some trophies." We feel like dancing. Let's go to a club. Have you got a spare cigarette?

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"The only thing I found out is that the manager of the restaurant wanted to offer a folk programme, and that when the girls in the ensemble came in, the referees stood up and left. I am not afraid. We did nothing wrong" - Gheorghe Stefan, the manager of Romanian side Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt, at a Uefa enquiry into claims that prostitutes were offered to the referees in charge of their Intertoto Cup match with Austria Vienna.

COME BECK UP NORTH

The new season is still a good few weeks away - unless you're Scottish or Finnish - but the Fiver is heartened to find the summer recess has done nothing to smooth the Imperial Lord Ferg's spike. Because today, like a thin Jockey Wilson, he has nailed his favourite double: Becks and Posh Spice. And, as always, his arrow landed with unnerving accuracy. "Living in the south of England was not fair to me, the club, his team-mates or the fans who have supported him so loyally," harrumphed Ferg in the new version of his autobiography. "Nor, in football terms, was it fair to him."

"There is no doubt he benefited from recognising more clearly that his apartment in Cheshire must be his working base," Ferg went on. Which may in some way have something to do with Becks' promise to stay in Cheshire during the whole of next season. This means he will have to shun his £2.5m Hertfordshire pad - despite Posh's protestations about a new bar opening in London's trendy Soso. How Lord Ferg managed it will soon be required reading in League Managers' seminars up and down the land.

Lord Ferg pounced when Becks missed training because he claimed his young son Brooklyn was unwell. "Liar!" he screamed, and he lost his temper badly - "something I hadn't done for years" (hmmmm). You see, some rat had told him that while Becks was at home with the baby, Victoria was out shopping in London. The wench! And so Becks was dropped from the game against Leeds. Fearing expulsion from United's Big Cup side, Becks soon agreed to all of Fergie's demands. Even if it meant living in Alderley Edge.

THE RUMOUR MILL

Middlesbrough could make a late bid for Lazio's Croatian striker Alen Boksic. Boksic, 30, had been expected to join Galatasaray, but has not yet put pen to paper, and Boro could yet snatch him from under the noses of the Turkish champions. Bryan Robson is also rumoured to be ready with a second £12m bid for Barcelona striker Dani.

Leeds are believed to have made another attempt to sign Rio Ferdinand, and again Harry Redknapp has insisted he won't sell. "Rio's staying here. I have told him the time is not right for a parting of the ways, either for him or for us," he said.

Barcelona representatives are due to arrive in London on Thursday to discuss the possibility of Marc Overmars and Emmanuel Petit moving to Spain.

NEWS IN BRIEF

Wolves striker Ade Akinbiyi has agreed terms on his record-breaking £5m move to Leicester and will complete his transfer later today subject to a medical.

St Mirren striker Junior Mendes has joined Dunfermline for a nominal fee.

Liverpool have signed a £20m deal with Granada which gives the media group rights to show delayed coverage of their matches on the internet, Wap mobile phones and through digital TV. The venture will also include an archive of edited highlights and live audio commentary, an online betting service, online shopping for Liverpool merchandise and live auctions of memorabilia.

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

Channel 4: Football Stories (10pm)
Spend an hour with David Elleray. Alternatively you could gouge chunks from underneath your toenails with a rusty razor blade.

Sky Sports 1: European Beach Soccer (6.30pm, 12midnight)
Schedule filling? This?

World Football Show (7.30pm)
Not in any way a repeat from last night.

World Cup Football (3am)
The official Fifa film of the 1958 World Cup from Sweden, lovingly restored from the original brass rubbings.

British Eurosport: Football (7.30pm)
Live action of a friendly between Lazio and Beyer Leverkusen. Now this is more like it.

webTitle: The people's PM is far from finished

fields.headline: The people's PM is far from finished
fields.standfirst: It is not surprising that Tony Blair's popularity is falling, says Guardian columnist David McKie. What is unusual is that it has taken so long to happen
fields.trailText: It is not surprising that Tony Blair's popularity is falling, says Guardian columnist David McKie. What is unusual is that it has taken so long to happen.
fields.body:
Lost his Midas touch. Lost his magic. Used to walk on water but has now started to sink. His magic coach has been changed back into a pumpkin.

This and other dismissive judgments fly daily around the head of the man who not so long ago was Britain's most popular prime minister since records began. Now those who still like and trust him are exceeded, if only modestly, by those who do not.

Tony Blair, however, is realist enough to have expected just such an outcome. Most British prime ministers have at some time experienced the slide from adulation to rejection. Some have later recovered; others have not.

Winston Churchill, feted for having led us to victory in the war, was turfed out of office in 1945 - not because the nation no longer loved him but because people judged that the leadership talents that won the war were not those best suited to win the peace.

Clement Attlee, who succeeded him as prime minister, never plunged from the heights to the depths because he never attained the heights: nor sought to. The notion of having anyone spinning on his behalf, attempting to redesign him, glamourise him, would have made him feel sick. He remained, as one critic put it, a modest man with plenty to be modest about: not Mr Midas but Mr Next-door. Only later, as the record of his government was assessed and reassessed, did he seem exceptional.

Anthony Eden, who had waited so long to become prime minister, was lavishly welcomed, with approval ratings in his early months of 70%. They did not last long. Even before his disastrous Suez adventure confirmed what some had long feared, that he wasn't up to the job, disillusion was setting in.

Initially people were wary of Harold Macmillan, who followed Eden. With his lugubrious air, hangdog moustache and patrician vowels, he looked like a museum piece. But by 1959, election year, opinion had shifted,. He was seen to be doing well. The label Supermac, invented by a cartoonist to mock him, was now applied with approval. But when his government ran into trouble in the early 60s, what people had admired as insouciance began to look like negligence. He was out of touch, an antique. By the spring of 1963, only 30% still approved of him. Soon after, his illness was used to prise him out.

Alec Douglas-Home was prime minister for only a year, to be followed by Harold Wilson, whose popularity climbed over his early months and swept him on to win a second election in 1966. But again there was disillusion. Through the crises of the late 1960s people liked him more than they did his government - but they did not like him that much. "Wily" - a word which implies both good and bad - was a term often used to describe him.

But they liked Edward Heath even less. Though they voted him into power in June 1970, his ratings usually lagged behind those of his party. Again, there was no great plunge - but only because there was no great height to be plunged from.

James Callaghan, who took over in 1976 after Wilson's second spell as prime minister, fared much better. People grew to like and trust kindly, shrewd, Uncle Jim. Through 1978, no easy year, his approval ratings topped 50%. But that melted away in the so-called winter of discontent which followed.

Margaret Thatcher's early ratings as prime minister were unspectacular. At the start of the 80s some Tories suspected she would not last for long. What lifted her popularity was the Falklands war. An unpopular Labour party kept her in power, but unpopular policies such as the poll tax led to her downfall. By the time she bade a tearful farewell to Downing Street she retained her old magic for only about a third of the electorate.

John Major prospered because he seemed decent and modest - and because he was not Thatcher. His early involvement in the Gulf war sent his ratings soaring. Soon he was being described as the most popular leader since Churchill. Then, after the pound crashed out of the Exchange Rate Mechanism on Black Wednesday, he too found himself mired in the relegation zone. The tabloids, still reeling from the loss of their heroine Thatcher, pursued him mercilessly. By the spring of 1994 only around 20% still approved of him - still a lot more than approved of his government.

Mr Blair's early months in office broke all records. "It can't last," people said - but somehow it did. People liked this modest, smiling young man with his happy family, who had washed his hands of Labour's ideology and seemed intent on giving voters what they wanted.

But that impression was fed by illusion. Government is full of awkward choices and events which force even crowd-pleasers to do the unpopular. The row over section 28 - either the government alienates the gay and lesbian lobby or supporters of so-called "family values" and the Daily Mail - is a potent example of that.

He had high hopes for the year 2000, with millennium celebrations and the birth of a Downing Street baby. But he was judged not to be delivering. The greater the illusion, the greater the disillusion: which is why he is foundering now.

On the other hand, he is still more popular than most of his predecessors at No 10 at this stage of the electoral cycle. He may never reclaim the dizzy heights of the early days, but he's far from finished.

webTitle: Wanderers to lock horns again - 124 years on

fields.headline: Wanderers to lock horns again - 124 years on
fields.standfirst: In wisden.com's gossip column today, Charles de Lisle reveals the cricket clubs who are to play each other for the first time since 1876 and reports on cricket's Do of the Week, a portait unveiling at the MCC Museum
fields.trailText: Ancient clubs meet again - after 124 years
fields.body:
Ancient clubs meet again - after 124 years

Two famous amateur cricket clubs are to do battle for the first time in 124 years. Next month's clash between the Free Foresters (FF) and I Zingari (IZ) will be their first encounter since 1876.

The two clubs will face one another in the first International Millennium Cricket Festival for Wandering Clubs on August 9 on the beautiful ground at Christ Church, Oxford. "There's so much excitement about this game," says Guy Beresford, the FF's match manager, "it's unbelievable".

Quite why regular fixtures between the two, begun in 1859, ceased after the drawn two-day game at Walton Hall, Warwickshire, in August 1876 is not clear. There was no falling out. "The main reason," says Beresford, "is that we're both wandering clubs, without home grounds, who play most of our games against sides with fixed homes."

Another club official says that, despite a considerable overlap in membership (Colin Cowdrey is one dual member), the two clubs "never gelled", and developed in different directions as cricket expanded. The FF, which still has strong military connections, went on to become much bigger, playing some first-class cricket until relatively recently; IZ, founded 10 years earlier, in 1846, has restricted itself to playing at schools, country houses and other spots on the "jazz hat" social circuit. Even in its early days, it was regarded as "the Queen Mother of wandering clubs".

The festival, organised by The Cricketer magazine, brings together 28 clubs from around the world, among them the Gentlemen of Philadelphia, the Stragglers of Asia, the South Wales Hunts and the Wiltshire Queries. But no match will generate as much emotion as the FF-IZ game.

Such is the enthusiasm of IZ members to be selected that the club suggested fielding 12 men a side, with only 11 batting and 11 fielding. "We thought 12-a-side a silly idea," says Beresford, "but still think we can beat them, even if they do field 12 men. However good they are, we won't be humiliated."

It's just as well that sides in this most traditional of one-day competitions are playing solely for pride, and charity: there are no over limits, no places, and no prize money. And the FF have laid on a sponsored supply of 200 bottles of champagne to keep their guests happy. Says Beresford: "Things could get very lively later on".

Do of the Week (the sixth in an occasional series)

Occasion The unveiling by the MCC Museum at Lord's, on Friday, July 21, of its latest commissions: portraits of Mike Atherton and Alec Stewart, by Andy Pankhurst, a conversation piece featuring Barry Richards, Sir Richard Hadlee and Clive Lloyd, by Andrew Festing, and a giant photograph of Nasser Hussain and Karen Smithies, by David Buckland.

Format Champagne and canapes, 6-8pm.

Attendance 70, led by Hadlee, who posed contentedly in front of his portrait during the formalities, Smithies (ditto), and Lloyd, who arrived just too late to do so. Also there: Peter Brooke, the cricket-loving former Tory Northern Ireland Secretary, plus a committee-room full of MCC names. Star of the show: Pankhurst's four-year-old son Josh, as blonde and charismatic as Shane Warne and thrilled that Atherton gave him the bat seen in the portrait.

Notable absentees Richards, Atherton, playing for Lancashire, and Stewart, who was expected but was too busy preparing for the following day's one-day final against Zimbabwe. He had popped in that afternoon for a private view of the finished painting; Atherton hasn't yet seen his.

Main talking point The excellence of the work. It's highly unusual for MCC to honour current internationals - even those on the verge of their 100th Tests - but the studies of Atherton and Stewart, both depicted on the England balcony at Lord's, were judged a success.

The artist, 32, came to his subjects fresh, having little knowledge of the game. He got only eight hours with Atherton, who sat shortly before flying to South Africa last October, and six with Stewart, who sat at the end of the tour (when he had time on his hands after being dropped from the one-day side). "I wanted to show the players' strength and seriousness," Pankhurst said, "also a kind of nobility. Both of them are quite noble."

While Stewart showed more interest in the process of painting - the mixing of paint, and so on - Atherton came across as an art lover, concerned that he'd missed the big Rembrandt show. At one point Pankhurst said to Atherton: "You know more about art than I know about cricket."

There was also praise for the overseas players' picture by Festing, a Royal portrait painter. Set in the Long Room at Lord's during the last World Cup, it has a whimsical touch: just discernible in the background are other great players including Ted Dexter, chatting to Graham Gooch, and two Alan Knotts. Another mystery: how did the laid-back Richards, shown in an open-necked shirt, manage to get in to the Long Room without a tie?

The Hussain/Smithies picture, taken when she was still captain of England, drew less attention. The backdrop is the space-age NatWest media centre, but the pair didn't actually pose in front of it - they were superimposed on it during production.

Lewis hailed the acquisitions as proof that, at Lord's these days, "everything moves forward, and moves forward quickly". Alexander noted, to laughter, that one of the joys of his committee's work is that "we don't have to run English cricket", and said that Atherton and Stewart had been "brilliantly captured" by Pankhurst.

fields.headline: The viral timebomb
fields.standfirst: One in 100 of us has hepatitis C, according to new research. That's 500,000 people nationwide. Yet many have no idea that they are carrying this potentially fatal disease, says  Claire Wallerstein
fields.trailText: One in 100 of us has hepatitis C, according to new research. That's 500,000 people nationwide. Yet many have no idea that they are carrying this potentially fatal disease, says Claire Wallerstein
fields.body:
With Aids there came health warnings on TV and talk of divine retribution: a health holocaust was on its way. Horrified contemplation of half-remembered flings became a national pastime. We whipped ourselves into the same panic over BSE, and billions of pounds were spent on research into both.

But all that may soon seem like a storm in a teacup. There is a much bigger, seriously underestimated killer around, which has already infected 170m people worldwide - hepatitis C. Unlike Aids, it is just as likely to hit nice little Middle Englanders as prostitutes, drug addicts and homosexual men. Yet there are no signs of the health campaigns or government inquiries we might expect.

Maybe it's all just too confusing. Hepatitis ranges through types A to E, all with varying degrees of severity - and there could be up to a dozen more types still unidentified. Maybe it is because the disease can take up to 30 years to have any obvious effect on health. Whatever the reason, the ignorance is astounding, even in the medical profession. Britain is ill-prepared to deal with what experts are calling a "viral timebomb".

A survey of 5,000 women at a London ante-natal clinic gives a hint of what could lie in store: almost one in 100 were found to be infected with hepatitis C, which, extrapolated, would suggest up to 500,000 people across the country are carrying the virus. The report's authors, from St Mary's Hospital, London, are now calling for routine screening.

Dr Graham Foster, a leading liver specialist at the hospital, says: "There is no question there will be a huge epidemic of deaths - we're looking at anything up to 200,000 cases within the next decade. In the United States there are targeted screening campaigns. The French plan to identify 85% of sufferers by 2002. Here it seems we are all just hoping it will go away."

Foster says most people developing hepatitis C today are in their 40s and caught it 20 years ago, when it was fashionable for students to dabble with intravenous drugs. Most people only tried them once - but that was enough. "What makes it worse is that at that time we were short of blood and going round universities to get donations," says Foster.

The disease is caused by a virus (called the hepatitis C virus, or HCV) which was not identified until 1989. It is thought to have existed for at least 4,000 years in Asia before jumping to the west after the second world war.

Possible routes of infection are legion, including acupuncture, tattooing, ear piercing, sharing razors or dental treatment - some surveys suggest only a fifth of dentists use sterilisation techniques adequate to wipe out HCV. Occasionally it is passed on during childbirth and sex, but most of those at risk will have used intravenous drugs or had blood transfusions or clotting treatment before the early 90s.

Unlike HIV, which can survive for less than a minute outside the body, HCV can survive for hours or even weeks. Patients can live for decades with no obvious symptoms, and tens of thousands of people in the first, acute, stages are probably being misdiagnosed - up to 40% of those diagnosed with chronic fatigue syndrome could actually have hepatitis C. Later on, however, 60% will develop severe liver disease, at least half of them cirrhosis or liver cancer. Once the liver starts to fail, it does so quickly. If a transplant liver cannot be found, the patient will usually die within six to 12 months.

Although a combination of the drugs interferon and ribavirin can cure up to 40% of patients, many are denied the £7,000 therapy by their local authority, often ending up with a choice between transplant or death. Transplants may cost more than £30,000 plus £7,000 per year in anti-rejection drugs, but - crucially - are centrally-funded. William Rosenberg, of the liver group at the University of Southampton, says the cost of treating hepatitis C over the next 20 years could reach £9bn. "We can make a huge dent in that by spending something now. We can do a huge amount more about hepatitis C than we can about heart disease or hypertension or diabetes."

In the past, some patients have moved to different health authority areas to get treatment and beat the "postcode lottery". The loophole which allowed this has now been closed, however. Dr Foster says: "It beggars belief that anyone can possibly justify depriving a patient of a life-saving treatment, which will also reduce the long-term burden of care and cost to the NHS - but it is happening. We're also going to run out of organs for transplant very quickly at the rate cases are increasing."

The side effects of the drugs are so harsh that 20% of patients give up taking them, but John Bexon, 45, from Allestree, Derby, is one of the thousands who has been refused the chance even to try them. "I had to give up my work in construction because I got so ill," he says. "I've already cost the state a huge amount in terms of benefits and free prescriptions - never mind if I have a transplant." Bexon, who has tattoos and pierced ears, had several operations and was once an intravenous drug user, does not know how he caught the virus. It was detected in 1990 when he went to donate blood - worryingly, his 18th pint.

Hepatitis C has taken a heavy toll on him. "You get massive fatigue attacks which leave you unable to get out of bed for days. Sometimes you're too tired to even eat. I feel like an old man. I get headaches, I'm apathetic and depressed - in fact the psychological effects are as much torture as the physical ones. It's hard to explain how it feels to know that when your liver packs up there may very well be no liver available for transplant - and that you'll end up in a box."

Therese Cronje, 51, who also found out she was infected after giving blood in 1992, has been free of the disease for almost three years after receiving the combination drugs.

An employee of Barnet council in north London, she was offered treatment as part of an experimental programme at St Mary's Hospital, starting with interferon in 1995 and the combined drugs in 1997. She feels "guilty and privileged" to be cured.

Like Bexon, she still has no idea how she became infected, although she grew up in West Africa and had two miscarriages and blood transfusions in the 70s. It could also have been something as innocuous as dental work or electrolysis. "The fear when I found I was infected was incredible," she says. "My GP had never even heard of hepatitis C. I bought a book about it for information, which basically told you to prepare for death. It wasn't exactly helpful to be reading about 'end stages'."

The National Institute for Clinical Effectiveness (Nice) is reviewing the prescription of interferon and ribavirin, with a view to making them uniformly available - which it will probably do in November. "But the real question is what will happen next?" asks Dr Foster. "Where will the money come from to pay for treating all the patients? Who will do the sophisticated virological testing? Most importantly, where is the strategy?

"We need central funding as we had with Aids, because if decision-making remains at local level, the health authorities still won't have the budget for the drugs, and patients will go on suffering."

A guide to the hepatitis viruses
Hepatitis is an inflammation of the liver which causes slow, long-term damage. It is generally caused by viruses, occasionally by other infections such as mononucleosis, yellow fever and herpes simplex.

A, B and C are the most serious forms, and between them account for 75% of all chronic cases.

Anyone with hepatitis should drink plenty of water and avoid alcohol, processed foods, saccharin, wild mushrooms, iron and excessive amounts of vitamins such as Aand B3. This will stop your liver working too hard, and give you some control over the progress of the disease and speed of recovery.

Hepatitis A
Spread by consuming food or water contaminated with the stools of an infected person.

The virus can survive for four hours at room temperature in a speck of faeces on a nappy, hand or hard surface, and is most common in Latin America, Africa and parts of Asia.

Risks include eating infected food, such as shellfish contaminated with untreated sewage, oral or anal sex, poor hygiene, intravenous drug use and eating vegetables fertilised with human manure (a common practice in China).

Hepatitis A can worsen liver damage or even kill patients suffering from hepatitis B or C.

Hepatitis B
Spread by contact with blood and bodily fluids such as semen, vaginal secretions, saliva and open wounds.

Risks include intravenous drug use, unprotected sex, sharing razors or toothbrushes, and problems during childbirth. Cancer patients and those on dialysis are at increased risk, as are people living in closed communities such as prisons, or those exposed to blood at work.

95% of people fight the disease off themselves, but in America it kills 5,000 people a year, and one million are chronic sufferers who may go on to develop cirrhosis or cancer. In some states a child must be vaccinated before being allowed into elementary school.

In experiments, woodchucks vaccinated against hepatitis B were also apparently immune to liver cancer.

Hepatitis B is most common in the Pacific Islands and Asia.

Hepatitis C
Men, or anyone who contracts the virus over the age of 40, are most likely to develop serious damage.

Hepatitis C is twice as common in southern, as compared to northern Europe, three times as common in the Middle East, and 13 times more common in North Africa. In Egypt 15-20% of the adult population is infected.

Hepatitis D
Cannot take hold in anyone not already suffering from hepatitis B. Transmitted in the same way, although less commonly through sex or childbirth.

Hepatitis E
There are occasional epidemics in the developing world, but it does not become chronic.

Non A-E hepatitis
There could be up to a dozen other unidentified strains among those which currently do not respond to treatment. However, these are very rare. It is not yet known whether any go on to cause severe liver damage.

webTitle: Merope Mills  on the joys of getting muddy

fields.headline: Here's mud in your eye
fields.standfirst: If it's good enough for Madonna, it's good enough for us.  Merope Mills  on the joys of getting muddy
fields.trailText: If it's good enough for Madonna, it's good enough for us. Merope Mills on the joys of getting muddy
fields.body:
Last week one of our wonderful tabloids published "the most amazing pictures you will ever see of the world's biggest superstar". And they were pretty amazing, actually. There was Madonna, heavily pregnant, wallowing like a very jolly, very muddy hippo in the murky sludge of a volcanic lake on an island off the west coast of Sicily. It was clear she had spent time slapping the goo from the bottom of the reed-lined lake all over her bump (her second child is due in September), her limbs and her face.

I am not sure I have ever seen Madonna - a woman we never normally see out of make-up and designer clothes - looking happier, and there's no doubt that mud baths, especially in the open air, are brilliant fun. But coating yourself with mud is also said to have amazing benefits for both your skin and your health.

Can it be true? Judging by the number of health spas and beauty clinics that now offer their own in-house version of the treatment, it is not just Madonna who thinks so. "Nowadays we are more in need of this kind of treatment because a lot of nutrients that are in the soil generally have become so weakened that we need to remineralise the body," says Haley Neech, spa manager at Forest Mere in Liphook, Hampshire, which provides more than 1,500 mud baths each year for its clients. "Hence there is a lot of hype now about taking vitamins and minerals and eating organic food."

But like many hippy, New Age therapies, the idea is far from new. Cleopatra was apparently a big believer in the anti-ageing properties of mud; she is said to have sent slaves all the way to the Dead Sea to collect mud for her bath. That aside, a quick glance at any nature programme will probably confirm that elephants, rhinos and pigs are among those who hold the copyright. Lolling about in the mud appears to be a cunning skin- conditioning treatment for over-heated mammals. If it can work for them, why not us?

Human devotees say that both the open air and beauty parlour version (which involves being slapped in mud, wrapped up in cling film for about 20 minutes, showered and then wrapped up in cling film again to sweat out impurities), has an amazing smoothing and moisturising effect on the skin. There's no denying it because you can feel that it works.

As for the health benefits, you are not going to find a professor of anything with much to say on the subject, but tradition has it that minerals are absorbed through the skin, and different muds are good for different illnesses. "Muds from various parts of the world contain different mineral contents," says Neech, "each of which has different qualities. Madonna's volcanic mud is particularly rich in sulphur and sodium which is good for toning, and magnesium is a natural sedative that is good if you are particularly tense since it can help relax the muscles." Zinc-rich mud is recommended for acne and psoriasis, while copper is apparently beneficial for arthritis, rheumatism and aches and pains.

But before you start digging your own refreshing mud pit in your back garden, take note: no one says all mud is good for your skin. "A lot of the time the mud we have in the back garden is not refined enough to have any of the minerals in it," says Neech. fields.bodyText: Last week one of our wonderful tabloids published "the most amazing pictures you will ever see of the world's biggest superstar". And they were pretty amazing, actually. There was Madonna, heavily pregnant, wallowing like a very jolly, very muddy hippo in the murky sludge of a volcanic lake on an island off the west coast of Sicily. It was clear she had spent time slapping the goo from the bottom of the reed-lined lake all over her bump (her second child is due in September), her limbs and her face. I am not sure I have ever seen Madonna - a woman we never normally see out of make-up and designer clothes - looking happier, and there's no doubt that mud baths, especially in the open air, are brilliant fun. But coating yourself with mud is also said to have amazing benefits for both your skin and your health. Can it be true? Judging by the number of health spas and beauty clinics that now offer their own in-house version of the treatment, it is not just Madonna who thinks so. "Nowadays we are more in need of this kind of treatment because a lot of nutrients that are in the soil generally have become so weakened that we need to remineralise the body," says Haley Neech, spa manager at Forest Mere in Liphook, Hampshire, which provides more than 1,500 mud baths each year for its clients. "Hence there is a lot of hype now about taking vitamins and minerals and eating organic food." But like many hippy, New Age therapies, the idea is far from new. Cleopatra was apparently a big believer in the anti-ageing properties of mud; she is said to have sent slaves all the way to the Dead Sea to collect mud for her bath. That aside, a quick glance at any nature programme will probably confirm that elephants, rhinos and pigs are among those who hold the copyright. Lolling about in the mud appears to be a cunning skin- conditioning treatment for over-heated mammals. If it can work for them, why not us? Human devotees say that both the open air and beauty parlour version (which involves being slapped in mud, wrapped up in cling film for about 20 minutes, showered and then wrapped up in cling film again to sweat out impurities), has an amazing smoothing and moisturising effect on the skin. There's no denying it because you can feel that it works. As for the health benefits, you are not going to find a professor of anything with much to say on the subject, but tradition has it that minerals are absorbed through the skin, and different muds are good for different illnesses. "Muds from various parts of the world contain different mineral contents," says Neech, "each of which has different qualities. Madonna's volcanic mud is particularly rich in sulphur and sodium which is good for toning, and magnesium is a natural sedative that is good if you are particularly tense since it can help relax the muscles." Zinc-rich mud is recommended for acne and psoriasis, while copper is apparently beneficial for arthritis, rheumatism and aches and pains. But before you start digging your own refreshing mud pit in your back garden, take note: no one says all mud is good for your skin. "A lot of the time the mud we have in the back garden is not refined enough to have any of the minerals in it," says Neech. "Also there a lot of pesticide in mud these days and if you live in a city the chances are most of the mud is highly polluted rather than good for you." Shame. It would have given Madonna a great excuse to headline a mud-drenched Glastonbury next year.

fields.headline: Oh, for perfect skin ...
fields.standfirst: Acne is completely treatable, but many of us spend years suffering from spots without even thnking of asking a doctor for help. As a new light therapy is launched, Helen Caroll assesses the treatments on offer
fields.trailText: Acne is completely treatable, but many of us spend years suffering from spots without even thnking of asking a doctor for help. As a new light therapy is launched, Helen Caroll assesses the treatments on offer
fields.body:
Alison Dudley was 22 when a comment from a little boy at her local swimming pool sent her rushing off to the changing room in tears. It was the first time she had been swimming for as long as she could remember, and it had taken a great deal of courage to get her there.

Alison is one of millions of Britons who suffer from acne and, until that day, she had been too embarrassed to display the rash of angry spots that covered the whole of her back and chest.

"I couldn't do much to hide the spots on my face, which first erupted when I was 12 and became the bane of my life, though I never displayed the rest of my upper body in daylight," says Alison. "But when a couple of friends invited me along to the local pool I decided to take the plunge. I was sick of acne getting in the way of my enjoyment of life. Then, before I'd even got in, a little boy stared up at me and said to his mother: 'Mummy, look at that lady's back. What's wrong with it?'

"She tried to tell him as politely as possible that it was nothing and not to worry about it. But the damage had been done. I already felt self-conscious. After that, I wanted to die. I could have hit him for drawing attention to it.

"I should have been more grown- up about it. But at any age that sort of incident is very upsetting."

Twelve years later, after having finally found an effective treatment for the pimples that blighted her earlier life (the drug roaccutane), Alison is chief executive of the Middlesex-based national Acne Support Group. She has two daughters, Jessie, seven, and Lucy, two, and, as acne is often hereditary, it was for their sakes that she initially became involved in the organisation .

Around 90% of teenagers and adults have to contend with unsightly spots at some stage, and 15% require help from a doctor for clinical acne at some point. Even into their 40s, 5% of women and 1% of men still have big problems with spots.

Acne is a skin disorder affecting the tiny pores and grease glands (sebaceous glands) most common on the face, neck, back and chest. During adolescence, rising hormones - specifically, male hormones found in both men and women - cause the sebaceous glands to get bigger.

These glands make an oily substance called sebum, which reaches the skin by emptying through the openings of hair follicles. As a result the cells from the lining of the hair follicle shed more rapidly and stick together, forming a plug at the skin's surface.

The mixture of oil and cells also helps bacteria in the follicles to grow, and these create chemicals that can cause the wall of the follicles to break. At this stage, sebum, bacteria and shed skin cells spill into the skin causing redness, swelling and pus. In other words, spots.

Dr Tony Chu, a consultant dermatologist at Hammersmith hospital in London and one of the country's leading experts in acne, says that not enough people take the condition seriously. "Acne leaves scars on the skin and the psyche," he says. "And the psychological scars are as damaging as the physical.

"It usually strikes in puberty when children are just coming to terms with their sexuality and their physical appearance is very important. Along with the designer clothes they want a girlfriend or boyfriend but sadly acne very often results in poor body image and gets in the way of this natural development.

"I get lots of letters from people saying: 'Acne destroyed my life. I didn't achieve at school, I've never had a relationship and I can't get a job.' However sympathetic people might be, if it's a choice between dating or employing someone with acne and someone without most will opt for people with clear skin. Employers justify it because few people feel happy about being served in a restaurant or even being greeted by a receptionist with a face full of spots.

"And it's a disease we laugh at, many stand-up comedians have jokes in their routines about pizza faces or spotty dicks and this is very damaging for people who have acne. Although there are no hard figures, we know through experience that the suicide rate among acne sufferers is considerably higher than the population as a whole."

In Dr Chu's view the biggest tragedy is that so many people are troubled for years with a condition which is "totally treatable".

No treatment works for everybody, but there are hundreds available and it is simply a case of finding one that suits. Most take weeks or months to work.

Anti-bacterial lightbox
The latest treatment on the market is a lightbox, Dermalux, which kills the bacteria that cause acne. It sends out red and blue waves of light, which zap the spots and heal the skin by, in effect, exposing spots to extra oxygen.

The bacteria responsible for acne colonise in ducts in the skin. Because they are averse to oxygen, they breathe through a chemical, poryphyrin.

The lightbox works in two ways. The blue light activates the poryphyrin in the bacteria which, once stimulated by the light, produces oxygen that overwhelms the bacteria. At the same time, the red light stimulates the white blood cells, which then produce fibroblasts, the building blocks from which new tissue is created, which in turn heal any abrasions. The lights do not damage the skin because they are outside the UV spectrum.

In trials, the treatment worked for 75% of patients who, after 12 weeks, experienced a 76% decrease in the number of visible spots. There are also none of the side effects associated with some drugs traditionally used to treat spots.

The downside is that the box has to be used for 15 minutes every day and, as the treatment is not available on the national health service, it costs £200.

Roaccutane
One of a group of medicines known as retinoids which are derived from vitamin A, roaccutane is taken in tablet form daily, usually for four months. It works by dramatically reducing the formation of sebum in the skin.

At the same time, it attacks blackheads and whiteheads, bacteria and inflammation. It can only be prescribed by a dermatologist, usually after several courses of antibiotics have failed to work.

While the treatment has a very high success rate, in the initial stages it can exacerbate acne. It can also cause an increase in liver enzymes - so pre-treatment and follow-up liver function tests to keep levels in check must be carried out on all patients.

As it can damage unborn children, roaccutane must not be taken in pregnancy.

Over the counter
Many non-prescription acne lotions and creams help milder cases of acne. However, many will also make the skin dry if used too often.

Oral antibiotics
These drugs include erythromycin, minocycline and tetracycline. It may be up to six months before you see the full effects, although there will probably be some difference after about six weeks.

Oral antibiotics are effective in about two-thirds of cases of moderate to severe acne, and can safely be taken for a year or more.

Topical antibiotics
Mild-to-moderate acne can often be controlled using antibiotics such as erythromycin applied directly to the skin. These treatments come in bottles with a special sponge applicator, and should be applied over all affected areas, not just individual spots. The treatment is not useful for treating blackheads or whiteheads.

Peeling agents
Treatments such as benzoyl peroxide and tretinoin are effective against blackheads, unlike antibiotics, but can cause dryness and irritation.

Hormones
Women with acne can be helped by taking Dianette. This contains the hormones oestrogen and cyproterone, which counteract the male hormone androgen. Over-production of this hormone is the main cause of excessively greasy skin in women, which can then lead to acne.

Dianette is very effective for many women, and can be taken for many years. It is also an effective contraceptive.

Some common myths about acne

Junk food causes spots

Acne is not caused by eating chocolate, chips, pizza or any other food. Opinions from dermatologists on the importance of diet in the management of acne vary, but all agree that a strict diet alone will not clear up spots.

Too much sex causes acne

While the sex hormone testosterone is the primary cause of acne, spots do not develop because you have too much of the hormone or are over-sexed. Neither sex not masturbation causes spots. In fact, as both are believed to reduce stress levels, they may also help alleviate the aggravating effect stress has on acne.

Spots are caused by dirt

Acne is not caused by dirt. The black of blackheads is due to the pigment or colouring of the plug of "sticky" cells blocking the hair duct. Most people with acne wash more often than those without to clear away excess oil produced by their skins.

You should wash more with acne

Over-washing can actually make acne worse by drying the skin and making it sore. Washing with mild soap twice a day is all that is needed.

Pregnancy cures acne

While some women's acne virtually disappears during pregnancy, in oth ers the change in hormones reactivates an old condition or worsens an existing one.

Sun is great for spots

Although sun may temporarily mask acne, tighten pores or dry up oil glands it also damages follicular walls, thereby clogging pores. This results in more acne which may not not surface for three to four weeks after exposure to the sun.

Acne is curable

There is no cure for acne. However, through consistent use of appropriate treatments and remedies, it can be controlled or prevented.

More Information

fields.headline: Diary of a hypochondriac
fields.trailText: During a cooked breakfast, a friend calls to say that he has just heard about the re-eruption of my Etna-like piles. He warmly recommends the daily use of pure bran
fields.body:
Tuesday

During a cooked breakfast, a friend calls to say that he has just heard about the re-eruption of my Etna-like piles. He warmly recommends the daily use of pure bran. A martyr to his own Farmer Giles for many years, he insists that this is the only realistic way to avoid more radical and invasive procedures. I scrape the bacon and egg into the bin and head towards Tesco.

Wednesday

Eating my breakfast bran, it occurs to me that many people have their own individual recipes for treating piles. I once heard about a man who advised a friend with piles that every time you brew up a pot of tea you should pack the leaves round your bottom. "You see if the piles aren't gone in a fortnight, " he says. Two weeks later he meets his pal again and asked after the Farmers. "You and your bloody tea leaves," he says. "The piles are worse, much worse." "In that case," says the friend, "go to the doctor at once. You can't mess around with those piles." So this chap went to his GP, and he . . . no, I can't go on. The pain is too great. Despairingly, I look in the cupboard but all we have is pyramid-shaped tea bags.

Thursday

I have now had time to reflect on the rest of the story, in which the chap finally went to his GP. "I've tried packing tea leaves round my bottom, doctor," he says, "but it's done no good. Would you take a look?" "Take your pants down, and bend over," says the doctor. Gently he parted the cheeks and inspected. "Mmmm, I see, ahhhh," he says, "aha, yes, mmmmm. Dear, dear. I'm afraid, I can't do anything for your piles," says the doctor, "but you're going on a long journey."

Friday

Whether or not the bran is already having an effect, the Farmers are a little improved, and the leavening of agony reminds me that there is a positive side to this ailment. As with the common cold and muscular strains, I find the pain or discomfort of symptoms transparently non-terminal to be oddly reassuring. It takes the mind off mortality.

Saturday

Last night, I went to the sequel to Mission Impossible with a friend, a Jewish man much my own age and shape. In one scene a kidnapped pharmaceutical executive who has been infected with the lethal "chimera" virus is lying in a cubicle surrounded by plastic sheeting, very close to death. As he gasps ever more violently for air, I feel a little nudge on the arm. I look across. My friend raises his eyebrows towards the screen. "That's us in a few years," he says.

Sunday

At dinner last night, I was seated next to a talented novelist of 24 who says she has been obsessed with death and illness for years, "although I didn't start really worrying until I was 15". Causes of cancer are her specialist subject, and she informed me of a radioactive element called Thorium that is used in glossy magazines to give the pages unlikely whiteness. Something else to worry about.

Monday

I awake drenched and distressed having passed a profoundly troubled night. In the dream, I am leafing through Vogue, lying in the Gyspy Rose Lee Ward of the Royal Hospital for Haemmorrhoidal Soothsaying, when my physician Sarah Jarvis leads over a party of white coats over. Parting the buttocks, she begins to inspect. "Mm, yes, I see," she murmurs. "Most interesting." A siren goes off (looking round, I notice Karen Silkwood being dragged away by guards towards the showers), and Dr Jarvis delivers her verdict. "Well, I can't do anything for his piles," she says, "but he's going on a long journey to Cumbria, where his radioactive piles will power the new generator at Sellafield. And he's going to meet a tall dark stranger." When Jack Cunningham walks in, grinning dementedly and carrying a Geiger counter, I awake, and my thoughts turn instantly to the daily ordeal with the bran.

fields.headline: Lloyds TSB hatches incubator pact
fields.standfirst: Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: Lloyds TSB tried to persuade the City of its net credentials yesterday by backing a $30m joint venture with Antfactory, the internet incubator.
fields.body:
Lloyds TSB tried to persuade the City of its net credentials yesterday by backing a $30m joint venture with Antfactory, the internet incubator.

Dennis Holt, director of retail distribution at Lloyds TSB, said the bank was "not placing a long-term limit" on the amount of money it would put into the new Valuefactory Ventures but suggested that it was unlikely to run into hundreds of millions of pounds.

The bank, which is due to publish its interim profits figures later this week amid mounting pressure to convince the City it has scope for further growth, faced criticism earlier in the year for being slow to develop on the internet.

Mr Holt said Valuefactory Ventures would invest in internet businesses which were not core to the bank's strategy and which it might otherwise neglect. Lloyds TSB staff working with Antfactory might learn ways to hasten the bank's internet ventures.

He insisted the new operation would prove advantageous for the bank's shareholders and had not come too late to take the best investment opportunities for dot.com companies.

webTitle: Man quizzed over Sarah murder held after car chase

fields.headline: Man quizzed over Sarah murder held after car chase
fields.standfirst: More about the Sarah Payne case
fields.trailText: A man who was questioned by police hunting the killer of eight-year-old Sarah Payne was in custody today charged with stealing a car.
fields.body:
A man who was questioned by police hunting the killer of eight-year-old Sarah Payne was in custody today charged with stealing a car.

The 41-year-old man, who cannot be named for legal reasons, was arrested early on Sunday following a high-speed chase in Crawley, West Sussex.

The man, of no fixed abode, appeared at Crawley magistrates court yesterday morning charged with theft, assault and the aggravated taking of a vehicle. He was remanded in custody for a week after police objected to bail.

He was initially arrested after Sarah's disappearance. He had been living at his father's home, but both men had to be moved after intimidating crowds gathered outside the property. At the time of his second arrest, he was said to be living in a tent.

Police believe they have recovered Sarah's right shoe although they have yet to recover the rest of her clothing.

A second postmortem on Sarah's body was due to be carried out this week to ascertain the cause of death. Strangulation or suffocation are thought to be two possible causes of her death.

Officers are also sifting through information provided by about 2,000 drivers who were stopped at road checks on the A29 over the weekend. Police have decided to scale down media appeals in order to concentrate on existing leads, but are considering running a piece on BBC TV's Crimewatch, due to be broadcast later this week.

webTitle: No time for Cook to give up on ethics

fields.headline: No time for Cook to give up on ethics
fields.standfirst: While the government's supposed ethical foreign policy has fallen miserably short, a UN initiative shows that international consciences can be stirred to action, writes Victoria Brittain
fields.trailText: While the government's supposed ethical foreign policy has fallen miserably short, a UN initiative shows that international consciences can be stirred to action, writes Victoria Brittain.
fields.body:
The government's ethical foreign policy has had credibility problems almost from its announcement, but this week's finding by four Commons defence and foreign affairs committee on military equipment sales to Zimbabwe leaves its credibility in tatters.

Britain continued to supply spare parts for Hawk aircraft as late as February, in the full knowledge that Zimbabwe was using the Hawks in a civil war in the Democratic Republic of Congo. And when Robin Cook did finally move to stop the spares, in May, it was because he was worried about the pressure on white farmers in Zimbabwe, not because he was outraged at the appalling loss of life in DRC.

Not only does Zimbabwe have no national interest in the conflict, which has torn the country and the continent apart, but Zimbabwe's top military are known to be deeply involved in mining interests in DRC given to them - an undisguised bribe - by DRC president Laurent Kabila. Besides the extremely murky financial background, the war is bleeding Zimbabwe's economy and adding to the country's acute social strains as dead soldiers' families are not allowed to mourn publicly.

But the government cannot afford to give up on its attempt at an ethical foreign policy, especially at a moment when ethics are newly fashionable in powerful circles. The entire diamond industry has been shaken up by the pressures of non-governmental organisations to outlaw conflict diamonds, and the oil industry faces a similar shakeup with new demands for openness about kickbacks in the wake of the ELF inquiry in France and a Global Witness report on Angola.

Tomorrow in New York an extraordinary coalition of big business, trade unions, and environmental and human rights groups meets to cement the Global Compact for ethical behaviour in business launched by Kofi Annan at last year's Davos meeting of the world's most powerful businessmen. Among the 40 or more big companies which have sent top executives to the meeting today are Ericsson of Sweden, Tata of India, and multinationals such as BPAmoco, Nike, Rio Tinto, Volvo, Unilever, Dupont, Bayer, British Telecom, Deutsche Telecom and France Telecom. Scandinavia, Britain, France and Germany have responded enthusiastically, far better than US business. Japan has not responded at all.

The Global Compact, a most unusual initiative for the UN as it does not depend on the countries which are its members, has the potential for making more dramatic changes for the poor around the world than traditional aid programmes have ever done.

The companies' projects, such as prepositioning emergency communications, and tele-medicine sites, will be posted on the Global Compact website. "It's an exercise in transparency, " says John Ruggie, UN assistant secretary-general, and Mr Annan's special adviser on the Global Compact. "We are not monitoring corporations' behaviour, but asking all partners to pool the concrete steps they are taking to show responsible corporate behaviour, concern for the environment, concern for labour standards."

Global Compact

fields.headline: Analysed: the Woodwards in court
fields.standfirst: Louise Woodward's parents walk free
fields.trailText: The fraud allegations against Louise Woodward's parents were the latest and most venomous twist in a row which erupted two years ago after the former au pair sacked her American lawyer, Elaine Whitfield Sharp.
fields.body:
The fraud allegations against Louise Woodward's parents were the latest and most venomous twist in a row which erupted two years ago after the former au pair sacked her American lawyer, Elaine Whitfield Sharp.

A police officer who arrested the lawyer for drink-driving is alleged to have heard her say she no longer believed Ms Woodward was innocent.

Mrs Whitfield Sharp and her husband, Dan added fuel to the flames with their claim that Ms Woodward's mother Susan had asked for $15,400 (£9,100) from their daughter's appeal fund to pay for an extended stay at their home when they had charged her nothing.

A police investigation was launched in 1998 and the Woodwards were arrested last summer.

Louise Woodward's mother and father Gary regularly flew out to America to visit their daughter after her arrest in February 1997 when the baby in her care became ill. She was charged with murder when eight-month-old Matthew Eappen died.

Back home in the village of Elton, Cheshire, an appeal fund raised £20,000 which was used to pay off the couple's credit card bills when they were in the US.

A proper trust was set up as the British public opened their chequebooks and sent in more than £250,000 in donations.

In April 1997 Mrs Woodward moved into a spare room at Ms Whitfield Sharp's home, where she stayed until October. Shortly before the trial the couple moved to an apartment near the Boston court paid for by Louise's au pair agency.

Louise was convicted and imprisoned for second degree murder in October 1997, but the verdict was subsequently reduced to involuntary manslaughter and she was sentenced to the time she had already served awaiting trial.

Mrs Whitfield Sharp, who originally comes from Merseyside, claimed she was told about the invoice by a journalist in June 1998, after an appeal fund trustee read in a British newspaper that Mrs Woodward had not been charged for her accommodation.

At the Woodwards' Chester Crown Court trial, she said she would never have charged $2,200 a month to put someone up in her spare room, as the invoice alleged.

"That would be outrageous. It would be extortionate. That is more than our mortgage. It is way over the market value," she told the court.

"Apart from the fact that I wouldn't charge somebody to stay in the spare bedroom after inviting them into my home, I think $2,200 is an outlandish figure."

The trial has heard vitriolic claim and counter-claim; Mrs Woodward said the lawyer was angry at not being allowed to make money by writing a book that 'dished the dirt' on the family.

Mrs Whitfield Sharp denied this, claiming she had considered writing a general text on legal issues surrounding shaken baby syndrome.

Mrs Woodward insisted she paid Mrs Whitfield Sharp for accommodation, and that it was the lawyer's idea to submit the invoice.

The trial also revealed that the Woodwards were painstakingly thorough in drawing up their expense claims. Among the receipts submitted at the time of the rent claim was $6.80 for pet food for Louise's hamster and 50 cents for bubblegum.

fields.headline: Woodward parents cleared of fraud
fields.trailText: Fraud charges against the parents of Louise Woodward, the former au pair who was convicted of the manslaughter of a baby in the US, were today dismissed at Chester crown court.
fields.body:
Fraud charges against the parents of Louise Woodward, the former au pair who was convicted of the manslaughter of a baby in the US, were today dismissed at Chester crown court.

Gary and Susan Woodward walked free after a jury was told to find them not guilty on charges of defrauding their daughter's appeal fund.

The estranged couple breathed a sigh of relief from the dock as the jury foreman officially cleared the couple on the instructions of Judge John Rogers.

The Woodwards, both 44, had denied defrauding their daughter's appeal fund of more than £9,000.

The judge said the crown had failed to prove that certain sums of money within the Louise Woodward and Family trust fund were not donated solely for the use of her parents.

Mr Woodward, a joiner, of Ellesmere Port, and Mrs Woodward, a clerical worker, of Elton, Cheshire, had denied defrauding the fund of more than £9,000 by falsely claiming for the cost of accommodation at the home of Boston lawyer Elaine Whitfield Sharp before and during their daughter's trial for killing a baby in her care in November 1997.
