fields.headline: Section 28
fields.standfirst: The government has failed in its bid to remove section 28 from the statute book.  Julia Hartley-Brewer, Patrick Barkham, Ros Taylor and Julian Glover explain why a small piece of legislation has caused such passionate controversy
fields.trailText: The government has failed in its bid to remove section 28 from the statute book. We explain why a small piece of legislation has caused such passionate controversy.
fields.byline: Julia Hartley-Brewer, Patrick Barkham and Ros Taylor
fields.body:
What was section 28 for? Brought in by the Thatcher administration in 1988, it was designed to prevent local authorities from intentionally promoting homosexuality, publishing material with that intention, or promoting the teaching in their schools of the acceptability of homosexuality as a family relationship. It is in fact not really section 28 at all, but a section retrospectively inserted in clause 28 of the local government act of 1986.

How did it begin life? The proposal was first put forward as a private member's bill tabled by Lord Halsbury in 1986. Originally, the Conservative government did not support the bill on the grounds that it was "open to harmful misrepresentation". Later, it included the clause in a government bill.

What does the law say? "(1) A local authority shall not (a) intentionally promote homosexuality or publish material with the intention of promoting homosexuality; (b) promote the teaching in any maintained school of the acceptability of homosexuality as a pretended family relationship. (2) Nothing in subsection (1) above shall be taken to prohibit the doing of anything for the purpose of treating or preventing the spread of disease. (3) In any proceedings in connection with the application of this section a court shall draw such inferences as to the intention of the local authority as may be reasonably be drawn from the evidence before it."

Why do opponents of section 28 want it repealed? They argue that the law has been used to discriminate against and penalise lesbians, gays and bisexuals. And, although the law has never been enforced, opponents claim it has meant schools censor their own teaching of sex education and local councils have withdrawn funding from gay and lesbian projects. They say it also deters teachers from providing protection or pastoral care to vulnerable gay teenagers, as well as enshrining in law the notion that homosexuality is unacceptable and undesirable.

Are they right? Despite huge controversy when it was introduced, no local authority has ever been prosecuted under section 28. It has never applied directly to schools in England and Wales, although a third of teachers believe that it does and that they cannot do anything to promote homosexuality in the classroom. The law applies to local authorities, but not to teachers or governors, so the introduction of local management has reduced the intended impact of the legislation of schools.

Why is it back in the news now? The government is committed to repealing the clause. The House of Lords has blocked this.

Why does the government want this? The government is committed to repeal because it believes that section 28 "causes confusion and creates a climate that may encourage discrimination and discourage schools from developing sensible policies to tackle homophobic bullying". They also argue that the law was badly drafted.

And what has the reaction been? Repealing the law has proved highly troublesome. In Scotland, the Scottish parliament repealed the clause despite a privately-funded referendum which found a massive majority in favour of its retention. In England and Wales, a local government bill which included repeal among its measures was blocked by a coalition of Tories and church leaders in the House of Lords. To pacify them, David Blunkett amended the learning and skills bill to provide legislative guidance for schools on the sanctity of marriage. Opponents in the upper house once again blocked repeal.

Who wants to keep the law? The Conservatives remain opposed to repeal. Church leaders have also fought to keep the law. The issue has also bitterly divided Scotland, which legislates separately. Cardinal Thomas Winning, the leader of the Roman Catholic Church in Scotland, recently called on Scotland's 'silent majority' of Christians to oppose the abolition of section 28.

What happens now? The government has made it clear that it remains committed to repeal but when this will happen is uncertain. The issue may be left until after the general election.

The case for section 28: Conservative christian fellowship

webTitle: Gynaecologist struck off for five years

fields.headline: Gynaecologist struck off for five years
fields.trailText: Disgraced gynaecologist Richard Neale was today struck off the medical register after the General Medical Council found him guilty of serious professional misconduct.
fields.body:
Disgraced gynaecologist Richard Neale was today struck off the medical register after the General Medical Council found him guilty of serious professional misconduct.

Neale stood silently with his head bowed as the GMC's professional conduct committee chairman Professor Ken Hobbs announced the decision at the central London hearing. Professor Hobbs said: "The findings of fact reveal many deficiencies in the standard of care you provided to patients as well as unprofessional and dishonest behaviour. Your diagnostic skills and clinical management of patients fell seriously below accepted standards."

The Medical Protection Society, representing Neale, issued a statement on his behalf. He said: "My family and I are totally devastated by this decision, the events of recent weeks and the two years it has taken to bring evidence before the GMC. I would like to apologise fully and unreservedly to those patients whose cases have been the subject of this hearing. However, I hope that the public will accept that, as a committed Christian, I went into medicine and became a surgeon, not to cause pain and suffering but to alleviate it wherever possible."

Neale is one of the first people to be punished under a new rule which means doctors who are struck off the medical register are erased for a minimum of five years. Previous rules allowed doctors to resume practice within 10 months of being struck off.

The professional conduct committee of the General Medical Council reached their decision after considering his case over the past week. On Thursday they found 34 of 35 "facts proven" against the 52-year-old consultant. He was found guilty of performing operations without consent, sub-standard surgery, unnecessary procedures and failing to inform his patients' GPs of complications resulting from his incompetence. Women were left in agonising pain after complications following surgery, and they said Neale became abusive when they complained.

The three-week case was one of the most shocking to come before the GMC and exposed a scandal in which Neale was allowed to carry on working up until last year, when he was suspended "for public safety". He is now expected to face a flood of litigation from women both in the UK and Canada, where police are also considering criminal charges.

Neale was struck off the medical register in Canada in 1985 after a woman died in childbirth and was implicated in the death of another Canadian woman who also bled to death after surgery. Despite being struck off in Canada, Neale was allowed to work in this country when he returned here in 1985. The consultant worked at the Friarage Hospital in Northallerton, North Yorkshire, from 1985 to 1995, and in Leicester, London and the Isle of Wight. UK hospitals were not automatically told of Neale's blunders in Canada and it was only when his past mistakes were publicised in 1993 that any action was considered. Despite concerns about his "commitment" at the Friarage Hospital, Neale left with £100,000 severance pay and a positive reference. Two complaints were finally made in 1998 and the floodgates of cases opened.

Kathy Tanner, whose mother Geraldine Krawchuck died at the hands of Neale when he practised in Canada, said justice had been done but called for the gynaecologist to face criminal charges in court. "Being struck off is not good enough," she said. "It's just a slap on the hand for him, he needs to be held responsible for his actions and the pain and suffering he's caused his victims."

Department of Health
British Medical Association

fields.headline: Bananas
fields.standfirst: All you need to know about the world's favourite fruit, and how to buy it with a clear conscience
fields.trailText: All you need to know about the world's favourite fruit, and how to buy it with a clear conscience
fields.body:
1. Sainsbury's supermarkets are now stocking bananas with an F-label on them. That means they are supplied through the Fairtrade Foundation, which guarantees a fair price to growers in the Windward Islands.

2. The new deal is the latest move in the campaign to protect poor Caribbean producers from the Big Five, also known to industry watchers as the Wild Bunch.

3. Giant US producers like Chiquita, Dole and Del Monte are expert in growing big, shiny, uniform and almost entirely taste-free bananas.

4. Their huge plantations in Central and South America can produce bananas much more cheaply than the family farms on islands like St Lucia.

5. Until recently, Caribbean exports to Europe were protected by the EU. The World Trade Organisation, under intense pressure from Washington, has forced the European Commission to open the market to the US producers. That has plunged the Caribbean trade into deep crisis.

6. The Caribbean Banana Exporters Association is so alarmed that it is talking of the end of the industry, the region's main export earner.

7. A damning article in Time magazine in February, suggested that Chiquita chief executive Carl Lindner, the biggest banana baron of them all, had poured money into presidential election campaigns in return for Washington's support in the trade dispute with the EU. Chiquita was not amused.

8. Bananas are the world's favourite fruit. They are also Britain's favourite fruit. The market is growing by 5% a year, mostly supplied by household names Fyffes and Geest.

9. There is rising consumer interest in ethical trading. Organisations such as the Fairtrade Foundation and its partner Traidcraft, offer a growing range of produce and goods produced in developing countries.

10. The trade is promoted by pressure groups such as Oneworld, which even offers online ethical shopping.

That means they are supplied through the Fairtrade Foundation, which guarantees a fair price to growers in the Windward Islands. 2. The new deal is the latest move in the campaign to protect poor Caribbean producers from the Big Five, also known to industry watchers as the Wild Bunch. 3. Giant US producers like Chiquita, Dole and Del Monte are expert in growing big, shiny, uniform and almost entirely taste-free bananas. 4. Their huge plantations in Central and South America can produce bananas much more cheaply than the family farms on islands like St Lucia. 5. Until recently, Caribbean exports to Europe were protected by the EU. The World Trade Organisation, under intense pressure from Washington, has forced the European Commission to open the market to the US producers. That has plunged the Caribbean trade into deep crisis. 6. The Caribbean Banana Exporters Association is so alarmed that it is talking of the end of the industry, the region's main export earner. 7. A damning article in Time magazine in February, suggested that Chiquita chief executive Carl Lindner, the biggest banana baron of them all, had poured money into presidential election campaigns in return for Washington's support in the trade dispute with the EU. Chiquita was not amused. 8. Bananas are the world's favourite fruit. They are also Britain's favourite fruit. The market is growing by 5% a year, mostly supplied by household names Fyffes and Geest. 9. There is rising consumer interest in ethical trading. Organisations such as the Fairtrade Foundation and its partner Traidcraft, offer a growing range of produce and goods produced in developing countries. 10. The trade is promoted by pressure groups such as Oneworld, which even offers online ethical shopping.

fields.headline: Blood on the shelves
fields.standfirst:
A year after the accident that almost killed him, Stephen King, the most successful writer on the planet, is attempting, single-handedly, to break 'Big Publishing'. How? By delivering his new book, bit by bit, via his website - and asking his fans to stump up for it. John Sutherland reports

Read the first instalment

By delivering his new book, bit by bit, via his website - and asking his fans to stump up for it. John Sutherland reports
fields.body:
On June 19 1999 the novelist Stephen King suffered a devastating accident. Walking along the highway outside his summer home in Lovell, Maine, he was run into by a wayward camper van. Bones were broken, and organs damaged. He was lucky to survive and will be maimed for life. Therapy may restore the partial use of his limbs, but can it mend his genius?

For King, writing had always been as physical an endeavour as prizefighting. A bear of a man, 6ft 4in tall and 200lbs in weight, he turned out his fiction in what his fans called "firestorms"; three-book contracts (fulfilled in a couple of years) were commonplace. Stories rolled out of him like hot lava.

King's fiction was as generously proportioned as its author. Hyped up by high-volume rock'n'roll (he owns the local radio station, WKIT 100.3), King consistently produced half a million printed words a year. He liked big books - works like The Stand which are the size of breeze blocks. And everything he wrote was a super-seller. He was the first author routinely to have a million-copy first print run. No novelist has had more millions from the publishers. And he makes even more millions for them.

Above all, King seemed to love writing as a champion athlete loves his sport. Everything he did was infused with his exuberant energy. He had, in his time, used stimulants - alcohol and drugs - to drive himself to Stakhanovite levels of overachievement. But with middle age, the grace of God and the devotion of his wife, Tabitha, he conquered those personal demons. He worked as hard and productively in sobriety as he had in intoxication. Harder, even. Nothing could stop him - except two tonnes of out-of-control recreational vehicle careering down the high road.

How, one wondered, would the trauma of being mashed into pulp affect Stephen King the writer? Could he ever be the same again? King's fans have been uneasy on the point.

The line which was put out by King in his communiqués to his fans was that he would take a year's sabbatical after the accident and return to the fray, full time, in July 2000. That year is now up. It's showtime.

No one could accuse Stephen King of lacking a sense of the dramatic. He rides back not merely with a new novel but with an attempt, singlehandedly, to overturn the whole American publishing industry. Stephen King has gone to war against the book trade. His new work, The Plant, is being released on his official website at www.stephenking.com. Access is free. The narrative will be downloadable and - unlike his previous web novel, Riding the Bullet, which was read-only - The Plant can be printed out and passed on.

The first instalment came out yesterday; the second (already written) is penned in for August 21. Each instalment comprises some 5,000 words.

There is no purchase price or charge. Those who read or download the episodes are, however, bound by an "honor system". If they like what they read, they are required to kick in a "buck an episode" to King. "Napster this ain't," King has declared. No freebies. If 75% of those who log in to the story come through with their dollar (the website can compute this precisely) a third episode of The Plant will be forthcoming in late September. If subscription stays "strong" the author will bring the novel to its conclusion in however many instalments it takes. As King puts it: "If you pay, the story rolls. If you don't, the story folds." The initial response on the King website has been positive - but the crunch will be how many new subscribers are drawn in and whether they act honourably or not. Human nature being what it is, one has one's doubts.

What is King playing at? Whatever else, the game is big. As he puts it, The Plant represents a whole new system of producing and distributing works of the imagination: "My friends, we have a chance to become Big Publishing's worst nightmare. Not only are we going glueless, look Ma, no e-Book! No tiresome encryption! Want to print it and show it to a friend? Go ahead! There's only one catch: all this is on the honor system. Has to be. I'm counting on... plain old honesty. 'Take what you want and pay for it,' as the old saying goes."

Publishing historians of the future will probably see The Plant as an interesting technical experiment - perhaps a breakthrough. In his July 11 announcement on his website, King claimed that with The Plant he was blazing a trail for the "marginalized" of the writing profession. Authors of the world can unite around him.

No longer need novelists be in thrall to the stony-hearted publisher and bookseller. Thanks to King (assuming it all works out) they can post their works on the web and wait for the money to roll in from all those honest, kind-hearted readers.

Philanthropy apart, King loves the new thing. He had an electric typewriter when everyone else was manual. He has experimented with film tie-ins, pseudonymy, audio tapes, and innumerable forms of author franchise. With The Green Mile, he quixotically revived the Dickensian novel in monthly episodes. Like Dickens, he made money with The Green Mile and cultivated his own version of make 'em laugh, make 'em cry, make 'em wait.

King was also the first big-name author to venture into cyber-fiction, with Riding the Bullet, in March last year. It was so successful (perhaps because of the novelty, probably because of the irresistible lure of the King brand-name) that the delivery system crashed.

Riding the Bullet demonstrated that there was a big market for popular fiction on the internet. And there are no great difficulties in the mechanics of online publishing. Difficulty presents itself when you try to collect. Within a couple of hours of Riding the Bullet going on sale, bootleg copies were available on the web. The cash flow stopped dead.

It is impossible to sustain viable commerce if your product is saleable only for a few minutes after its launch. The web may be the future, but it is outlaw territory and private literary property isn't safe there. You can electronically watermark and protect images (it's tricky, but it can be done). You can protect software - or at least make it inconvenient to use unlicensed copies. But protecting words on the page, when there is no page, is like catching moonbeams.

During his year off King has evidently come to the conclusion that the only way to create a revenue stream for the novelist (or any other dealer in words) from net publication is trust. Hence he has drawn up a contract, on his authorised website, with his fans. In his missive of July 11, he lays out - in quasi-legal clauses - what he as producer undertakes to do (write the damn thing) and what the consumer must do (cough up).

The web will only work for creative artists when a new morality and new contractual relationships are evolved. As it is, the only cultural product that thrives is pornography. But even if King succeeds with The Plant, as he has succeeded with everything else, his is not an example which less addicting writers can hopefully imitate. If most novelists threatened never to write another word - unless that word were adequately remunerated - the reading public wouldn't give a toss. Like Charles Dickens, Stephen King is a Great Inimitable. It is hard not to suspect that King is mounting this elaborate scheme as a test of whether his readers really love him. Their dollars will be tokens of loyalty - "love gifts", as the televangelists like to call them.

There is another test hinted at. Can Stephen King still work his old magic on his readers? Does he still have what it takes? Those dollars will tell him. If they roll in, they will do more for him than all the physiotherapists.

There is another strange aspect to The Plant. It has been widely described as a new and original work of fiction, specifically written for Stephen King's comeback to active authorship. It is not. The Plant was begun (but never completed) as three short instalments of a story, issued on Christmas cards to King's friends in 1982, 1983 and 1986.

King printed the works himself, under his Philtrum imprint. Only 200 copies of the fascicules were run off. The Plant fragments, as first produced almost two decades ago, are among the most sought-after collector's items in King's oeuvre - his Dead Sea Scrolls. Few have been privileged to read them and they have not (until now) been reprinted. But the general outline of the unfinished narrative has been described in the extensive library of commentary on King's work.

Why, one may ask, would King go back to this early and discarded work now? He has had a fallow year (his first for decades). Could he not come up with something new? Even if The Plant is a huge success, it augurs ill that he should have exhumed this ancient piece of fiction. Has he dried up? Or is the old mastery still there? Pay your dollar and find out.

The Plant so far: a critic delivers his verdict
Stephen King may claim the great Victorian writers of serial fiction as models for his own experiments, but it is from the 18th century that he has taken the form of his latest work. It is an epistolary fiction - a novel in letters - such as was all the rage over two centuries ago. It is set in the 1980s "before e-mail, in other words", as his own blurb emphasises. Published on a website, the story is pre-electronic. The characters write letters, memos, notes, all on bits of paper. The novel is nothing more or less than those bits of paper, collected together. What they reveal is at first amusing, but, by the end of episode one, is turning nasty.

Most of the letters are written by John Kenton, a well-educated malcontent working for a lowbrow publisher. To start with, his notes to an equally disenchanted colleague are sardonic ruminations on the absurdities of the publishing industry. Once an English major at an Ivy League college and president of the university Milton society, he has plans to write serious novels but earns his living caressing the decidedly unliterary authors published by Zenith House. His memos make facetious allusions to Voltaire and Nabokov (Stephen King, an English literature graduate and former English teacher, enjoys his literary jokes). But his company publishes Rats from Hell, His Flaming Kisses and Gash Me, Darling.

Kenton laughs at the creepy and absurd Carlos Detweiller, who writes proffering his typescript of True Tales of Demon Infestations. Maybe it is something that can be "cut down and juiced up and sold to the Amityville Horror audience". Of course, he should know that if you are looking for something to scare the gullible, you could end up scaring yourself. Oddly, Kenton seems not to have read any Stephen King novels, which often discover the powers of hell in what begins as just an average personality disorder.

So the letters of Carlos Detweiller are aptly ridiculous rather than frightening. He's "a ding-dong with delusions of grandeur", as Kenton accurately puts it. From his ouija board he has found "Demonic forces at work on HMS Titanic" and "There will be a President from ARKANSAS!" (this is set in 1981, remember). He writes about attending covens and working in a flower shop. "I am very good with plants" - the sign of horrors to come (there is a hint that Kenton's fiancée is a botanist, which will presumably be useful later). The humour is the best reason for paying one's dollar. Comic horror has always been a part of the King oeuvre. Misery, in which a novelist is terrorised by a truly fanatical fan, is a kind of satire. Christine, the tale of a car-loving nerd turned into a sinister destroyer by the 1950s saloon ("Christine") that takes possession of him, is deliberately hilarious. King's own website tells his followers that The Plant will be "funny and at the same time pretty gruesome". "Think Christine," it advises.

What is mildly appealing about this first instalment of The Plant is that sense of the funny becoming the not-so-funny, the oddbod becoming a monster. It is a horror book that mocks someone making a living from such stuff. Detweiller is a laughable eccentric, but rejected authors can turn nasty (Kenton provides droll anecdotes of such things). And those photos that he sends with his ill-written typescript do seem to show something truly terrible...

Yet that's the trouble. Things are destined to become serious. When they do, what redeems the story will be lost, even if paid-up King followers (net surfers all) will be happily reading on.

fields.headline: Ken Lomas
fields.standfirst: Labour MP who made car number plates glow in the dark
fields.trailText: Labour MP who made car number plates glow in the dark.
fields.body:
The career of the former Labour MP Ken Lomas, who has died aged 77, perfectly spanned a political generation. He entered parliament in 1964, at the time of Harold Wilson's accession to power, and withdrew in 1979, as Mrs Thatcher's Tory tide was coming in.

It seemed suitable for Lomas to be a fervent Wilson loyalist for two reasons. He secured Huddersfield West, the seat in which Wilson himself had been born, and his victory contributed to the tiny majority on which Labour slipped in in 1964. Ironically, this happened because of the breakdown of a secret Liberal-Tory pact.

In an effort to stop Labour from winning, those parties traditionally did not field candidates against each other in Huddersfield West and one other seat. Since the 1950 election, the Liberal, Donald (later Lord) Wade, had held the seat without facing a Tory opponent.

The moment it became a three-cornered fight, Lomas beat Wade by 1,280 votes (with the help of the candidacy of a clever Tory public relations man, John Addey, who came a close third). In the 1966 election, an up-and-coming young Yorkshire rightwinger, Marcus Fox, came second by 4,476 votes.

Lomas was a most suitable candidate for such a target seat. He was born in Ashton-under-Lyne, the son of George Lomas, a Co-op store manager, and Helen Clayton. Educated at the local elementary and central schools, he went to work at the age of 14 as an office boy for the shopworkers' union, Usdaw. He began his political life in the Independent Labour Party.

During the war he qualified as a sergeant in the Royal Marines, and won the Italian Star during the fighting in Salerno before his unit was shipped to south-east Asia.

After demobilisation, he went back to work for Usdaw, married Helen Wilson, a munitions worker, and, with his family, settled in Wilmslow, Cheshire, where he became a justice of the peace. In 1965, he became assistant regional organiser of the Blood Transfusion Service for Manchester.

Lomas had made his political ambitions clear early on. He fought Blackpool South in 1951 and hopeless Macclesfield in 1955. When he showed an interest in Huddersfield West in 1962, the selectors may have thought his limpid brown eyes and dark skin would persuade Asian workers in Huddersfield's woollen mills that he was part-Indian, helping to push fellow-aspirant Betty Boothroyd into second place.

Yet without his wife on hand to provide him with stability, he never settled in at the Commons. He was an active constituency man and party loyalist, but was sometimes unpredictable, even lashing out against immigration.

He served widely on select and specialist committees, but the highest point he reached on the greasy pole was in 1969, when he worked for a year as parliamentary private secretary to Tony Benn, then minister for technology. Lomas achieved a private member's bill, which introduced a reflective element on car number plates.

Soon after he retired on grounds of ill-health in 1979, his name mysteriously disappeared from Who's Who. He was known to suffer from ulcers, and was a heavy private drinker, particularly when in London and away from his wife. It seemed sensible for so stressed-out a person to want to fade away quietly back home in Upton-on-Severn. He worked for some time as a public relations consultant.

When his wife Helen died in 1998, Lomas lost his mainstay. He leaves two sons and a daughter.

Andrew Roth

Kenneth Lomas, politician, born November 16 1922; died July 15 2000

It seemed sensible for so stressed-out a person to want to fade away quietly back home in Upton-on-Severn. He worked for some time as a public relations consultant. When his wife Helen died in 1998, Lomas lost his mainstay. He leaves two sons and a daughter. Andrew Roth Kenneth Lomas, politician, born November 16 1922; died July 15 2000

fields.headline: Sunderland seal covenant with Arca
fields.trailText: Peter Reid has added to his roster of summer signings by agreeing a £3.5m deal to bring Argentinian defender Julio Arca to the Stadium of Light. The 19-year-old left-back, who qualifies for an Italian passport, is expected to sign a five-year contract with the club.
fields.body:
Peter Reid has added to his roster of summer signings by agreeing a £3.5m deal to bring Argentinian defender Julio Arca to the Stadium of Light. The 19-year-old left-back, who qualifies for an Italian passport, is expected to sign a five-year contract with the club.

Arca, who will join Sunderland from Argentinos Juniors (who can count Diego Maradona and Fernando Redondo amongst their old boys), said today: "I am very happy to be coming to Sunderland. I am looking forward to training with the team and I hope that I can win a place in the side and that we can win some trophies."

Reid has been following Arca for six months, and is obviously pleased with the deal. "I spotted Arca playing for Argentina Under-21s against England last season," he said. "He's an exceptional player and was possibly the best player on the field that night. I've had him watched ever since and we have been extremely impressed."

Reid hopes to add another defender, Slovakian international Stanislav Varga, to his squad for £800,000. He has also been linked with Ray Parlour, Celta Vigo's Claude Makelele, Lorenzo Amoruso and Ugo Ehiogu.

fields.headline: French director Claude Sautet dies
fields.trailText: French film director Claude Sautet has died aged 76
fields.body:
French film director Claude Sautet yesterday died of cancer at the age of 76.

Sautet, who made some 30 movies, was celebrated as a chronicler of French bourgeois life, examining the fate of individuals. His big break came in 1969 when he made Les Choses de la Vie (The Things of Life), a story about a middle class man who begins to re-examine his life after a car accident.

Sautet directed many French stars including Yves Montand, Romy Schneider. Emmanuelle Beart and Gerard Depardieu, and won a Cesar, the France's top film prize, in 1996 for his last film Nelly et Monsieur Arnaud. Other successes included Cesar et Rosalie, Vincent, Francois, Paul ... et les Autres and Un Coeur en Hiver. He was nominated for an Oscar for best foreign feature for his 1980 picture, A Simple Story.

fields.headline: Casting news
fields.trailText: Kevin Spacey signs for sci-fi psychodrama, Max Beesley set for glitter, Santa returns, and a starring role for Stockwell, SW9
fields.body:
 Kevin Spacey (pictured) is to star as a delusional mental patient in his next film, according to the Hollywood Reporter. The Oscar-winning star has signed up to star in Universal Pictures' forthcoming sci-fi psychodrama K-PAX in which he will play a patient who claims he is from another planet. The psychiatrist who treats him at first believes that he is suffering from multiple-personality disorder but begins to have doubts about the diagnosis when he notices the beneficial effects he has on his other patients. Iain (Wings of the Dove) Softley will direct.

 British actor Max Beesley has been cast as the male lead opposite pop diva Mariah Carey in All That Glitters. The story is set around the New York club scene and centres on a singer who overcomes a troubled childhood to rise to the top of her profession. Beesley will play a streetwise DJ who helps Carey with her career. Rap singer Da Brat and Tia Texada will also feature as the singer's best friends.

 Comedian Tim Allen is to reprise his role as Santa in a sequel to Disney's 1994 film The Santa Clause, reports Ananova. Although script details have not been released, it is expected the story will take place five years on from the first picture. The release is pencilled in for for November 2001.

 British R'n' B singer Jamelia is to star in a new movie with the people who bought you Human Traffic. The film, to be set in Stockwell, London, will be named after its postcode - SW9. Filming is scheduled to begin in August.

webTitle: Cheney: a safe pair of hands for Bush

fields.headline: Cheney: a safe pair of hands for Bush
fields.standfirst: George W Bush is wise to pick a running mate who is the polar opposite of Dan Quayle, says former US correspondent Mark Tran
fields.trailText: George W Bush is wise to pick a running mate who is the polar opposite of Dan Quayle, says former US correspondent Mark Tran.
fields.body:
Richard Cheney, who is likely to be named today as George W Bush's running mate, was once described rather unkindly as everybody's second choice for president.

In that sense, Mr Cheney is an ideal choice for No 2 on the Republican ticket. The 59-year-old brings an insider's knowledge of Washington, where he was a long-time congressman for Wyoming. More importantly, he brings foreign policy expertise to a candidate wet behind the ears on international matters. As defence secretary during the Gulf war under president George Bush, Mr Cheney formed an impressive double act with General Colin Powell.

During his time in Washington, Mr Cheney projected a sense of calm confidence and a down-to-earth quality that was a refreshing antidote to the outsized egos than run rampant in the capital.

He also had the knack of coming across as a moderate rather than a Neanderthal rightwinger, despite a highly conservative voting record on issues ranging from abortion to school buses. His supporters say he had little choice but to represent his conservative constituency in Wyoming, but his detractors point out that he had wide latitude as he represented a very safe Republican seat.

From a European perspective, what will be of most interest is how hard he will push the idea of a national missile defence system, which threatens to unravel the Anti-Ballistic Missile treaty, one of the underpinnings of the arms control regime. Russia and China dislike NMD intensely, while the Europeans are highly uneasy. It will come as little comfort to those who consider NMD to be a dumb idea that Mr Cheney supported Ronald Reagan's Star Wars, the precursor of NMD.

For George W Bush, the opinion of other governments on NMD is a very secondary consideration. Uppermost in his mind is whether Mr Cheney will help or hinder his White House prospects. It should not hurt. Mr Cheney personifies the concept of a safe pair of hands and he has received a clean bill of health despite a history of mild heart attacks.

But as somebody no longer in politics and who doesn't bring represent a state with many electoral votes, he is not a potent vote-getter. A bolder choice would have been senator John McCain, who would have brought many independents to the Bush candidacy. But that seemed highly unlikely because of bad blood between the two men during the race for the Republican nomination.

Mr Bush can be sure of one thing. Mr Cheney should not embarrass him as Dan Quayle embarrassed his dad. Mr Quayle was a political joke from the moment he was picked by Bush senior as his running mate and will go down in political folklore as the man who spelt potato with an "e". Mr Cheney is no joke, but a serious and accomplished political operator, and an asset to the Bush campaign.

webTitle: Comment: Hugo Young on reforming the Lords

fields.headline: The Lords is potent, wise and quite indefensible
fields.standfirst:
It might be the nation's conscience, but it should be elected
Special report: Lords reform
fields.trailText: The only debate that mattered, on clause 28, took place yesterday in the Lords. It may not have been edifying, but nobody knew which way it would go. Its outcome will be decisive. So have been the outcomes of many other Lords proceedings.
fields.body:
The only debate that mattered, on clause 28, took place yesterday in the Lords. It may not have been edifying, but nobody knew which way it would go. Its outcome will be decisive. So have been the outcomes of many other Lords proceedings.

Something has happened to the bloodstream pumping through the heart of British democracy. One chamber, the elected one, is a passive agent in the body politic: uninteresting, unattended, oxygen-free. The other is uncontrolled, unpredictable, life-enhancing. Yet the better the House of Lords performs, the bigger the challenge it presents not just to government but to the parliamentary system. Paradoxically, we're watching an institution that defends the quality of politics become, itself, ever more indefensible.

New Labour's achievement has created the most potent Lords of modern times. The place is illegitimate, but it has built a new legitimacy. It is defeating the government, or threatening to, time and again. Government plans for utilities supplies, big-brother email oversight and freedom of information are among major matters that either have had or will have unwelcome attention from the peers.

Two issues discussed in this space - indirect racial discrimination by public bodies, and the penal removal of benefit without court orders - have happily seen Lords victories, which ministers have gone along with. War widows have been other beneficiaries, as ministers buckled.

Many of these interven tions show a pattern. They have a lot to do with the rule of law. That's true of the regulation of investigatory powers bill, and the same instinct will summon peers to the defence of trial by jury. Football hooligans' right to travel may receive similar attention.

Liberal Democrats have been prominent in this sequence, and so have lawyers. There are a lot of new lawyers in the house. A doctrine seems to be developing. In place of the Salisbury convention, which debarred the old hereditary chamber from blocking a government's manifesto pledges, comes an anti-Napoleonic convention, which says the Lords have a duty to stop authoritarian diktats from the Commons.

What helps them is time. Ministers didn't want to give way on benefit deprivation for alleged breaches of community orders. The principle here did not move them. But they knew they stood to lose their whole pension reform bill. The same was true of other measures, including clause 28.

Where Socratic dialogue has no chance, alliances of Labour, Tory, Lib Dem and cross-bench peers can apply the frighteners. They often are alliances. Though clause 28 was a different case, rule-of-law protection doesn't pit Tories against Labour but draws every party into partnership. When the surrender comes, the government may even become a co-signatory to the amendment in question.

So the Lords is genuinely adversarial. But it is also collaborative. Its entire style of politics is thus a lesson to the Commons. A proportion of its legislators are free of whipping. Its debates are allowed to change minds. Its solutions produce intelligible compromise. It stops ministers playing dirty tricks. It has some claim to be called the conscience of the nation, proudly declaring the merits, as an unelected chamber, of not always having to submit to what the voters, on the basis of some focus group or other, are supposed to be saying. All in all, give or take a fuming outburst of bigotry from the Christian right, it has recently done far more good than harm.

Yet this paragon among legislative bodies is deeply defective, and the more good work it does the more that is apparent. Are we seriously to say that only the undemocratic house is to be trusted with the rule of law? With the protection of minority rights? With freedom of debate? With the very principles of parliamentary democracy, which include the accountability of an executive to bodies it can't always imprison in its stranglehold?

That's the way it looks now. Maybe if the Commons reverted to smaller majorities, the Lords would be less inclined to mount its pious high horse. But on the whole, I doubt it. Shorn of most of its hereditaries, it has taken a giant leap towards self-belief. It's unlikely to be any less active, for example, if a new Commons produces a Labour majority dependent on Scottish MPs whose UK-wide legitimacy is undermined by the Scottish parliament. Then the Lords will be fearlessly stepping in again. Britain, in other words, will be asked to continue to revere the second chamber not merely as the equal but, in some sense, the superior house.

S ome people, most of them peers, have no problem with this. They see it as an example of the genius of evolution whereby the houses complement each other: in this case, the Lords stepping in when the Commons has degenerated into an executive instrument, and doing so after a reform which is enough to make things seem less unacceptable than they were.

Just as the 1911 version of Lords reform, reducing the house's powers, was intended to be interim but lasted the rest of the century, maybe New Labour's reform, changing the membership, will last another. As argued here before, this looks the best bet. I'm not convinced that ministers will discover, or even desire to find, the blueprint for a properly legitimate second chamber which MPs and peers will ever vote for.

There's a talk-out for this. Perhaps the House of Lords is already legitimate enough. After all, every amendment it passes has to be approved by the democratic Commons. That's the way these measures take root, theoretically, in the popular will. So the peers should no longer be seen as unelected legislators, but as a kind of super-advisory committee to the Commons. Maybe their expertise and electoral disinterest are brought to bear in that way, with teeth bared to ensure the government is obliged to give their advice the most serious attention, but without usurping the electorate.

That's probably the argument we'll hear, as Lords activism continues. I don't buy it. What we're witnessing is something very uncomfortable, not made less so by most of the interventions being, in my opinion, wise. The fact is that an unelected chamber is now a power centre in its own right, which claims for itself unique insights into what the country really needs.

In a 21st century democracy, this isn't good enough. A tranche of unelected cross-bench peers would always improve the quality of the advisory committee. But party peers should, in the end, be the people's choice. It is unconscionably perverse to defend a nominated chamber as the only way to make up for the deficiencies of the elected chamber. The Commons itself needs to learn why it is that the Lords, incredibly, has the more credibility. The Commons is where the defects of democracy begin. But the Lords cannot go on dishing out virtue from the table of the unelect, and expect the world not to be haunted by a sense of revulsion.

webTitle: In praise of building a bypass

fields.headline: In praise of building a bypass
fields.standfirst:
We live in a subtly beautiful and crowded country. Inches matter
Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: We live in a subtly beautiful and crowded country. Inches matter
fields.body:
A few hours after John Prescott made his transport announcement in the Commons on Thursday, I was sitting in the garden of a pub called the Farmer's Boy by a narrow and twisty country lane on the edge of the Forest of Dean in Gloucestershire.

It had been a perfect summer's day, and I dare say the birds were twittering and all of that. It was difficult to tell, because this jumped-up cart-track is officially known as the A40, and every 30 seconds a juggernaut thundered by, a few inches beyond the hedge.

One of the more intriguing books of the summer is billed as "a biography of the A40": Edward Platt's Leadville (Picador £9.99). Platt is a young journalist who was alert and curious enough to start knocking on the doors of the houses on either side of the road that in the mid-90s were being condemned for a widening scheme. It is a nicely written and non- judgmental insight into lives of quiet desperation. But that, of course, is the London end of the road. The book is hardly a biography of the A40, because what goes on in that small and overcrowded metropolitan stretch is but one small chapter of the road's picaresque life story en route to Oxford, Cheltenham and points west to Fishguard.

Rivers gradually broaden to carry the weight of water that flows into them. The A40 narrows and broadens all the way along, uncertain whether it is a highway or a glorified footpath. Either side of the Farmers' Boy, the speed limit varies every mile or so: 30, 40, 50, 60, 70 - no motorist can respond to the changes, but it hardly matters since there is nowhere safe enough even to overtake a tractor. The result is disastrous for everyone who comes close to it, drivers and residents alike.

In Platt's book, there is an unspoken understanding between his characters, the author and the reader: that there is something diabolical about all the heedless drivers rushing by. During construction of the Newbury bypass, there was a national groundswell of sympathy for Swampy and co, a sense that the country needed trees more than it needed the bypass. Though this battle was lost, the intellectual argument was temporarily won. In 1995, the road-building budget was slashed; the A40 widening was scrapped when Labour came in two years later. Utter madness.

We live in a subtly beautiful and crowded country. Every inch matters. And there are few fates more awful than to buy a home in a quiet spot and discover someone in Whitehall has decided to stick a road near enough to destroy everything you cherish (especially if it's just far enough away for you to be cheated out of compensation).

But people and goods have to move. Without bypasses, urban life becomes intolerable. If you have a road called the A40, it has to be a quick and efficient route. This isn't an argument for road v rail (see past columns, passim): we have proved even more incapable of building railways - the Eurostar will chug through Kent because the Tories were too petrified to offend their own voters. Transport policy requires political courage: vision, investment and hard choices.

The Brown and Prescott announcements last week do suggest that for the first time in at least 40 years, we have at last a modicum of the vision and the investment. The hard choices come later, when the next generation of anti-road campaigners start climbing into the trees, the pro-roads lobby start screaming about congestion charges and the government panics about the cost of tram tracks.

What we have is a start. Any Guardian readers in despair about this government might benefit by looking at Thursday's Hansard and reading the vapid, idea-less and quite simply bone-headed response to Prescott from the Tory spokesman, Bernard Jenkin. The government may be dithery, self-obsessed, vainglorious, illiberal, unfeeling and gutless but, by golly, the alternative looks grim. The transport policy has to stick.

Matters arising: the American vice-president William R de V King quite possibly was President James Buchanan's lover, but he was actually vice-president to Buchanan's predecessor, Franklin Pierce. Apologies. In last week's piece I should also have said that 1988 (not 1968) was the last time both vice-presidential places were open until convention season, but it was such a ghastly election it is best forgotten, anyway. Meanwhile, there are continuing rumours that this year's Republican nominee will be Frank Keating, who is apparently the governor of Oklahoma. Funny: he's been on this paper years and never mentioned it.

The member for Greenwich, Nick Raynsford, wrote to the Guardian theorising that because I said the cost of taking a family of four to the Dome was £73 not £57.50, therefore I could not have gone there. No, what it means is that, on top of all its other debts, the wretched place owes me £15.50.

Either side of the Farmers' Boy, the speed limit varies every mile or so: 30, 40, 50, 60, 70 - no motorist can respond to the changes, but it hardly matters since there is nowhere safe enough even to overtake a tractor. The result is disastrous for everyone who comes close to it, drivers and residents alike. In Platt's book, there is an unspoken understanding between his characters, the author and the reader: that there is something diabolical about all the heedless drivers rushing by. During construction of the Newbury bypass, there was a national groundswell of sympathy for Swampy and co, a sense that the country needed trees more than it needed the bypass. Though this battle was lost, the intellectual argument was temporarily won. In 1995, the road-building budget was slashed; the A40 widening was scrapped when Labour came in two years later. Utter madness. We live in a subtly beautiful and crowded country. Every inch matters. And there are few fates more awful than to buy a home in a quiet spot and discover someone in Whitehall has decided to stick a road near enough to destroy everything you cherish (especially if it's just far enough away for you to be cheated out of compensation). But people and goods have to move. Without bypasses, urban life becomes intolerable. If you have a road called the A40, it has to be a quick and efficient route. This isn't an argument for road v rail (see past columns, passim): we have proved even more incapable of building railways - the Eurostar will chug through Kent because the Tories were too petrified to offend their own voters. Transport policy requires political courage: vision, investment and hard choices. The Brown and Prescott announcements last week do suggest that for the first time in at least 40 years, we have at last a modicum of the vision and the investment. The hard choices come later, when the next generation of anti-road campaigners start climbing into the trees, the pro-roads lobby start screaming about congestion charges and the government panics about the cost of tram tracks. What we have is a start. Any Guardian readers in despair about this government might benefit by looking at Thursday's Hansard and reading the vapid, idea-less and quite simply bone-headed response to Prescott from the Tory spokesman, Bernard Jenkin. The government may be dithery, self-obsessed, vainglorious, illiberal, unfeeling and gutless but, by golly, the alternative looks grim. The transport policy has to stick. Matters arising: the American vice-president William R de V King quite possibly was President James Buchanan's lover, but he was actually vice-president to Buchanan's predecessor, Franklin Pierce. Apologies. In last week's piece I should also have said that 1988 (not 1968) was the last time both vice-presidential places were open until convention season, but it was such a ghastly election it is best forgotten, anyway. Meanwhile, there are continuing rumours that this year's Republican nominee will be Frank Keating, who is apparently the governor of Oklahoma. Funny: he's been on this paper years and never mentioned it. The member for Greenwich, Nick Raynsford, wrote to the Guardian theorising that because I said the cost of taking a family of four to the Dome was £73 not £57.50, therefore I could not have gone there. No, what it means is that, on top of all its other debts, the wretched place owes me £15.50. Matthewengel@ndirect.co.uk

fields.headline: Everton complete Gravesen signing
fields.trailText: Everton manager Walter Smith took his summer spending to almost £15m this morning when he completed the signing of Danish international midfielder Thomas Gravesen.
fields.body:
Everton manager Walter Smith took his summer spending to almost £15m this morning when he completed the signing of Danish international midfielder Thomas Gravesen.

Gravesen agreed a five-year contract with the Goodison Park club after completing a £2.5m move from German club SV Hamburg.

Gravesen becomes Smith's sixth signing of the summer, after the arrival of Paul Gascoigne, Steve Watson, Alessandro Pistone, Ghanaian Alex Nyarko and Swedish midfielder Niclas Alexandersson.

However, Smith has also lost the services of key players Nick Barmby, John Collins and Don Hutchison, and the Scot is banking on his new signings being adequate replacements.

"I think we have replaced the lads who have left with some good players," he said today. "Once they are allowed time to settle in I am sure they will all make a good impression."

webTitle: Big Brother rivals fear the chop

fields.headline: Big Brother rivals fear the chop
fields.trailText: Housemates in the Big Brother television show have become so obsessed with the fear of eviction that the producers are having to step in to change their topics of conversation.
fields.body:
Housemates in the Big Brother television show have become so obsessed with the fear of eviction that the producers are having to step in to change their topics of conversation.

A week after moving into their purpose-built home, the 10 contenders vying for the Channel 4 surveillance show's £70,000 jackpot have split into male and female cliques. But even these are fracturing - with father-of-three Darren retreating into a shell and forceful women Caroline and Sada emerging as likely candidates to be kicked out.

A spokeswoman for the show said yesterday: "They have spent nearly all weekend talking about who is going to be thrown out. They were obsessing so much about it, Big Brother had to give them another topic of conversation."

Each member of the household was last night due to vote secretly on who they wanted evicted, with the result shown on tonight's Channel 4 highlights slot. The public will then be given two days to choose which of the two most popular choices should go - a scene to be shown live on TV on Friday.

With one member ejected each week, the idea is for one survivor, the prize winner, at the end of the 64 days.

 Press Association

fields.headline: British policy on arms sales
fields.standfirst: The government has been criticised by MPs for failing to strike a balance between its "ethical foreign policy" and the need to protect the UK arms industry. Jeevan Vasagar explains why
fields.trailText: The government has been criticised by MPs for failing to strike a balance between its "ethical foreign policy" and the need to protect the UK arms industry. We explain why.
fields.body:
What is Labour's policy on arms sales?
"Labour will not permit the sale of arms to regimes that might use them for internal repression or international aggression," the party's manifesto promised before its election in 1997.

In government, say critics, it has followed a subsequent manifesto pledge more closely: "We support a strong UK defence industry, which is a strategic part of our industrial base as well as our defence effort."

The sale of arms to foreign countries is big business - and Britain is the second biggest exporter of arms in the world. Two of the biggest buyers of British arms are Indonesia and Saudi Arabia, both with poor human rights records. The two account for 25% of UK arms sales.

The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, who inaugurated an "ethical foreign policy" one month into office, last July reaffirmed the importance of ethical considerations when exporting arms. He said that the government "will not issue an export licence if there is a clearly identifiable risk that the proposed export might be used for internal repression" and promised to publish an annual report detailing arms export applications.

But the tension between Labour's two manifesto promises has continued, as demonstrated by rows over the sale of arms to Indonesia, aircraft spares to Zimbabwe, and now by four Commons committees - foreign affairs, defence, international development and trade and industry - demanding prior scrutiny of future arms sales licence applications.

How are British-made weapons sold to other countries?
Licences to export "strategic goods" are issued by the government's export control agency, which is part of the Department of Trade and Industry.

Businesses wanting to export their products fill in a form (they can even do it online). The DTI circulates relevant licence applications to other ministries, such as the Foreign Office and the Department for International Development, before approval is given. A raft of regulations and guidance notes for exporters restricts the sale of arms or other goods which could be used to make weapons to regimes embroiled in conflict.

The UK must also obey EU-wide arms trade embargos. Mr Cook courted controversy after approving the delivery of nine British Aerospace Hawks to Indonesia, part of an export contract agreed under the previous Conservative government. Three were delivered in September 1999, but a four-month EU embargo on arms sales to Indonesia stalled the remaining delivery. The sale of Hawk aircraft spares to Zimbabwe undermined an EU embargo brought in because of the country's instability and its intervention in the Congo civil war.

How is the government divided on the issue of arms?
The DTI works to boost British industry: its ministers and civil servants favour free trade and tend to take a relaxed view of exporting weapons. Similarly, the Ministry of Defence instinctively supports Britain's arms industry.

The Foreign Office works to boost exports with the DTI through British Trade International and the Invest in Britain bureau, and more than a third of Foreign Office staff time is spent helping British exports and investment opportunities abroad. But Mr Cook has repeatedly stressed the importance of an ethical foreign policy. He opposed the sale of fighter jet spare parts to Zimbabwe, but was overruled by the prime minister, Tony Blair, whose official spokesman said there was a commercial obligation to stand by contracts in all but "extreme circumstances".

What about export credit guarantees?
The government's export credit guarantee department (ECGD) operates as insurance for British exporters involved in risky export projects. It guarantees that if a foreign country defaults on paying for British goods the government will recompense the exporter. Last year, more than 50% of ECGD cover supported arms sales.

In December 1999, Mr Blair controversially allowed an export credit guarantee to be issued to underwrite engineering firm Balfour Beatty's building of a hotly disputed Turkish dam, which will flood 52 Kurdish villages and 15 towns.

The chancellor, Gordon Brown, has announced that the Treasury would ban export credits for arms sales to 63 of the world's poorest countries. These include Bolivia, Mozambique, Afghanistan and Sri Lanka, as well as countries embroiled in wars, such as Sierra Leone and Ethiopia.

While these moves appear to discourage British arms exporters and bad debt, the Campaign Against the Arms Trade argues that the government has not gone far enough. It says that, with the exception of Sri Lanka, none of the countries listed are big customers of the UK arms trade.

At what point good business becomes bad ethics, as well as bad diplomacy, will continue to trouble the government.

fields.headline: Daniels: Why I am resigning
fields.trailText: Barbara Daniels, 35, has been the national manager for women's cricket since May 1998. She oversaw the merger of the Women's Cricket Association with the ECB and helped build up the profile of female cricketers at Lord's. She is also England's most senior player and she scored 231 runs at 57.75 in the one-day series against South Africa in June. She is resigning from the ECB at the end of this season so that she can concentrate on playing cricket.
fields.body:
Barbara Daniels, 35, has been the national manager for women's cricket since May 1998. She oversaw the merger of the Women's Cricket Association with the ECB and helped build up the profile of female cricketers at Lord's. She is also England's most senior player and she scored 231 runs at 57.75 in the one-day series against South Africa in June. She is resigning from the ECB at the end of this season so that she can concentrate on playing cricket.

When did you decide to resign from the ECB?
I had decided in my mind before the South Africa series, though I didn't do anything about it. But suddenly scoring runs once I'd made the decision confirmed that it was the right thing to do.

Why?
The Australian series was a bit of a disaster. [In six games she made 34 runs at 5.66, with a highest score of 19.] I felt I was doing neither my cricket nor my job at the ECB justice, and I decided that if I wanted to continue playing for England I had to put my whole heart into it.

Was it a hard decision?
It wasn't easy because I've enjoyed working at the ECB and they've been very good employers and very understanding about my cricket commitments. I have days when I think, what have I done? But then I remember how relaxed I felt during the South Africa series.

Who did you discuss your decision with?
Essentially I came to the decision by myself. I didn't want to alert too many people to what I was thinking. But I did speak to Paul [Farbrace, the coach] and Joce Brooks [England's psychologist] about what my future cricket career might hold. I still felt that I had something to offer if I could get myself back into form, but I realised that I had to reassert myself back into the team and in my own mind.

How will you support yourself?
I'm a teacher [of English to secondary-school pupils] by profession so I know that I can always do supply work if necessary. And I won't be lost to cricket - I'm sure I'll end up on some committee somewhere.

Will you get paid for going on tour?
The ECB have given the players something on the last two tours and we are waiting on news of a lottery bid. Things are looking fairly hopeful. But whatever happens we're guaranteed to have our expenses paid. It's a wholly different world to when I first started.

Do you feel that there is a conflict of interest in being both a player and an administrator?
Not as far as I am concerned. But my job has grown a lot in four-and-a-half years so it has become increasingly difficult to combine it with playing. Cricket has grown harder too. We never used to play every year and, of course, as I've got older I've had to train harder.

Do you feel satisfied with the job you've done?
I became the first full-time executive director of the Women's Cricket Association in February 1996, and it very quickly became apparent that unless we worked more closely with the ECB we weren't going to go anywhere. The merger wasn't an easy thing to do and a lot of people needed convincing. And understandably so - it was a leap of faith. But it has made women's cricket far healthier and is good for the game full stop. There is still an awful lot to do but it's been a very exciting time to be involved with women's cricket.

Marion Collin, the England scorer, said she'd never seen you bat as well as you did during the South Africa series. Do you agree?
It is nice of people to say that. Certainly I felt back to something like my best form. I was lots more relaxed and lots more positive, and I thoroughly enjoyed it which is the key. I hope it is a sign of things to come. New Zealand and Australia really knocked the confidence out of us. Not just me, but the whole side.

How long will you play on for?
The World Cup and then I'll see. There are a lot of youngsters coming up who need some experienced people around, like this old girl. I'll play as long as I can. You're a long time retired as they say.

Are people more enthusiastic about watching women's cricket than they used to be?
At Canterbury [the third one-day international] we had over a thousand people watching and at Taunton [the fourth] it was between two and three thousand which was great, though I still think we should be looking to get five thousand people at our games. People are not always keen to come, but once they do they are very, very impressed. It is important for girls to see women playing cricket. There were loads of kids at Taunton, and two girls were overheard discussing who they wanted to be. One said, "I'll be Clare Connor, the batswoman." That is great.

Have things changed?
Yes. In the last four or five years there has been a sea change in the general attitude to women and sport. It is seen as acceptable and normal. Girls in cricket are now demanding things from development officers. I think Kwik Cricket has made a real difference, it is a positive, fun, experience. And because of the merger all the county sides have had to take notice of women's cricket. They might have been hesitant to start with but then they realised the commercial value. The money is not to be sniffed at.

Tanya Aldred is assistant editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly

webTitle: Watchdog blocks Kelda plans for Yorkshire Water

fields.headline: Watchdog blocks Kelda plans for Yorkshire Water
fields.trailText: The regulator Ofwat today said that water company Kelda's proposals to restructure Yorkshire Water could not go ahead.
fields.body:
The regulator Ofwat today said that water company Kelda's proposals to restructure Yorkshire Water could not go ahead.

Kelda had unveiled plans in June to turn Yorkshire Water into a mutual society owned by its customers and run as a not-for-profit business.

However, Sir Ian Byatt, director general of water services, today said the company's proposals failed to set out clearly how customers would benefit. The plans failed to ensure the drinking water inspectorate and environment agency were able to enforce the required quality standards, he said, and did not demonstrate clear independence between the proposed mutual and Kelda.

Sir Ian said: "Water utilities should not become mutuals unless there are benefits to customers. This has still to be demonstrated - the advantages claimed could be achieved within the existing equity model.

"The Kelda proposals cannot go ahead on the present basis. More analysis and more consultation is required before any steps in this direction could be contemplated."

John Napier, executive chairman of Kelda, said: "We have made it clear that the proposals require regulatory approval and because they involve mutuality, they also require some form of clear customer endorsement."

He said the group believed the regulators concerns "cannot be addressed by amendments to the current proposal".

"Accordingly, we are withdrawing our current proposal with the intention of seeking a way forward that is acceptable to the director general of water services and others," he said.

Sir Ian told BBC Radio 4's Today programme: "Customers in Yorkshire need to be properly consulted in an informed way before anything can go ahead and that has not yet happened.

"There would be some risks for them in this situation"

Kelda executive chairman John Napier told Today: "This industry is affected by still massive political issues and deep disquiet over the privatisation process, which took place 10 years ago.

"We continue to be convinced that there are significant benefits and advantages to customers, shareholders and the community from the sorts of proposals that we have been trying to develop.

Brian Strutton, the GMB union's national secretary for utilities, said: "As it was proposed, the mutualisation of Kelda would have unfairly saddled customers with huge debt for no benefit.

"In the process, operations would have been contracted out and that would have spelt disaster for consumers concerned with standards, reliability and safety."

"In the process, operations would have been contracted out and that would have spelt disaster for consumers concerned with standards, reliability and safety."

fields.headline: New football millions target grassroots
fields.trailText: The government and sporting bodies today unveiled a new scheme to bolster British football with with the launch of a multi-million pound grassroots initiative. The Football Foundation, which is backed by the government, the Premier League, and Sport England, aims to provide around £60m a year to improve facilities and encourage more young people to take up the game.
fields.body:
The government and sporting bodies today unveiled a new scheme to bolster British football with with the launch of a multi-million pound grassroots initiative. The Football Foundation, which is backed by the government, the Premier League, and Sport England, aims to provide around £60m a year to improve facilities and encourage more young people to take up the game.

The scheme was launched in the back garden of 10 Downing Street this morning, with England coach Kevin Keegan and prime minister Tony Blair indulging in a now-obligatory kickabout for the cameras.

The prime minister said the foundation was not simply an attempt to improve the standard of football in England, a hot topic of debate following England's dismal showing in Euro 2000, but a social initiative too. "We want to end up not just winning competitions in 10, 15, 20 years' time but, as important as anything else, end up giving these kids a decent start, a decent chance to life," he said.

The foundation's main aim is to build new "mini soccer centres" around the country, equipped with special smaller pitches for under 11s and floodlit Astroturf pitches available for use by schools and local communities. Existing facilities will also be given money for improvement and extra equipment.

Dave Richards, the chairman of the Premier League, which will donate £90m to the foundation over the next four years, said: "The launch of the Football Foundation marks a new beginning for the funding of grassroots football and the start of the new partnership between football and the government.

"We have worked hard with colleagues within the FA, Sport England and government to put together the new body and we can now look forward with confidence to the delivery of quality facilities for young footballers up and down the country."

webTitle: Milos Forman to head Venice jury

fields.headline: Milos Forman to head Venice jury
fields.trailText: It was announced yesterday that director Milos Forman will be the president of the main jury at the forthcoming 57th Venice Film Festival
fields.body:
It was announced yesterday that director Milos Forman will be the president of the main jury at the forthcoming 57th Venice Film Festival.

The Czech-born director, who is now an American citizen, has had a long and celebrated career, winning two best director Oscars for One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest (1975) and Amadeus (1984). Most recently, he directed Jim Carrey in Man on the Moon.

Forman will front a jury which includes actress Jennifer Jason Leigh, Iranian director Samira Makhmalbaf, Italian director Giuseppe Bertolucci, French director Claude Chabrol, Moroccan novelist Tahar Ben-Jelloun; and German film critic Andreas Kilb.

The festival runs from August 30 to September 9 and will also see Sharon Stone present Clint Eastwood (pictured) with the Golden Lion for his contribution to cinema. The actress will also host a gala evening called Cinema Against Aids.

The organisers of Europe's oldest film event have also revealed that Armenian-born Canadian director Atom Egoyan will head the jury of for the Luigi De Laurentiis prize for first works.

 The full line-up of films in the competition will be announced on Friday.

fields.headline: Blair loses section 28 vote
fields.standfirst: More about section 28
fields.trailText: The government was last night in full retreat over its plans to repeal section 28 - the law banning the "promotion" of homosexuality - after peers threw out the legislation in the House of Lords.
fields.body:
The government was last night in full retreat over its plans to repeal section 28 - the law banning the "promotion" of homosexuality - after peers threw out the legislation in the House of Lords.

An alliance of Tory and crossbench peers blocked repeal of the controversial legislation, which was introduced by Margaret Thatcher's government, by 270 votes to 228, a majority of 42.

Although government officials refused to admit that Tony Blair will be forced to drop the disputed clause this side of the general election, the prime minister risks losing the important local government bill - which contains the clause - as well as other legislation if he tries to face down the recalcitrant peers on this highly emotional issue.

Ministers now look set to disappoint gay rights campaigners by agreeing to postpone legislation until after the next general election.

The fate of the clause, which forbids local authorities from "promoting" homosexuality in schools, was decided after a highly charged debate in a packed Lords chamber on the bill, which also includes measures to reform local government by creating directly elected mayors and cabinets.

The decision to abandon the measure will infuriate supporters of gay rights, who fear that the prime minister has caved in to pressure from rightwing newspapers which have campaigned vigorously to defeat the bill.

Last night's vote came after a memo was leaked last week in which Mr Blair revealed his concern that Labour's stance on homosexual rights and "gay issues" had made it look "weak" on the family.

Last month, the Scottish parliament voted to repeal section 28 despite the efforts of the Stagecoach boss Brian Souter, who funded a referendum designed to show opposition to the repeal of the measure.

During the Lords debate, Baroness Young, the former Tory leader of the Lords and "family values" campaigner who has led the rebellion, appealed to the peers to "speak for the majority of the British people" in voting to protect youngsters from the "appalling material" on gay and lesbian lifestyles that would inevitably find its way into the classroom if the government had its way.

But the local government minister Lord Whitty said many people had been misled into thinking that section 28 applied to schools, adding: "Local authorities provide a number of services to gay and lesbian people, health and medical advice, social and counselling services.

"It must be right that local authorities should be able to continue to do that, without running into the danger of being accused of promoting homosexuality under section 28."

Despite the controversy that has raged on all sides since section 28 was introduced by Margaret Thatcher's government as part of the 1988 Local Government Act, no council has been prosecuted for breaching it, although it has been invoked more than 30 times to prevent local authority activities.

After last night's vote, the immediate future of the bill was unclear. While the government has repeatedly stressed its commitment to repeal the clause, any attempt to tack the measure onto another bill in the Queen's Speech in November is likely to be met with the same response in the Lords, forcing long delays in the legislative process and making it highly improbable that any change could be implemented within this parliament.

Ministers are instead expected to make a manifesto commitment to repeal section 28 so that if the measure is defeated in the Lords again, despite the government's mandate, ministers can invoke the Parliament Act to force through the change.

The bill has had a difficult passage through parliament. The Lords threw out an attempt by ministers to repeal section 28 in February by a majority of 54 but that decision was later overturned by the government's huge majority in the Commons.

Since then Mr Blair has created 30 new Labour and Liberal Democrat life peers, but still only a third of peers are government supporters.

webTitle: Vinnie Jones to star with 'hero' Travolta

fields.headline: Vinnie Jones to star with 'hero' Travolta
fields.trailText: Vinnie Jones has landed a £2m starring role opposite his hero John Travolta
fields.body:
Vinnie Jones has landed a £2m starring role opposite his hero John Travolta.

According to the Sun newspaper today, Travolta personally chose Vinnie after seeing him debut in Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels. Vinnie is set to play a tough fraudster in the new £60m blockbuster Swordfish, which will also star Ben Affleck. The former Wimbledon football star will get second billing after Travolta in the feature, which is due to start filming in September.

Jones moved to Hollywood recently when he was advised that if he was serious about an acting career, that was the place he had to be. He believes it was the right move: "I feel the gamble's paid off. I've now got four films under my belt and I'm loving it. I am so busy it's incredible."

He was back in Britain yesterday for the premiere of his latest film, Gone in 60 Seconds, which stars Nicholas Cage. He told the Sun: "This really is a dream come true. Travolta is a hero of mine and it's hard to believe he personally wanted me for the part."
