webTitle: Tourist's kidnap signals worsening of Kashmir strife

fields.headline: Tourist's kidnap signals worsening of Kashmir strife
fields.standfirst: The prospects of peace in Kashmir are bleak after this month's abduction of a German traveller in the disputed Indian territory, reports Luke Harding in New Delhi
fields.trailText: The prospects of peace in Kashmir are bleak after this month's abduction of a German traveller in the disputed Indian territory, reports Luke Harding in New Delhi.
fields.body:
Where is Harfurth Rolf? On July 11, the German backpacker checked out of his hotel in the Zanskar valley in Kashmir and set off on the road towards Kargil. Ahead of him the spectacular twin peaks of Nun and Kun towered over the monastery, or "gompa", at Rangdum.

Like many other tourists in the remote region, Rolf decided to hitch a lift. Somewhere outside the town of Padum, he flagged down a truck and climbed on board. What happened next is the stuff of nightmare.

Soon afterwards the truck was hijacked by five militants, three of them armed. The separatist insurgency which has raged in Kashmir since 1990 had - until that moment - not affected the predominantly Buddhist region of Ladakh. The militants were not supposed to be there.

As the truck approached Rangdum gompa, its horn blaring, four monks came out to see what was going on. The driver, the monks thought, might have lost his way or be in trouble.

They were wrong. Minutes later, the Muslim gang opened fire from the truck. Three monks, Tashi Motup, Zoolpa Stanzin and Lama Kunchok, lay dead on the road, ripped apart by more than 30 rounds from an automatic rifle fired at point-blank range. One monk, Stanzin Tsering, survived by diving into a mountain stream, where he concealed himself until help arrived. The killings - of Buddhists by Muslims - marked a new and sinister chapter in the ethnic strife which has beset Kashmir.

Leaving behind a scene of carnage, the gang then forced truck driver Nazir Ahmed to continue along the glacial highway. At a sheep farm near Panikhar they got out. They took Rolf, 48, with them. He was last seen being led off into the mountains. "They told him, 'You come along,'" Ashok Kumar, inspector general of Kashmir police, said. "The other passengers on the truck protested. The militants replied, 'No, we will take him away.' It is difficult to say whether he is still alive."

Rolf's gunpoint abduction has a chilling precedent. Five years ago six trekkers in another part of Kashmir were captured by al-Faran, a previously obscure militant group fighting against Indian rule in the province. One American hostage escaped. The other five, including Britons Paul Mangan and Keith Wells, were less fortunate. For several weeks negotiations continued. Photos of the hostages, looking dazed and tanned, were released.

Then negotiations then broke down. The decapitated body of one hostage, a Norwegian, was discovered soon afterwards. The bodies of the other four have never been found. Al-Faran boasted: "You won't even find their ashes."

Rolf's fate is similarly unclear. And several questions remain unanswered. Why, for example, did the truck driver wait almost a week before informing police that a German tourist was on board his truck at the time of the hijack? And what did the Muslim gang hope to gain by abducting him?

Indian detectives have little to go on. In the truck they discovered a small bag belonging to Rolf containing a diary, but no other clues. A team from the Germany embassy which flew last week to Srinagar has been unable to shed further light on the mystery.

Rolf's disappearance also has ominous implications for tourism in Ladakh. The narrow mountain valleys - only passable after the snows melt, between June and October - are full of young backpackers during the summer months. These days, few western tourists venture up to Dal Lake in Srinagar because of the insurgency, though Indian tourists are gradually returning. Instead, most trek up to Zanskar via Manali or - if they are lucky enough to get a seat - fly directly to Leh. Unless Rolf turns up alive soon, with a intriguing story to tell, Ladakh may suffer the same fate as Srinagar, with its eerily empty houseboats and ghostly lake.

webTitle: Tabloid sets vigilante terror on innocent man

fields.headline: Tabloid sets vigilante terror on innocent man
fields.standfirst: Unwitting victim of 'name and shame' campaign
fields.trailText: A man told yesterday of his terror at being mistaken by vigilantes for one of the alleged paedophiles named and pictured by the News of the World, as Labour and Conservative frontbenchers joined in condemning the paper.
fields.body:
A man told yesterday of his terror at being mistaken by vigilantes for one of the alleged paedophiles named and pictured by the News of the World, as Labour and Conservative frontbenchers joined in condemning the paper.

Ian Armstrong was last night still afraid for his life and of leaving his Manchester home, as teenagers continued to gather outside to torment him and his children.

On Sunday, the day the list was published, a 300-strong mob had surrounded his house, and later a window of a neighbouring house belonging to his ex-wife was smashed with a brick.

The case underscored criticism of the Sunday newspaper's decision to name and print pictures of 49 men that it alleged were paedophiles.

The home secretary, Jack Straw, and the Tory home affairs spokeswoman, Ann Widdecombe, united in condemning the tabloid. But it won support from the mother of the murdered schoolgirl Sarah Payne, eight, whose death the paper said had motivated its decision to "name and shame" child sex offenders.

It is thought that the fact that Mr Armstrong wears a neck brace led to him being mistaken for a man alleged to be a sex offender, Peter Smith, 60, from Warrington, in Lancashire, who was pictured by the paper wearing a neck brace.

Mr Armstrong, 49, said that people had abused his children, screaming "paedophile's kid, rapist's kid" at them. "It's just a nightmare, I wish I could wake up from it. There are 14 kids outside the house now. They're saying 'we're going to get our dads on you'.

"Three or four times today, they've backed a six-year-old child halfway down the path to my door shouting 'do you want this one'. Yesterday the mob were shouting 'paedophile, rapist, beast, pervert'.

"I'm scared of what will happen at nightfall."

Greater Manchester police, who have fitted a panic alarm to Mr Armstrong's home, blamed an "irresponsible reaction to emotive stories in a national newspaper".

The News of the World's actions, condemned by senior police officers, presented a dilemma for the government. A leaked memo written by Tony Blair revealed Labour to be fearful of being outflanked by the Tories on the populist issue of law and order.

In the Commons, Mr Straw rebuked the paper: "In our judgment the press in these matters ought to act on the advice of the police, above all, who have the concern of the public safety there before them."

Ms Widdecombe said: "This incident shows that the News of the World, whatever their intentions may have been, are inciting a lynch mob mentality. They should now think about campaigning in a different way on an issue we are all worried about."

The editor, Rebekah Wade, stood by her pledge to name 110,000 child sex offenders. She said that the paper did not advocate vigilante action, but asserted that placing convicted men on the sex offenders register did not give children sufficient protection.

In a statement she said: "The News of the World will continue the campaign to name and shame convicted paedophiles living in the community.

"Since publication of Sunday's paper our phone lines have been inundated with overwhelming support from our millions of readers, confirming our belief that every parent has an absolute right to know if they have a convicted child sex offender living in their neighbourhood."

Since Sunday the paper has been condemned by the Association of Chief Police Officers, penal policy groups, and child welfare organisations.

The parents of Sarah Payne, whose naked body was discovered last week, backed its campaign. Sara Payne said: "I don't condone in any way any vigilante attacks, but parents have the right to protect their children and children have the right to protect themselves. There's no way a child should come forward and say someone has hurt them only to find that 10 years down the line that person is back on their street again.

"Paedophiles can't help themselves. We need to help them stop, by looking after our children."

Yesterday a spokesman for the National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children said that, when contacted by the News of the World on Thursday, it had declined to give its support to the campaign: "We felt at the time that it would be a populist campaign, and not something that we would want to be associated with."

"Since publication of Sunday's paper our phone lines have been inundated with overwhelming support from our millions of readers, confirming our belief that every parent has an absolute right to know if they have a convicted child sex offender living in their neighbourhood." Since Sunday the paper has been condemned by the Association of Chief Police Officers, penal policy groups, and child welfare organisations. The parents of Sarah Payne, whose naked body was discovered last week, backed its campaign. Sara Payne said: "I don't condone in any way any vigilante attacks, but parents have the right to protect their children and children have the right to protect themselves. There's no way a child should come forward and say someone has hurt them only to find that 10 years down the line that person is back on their street again. "Paedophiles can't help themselves. We need to help them stop, by looking after our children." Yesterday a spokesman for the National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children said that, when contacted by the News of the World on Thursday, it had declined to give its support to the campaign: "We felt at the time that it would be a populist campaign, and not something that we would want to be associated with."

webTitle: Straw angry over sex video sales

fields.headline: Straw angry over sex video sales
fields.trailText: Jack Straw last night vented his anger at a high court ruling legalising the sale of sexually explicit videos in Britain by proposing to abolish the independent watchdog that passed them for sale in adult-only licensed sex shops.
fields.body:
Jack Straw last night vented his anger at a high court ruling legalising the sale of sexually explicit videos in Britain by proposing to abolish the independent watchdog that passed them for sale in adult-only licensed sex shops.

The home secretary proposes to replace the independent video appeals committee - which includes writers such as Fay Weldon, Nina Bawden, and Claire Rayner, as well as legal and child welfare experts - with a body appointed by the government.

Mr Straw last night claimed there was evidence that paedophiles "sometimes used this sort of material to 'groom' children for sexual abuse", which, he said, justified the ban on the sale of videos showing consensual adult sex.

In a Home Office consultation paper published last night, Mr Straw also proposed to overturn the high court decision by introducing two new offences of showing a classified R18 video to a child and "failing to prevent a child from watching an R18 video", which would carry a prison sentence of up to six months or a fine of £20,000.

It also proposes to increase fines to a minimum of £20,000 for selling such videos by mail order, and to increase the maximum penalty, for selling such videos, to two years in prison.

The Home Office also said last night that a communications white paper to be published later this year will propose internet obscenity laws.

The consultation paper on videos acknowledges that there is "little conclusive evidence of the harmful effects" of such films that show consensual explicit adult sex, and that the high court judges had ruled that the risk of the videos being seen by children and causing them harm was, on present evidence, insignificant.

The Home Office paper says that the videos at issue are less explicit than those available in much of Europe and can only be bought in 90 licensed sex shops or by mail order.

The high court battle followed a decision by the video appeals committee to overrule a ban last year by Andreas Whittam Smith's British Board of Film Classification on seven sexually explicit videos. The judge ruled that the committee was right and within its powers to insist the ban should be lifted.

But the Home Office document says "there seems to be a general public perception that the committee is unrepresentative and unaccountable" and reports that its system of appointments is not "as open as contemporary standards require". The document also says that its membership does not "reflect the diversity required".

The Home Office says it wants to see in the video appeals committee "a proper balance in the membership to include senior lawyers who may be specialists in child welfare".

The chairman of the watchdog, John Wood, is a former deputy director of public prosecutions, and the members include the chairman of the national children's bureau.

Claire Rayner, the writer and agony aunt, sits on the committee. She said: "I expected this to happen. We are outspoken. We do not toe any party line. We are reasonably liberal and several of us are involved in the welfare of children. It certainly seems a vindictive action by Jack Straw."

Mr Straw said last night: "I was disappointed with the high court decision in May which dismissed the British Board of Film Classification's application for judicial review. The government has a clear and determined commitment to protect children from unsuitable sexually explicit material."

Mr Whittam Smith welcomed Mr Straw's proposals saying he shared the home secretary's concern: "I am very pleased that the home secretary is considering a range of options for strengthening the protection of children from exposure to sexually explicit videos."

fields.headline: Pervert special - buy the set
fields.standfirst: The News of the World's real motive behind the publication of its paedophile list
fields.trailText: The News of the World's real motive behind the publication of its paedophile list
fields.body:
There's a pervert on my doorstep. His name is Robert Tickner and he lives somewhere in North London. I don't know the exact location, but it shouldn't be that hard to find out. It's only two days since the News of the World published his name and photograph in its list of child-sex monsters. Maybe he hasn't had time to find somewhere to go. Some people must surely be hoping that he hasn't read the paper, watched the news or met anyone in Londis who put two and two together.

Otherwise, this unique opportunity to bag the beast closest to them will have been lost and transferred to the residents of wherever Tickner lands next. If that happens to be Manchester, there's every chance that the nation's most on-the-ball mob - who got to the man they took to be their beast in a record six hours on the Sunday of publication - will put an end to his wandering for good. The fact that they mistook the physically challenged but perfectly innocent Mr Armstrong for the pervert in a neck brace they were after will surely not detract from their ambition to be the first mob in Britain to claim their Sarah Payne memorial scalp.

I seldom get angry with tabloids. Of course, I know they lie but somehow that is now so well established that it stops me from being shocked at any specific example. This Sunday was an exception. My objections to Rebekah Wade's efforts to make her mark as the News of the World's new editor all proceeded from the thought of her sitting there one night at her computer, trying to work out how to reinvigorate her brand. I pictured her thinking her "naming and shaming" campaign through, weighing up the pros (massive publicity, increased sales and, most importantly, the tangible proof that she means business) against the cons (bad press, some political flak and a couple of whingeing liberal editorials). On that basis, it's no wonder she went for it. If you exclude the human consequences of publishing the paedophile register, it looks like a fantastic idea. With negligible journalistic effort and little financial outlay, the News of the World gets on the TV news as the "paper at the heart of the controversy" and Wade moves a step closer to her ambition to be the first woman to edit a daily tabloid.

The only potential problem with this plan was the danger that some dense souls might misuse the beast list for purposes other than "knowledge" and that these same individuals might well prefer to pour petrol through the letterboxes of their chosen pervert than just stick their faces up on the fridge. But given that Wade is, by all accounts, a very intelligent woman, it is fair to assume that she had no inkling that the information she was providing would fall into the hands of her readers. The fact that some people ignored the News of the World's warnings against vigilantism - "We do not want our readers to take any action" - and plumped instead for its injunctions to take steps to protect "our children" - "We say again. It is time for action" - has many reverberations in which Wade and her colleagues are in no way implicated.

"The rule of law is crucial and outbursts of uncontrolled anger will solve nothing." According to the News of the World's editorial, the only proper response to discovering a beast in your midst is to forget you found him. Under "What to do if there is a pervert on your doorstep," readers are warned against leaving their children unattended in dark alleys - which is odd. You're going to look after your children whether or not the pervert is a clear and present danger. Which rather puts the dampeners on the idea that the list has any legal uses. It doesn't. The only things you can do with the name and address of someone you believe to be evil incarnate are a) call him up and tell him what you think of his lifestyle, b) send him something vile in the post or c) pay him a visit on the way back from the pub one evening.

The News of the World knows this. The key editorial pages are peppered with the language of pursuit. It is "scouting out the beasts", it says, encouraging us to "catch 'em on the web". It's hard not to think of Pokémon's "gotta catch them all" when you hear that the NoW will dribble out names "week by week". In order to get the set, you have to keep on buying.

Exactly how the pub- lication of the photographs of free men will impact on the rulings on those who have yet to be sentenced is a mystery. Nor is it clear how a campaign can be effective if nothing is demanded of its supporters. If we agree with Sarah Payne's mother that the way to deal with paedophiles is simply to "put them in prison and let them die there", what can we do about it? There isn't any cut-out postcard to send to your MP, nor any single suggestion as to how the average person can help ensure that "life means life". In this sense, the NoW campaign is not a campaign at all but a call for consumer action which bypasses politics in favour of a brokered relationship between public and errant quarry.

The paedophiles have been run down by the media acting on the people's behalf. In this scenario, the papers are the law enforcers and their mandate from the public (88% in a Mori poll agreed with naming and shaming) allows them to effect change directly, instead of pressuring government. That's why there's no need to write to your MP. Your support has been sought, via Mori, for the NoW's strategy and it is intending to use that as a government would use its electoral mandate. It's particularly easy to do this around law and order since New Labour made it a consumer issue. No longer concerned with the impact of crime on society, the focus has shifted to the impact of the criminal on the victim. The effect of allowing victims of crime to present their testimonies in court has been to reduce the issue to a stand off between two individuals - abuser and abused.

As long as this trend continues, tabloid editors will be able to exploit it and no one will be accountable for what happens. The "pervert on your doorstep" is yours to do with as you see fit, and if you're going to send him razor blades that's OK, as long as you address them correctly.

fields.headline: Smooth-talking Allen awaits his cue
fields.trailText: Granada chief's testing time
fields.body:
Granada chief's testing time

The telephone lines to Ludgate House, the imposing headquarters of United News & Media on London's South Bank, were no doubt red hot yesterday. The music stopped on Friday, and United's chief executive, Lord Hollick, found himself without a seat in the consolidation of ITV. He subsequently conceded defeat and has set about satisfying shareholders, aiming to get as much as possible for the company's three ITV franchises.

Much has been written about the challenges of getting the three "ambitious" chief executives of the ITV companies to agree on anything, but the next few days will put that to the test.

Granada Media clearly did an impressive job convincing the competition commission of its arguments, which derailed United's merger with Carlton and put itself in a position of primacy.

But Lord Hollick and/or Carlton's Michael Green will be trickier for Granada's undeniably smooth-talking chief executive, Charles Allen.

His friends say he had not been surprised by the collapse of the deal, but even he was caught unawares by Lord Hollick's subsequent capitulation. There can be little doubt now, however, that he would rather broker a friendly agreement than launch a costly takeover battle which would leave Granada with a clutch of unwanted assets - including the Daily Star.

The strategic value of acquiring Meridian and Anglia, the ITV franchises Mr Allen has his sights trained on, must surely override short term concerns about price. Potential synergies also suggest Granada can justify paying more than a non-ITV company. Carlton, meanwhile, appears to be strangely sanguine for a company whose merger has just collapsed - and insiders suggest it will be content to pick up the HTV franchise the regulations say Granada would be unable to swallow.

Mr Allen will surely have taken encouragement from the words of Carlton's new chief executive, Gerry Murphy, who was at pains to stress that he was backing an agreed carve up with Granada to keep ITV in the family.

Air fix kit

MyAircraft.com sounds innocent enough. Airfix kits online, perhaps, aimed at nine to 11-year-old boys with a free can of red enamel to spill on the carpet for orders received in 14 days.

Mario Monti at the EU competition commission suspects something altogether more sinister. The site is, in fact, a joint venture between Honeywell International, United Technologies and i2 Technologies aimed at handling the sale of real aircraft spare parts over the web. The EU has now set a deadline of August 7 to decide whether to launch a full scale inquiry into fears that it could mutate into a cartel.

Such business to business exchanges are springing up on a daily basis, covering all conceivable areas of commerce. The underlying idea is simple: to cut procurement costs and speed the delivery of goods, promising a radical reduction in the amount of capital tied up in businesses of all shapes and sizes.

In every industry there is terrific competition to run or own the most popular e-exchange. MyAircraft.com, for example, faces competition from an as yet unnamed website being put together by Boeing Lockheed Martin, Raytheon and BAE Systems.

This is fertile ground for big business paranoiacs: the potential for abuse is almost endless in terms of the cartels and the squeezing of smaller suppliers. Against this comes the promise of spectacular productivity gains and the reduction of waste.

But the real point here is that it is just too early to tell how the whole area of business to business e-commerce will pan out. In many cases, old economy firms are jumping into online joint ventures because they fear being squeezed out. Rather than hatching dastardly plots to squeeze someone else they are fighting for their own corporate lives.

Mr Monti and his officials should be aware of this. Real regulatory vigilance is required, given the apparent risks. But stomping bureaucratically over this crucial area of the new economy risks crushing too many fragile and worthwhile creations.

Follow the Gent

Rather than apologise to Vodafone shareholders at Thursday's annual meeting for the bad blood created by his £10m deal maker's bonus, chief executive Chris Gent might just say thanks.

If he had used the £5m portion delivered in cash to buy Vodafone shares when the money was awarded its value would have shrunk by almost 25% by now. But he is now purchasing at a time when London's analytical community is pushing out note after note telling institutional clients to buy. Vodafone is a world class business. With the furores over tax and pay now drifting into the background, ordinary investors might do well to follow Mr Gent's example.

webTitle: United shares hit record as rivals prepare bids

fields.headline: United shares hit record as rivals prepare bids
fields.trailText: Shares in United News & Media reached an all-time high yesterday as rival ITV companies Granada Media and Carlton Communications prepared for an anticipated carve-up of the business.
fields.body:
Shares in United News & Media reached an all-time high yesterday as rival ITV companies Granada Media and Carlton Communications prepared for an anticipated carve-up of the business.

United raised the for-sale sign over its television interests including the ITV franchises Meridian, Anglia and HTV last week after the company's planned £10bn merger with Carlton collapsed. Insiders have said that offers for the entire business will also be entertained and would be preferred by United's chief executive, Lord Hollick.

Shares in United ran 32p higher to 990p. Carlton gave further ground, slipping 2p to 802p, and Granada Media was 2p better at 579p.

RTL, the pan-European television group which has been named as a potential bidder for United assets, also stuck its head above the parapet. Chief executive Didier Bellens said: "We are looking at all combinations you can imagine and all that can be done, including trying to be a bit creative. In a short period of time our UK position will be stronger than it is today, for sure."

Granada's chief executive, Charles Allen, is understood to be working toward a preferred option of acquiring Meridian and Anglia rather than a full bid. Carlton's new chief executive, Gerry Murphy, indicated at the weekend that he too was in favour of an orderly parcelling of United's assets between the two.

Carlton insiders suggest that company would be content to walk away with United's HTV licence, which suggests an accord with Granada could be struck.

The sticking point will be price, with Lord Hollick said to be seeking upwards of £2.2bn for the ITV licences. City analysts have valued the franchises at about £1.9bn and many remain cynical about the chances of the three sides agreeing a behind the scenes deal.

Under takeover panel rules, Granada Media has until August 4 to declare its hand. A bid for United from Granada is still seen as more likely than a hostile approach to Carlton if the negotiations fail.

Analysts are also beginning to play down the chances of the intervention of an overseas player bidding for United. "ITV is likely to remain a domestic game because the only companies that can afford to pay a full price are those that will be able to benefit from synergies," one analyst said.

fields.headline: Rights campaigners prepare Saddam dossier
fields.standfirst: Indict
fields.trailText: A London-based human rights group has prepared a secret dossier outlining cases which could put Saddam Hussein and other leaders of the Iraqi dictatorship before a war crimes tribunal.
fields.body:
A London-based human rights group has prepared a secret dossier outlining cases which could put Saddam Hussein and other leaders of the Iraqi dictatorship before a war crimes tribunal.

Indict, which is funded by the US government, has compiled witness statements from many of Saddam's victims as well as more than five million official Iraqi government documents detailing the regime's atrocities.

The group has been advised by a leading British barrister - who is staying anonymous for safety reasons - that its evidence would be enough for indictments to be made against seven Iraqi leaders, including Saddam, under the Geneva convention and international conventions on torture. The dossier has been delivered to the US government, which is urging all other nations - especially its allies in Europe - to detain any of those named who enter their territory, reported BBC Radio 4's Today programme.

The evidence will also be used to try to persuade the United Nations to set up an international war crimes tribunal covering Iraq, similar to those dealing with atrocities in Rwanda and the former Yugoslavia. Labour MP Ann Clwyd, the chairwoman of Indict, told Today: "As yet, we don't know whether the political will exists in various countries in Europe, and indeed in the UK itself. "We have evidence where actions could be taken in the UK.

"This is a test of resolve of countries to do what they say they want to do and that is to bring Iraqi war criminals to justice."

Indict has investigated an A-list of 12 of the most notorious Iraqi leaders, including Saddam, his two sons, and Deputy Prime Minister Tariq Aziz, as well as a B-list of 31 less prominent people. Evidence covers atrocities during wars against Iran and Kuwait, internal repression of political opponents, torture of prisoners and attacks on minorities including the Kurds.

The announcement of the existence of the dossier today amounts to a challenge to the Russian government to act, as Mr Aziz is presently on a visit to Moscow.

webTitle: Bush picks family friend Cheney as running mate

fields.headline: Bush picks family friend Cheney as running mate
fields.trailText: Barring a last minute surprise, the Republican presidential hopeful George W Bush will today name the former US defence secretary Dick Cheney as his vice-presidential running mate in the November contest for the White House.
fields.body:
Barring a last minute surprise, the Republican presidential hopeful George W Bush will today name the former US defence secretary Dick Cheney as his vice-presidential running mate in the November contest for the White House.

Mr Bush was expected to telephone Mr Cheney to offer him a place on the ticket last night, several sources said. Assuming that Mr Cheney accepts, he will be presented to the media as Mr Bush's choice at a press conference in Austin, Texas, today.

Mr Cheney, 59, emerged as the frontrunner over the weekend, when it was reported that he had changed his voter registration from Texas - where he has worked since 1995 as chairman and chief executive of the Dallas-based Halliburton Corporation, the world's largest oil industry equipment supply company - to Wyoming, his home state which he represented in Congress from 1978 to 1989.

US law does not permit the president and vice-president to be registered voters in the same state. Mr Bush is governor of Texas.

Mr Cheney also had a full medical examination last week, a necessary precaution in view of the fact that he has had three heart attacks, including one while he was in his 30s, and had quadruple heart bypass surgery some years ago.

Not the least of the ironies of Mr Cheney's selection is that he was in charge of the search for Mr Bush's running mate. For many weeks he has been interviewing other candidates - only to emerge as Mr Bush's preferred choice.

Mr Cheney was chief of staff to President Gerald Ford and is widely seen as a Washington insider, as well as a Bush family intimate.

He had an extremely conservative voting record in Congress, which will endear him to party rightwingers, but has a reputation as an effective, non-ideological politician.

Other candidates for the job had included the Republican challenger who Mr Bush defeated, John McCain, and the former Missouri senator, John Danforth.

webTitle: Suspect in Sarah Payne inquiry held

fields.headline: Suspect in Sarah Payne inquiry held
fields.standfirst: More about the Sarah Payne case
fields.trailText: A suspect in the Sarah Payne murder inquiry was in custody last night after a high-speed police chase near his father's home, police revealed.
fields.body:
A suspect in the Sarah Payne murder inquiry was in custody last night after a high-speed police chase near his father's home, police revealed.

The 41-year-old handyman is accused of stealing a car and ramming several other vehicles during a chase through the Langley Green area of Crawley, West Sussex.

The man, who cannot be named for legal reasons, had been bailed to his father's home in the area after being questioned for more than 60 hours, beginning the day after eight-year-old Sarah went missing on July 1.

Both he and his father left the address last week after it was surrounded by vigilantes who threw a stone through one of the rear windows.

Sussex police declined to say where they had gone but last night they confirmed that the younger man had been arrested after the alleged theft of a Vauxhall Nova hatchback and a high speed chase in the early hours of Sunday.

The man has been arrested and charged with theft, assault and aggravated vehicle taking.

He appeared at Crawley magistrates court yesterday and was remanded in custody for seven days.

Forensic tests have quashed hopes that blue scraps of cloth found at a ruined Norman castle might be from the dress Sarah was wearing when she disappeared.

But tests are continuing on a shoe, the only piece of Sarah's clothing to be found so far. Detectives hope it could provide a vital DNA clue to the identity of the killer.

Police are also concentrating on finding a white van seen when Sarah disappeared near her grandparents' home in Kingston Gorse, near Littlehampton.

They have taken the decision to scale down media appeals in order to concentrate on existing leads, but are considering an appeal on BBC TV's Crimewatch, due to broadcast later this week.

A spokesman for Sussex police said a that second postmortem examination on Sarah's body was due to be performed this week to find out the exact cause of death.

No obvious signs of violent injury were found on the body but it is thought she may have been strangled or suffocated.

fields.headline: EU support hits new low
fields.standfirst:
British backing for EU at lowest for 20 years
Special report: Economic and Monetary Union
fields.trailText: Public support for Britain's membership of the European Union has plunged to its lowest level in 20 years, with just a quarter of the population convinced that it is a good thing, a new poll from the European commission showed yesterday.
fields.body:
Public support for Britain's membership of the European Union has plunged to its lowest level in 20 years, with just a quarter of the population convinced that it is a good thing, a new poll from the European commission showed yesterday.

In a survey likely to delight Eurosceptics and depress the government, the figures also reveal that the public's enthusiasm for joining the single currency has fallen away dramatically and is languishing at a three-year low.

Britain is outed as the most Eurosceptic country in the 15-nation EU, with the most negative view on six of the most important questions asked of the 16,000 Europeans who were polled in April and May.

Only 25% of Britons said they thought that UK membership of the EU was a positive thing, compared with the heady days of 1991 when the same survey found that 58% of the public felt positive about Brussels.

According to the commission's spokesman, Christophe Forax, the poll marks a new ebb in the UK's attitude towards Europe and tops a pre vious all-time low in support of EU membership of just 29% in 1993.

"These are the worst ever results published in the last 20 years. It would need a long time to explain why the UK has got such a bad result," he said. "All these results could be better and show that the European commission must work harder, harder for itself and for European construction."

British support for joining the single currency is even lower at 22%, the poll found, compared with a high of 36% in autumn 1998 and three points lower than the last survey in October 1998.

Support for the EU in the UK is down across the board on most issues compared with autumn of last year when the EC last asked the same questions, and only 24% of those surveyed were willing to say that they trusted the commission.

For the first time the commission tried to gauge the level of public support for the contentious idea of a European constitution, an idea criticised by the Tory party as a fatal step on the road to a federal European "superstate".

The British public seem less cautious, however, and 47% of those polled gave their backing to some kind of all-embracing European constitution.

Keith Vaz, minister for Europe, who was in Brussels yesterday to discuss EU reform, sought to play down the survey's findings.

"This is just one poll and I can tell you I have met thousands of people who are very supportive of Britain's membership of the EU. We will have a referendum [on the euro] if the conditions are right after the next election," he said.

Separately, however, commission officials admitted the survey was a particularly bad result and laid the blame for it at the door of the British press.

"It is in large measure a result of a seemingly deliberate attempt by large parts of the British media to distort the facts. We cannot invent a fair press in member states," one senior official said - adding that an article in yesterday's Sun which accused the EC of funding the Danish euro yes campaign was a case in point.

Other commission officials also admitted that Britain's scepticism about all things from Brussels set it apart from other European countries but said that this was because the British public were much less well informed than their European counterparts.

"The level of knowledge in Britain is the lowest in the EU and people are, relatively speaking, very ignorant. There is a conspiracy of disinformation in swaths of the British media. Look at the number of don't knows," one official said.

Simon Buckby, campaign director at Britain in Europe, the country's biggest pro-European lobby, put a brave face on the poll and played down its significance.

"This poll has been overtaken by events," he argued, "and the damage done to manufacturing and inward investment by the high pound in recent months has shown that Britain is suffering outside the single currency."

webTitle: Straw misled MPs over jury trial curbs

fields.headline: Straw misled MPs over jury trial curbs
fields.standfirst: Special report: trial by jury
fields.trailText: The home secretary, Jack Straw, seriously misled the House of Commons and Tony Blair over the extent of support among senior judges for his revised plans to restrict a defendant's right of trial by jury, a Labour MP revealed last night.
fields.body:
The home secretary, Jack Straw, seriously misled the House of Commons and Tony Blair over the extent of support among senior judges for his revised plans to restrict a defendant's right of trial by jury, a Labour MP revealed last night.

When the controversial criminal justice (mode of trial) bill returns to the Commons tonight the home secretary will be challenged to explain his behaviour - and to apologise to MPs, some of whom believe he deliberately withheld the disputed information.

Mr Straw told the Commons second reading debate on March 7 that his plan "enjoys the active endorsement of the lord chief justice, Lord Bingham, and the vast majority of the high court bench of nearly 100 senior judges".

Yet exactly a fortnight earlier Lord Bingham had expressed his "concern" and "unease" to the home secretary in a private letter about the "dangers" of the legislation which was amended after being thrown out by the Lords.

In a last-minute attempt to prevent the bill going through its final stages in the Commons tonight, the leftwing Labour MP and QC Robert Marshall-Andrews last night showed the exchange of letters between Mr Straw and the then lord chief justice to the Guardian - with Lord Bingham's consent to publish them.

"I think there are dangers in excluding consideration of anything which is relevant in the given case," Lord Bigham warned Mr Straw, admitting that the amended bill "causes me concern".

The charge of misleading the Commons is always a dangerous one for ministers. It is doubly so for Mr Straw, partly because of the issue at stake, partly because his critics suspect the mistake was not an accident.

In a letter to Mr Marshall-Andrews yesterday, the home secretary appeared to bluff it out, claiming that Lord Bingham still backs the change while admitting in the next sentence that the law lord will only back it if it includes a safeguard that Mr Straw has specifically rejected.

Mr Marshall-Andrews, arguing that Lord Bingham's alleged support was "obviously a critical factor" in winning a 96-vote Commons majority in March, then told Mr Straw: "This bill is not an insignificant thing. It goes to the very heart of civil liberty and has widespread informed opposition."

Mr Straw introduced the change, recommended by the 1993 Runciman royal commission on criminal justice, to save up to £120m and speed up justice by letting magistrates - not defendants - decide whether to allow a trial by jury in certain mid-range categories of theft or dishonesty.

It was bitterly contested by civil liberty groups and lawyers, whom Mr Straw accused of acting like trade unionists in defence of their fees.

When a cross-party coalition of peers, concerned about civil liberty implications, defeated it in January one of their crucial objections was to the so-called "reputation clause".

That would have allowed magistrates to take into account the defendant's reputation when deciding whether to allow the expense of a full trial by jury. But critics, including Mr Marshall-Andrews and more than 30 other Labour MPs, argued that this would create "class justice" with ethnic minority groups, the young and poor left more vulnerable to summary trial by case-hardened magistrates.

After consulting the attorney general, Lord Gareth Williams, Mr Straw decided not only to drop the "reputation clause" but also to forbid magistrates to take any account whatever of the "personal circumstances" of an accused person when making their decision.

Ministers feared that, if they allowed more discretion over reputations, defendants with a string of convictions would use that fact to claim that they would never get a fair trial from magistrates - and to insist on a jury. Far from saving money it would add to costs.

Lord Bingham had already raised the main worry in his private letter to Mr Straw, replying within 24 hours to the home secretary's explanation as to his decision to abandon the "reputation clause".

Lord Bingham, who has since been promoted to be senior law lord, cited the case of "a school caretaker of impeccable character" who stood to lose his tied flat and job if convicted.

Both he and "a defendant with numerous convictions for theft" who claimed to have been fitted up by the police would want their records discussed - "for opposite reasons ... I am uneasy at requiring decision-makers to ignore matters of which reasonable decision-makers might wish to take account," he wrote.

Mr Straw later set out his reasons to be "reassuring to you" but Lord Bingham, who has been succeeded as lord chief justice by Lord Woolf, is known to be unconvinced.

Mr Marshall-Andrews said last night: "I am very concerned by what appears to be a misleading statement by both the home secretary and prime minister."

The rights of defendants would be "a lottery" under the bill with busy magistrates sending cases for trial - and others dealing with them themselves.

fields.headline: Organic farmers fear growing pains
fields.standfirst:
Demand for traditional food values comes into conflict with 21st century mass marketing
Special report: what's wrong with our food?
fields.trailText: Demand for traditional food values comes into conflict with 21st century mass marketing
fields.body:
It is a sunny summer morning on Northwood farm in Devon. Tim Deane, his son and some local villagers are picking potatoes, carrots and beans from carefully cultivated soil. Later in the day they will load the vegetables into boxes, stack them on the back of a truck and drive them into town to sell at the market.

You could be forgiven for thinking this idyll exists only in someone's memory, but it is in fact farming life 21st century style. Mr Deane and his wife Jan, who own Northwood's 30 acres, began farming organically in 1984. The couple and their family found the going tough in the early years so they set up the country's first "box scheme" - delivering a selection of produce to local customers each week - to generate extra income.

Struggling to keep up
Today they supply wholesalers and supermarkets as well as trying to keep up with local demand.

Organic food appears to be the modern shopper's creed. In high streets and on doorsteps it has its evangelists and an ever-expanding army of devotees.

Consumers across the globe are proving willing converts, happy to pay up to a 100% premium for anything from chocolate to chickens bearing the assurance that what they are eating has not been touched by pesticides.

Fears that GM foods might be unsafe and the the rise of the fatal new variant CJD have helped fuel demand for organic foods. The result - a 40% annual increase in sales of such produce, with total sales in Britain predicted to reach as much as £5bn by 2005.

Shops and supermarkets say they are struggling to keep up with demand. However, for a vivid symbol of the appeal of organics, look no further than some of the drastic measures British supermarkets have taken recently to secure their slice of the cake. Sainsbury, having scoured the planet for ways to meet customer demand for organic tropical fruit, settled on commissioning the entire agricultural production of fruit on the Caribbean island of Grenada.

The retail chain Iceland, as part of a mission to transform itself from a downmarket frozen foods outlet, has invested £9m in securing 40% of the world's organic fruit and vegetable production.

A number of supermarkets, including Marks & Spencer and Waitrose, have begun offering grants to farmers if they convert to organic in an effort to reduce retailers' dependency on imports and thus reduce prices.

Simon Brenman of the Soil Association, which oversees organic standards in Britain, says: "I don't think the true impact has yet been felt. Companies are now under immense pressure to respond to consumer demand."

In just a few years the organic industry has gone from a pioneering cottage industry comprising a few farmers, co-operatives and specialist food shops scattered across the country to a multimillion-pound industry incorporating conglomerates such as Mars and Nestlé.

Whole Earth Foods, which began life as a specialist producer of organic foods in 1967, is one beneficiary of the recent explosion of interest. Its managing director, William Kendal, confirms that in the past 18 months the company has grown at a faster rate than at any other time in its history. Some ranges he says, are growing "at enormous pace some by as much as 100% year on year". Mr Kendal adds: "We were relatively small and now, like most companies, we are expanding our range as demand escalates."

Consumers seem unable to get enough organic produce. Joan Ruddock, the Labour MP who is championing the Organic Food and Farming Targets bill which is scheduled for a second reading in the autumn, says: "People have become more discriminating. The public now feels that the only safe food is organic. This is good for the agriculture industry and public health."

She argues that in order for the consumer and farmers to get a better deal from the "organic phenomenon" the government needs to increase grants to British farmers to convert - and encourage retailers to reduce prices.

The supermarkets, which now account for the majority of organic food sales in Britain at 70%, have been accused of wielding too much power and exploiting demand by elevating prices.

The supermarkets are quick to deny any accusations of price-fixing. They blame the higher cost of organic production and imports - three quarters of organic food sold in Britain is imported. Marks & Spencer, Sainsbury and Iceland all claim they do not charge a premium for organic foods and that they are not raking in excess profits at the consumer's expense.

Marks & Spencer says its margins on organic foods are identical to those on conventional produce. A Sainsbury's spokeswoman said: "Our customers are aware that it costs extra to produce organic goods and are prepared to pay the additional cost."

Rising pressure
About 1% of Sainsbury's £6bn annual turnover now comes from organic food, and consumer groups are worried that as the proportion increases there will be rising pressure to enhance margins, not reduce them.

The Soil Association points out that much of the price differential arises from the cost of mass distribution in a global market. Everything from the cost of packaging to distribution is pushing the price of organic foods higher and there are concerns that prices will go up further as the supply change becomes more complex.

Whatever the disputes about price differentials, one thing is certain: profits from organic foods will grow dramatically in the coming years. The big question is who will pocket the money. As Jan Deane puts it: "This is not a bubble that is going to burst. This is about people's concerns about food and the environment. It isn't going to go away."

Mr Deane and his wife Jan, who own Northwood's 30 acres, began farming organically in 1984. The couple and their family found the going tough in the early years so they set up the country's first "box scheme" - delivering a selection of produce to local customers each week - to generate extra income. Struggling to keep up Today they supply wholesalers and supermarkets as well as trying to keep up with local demand. Organic food appears to be the modern shopper's creed. In high streets and on doorsteps it has its evangelists and an ever-expanding army of devotees. Consumers across the globe are proving willing converts, happy to pay up to a 100% premium for anything from chocolate to chickens bearing the assurance that what they are eating has not been touched by pesticides. Fears that GM foods might be unsafe and the the rise of the fatal new variant CJD have helped fuel demand for organic foods. The result - a 40% annual increase in sales of such produce, with total sales in Britain predicted to reach as much as £5bn by 2005. Shops and supermarkets say they are struggling to keep up with demand. However, for a vivid symbol of the appeal of organics, look no further than some of the drastic measures British supermarkets have taken recently to secure their slice of the cake. Sainsbury, having scoured the planet for ways to meet customer demand for organic tropical fruit, settled on commissioning the entire agricultural production of fruit on the Caribbean island of Grenada. The retail chain Iceland, as part of a mission to transform itself from a downmarket frozen foods outlet, has invested £9m in securing 40% of the world's organic fruit and vegetable production. A number of supermarkets, including Marks & Spencer and Waitrose, have begun offering grants to farmers if they convert to organic in an effort to reduce retailers' dependency on imports and thus reduce prices. Simon Brenman of the Soil Association, which oversees organic standards in Britain, says: "I don't think the true impact has yet been felt. Companies are now under immense pressure to respond to consumer demand." In just a few years the organic industry has gone from a pioneering cottage industry comprising a few farmers, co-operatives and specialist food shops scattered across the country to a multimillion-pound industry incorporating conglomerates such as Mars and Nestlé. Whole Earth Foods, which began life as a specialist producer of organic foods in 1967, is one beneficiary of the recent explosion of interest. Its managing director, William Kendal, confirms that in the past 18 months the company has grown at a faster rate than at any other time in its history. Some ranges he says, are growing "at enormous pace some by as much as 100% year on year". Mr Kendal adds: "We were relatively small and now, like most companies, we are expanding our range as demand escalates." Consumers seem unable to get enough organic produce. Joan Ruddock, the Labour MP who is championing the Organic Food and Farming Targets bill which is scheduled for a second reading in the autumn, says: "People have become more discriminating. The public now feels that the only safe food is organic. This is good for the agriculture industry and public health." She argues that in order for the consumer and farmers to get a better deal from the "organic phenomenon" the government needs to increase grants to British farmers to convert - and encourage retailers to reduce prices. The supermarkets, which now account for the majority of organic food sales in Britain at 70%, have been accused of wielding too much power and exploiting demand by elevating prices. The supermarkets are quick to deny any accusations of price-fixing. They blame the higher cost of organic production and imports - three quarters of organic food sold in Britain is imported. Marks & Spencer, Sainsbury and Iceland all claim they do not charge a premium for organic foods and that they are not raking in excess profits at the consumer's expense. Marks & Spencer says its margins on organic foods are identical to those on conventional produce. A Sainsbury's spokeswoman said: "Our customers are aware that it costs extra to produce organic goods and are prepared to pay the additional cost." Rising pressure About 1% of Sainsbury's £6bn annual turnover now comes from organic food, and consumer groups are worried that as the proportion increases there will be rising pressure to enhance margins, not reduce them. The Soil Association points out that much of the price differential arises from the cost of mass distribution in a global market. Everything from the cost of packaging to distribution is pushing the price of organic foods higher and there are concerns that prices will go up further as the supply change becomes more complex. Whatever the disputes about price differentials, one thing is certain: profits from organic foods will grow dramatically in the coming years. The big question is who will pocket the money. As Jan Deane puts it: "This is not a bubble that is going to burst. This is about people's concerns about food and the environment. It isn't going to go away."

webTitle: Parliament demands power to vet arms sales

fields.headline: Parliament demands power to vet arms sales
fields.standfirst: Special report: Labour's ethical foreign policy
fields.trailText: The government broke its own and the European Union's arms sales rules by granting seven licences for the sale of Hawk aircraft spares to Zimbabwe in February, according to a joint report from four Commons select committees that will be published today.
fields.body:
The government broke its own and the European Union's arms sales rules by granting seven licences for the sale of Hawk aircraft spares to Zimbabwe in February, according to a joint report from four Commons select committees that will be published today.

The breach is regarded as so serious that the report recommends that future arms sales licence applications should be subject to prior scrutiny by the four committees.

The proposal, certain to be rejected by the Foreign Office, will embarrass the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, who is battling to retain his ethical foreign policy within Whitehall.

The granting of the licences undermined an EU resolution on arms sales to Zimbabwe - of which Britain was a co-sponsor - instituted because of the country's instability and its intervention in the Congo civil war. The committee's report says that the Hawks were used in Congo and that "there remains a clear risk that they might be so again".

It states: "Without these spares it has been widely reported that two of the Hawks would be unable to operate.

"There can be few decisions of greater potential impact on the conduct of foreign relations, and on the lives of many people overseas, than decisions as to whether to permit weapons made in this country to be put into the hands of overseas government and their forces ... There is an understandable anger when it is found that British-made weapons have been used to oppress or terrorise people, or to endanger the lives of our service men and women."

The four committees - foreign affairs, defence, international development, and trade and industry - say that but for a "well-informed" leak in the Guardian on January 20, revealing an interdepartmental row over the licences, the matter would not have come to parliament's attention until next summer, when the government reports on this year's arms sales.

On February 24 the government announced that seven outstanding licence applications for Hawk spares would be granted. Mr Cook revoked these in May, citing increased violence against white farmers in Zimbabwe.

Details given to the committees show that BAe Systems had signed contracts to supply Zimbabwe with Hawk spares for 15 years, but that this contractual obligation could be overridden by a ministerial licencing decision.

The committees conclude that the events reveal "a disturbing degree of muddle and confusion" arising from the government's conflicting objectives of being a leading arms exporter and a promoter of international human rights.

The report proposes that all arms exports licences should in future be scrutinised in detail by the committees before being granted. It insists that this will not threaten commercial confidentiality or delay the issuing of licences.

"Issues of such importance warrant democratic involvement," the report says, suggesting that the system should come into force in November, the start of the new parliamentary session.

However, the committees cannot make binding recommendations.

Francis Maude, the shadow foreign secretary, said the report would "consign Labour's ethical foreign policy to the growing scrapheap of their broken promises".

The Foreign Office minister Peter Hain - who is thought to have opposed the granting of the licences in private - responded last night by denying that the government had been in breach of its own criteria on arms exports. "When the situation worsened we acted quickly to impose a full embargo," he said.

webTitle: Even if Camp David fails, this conflict is on its last legs

fields.headline: Even if Camp David fails, this conflict is on its last legs
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Comment: Ehud Barak went a very long way towards the Palestinians, even before the beginning of the Camp David summit; longer than any of his predecessors ever dreamt to go; longer than any other Israeli leader is likely to go.
fields.body:
Ehud Barak went a very long way towards the Palestinians, even before the beginning of the Camp David summit; longer than any of his predecessors ever dreamt to go; longer than any other Israeli leader is likely to go.

On the way to Camp David, Barak's proclaimed stance was so dovish that it made him lose his parliamentary majority, his coalition government, even some of his constituency.

Nevertheless, while shedding wings and body and tail on the way, he carried on, like a flying cockpit, he carried on. Seemingly, Yasser Arafat did not go such a long and lonely way towards the Israelis. Perhaps he could not, or lacked the fierce devotion to making peace.

Though the Camp David summit now threatens to falter, this is by no means the end of the struggle for peace. We have seen time and again Israelis and Palestinians walking out of conference rooms, throwing their hands in the air, lamenting the impossibility of doing business with such terrible counterparts.

They always reconvene after some time, preparing together the next crisis: so the peace process limps its screaming, frustrating way toward a two-state solution. (The Middle East seems to belong in a Fellini movie, not in an Ingmar Bergmar film: sound and fury are always on the bill.)

And so, between one crisis and the next, the outlines of the future map of peace emerge. At this point, Israelis and Palestinians are divided by no more than a few disputed kilometres on the West Bank, and perhaps a few disputed hundreds of metres in Jerusalem.

Naturally, those last remaining plots of land are loaded with wrath and pain. Yet let us not forget that for almost a hundred years the two parties differed not over who would get how much of the land but over who should go away and give it up altogether.

This conflict is, despite the diplomatic stalemates and feuds, on its last legs now. Peace is impending. Even the extremists on both sides who hate the idea of compromising "sacred ancestral rights", even they know now that the country is on its way to becoming a two-family unit, a semi-detached house.

Who gets how much of the land? Who gets how much of Jerusalem? Barak and Arafat, or their successors, will have to sort it out eventually, even if the present Camp David summit ends with a big bang.

Those Israelis and Palestinians who oppose a peace agreement based on a painful compromise are obviously haunted by insecurity, by a fierce sense of injustice, by theological and ethical doubts about renouncing "sacred rights".

Yet peace, even domestic peace, can never be based on the notion of "all rights reserved". Among the basic rights which every individual and every nation reserve to exercise freely, there ought to be the elementary right to forfeit, at will, some of your rights in order to fulfil and secure your prime right to stay alive, to live in peace and freedom.

©Amos Oz

Amos Oz is an Israeli novelist

webTitle: Woman 'too fat' to carry drugs jailed

fields.headline: Woman 'too fat' to carry drugs jailed
fields.standfirst: Special report: drugs in Britain
fields.trailText: Customs officers welcomed a three-year jail term imposed yesterday on a mother of eight who was rejected as a drugs mule because she was too fat to conceal heroin under her clothes.
fields.body:
Customs officers welcomed a three-year jail term imposed yesterday on a mother of eight who was rejected as a drugs mule because she was too fat to conceal heroin under her clothes.

Frances Brett, a size 32, travelled back to Britain from Pakistan empty-handed after the gang decided she would be spotted by customs officers with "extra padding" strapped to her thighs.

Brett, 45, of Tile Hill, Coventry, was jailed at Birmingham crown court after being found guilty at an earlier hearing of conspiracy to smuggle drugs into Britain.

Investigators believe the gang abandoned a plan to strap heroin with a street value of £300,000 to Brett's thighs and shins and "smooth out" the drugs using long johns. A customs and excise spokesman said: "The judge is clearly sending out the right message. She had been recruited and was willing to smuggle heroin."

The spokesman said five co-conspirators had been jailed for a total of 53 years at other hearings, after a joint operation with national crime squad officers.

 Press Association

fields.headline: Prince defends farmers
fields.standfirst: Special report: the countryside in crisis
fields.trailText: The Prince of Wales yesterday warned of "a growing divide" between those who lived in the countryside and those who lived in urban areas, and suggested it was worsening the plight of farmers.
fields.body:
The Prince of Wales yesterday warned of "a growing divide" between those who lived in the countryside and those who lived in urban areas, and suggested it was worsening the plight of farmers.

The countryside was a precious national asset that should be treasured, said the prince, and "the people who live in it, many of them farming families, are an invaluable and unique part of our country's heritage and culture".

He added that "the countryside, which those who live in cities rightly like to enjoy, would be nothing without the care exercised by our farmers".

Opening the Royal Welsh agricultural show at Builth Wells in Powys, the prince said a "seemingly endless growth" in red tape and doubts over the future of small abattoirs threatened to stifle the enterprise of farmers who wished to diversify away from traditional methods. He also reiterated his opposition to GM farming.

The prince's warning came as the agriculture minister Nick Brown announced plans to cut 1,200 government jobs by computerising subsidy payments and other work undertaken as part of the EU's common agricultural policy.

The Liberal Democrats suggested the cuts were unrealistic, since small farmers were unlikely to have the computers required.

fields.headline: £200m payoff package for RUC
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, yesterday unveiled a £200m redundancy package for Royal Ulster Constabulary officers, declaring it the most generous scheme ever available to public sector workers in the UK.
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, yesterday unveiled a £200m redundancy package for Royal Ulster Constabulary officers, declaring it the most generous scheme ever available to public sector workers in the UK.

Under the scheme, which is key to reform of the police force, some of the RUC officers will be entitled to lump sum payments equal to three times their annual salary plus enchanced pension entitlements.

The aim, over five years, is to help cut the force from its total of 13,000 officers now, to 7,500, the number recommended by the European commissioner, Chris Patten. Recruitment measures will seek to boost Catholic representation above the 8% existing now.

The Police Federation of Northern Ireland, however, is unhappy with the deal. It said the plan was better than the initial proposals but fell short of what the federation wanted, and added that while some headline figures looked extremely generous, other officers would be much less happy with the money due.

Both the prime minister and Mr Mandelson have been involved in the difficult negotiations. The federation said it was unable to recommend it to its members but would leave it to them to decide.

The proposals as they stand would allow a chief superintendent, aged 50, with 30 years' enhanced pensionable service, to gain a lump sum of more than £300,000 and an annual pension of more than £27,000. A constable of the same age and service would get nearly £134,000, with an annual pension of more than £13,000.

Mr Mandelson said: "This is a unique scheme for a body of men and women who have served through some of the most difficult times imaginable. Taken overall, it is the most generous voluntary early retirement scheme ever offered in the UK public sector.

"The government has always recognised that the changes proposed to the police service in Northern Ireland, following the Patten report, will entail considerable challenges and uncertainty for the men and women of the RUC, who have served the community in the most difficult circumstances with courage and resilience over the last 30 years.

"That is why the prime minister and I have undertaken that officers who decide to take voluntary early retirement or severance will receive sympathetic and generous treatment, benefiting [their] distinguished service."

Les Rodgers, chairman of the Police Federation, said: "There can be no doubt that the package is not what we wanted but it is considerably better than that proposed by Patten and the NIO [Northern Ireland Office] in the early meetings. However, the federation sees it still, despite the prime minister's intervention, as failing to meet many of the members' expectations."

webTitle: Appeal court ready to take a hard line

fields.headline: Appeal court ready to take a hard line
fields.trailText: New powers for the court of appeal to increase too lenient sentences passed by judges on child molesters, importers of child pornography and drug traffickers will come into force next month.
fields.body:
New powers for the court of appeal to increase too lenient sentences passed by judges on child molesters, importers of child pornography and drug traffickers will come into force next month.

An order laid before parliament yesterday by the home secretary, Jack Straw, will widen the range of offences in which the attorney general may refer a sentence to the appeal court if he thinks it "unduly lenient".

At present, the powers cover all offences which can be tried only in the crown court - including murder, manslaughter and rape - plus indecent assault, threats to kill, cruelty to children and serious fraud.

The new powers, which will take effect on August 21, will add drug trafficking, illegal importation of pornographic material involving children, unlawful sexual intercourse and gross indecency with a child.

The move coincides with recommendations from the law commission today that the crown prosecution service should be given a right to appeal against judges' rulings which cause a case to collapse.

Had the right been available, it would have allowed the prosecution to challenge decisions throwing out the case against Colin Stagg, accused of the murder of Rachel Nickell, and refusing a second trial for Kevin Maxwell on fraud charges arising from the collapse of his late father's business empire.

Prosecutors would have no right to appeal in cases where a jury acquitted a defendant, even if the judge had made a mistake in summing up. Nor could they appeal against a judge's ruling aborting a trial on the grounds that there was no case to answer.

But they would have a right to appeal in cases where the judge ruled it would be an abuse of process for a trial to go ahead, as in the Maxwell case, or where the trial was aborted because the judge ruled key evidence inadmissible, as in the Colin Stagg case.

The right to appeal could also have led to a third trial for the men alleged to be the principal conspirators in a cocaine smuggling case. The first trial was aborted after customs and excise gave evidence not previously disclosed to the defence.

Five men were found guilty in the second trial but the convictions were overturned because of flaws in the judge's summing up and a retrial ordered. But a judge ruled that the retrial would be an abuse of process.

Judge Gerald Butler QC, who carried out an inquiry into the Doran prosecution, recommended in his report last month that a right of appeal for prosecutors in such cases should be considered.

The right would apply to the same range of offences covered by the attorney general's power to challenge sentences as unduly lenient.

Judge Alan Wilkie QC, the law commissioner responsible for criminal law reform, said: "Our proposals, if implemented, would allow the court of appeal to correct an erroneous ruling by a judge before the trial or during the prosecution case. It would be the jury, not the judge, who decided on the guilt or innocence of the defendant."

fields.headline: Today's TV
fields.trailText: Terrestrial
fields.body:
Brain Story
9pm, BBC2

Continuing her investigation into the way the brain works, Professor Susan Greenfield looks at the roots of human emotions. Far stronger and more vivid than our thoughts, our emotions can either make life joyous or cause immense anguish. "I feel like I'm trapped in some kind of hell", says Vietnam veteran Dennis Sines. As Sines struggles to cope with post-traumatic stress syndrome, a scan reveals that his war experiences have physically changed his brain's structure.

Glasgow Kiss
9.30pm, BBC1
A drama based around a will-they-won't-they affair between two 30-something protagonists may sound like TV by numbers, but this is better observed than other shows of its ilk. Stuart (Iain Glen) is a widower bringing up a young son, and Cara (Sharon Small) is a management consultant who can't seem to find the right man. The two meet when Cara is sent to Glasgow to sort out the ailing paper where Stuart works as a sports writer. Is either ready to take a chance on finding happiness? Probably, but not before they've negotiated a few misunderstandings. Well, there wouldn't be a lot of point to this if the course of true love ran smooth. See feature, page 17.

Rhona
9.50pm, BBC2

While much of the publicity about this has focused on the fact that Rhona (stand-up Rhona Cameron) is gay, it's actually rather a conventional sitcom. fields.headline: Tougher police line on speeding
fields.trailText: Police chiefs yesterday confirmed a reverse on speeding policy which could see drivers being prosecuted for travelling at just one mile an hour over the limit.
fields.body:
Police chiefs yesterday confirmed a reverse on speeding policy which could see drivers being prosecuted for travelling at just one mile an hour over the limit.

Motorists in 30mph zones were not stopped unless they topped 35mph under old rules drawn up by the Association of Chief Police Officers. But that policy has been abandoned after campaigners threatened legal action, claiming it was illegal and cost lives.

The campaign group Transport 2000 was given a green light to challenge Norfolk's chief constable, Ken Williams, chairman of Acpo's traffic committee, in the high court in May. Representatives met senior officers to discuss the guidelines last month and said then they hoped legal action could be avoided.

Mr Williams confirmed yesterday that new rules giving patrol officers greater discretion had been put in place.

The guidelines will allow officers to clamp down hard on those speeding in busy, built-up areas, for example, while giving more leeway to drivers who are just breaking the limit on quiet roads at night.

Acpo's guidance to chief constables on the prosecution of speeding offences has recently been enhanced to emphasise the importantance of discre tion by patrolling officers, Mr Williams said.

"As a result the document now provides clearer guidance to police on the need for speeding offences strictly but fairly to be enforced and to the public on the risk of facing formal action at speeds very close to but above the legal limit."

Transport 2000 welcomed what it called Acpo's "u-turn" over enforcing speed limits.

"The new speed policy sends a clear message to all drivers -if you break the limit, even by a very small margin, you may have to pay the penalty," the assistant director, Lynn Sloman, said. "We believe tougher enforcement will save lives."

webTitle: Ankara to answer for army's actions

fields.headline: Ankara to answer for army's actions
fields.standfirst: The Kurds: special report
fields.trailText: The massacre of seven shepherds - allegedly by Turkish soldiers - in the mountains of northern Iraq is to be investigated by the European court of human rights in Strasbourg.
fields.body:
The massacre of seven shepherds - allegedly by Turkish soldiers - in the mountains of northern Iraq is to be investigated by the European court of human rights in Strasbourg.

The court's ruling last week that the case is admissible establishes a significant legal precedent: for the first time Ankara will have to answer for the behaviour of its troops during cross-border raids into Iraq in pursuit of Kurdish rebels. The decision extends the principle that states are liable for actions beyond their borders.

Turkey, eager to advance its application to join the EU and increasingly sensitive about its human-rights record, frequently finds itself before the court for its "anti-terrorist" campaigns against the separatist Kurdistan Workers Party (PKK).

Last month the court found it responsible for the murder of a prisoner, Agit Salman, and the torture of a villager, Abdullatif Ilhan, who was beaten by soldiers in the predominantly Kurdish south-east; Ankara was ordered to pay £225,000 in damages and legal expenses.

Both cases were taken to Strasbourg by the Kurdish Human Rights Project (KHRP) in London, which is also supporting the case of the seven shepherds, who died in April 1995.

At that time the Turkish army was harrying the PKK in the Kurdish safe-haven established by the allies in northern Iraq after the Gulf war. The PKK used the mountains as a base from which to attack Turkey.

The shepherds saw Turkish helicopters transporting troops up the valley below their village, Azadi, which is just south of the Turkish border. Undeterred, the men set off with their sheep into the hills.

After 15 minutes they met a patrol of Turkish soldiers who, according to the claim submitted to the court, started shouting abuse at them and kicking and hitting them. Wives accompanying them were separated and sent back to the village. Other women who approached the detained shepherds were fired at by soldiers.

Local Kurdish officials who later asked Turkish officers to release the shepherds were promised that they would be freed, but the shepherds' bodies were found in the hills the next morning.

"The bodies had been shot at several times and were badly mutilated," the court documents record. "Ears, tongues and genitals [were] missing."

The shepherds' widows, who still live in northern Iraq, have been unable to take their case to the Turkish courts.

In its ruling, the human-rights court said: "The Turkish authorities failed to conduct a meaningful investigation . . . The Turkish authorities' reaction in this case must not be seen in isolation; rather, it must be seen in the context of their general reluctance to deal with allegations of involvement of state agents in unlawful conduct." The Turkish embassy in London declined to comment on the case.
