fields.headline: City briefing
fields.body:
PO plan called a turning point

Government plans for the future of the Post Office, including moves to prevent rural closures, are a "turning point" for the service, a minister said yesterday.

The spotlight now on the organisation gives a good chance for the public to support offices and for commercial progress to be made, said trade minister Alan Johnson.

He told the Commons trade and industry select committee that from the autumn "preventable" closures would not be allowed, especially among the 10,000 rural post offices.

US missiles headed for UK

Defence secretary Geoff Hoon said yesterday Britain would buy Maverick missiles from US defence firm Raytheon subject to trials and negotiations with the company.

"In March, I announced trials to integrate Maverick anti-armour missiles on Harrier GR7 aircraft and for enhanced security for air-to-air communications on key aircraft types," he told parliament.

"These trials have been progressing well. Subject to their satisfactory conclusion and to satisfactory contract negotiations, we will therefore be proceeding with the procurement of Maverick missiles."

Conservative defence spokesman Ian Duncan Smith said that fell a long way short of a commitment to buy.

Water firm warns on profit

Bristol Water Holdings said the price cut of 10% in real terms from April 1 specified by the industry regulator would adversely affect future profits.

But chairman Roger Woolley told the meeting: "If we can outperform the cost and efficiency assumptions then there will be benefits that can contribute to dividend growth."

Invesco alters boardroom

Invesco Fund Management, the British retail fund arm of Anglo-American investment firm Amvescap, said yesterday that it had appointed Angus Woolhouse and Rory Powe to its board of directors. Mr Woolhouse, who heads marketing across Invesco's retail and institutional businesses, will join the board as UK marketing director. Mr Powe, manager of Invesco's £2.9bn European Growth Fund, joins as head of the pan-European equities team.

Baan requests extension

The Baan Investors Association said it has requested that Invensys extend its tender offer for Baan Co shares by four weeks.

The association said it questioned the 1999 annual figures and second-quarter figures, as well as the picture Baan portrayed of the company's future.

It also requested that Baan arrange a new general shareholders meeting to discuss the "state of the company".

DMGT buys Oz trade shows

Daily Mail & General Trust said its DMG World Media division acquired 10 of Australia's top consumer and trade shows for an undisclosed sum less than £10m. Net assets acquired were negligible, DMGT said, adding that the acquisition of Australian Trade Exhibitions strengthened DMG World Media's position in Australasia.

webTitle: Obituaries:  Anthony Smith on John Aspinall's zoo-keeping

fields.headline: Letter: John Aspinall
fields.trailText: Anthony Smith writes: It was so easy, and correct, for the negative side of John Asp- inall's zoo-keeping (Obituary, June 30) to receive publicity, but the positive portion needs to be affirmed.
fields.body:
Anthony Smith writes: It was so easy, and correct, for the negative side of John Asp- inall's zoo-keeping (Obituary, June 30) to receive publicity, but the positive portion needs to be affirmed.

He bred more lowland gorillas, for example, than the rest of the caged world in total, and anyone visiting Howletts Animal Park can soon see why. His main gorilla enclosure is more gymnasium than place of captivity. At about 180ft long, some 60ft wide and 30ft high, it can make human visitors long to be inside, romping with its inmates, clambering, climbing, sliding, rollicking.

There are dens off that main area, where individuals can retreat when they wish, as in giving birth or merely wishing to escape awhile. This bustling and procreat ing community is as far removed as could be from London's Zoo's solitary Guy, for years the lonely member of his clan. But Aspinall had to fight to achieve his brand of excellence. The local authority forbade his zoo's opening for years.

It is easy to play with gorillas or tigers or elephants when they are small. Aspinall did not see why, or how, that play could be curtailed solely because the animals put on several hundred pounds. I once stood with two Aspinall Siberian tigers resting their front paws on my shoulders, an astonishing, miraculous and heart-warming (as well as heart-stopping) experience impossible in any conventional menagerie.

John Aspinall put his animals first, and hated well-meaning human inter- ference, such as forbidding leopards from receiving living chickens as food, a more natural circumstance, or resenting irregular feeding, say, of tigers (another more natural event).

He acquired his first animal, a tiger, when aged 29 (after he had made some "useful" money). For the next 45 years, he did his best to make his rhinos, roan antelope, axis deer, wolves, sambar - to name a few other favourites - feel at home. He gave them delicacies, and lavished every form of care that money could buy. He also knew that Kent, however nurtured, is not Africa or Asia, and determined to put animals back in their homelands. In Brazzaville on the Zaire river, I once met a group of Aspinall gorillas, still playing with their keepers while en route to a chosen piece of wilderness.

webTitle: Dobson comes out top on mayor spending

fields.headline: Dobson comes out top on mayor spending
fields.standfirst: Special report: Livingstone's London
fields.trailText: Frank Dobson had hoped to retire gracefully to his collection of rare books after his humiliation at the hands of Ken Livingstone. But the former cabinet minister was given an uncomfortable reminder of the London mayoral contest yesterday when new figures showed that he outspent all his rivals in the May elections.
fields.body:
Frank Dobson had hoped to retire gracefully to his collection of rare books after his humiliation at the hands of Ken Livingstone.

But the former cabinet minister was given an uncomfortable reminder of the London mayoral contest yesterday when new figures showed that he outspent all his rivals in the May elections. Although he was roundly beaten into fourth place by all the main candidates - with a mere 13% of the first round vote - Mr Dobson spent £411,435.81 on his campaign, a sum which has left Millbank's fundraisers scratching their heads.

Mr Livingstone, who swept to victory on 58% of the second round vote, spent nearly £22,000 less than his Labour rival with a total campaign budget of £389,705.48.

Steve Norris, the Tory candidate who came second with 42% of the second round vote, was sandwiched between his two rivals in the spending table, with a budget of £392,253.05. Susan Kramer, the Liberal Democrat candidate who was third in the election, spent a mere £127,007.68.

Labour supporters of Mr Livingstone said last night the huge Dobson budget showed what a catastrophic error Millbank made in blocking Mr Livingstone. One Livingstone admirer, who asked to remain anonymous for fear of being expelled from the party, said: "We won but there is no need to gloat. Poor old Frank - he has suffered enough."

The mayoral candidates' budgets were published yesterday by the Greater London authority. Mr Livingstone and Mr Dobsson are likely to face questions over their mayoral budgets which outstrip the declarations they have made in the MPs' register of interests.

fields.headline: On message
fields.trailText: Out of the Blue: US hardware maker IBM yesterday introduced a commercial version of what it says is the world's most powerful supercomputer, able to process 12.3 trillion calculations a second.
fields.body:
 Out of the Blue: US hardware maker IBM yesterday introduced a commercial version of what it says is the world's most powerful supercomputer, able to process 12.3 trillion calculations a second. The ASCI White computer, which is 30,000 times faster than the average PC, is a commercial version of a machine sold to the US department of energy last month to simulate nuclear weapons tests.

 Tuned up: Online music company eMusic announced yesterday that it is to start a service allowing users to download an unlimited amount of material from its catalogue for a monthly subscription fee. EMusic's catalogue features acts such as Elvis Costello, Tom Waits and Willie Nelson. In May, Sony Music and Seagram's Universal Music announced plans to start subscription-based digital services this year.

 Celtic growth: American internet equipment company Cisco Systems is to locate a new manufacturing plant in Dublin, creating up to 3,000 new jobs. The proposed plant is part of a European expansion programme by Cisco, which employs 30,000 people globally and is the world's most valuable company, with a market capitalisation approaching some $500bn (£330bn).

 Building site: British construction companies are set to announce a joint internet exchange, industry sources said yesterday. The joint venture, named Arrideo , will allow companies to conduct tenders, procurement and other business more efficiently with architects, engineers, sub-contractors, distributors, suppliers and manufacturers. It is expected to include AMEC, Balfour Beatty, Bovis Lend Lease, Kvaerner and John Laing.

 Network deal: The Wall Street Journal reported yesterday that Nortel , the world's number two telecommunications network equipment supplier, was in talks to sell the business to Corning - a deal the newspaper said could be worth more than $100bn (£66bn). Analysts said the timing of such a sale would make sense for Nortel in light of JDS Uniphase's stock bid, valued at $41bn when announced two weeks ago, to take over its rival, SDL.

webTitle: US Senate squares up to Deutsche Telekom

fields.headline: US Senate squares up to Deutsche Telekom
fields.trailText: Deutsche Telekom faces an uphill struggle winning approval from US regulators for its $50.7bn takeover of VoiceStream, the wireless group.
fields.byline: Anne Hyland, Jane Martinson  in New York and  Andrew Osborn in Brussels
fields.body:
Deutsche Telekom faces an uphill struggle winning approval from US regulators for its $50.7bn takeover of VoiceStream, the wireless group.

A bill that would stop the federal communications commission from granting a licence to a foreign government-dominated company in the US was set to go before the Senate last night, but has been postponed. If approved, the bill would make it even less likely that DT will win approval for the takeover within a year.

In a letter to his colleagues at the end of last week, Senator Ernest Hollings, who filed the amendment to yesterday's appropriations bill, wrote: "We did not deregulate US telecommunications to permit the regulated foreign government-owned telecommunications companies to take over the US market."

The European commission waded into the debate yesterday, putting the US government on notice that it would face a damaging trade dispute if it blocked the deal on those grounds.

The EU intends to argue that blocking the deal would violate the 1997 World Trade Organisation agreement to open telecommunications markets to private and public companies.

The EU will have to take on the Senate's foreign investment committee. National security concerns voiced by this committee have already delayed the acquisition of Verio, an internet backbone provider, by NTT, the Japanese telecommunications group.

Analysts suggested yesterday that the complicated nature of the deal could mean that DT would not even file its proposals until September. Approval from the FCC would then take six or nine months.

Deutsche Telekom will offer 3.2 of its shares plus $30 a share in cash for each Voice-Stream unit. Alternatively, VoiceStream shareholders can accept $200 in cash or 3.7647 Deutsche Telekom shares. The deal has been agreed by both companies' boards and includes Deutsche Telekom assuming $5bn in debt.

The takeover has also won the approval of VoiceStream's major shareholders, Hutchison Whampoa and Sonera.

Hutchison Whampoa will sell its 22% stake in VoiceStream for $10.86bn in cash and stock, creating a potential profit of more than $9bn. It will also take a 4.6% stake in DT. Sonera has agreed to sell its 7.9% holding for $3.7bn and a 1.7% share in DT.

Chief executive Ron Sommer said yesterday: "This transaction is a unique opportunity to enter the US wireless communications market, one of the most attractive in the world. American consumers will see an acceleration in the rollout of state-of-the-art GSM technology."

Deutsche Telekom is 58% owned by the German government but its holding would fall to 45% after the VoiceStream acquisition. However, a US law prohibits the acquisition of an American telephone company by any firm that is more than 25% owned by a foreign government.

Wall Street analysts voiced concern about Deutsche's ability to complete the deal.

Sonera has agreed to sell its 7.9% holding for $3.7bn and a 1.7% share in DT. Chief executive Ron Sommer said yesterday: "This transaction is a unique opportunity to enter the US wireless communications market, one of the most attractive in the world. American consumers will see an acceleration in the rollout of state-of-the-art GSM technology." Deutsche Telekom is 58% owned by the German government but its holding would fall to 45% after the VoiceStream acquisition. However, a US law prohibits the acquisition of an American telephone company by any firm that is more than 25% owned by a foreign government. Wall Street analysts voiced concern about Deutsche's ability to complete the deal.

webTitle: Labour HQ takes over Benn seat selection

fields.headline: Labour HQ takes over Benn seat selection
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Labour's HQ is to draw up the shortlist to succeed Tony Benn in Chesterfield after taking control of the parliamentary selection process.
fields.body:
Labour's HQ is to draw up the shortlist to succeed Tony Benn in Chesterfield after taking control of the parliamentary selection process.

The party's national executive committee's byelection panel will decide which names go forward following a dispute over which delegates were entitled to vote at a key meeting.

The decision was criticised as "unprecedented" last night by the veteran leftwinger. "A constituency should be able to select its own candidate," said Mr Benn.

The NEC panel set up to vet byelections will draw up its own general election shortlist to go before Chesterfield's local membership at the end of September. The 15 would-be successors include Liz Kendall, a former aide to Harriet Harman.

Leftwingers fear only "approved" names will go forward but an East Midlands party spokesman said it had proved impossible to agree who was entitled to be a delegate on Chesterfield's general committee.

"If we went ahead with an unsafe list we would be criticised. This is the fairest way forward," said the spokesman.

webTitle: Straw faces new retreat on fans bill

fields.headline: Straw faces new retreat on fans bill
fields.standfirst: Special report: football violence
fields.trailText: The home secretary, Jack Straw, will today face pressure to make further concessions on emergency legislation banning football hooligans from travelling abroad if the law is to be in place in time for England's World Cup qualifying matches this autumn.
fields.body:
The home secretary, Jack Straw, will today face pressure to make further concessions on emergency legislation banning football hooligans from travelling abroad if the law is to be in place in time for England's World Cup qualifying matches this autumn.

Conservative and Liberal Democrat peers in the House of Lords are expected to vote for a "sunset" amendment to the government's football (disorder) bill today which would cause the legislation to fall after only one year, instead of the five year period proposed by the government. The government's attempts to rush the controversial bill through parliament after the trouble at last month's Euro 2000 tournament has already prompted more than 30 amendments in the Commons from opposition MPs who claim the bill threatens civil liberties.

Under the legislation, police will have the power to confiscate the passports of suspected troublemakers to prevent them from travelling abroad to football tournaments even if they had not been convicted of any offence. Mr Straw has already agreed a number of concessions, including extra safeguards to constrain police powers, limiting the length of time they can detain a suspected offender, and restricting the grounds for arrest.

But the latest opposition amendment, which comes during the bill's report stage in the Lords, would mean the measure returning to the Commons once again - making it difficult to get the legislation on the statute book before parliament's began its summer recess on Friday. This would mean that the bill would not be in place to prevent troublemakers from travelling to Paris for England's friendly against France in September and for England's World Cup qualifying matches against Germany and Finland in October.

Tory and Lib Dem peers - who make up a majority in the upper chamber - are expected to vote to reduce the "sunset" clause, which allows the legislation to fall off the statute book unless it is re-enacted, from five to only one year. The amendment comes despite bitter wrangles within the Conservative party over the football hooliganism law, with many Tories fearing that if the bill is defeated, the government will seek to blame any trouble at the games this autumn on them.

Lord McNally, the Lib Dem home affairs spokesman in the Lords, said: "The bill has been rushed through with indecent haste, so the sooner it should come back to parliament for a proper and considered examination, the better. You don't throw centuries of law making procedure out the window because there's going to be a game in Paris in September. It's the government that's got itself in this straitjacket, not us."

webTitle: Leader: ending the asylum backlog should be welcomes

fields.headline: The politics of asylum
fields.standfirst:
Ending the backlog should be welcomed
Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: Leader:History shows all steps to "reform" our asylum procedures deserve the most rigorous scrutiny. New moves, in the wake of the prime minister's leaked memo suggesting Labour was considered soft on asylum, need an even more forensic examination.
fields.body:
History shows all steps to "reform" our asylum procedures deserve the most rigorous scrutiny. New moves, in the wake of the prime minister's leaked memo suggesting Labour was considered soft on asylum, need an even more forensic examination. One of Tony Blair's proposals was the need "to highlight removals". So clearly there is one obvious political "benefit" in our frontpage story yesterday which disclosed a massive expansion of the immigration service to speed up decisions on asylum seekers: the bigger the number processed, the bigger the number of removals. But this is too cynical. The new move to end the asylum backlog is unalloyed good news.

There can be few more debilitating experiences than waiting in limbo for a ruling on an asylum application. It takes months to obtain a decision. Consider the enfeebling sense of insecurity which weeks of waiting creates. Under the Tories, 10,000 applicants had still not had a decision after a five-year wait. Labour has got the average wait down to 13 months, but the backlog climbed to a shameful 104,000 earlier this year. Remember, to measure the aggregate misery, total numbers are even larger because "applications" do not include chil dren and wives. Eliminating this inhumane backlog is a move all progressives should welcome.

The new investment is large. Overall staff numbers are expected to rise from 6,500 to 11,000 over two years. The aim is to make up to 150,000 decisions this financial year, clearing the backlog by March next year. There are three provisos which ministers must meet: first the need to ensure the decisions taken in this new procedure are of a high quality with no corners cut; second - and related to the first - legal aid for asylum applicants, now being dispersed across the country, must be improved. The application form, which has to be filled up, is a crucial part of the process. Earlier expert advice will reduce the number of appeals based on incomplete evidence. Third, and most serious of all, the proposal to expand the number of detention places from the current 900 to 2,700 still awaits justification. This is not just an administrative matter. Depriving people of their liberty must be treated far more seriously than it currently is. Britain has one of the worst records on this issue. Ministers must fully justify the change and ensure that strong safeguards, including detention time limits, are introduced.

fields.headline: Malnutrition hits NHS treatment
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: Increasing numbers of patients admitted to hospital are likely to get infections and have to stay longer at higher cost to the NHS because they are malnourished, a conference heard yesterday.
fields.body:
Increasing numbers of patients admitted to hospital are likely to get infections and have to stay longer at higher cost to the NHS because they are malnourished, a conference heard yesterday.

But despite the serious consequences both for the patient and the health service, malnutrition is often not spotted when a patient is admitted to hospital.

Mike Lean, of the department of nutrition at Glasgow University, told the International Congress of Dietetics in Edinburgh that 13% of the patients admitted over four weeks to Glasgow Royal infirmary were malnourished, but in only a quarter of the cases was this recognised and the patient sent to a dietician. In only 18% of cases a letter was sent informing the GP, after the patient was sent home, that he or she had not been eating properly.

"Very few patients admitted to hospital with malnutrition have any mention of this in their medical records," Professor Lean said. "More research and monitoring is required, but by insisting on assessing nutritional status in every patient and ensuring that there are sufficient staff to help feed patients for long enough, we do hope that this very worrying and costly situation will improve."

Cases of malnutrition have risen from 3,581 to 6,293 in 10 years, according to government figures. Many people who are already underweight, through poverty or illness, lose more weight in hospital. Some nutritionists suggest that nurses are too busy with duties that used to be the preserve of doctors, to feed those patients unable to feed themselves. Some hospitals are recruiting volunteers to do the job.

Jackie Edington, who works for the medical division of Abbott Laboratories, a pharmaceutical company, screened patients for malnutrition with the help of medical and dietetic staff in four hospitals. She found that patients who were malnourished stayed longer in hospital, had more prescriptions and more infections during their stay.

"From our research it is clear that malnourished people have poorer clinical outcomes and the resulting cost to the national health service cannot be ignored," Dr Edington said. She added that health care professionals in hospitals and in the community need to be trained to identify malnutrition.

Rick Wilson, director of nutrition and dietetics at King's College hospital, London, said: "Delivery of food past the patients' lips is a joint effort principally by nurses, food service personnel and dieticians. If any one of these groups is not fulfilling its role then it's quite likely that the food service will fail to nourish the patient. Poorly presented food, drab surroundings or distractions such as bad smells will dimish enjoyment of a meal and reduce the likelihood of adequate nourishment."

webTitle: Milosevic tightens his grip on power

fields.headline: Milosevic tightens his grip on power
fields.standfirst: Serbia: special report
fields.trailText: The Yugoslav parliament opened the way yesterday for President Slobodan Milosevic to stay in power for eight more years.
fields.body:
The Yugoslav parliament opened the way yesterday for President Slobodan Milosevic to stay in power for eight more years.

Its action once again wrong-footed his domestic opponents as well as the government of Serbia's tiny sister republic of Montenegro, leaving them uncertain whether to boycott the proposed elections.

It also dismayed western governments which have funded opposition media and civic groups and long hoped to see the Belgrade strongman removed from power.

In a brief session both houses of the Serbian-dominated house approved election bills which flesh out changes to the constitution agreed a fortnight ago.

They provide for the direct election of the federal president for a maximum of two four-year terms. Mr Milosevic has already served two terms as the directly elected president of Serbia, and he became Yugoslav president in 1997 under the old scheme, in which parliament chose the person to fill what used to be a mainly ceremonial job.

But he soon took over executive power, leaving his successor as Serbian president the figure-head.

Now, in another quick-step, he is giving himself the chance to be chosen by direct election again, thus gaining a mantle of legitimacy.

With the opposition divided as usual, not only over who could be a joint candidate, but whether to run at all, he must be the favourite to win.

Local and parliamentary elections are due this autumn and Mr Milosevic may hold the presidential poll early, possibly in September.

Montenegro's pro-western government has strongly condemned the changes which downgrade the republic's role, but it has stopped short of declaring independence for fear of provoking intervention by the Yugoslav army.

It is also hesitating over calling a referendum.

The US state department reacted with embarrassment, saying it continued to reject independence for Montenegro, and adding: "We have urged President Milo Djukanovic to avoid any precipitous unilateral moves."

The federal parliament in Belgrade also cocked a snook at the United Nations administration in Kosovo yesterday. It reshuffled electoral districts in Serbia so that voters from Kosovo, which is still nominally part of Serbia, can cast their ballots in two districts in Serbia proper.

International officials in Kosovo, from which Serb forces withdrew last summer, have just completed registering voters for the polls expected in October. While around a million ethnic Albanians registered, barely a thousand Serbs did.

The UN wants Serbs to take part as a sign that the territory still has a multi-ethnic future.

This has not impressed many Serbs, and Belgrade's option of giving them a vote in Serbia itself reinforces that.

webTitle: Clinton's return stirs stagnant peace talks

fields.headline: Clinton's return stirs stagnant peace talks
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Bill Clinton has begun a round-the-clock effort to reinvigorate the Middle East peace talks at Camp David, to hints that the negotiators may be closer to an agreement than seemed likely when the talks nearly broke down last week.
fields.body:
Bill Clinton has begun a round-the-clock effort to reinvigorate the Middle East peace talks at Camp David, to hints that the negotiators may be closer to an agreement than seemed likely when the talks nearly broke down last week.

Mr Clinton's return from the G8 economic summit in Okinawa on Sunday night has re-energised the US-led negotiations between Israel and the Palestinians at the presidential retreat in the Maryland mountains.

Within hours of his return from Japan, Mr Clinton embarked on a gruelling 10-hour overnight session of talks, and resumed again yesterday after less than five hours sleep.

As the talks enter their third week, Israeli and Palestinian negotiators have now spent more time in the closely guarded Maryland compound than their Israeli and Egyptian predecessors did when they made the first Camp David agreement in 1978.

With the Camp David news blackout still in force, there were again few details about the talks. But in a relatively upbeat briefing by the terse standards of the talks, the White House described yesterday's discussions as "intensive and substantive" and said Mr Clinton believed that they had the potential to produce the elusive agreement.

Israel's chief negotiator, Shlomo Ben-Ami, told Israeli Army radio that "a final or nearly final clarification will be apparent in the next two days".

The White House merely said that Mr Clinton was "taking this day by day", refusing to put a deadline or a timetable on this phase of the talks.

The future status of Jerusalem remains the biggest stumbling block to an agreement: Israel and the Palestinians still regard their control of the city as a precondition to a peace deal.

An opinion poll published yesterday in Israel showed that 59% of Israelis hope a deal will nevertheless be reached, and only 31% hope the talks will fail.

A senior Palestinian official in Gaza took a sombre view, saying that reports of a near agreement were untrue, and that the negotiations were at their most difficult stage.

"There has been no agreement reached on any of the negotiable issues on the table, including Jerusalem, borders, economy, refugees, security, settlements and water.

None of the files have been closed," Tayeb Abdel Rahim said.

Mr Clinton had separate meetings with the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, and Palestinian Authority president, Yasser Arafat, on Sunday night.

It was his first direct discussions with them since he left for Okinawa on Thursday morning, leaving the secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, in charge.

After a dinner attended by the 30 or so principal negotiators on Sunday, Mr Clinton then met a small team of negotiators from both sides until just after 5am.

The meetings resumed shortly after 10.30am yesterday and were expected to last for "several hours", the White House said.

"Those meetings were intensive and substantive and, as the time indicates, went quite long into the night," the White House spokesman, Joe Lockhart, said yesterday.

"The president in his mind is working on what I'll call a rolling assessment of whether the substance and atmosphere at these talks are such that potentially could lead to an agreement."

Mr Clinton did not have a "calendar-driven deadline", he said, adding that the president would remain at Camp David and would keep the parties working for as long as those conditions applied.

"I think the fact that he was up until 5am working through the issues in a very personal, hands-on way, and that he was back at it early this morning, should lead you to believe that he thinks staying here for the time being is worthwhile," Mr Lockhart added.

webTitle: Hi-tech sector delivers thousands of jobs

fields.headline: Hi-tech sector delivers thousands of jobs
fields.standfirst: Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: Two technology driven firms yesterday announced thousands of new jobs, underlining the continuing shift within the British economy from manufacturing to services.
fields.body:
Two technology driven firms yesterday announced thousands of new jobs, underlining the continuing shift within the British economy from manufacturing to services.

Pay-TV group ONdigital, which is jointly owned by Carlton Communications and Granada Media, said it was creating 1,500 jobs, while telecommunications equipment maker Marconi an nounced a £2bn deal with BT which will boost employment at its Coventry plants.

The news came as Asda Wal-Mart opened the first of 10 planned supercentres which are expected to create 3,000 jobs over the next five years and help change the face of British retailing.

The latest good news on the jobs front follows reports last week that Corus, the steelmaker formed by the merger of British Steel and the Dutch group Hoogovens, that it plans to cut a further 1,600 jobs, bringing the total job losses announced by the group to 4,000 in the past month.

A further 630 jobs are reported to be at risk at Courtaulds Textiles because of the proposed closure of its knitwear factories near Nottingham.

Marconi announced earlier this year that it expected to create some 2,000 jobs in Coventry but the group said yesterday that its five-year contract to supply sophisticated fibre optic equipment to BT would not only underpin that expansion but also create about 150 additional jobs in Britain.

Although the contract is part of an ongoing procurement programme from BT as the telecoms group builds up its broadband network, Marconi believes it represents a milestone in rolling out the next generation of optical fibre equipment.

"We have been working very hard with this product. We have competed against the very best in the world for this next-generation transmission contract. We can now roll it out across our installed base," a spokesman said.

ONdigital said it planned to create 1,100 jobs at a new cus tomer contact centre in Pembroke's Cyber Bay business park and a further 400 at the firm's existing centre in Plymouth.

"The rapid growth of ONdigital's customer base and the roll-out of new services means we need to expand rapidly to handle the expected volume of demand," said ONdigital chief executive Stuart Prebble.

Although the "new" economy's increasing contribution towards employment is broadly welcomed, there are some concerns that the shift from traditional manufacturing towards services could go too far.

"It is not something I would see as particularly encouraging," according to Royal Bank of Scotland Neil Parker. "It would be nice to see losses in manufacturing replaced with jobs in manufacturing."

Britain was having to import more goods and was more reliant on exports of services, leaving the economy exposed to changes in the exchange rate, he said.

Marconi announced earlier this year that it expected to create some 2,000 jobs in Coventry but the group said yesterday that its five-year contract to supply sophisticated fibre optic equipment to BT would not only underpin that expansion but also create about 150 additional jobs in Britain. Although the contract is part of an ongoing procurement programme from BT as the telecoms group builds up its broadband network, Marconi believes it represents a milestone in rolling out the next generation of optical fibre equipment. "We have been working very hard with this product. We have competed against the very best in the world for this next-generation transmission contract. We can now roll it out across our installed base," a spokesman said. ONdigital said it planned to create 1,100 jobs at a new cus tomer contact centre in Pembroke's Cyber Bay business park and a further 400 at the firm's existing centre in Plymouth. "The rapid growth of ONdigital's customer base and the roll-out of new services means we need to expand rapidly to handle the expected volume of demand," said ONdigital chief executive Stuart Prebble. Although the "new" economy's increasing contribution towards employment is broadly welcomed, there are some concerns that the shift from traditional manufacturing towards services could go too far. "It is not something I would see as particularly encouraging," according to Royal Bank of Scotland Neil Parker. "It would be nice to see losses in manufacturing replaced with jobs in manufacturing." Britain was having to import more goods and was more reliant on exports of services, leaving the economy exposed to changes in the exchange rate, he said.

webTitle: Ebookers pulls in an extra $45m from institutions

fields.headline: Ebookers pulls in an extra $45m from institutions
fields.standfirst: Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: Ebookers, the online travel agency, has brushed aside fears that it was heading for a cash crisis by raising $45m (£30m) in a placing of shares with institutional investors.
fields.body:
Ebookers, the online travel agency, has brushed aside fears that it was heading for a cash crisis by raising $45m (£30m) in a placing of shares with institutional investors.

The company said the money should be enough to fund it through to profitability by early 2002. Finance director Sanjiv Talwar said: "This reinforces the message that we are a real business rather than a paper tiger."

Ebookers is a pan-European travel agency, operating in 11 countries. Although the company is based in London, its shares are listed on New York's Nasdaq and Franfkurt's Neuer Markt. It claims to have the highest transaction value of any online ticketing agent, with customers spending an average of £425 each.

The new money will fund a renewed advertising campaign, predominantly in print media, to convince travellers of the virtues of buying tickets on the net. It will also pay for upgrades in technology and the group has said it wants to make an acquisition to take it into Italy.

Mr Talwar said that assuming the group sticks to its current business plan, it will not need to raise any more cash. However, he added: "Of course, if there are strategic reasons for going in other directions, we will consider it."

The shares were placed at $11. In March, the price reached $35 but subsequently slumped as low as $6, amid rumours that the group was burning cash far faster than expected. Sentiment among investors was affected by the disappointing flotation of Lastminute.com, which also sells air tickets online.

Ebookers' chief executive is Dinesh Dhamija, who previously founded the offline Flightbookers travel agency.

The company announced last week that quarterly sales had reached £20m, with losses up from £660,000 to £6.6m.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Satellite, cable and digital
fields.body:
Captain Horatio Hornblower
(Raoul Walsh, 1951) 4pm, Sky Cinema

Just the thing as the school holidays get going: a rousing seagoing epic, based on three of CS Forester's tales. The action follows Gregory Peck's staunch and heroci Hornblower from the Pacific, where his frigate the Lydia is busy scuppering Spanish interests, to home waters and action against Napoleon's navy. The vivid battle scenes were among the most expensive ever shot; and there are romantic larks too, with the captain mopping the brow of Virginia Mayo's fever-struck beauty.

Ride The High Country
(Sam Peckinpah, 1961) 9pm, TCM

Peckinpah's marvellous elegiac western incorporates the themes of The Wild Bunch - the end of the old west, friendship and betrayal. Joel McCrea and Randolph Scott as friends on opposite sides of the law, reunited by a sack of money and the gallant urge to rescue a young bride from the odious Hammond brothers.

Pecker
(John Waters, 1998) 10.10pm, Sky Premier

A slightly subdued, but still interesting offering from the director of weird worldviews Mondo Trasho, Pink Flamingos and all. This stars Edward Furlong as Pecker (so named because of his habit of pecking at his food like a bird) who is a part-time burger bar chef and part-time photographer snapping Baltimore life; Lili Taylor plays the glitzy art dealer planning to put him on show. In among the cast of off-centre characters is Christina Ricci as Pecker's girlfriend.

Cold Fever
(Fridrik Thor Fridriksson, 1994) 11.35pm, FilmFour

So well worn is the European road movie tradition, something radical is required to create an interesting variation these days. So how about a Japanese man travelling across Iceland? It's a successful effort on the whole, making full use of Iceland's landscape and bizarre customs. The protagonist is Masatoshi Nagase, best known from Jim Jarmusch's Mystery Train (it's produced and co-written by Jarmusch regular Jim Stark); the excuse is his mission to honour the site where his parents died.

fields.headline: Getting personal with... David Haig
fields.trailText: Answer me
fields.body:
Have you ever adopted a pseudonym and, if so, why? My real name is David Ward so in a sense I've been using a pseudonym since I started acting in 1977.

Have you ever lied about your age and, if so, why? I often forget my own birthday, so who knows? For the record, I'm 44... I think.

How would you describe yourself in a lonely hearts ad? Balding, obsessive and hyperchondriacal. If you are still interested, please contact me.

What was the last illegal thing you did? I wouldn't dream of telling you, but it was yesterday.

What was the last kind-hearted thing you did? I have promised never to sing in front of my daughters' friends again.

Who's the nicest person you've ever worked with? Julia, my wife.

Has a critic ever made you cry? Oh, probably.

What would you advertise without a fee? Tommy's Campaign.

What would you never advertise? Tobacco.

What wakes you up screaming at four in the morning? What doesn't?

What takes you to a "happy place"? Driving through the rain, playing Bob Dylan music incredibly loudly on the car stereo.

 David Haig's The Good Samaritan at Hampstead Theatre runs to 26 August.

fields.headline: Put up or shut up
fields.trailText: You Only Live Once | Paul O'Grady's Orient | The Thing About Vince...
fields.body:
Lily Savage once offered to lend Mo Mowlam a wig to cover her radiotherapy baldness. Patrick Kielty enjoyed weekend parties at Stormont when Mowlam was Secretary of State for Northern Ireland. Ms Mowlam obviously gets on well with comedians in general, which made the strained relations between her and Nick Hancock in You Only Live Once (BBC1) all the more obvious. Hancock grilled her in his usual cocky style, cracking jokes about cannabis and masturbation and ensuring that Mowlam didn't hog the spotlight - a novel approach to the feature interview. "I've come over all Frankie Howerd", he said, to excuse his eye-rolling double entendres; he then had to restrain his mirth when she said the word "bankers". "Yes," said Mowlam, so much unspoken in the pause, "bankers".

After half an hour of this, one almost began to believe Michael Parkinson's oft-repeated claim that being a chat-show host isn't as easy as it looks. Mo Mowlam is a TV natural: she's funny, she's unabashed, she tells a good story, and she can be serious too. But every time she got warmed up, Hancock was interfering with another of his jokes, as if this was an encounter between equals. And when the host wasn't cutting her short, the editors were. On several occasions, as Mowlam was launching into an interesting point about her life and work, we were vouchsafed only the first sentence. It's hard to believe that she rambled on, or that she started swearing, or said something libellous - she is a politician, after all. Occasionally, however, she was allowed to win a round. Hancock was determined to get mileage out of the Buck ingham Palace question, to which he returned despite Mowlam's obvious disinclination to discuss it. Why, he asked, does it keep returning to haunt her? "We could let it drop now, so it doesn't come up again", she said, leaving Hancock frantically scanning his notes for the next question. Mischievous Mowlam deliberately shifted in her chair to block Hancock's view of the autocue.

Mo's friend Lily Savage left the wigs at home and set off to the Far East in Paul O'Grady's Orient (ITV), a travelogue with a twist. First stop Shanghai, where O'Grady hoped to plunge headlong into vice but found only cheerful pensioners doing Tai Chi in the park. Following up a lifelong interest in "Hollywood prozzies" he went in search of Shanghai Lily, as embodied by Marlene Dietrich in Shanghai Express, but his nearest brush with the trade was a barber who may or may not have offered him a blow-job. This was all by the by, though: the greatest spectacle in Paul O'Grady's Orient was not Shanghai but O'Grady, hungover and in vicious mood, launching into a five-minute diatribe about his high-tech hotel accommodation. "I don't want to do a degree course in computer studies before I can wipe my arse", he raved as he prowled round the suite looking for his socks. "Next time I want a single bed and a plug on a chain." Unlike other character comedians, O'Grady's just as funny as his creation - in fact it's hard to know where one ends and the other begins. Savage, whether dressed in sports jacket and slacks or the more usual hooker's wardrobe, is still savage.

Timothy Spall turned in a likeable performance as a middle-aged malcontent in The Thing About Vince... (ITV). Home life for Vince and wife Wendy (Marion Bailey) meant "sitting in front of the telly with a Fray Bentos pie"; little wonder, then, that he spent the night with "some little tart" in a hotel. Nothing happened, he insisted, but Wendy chucked him out anyway.

This allowed us to meet Vince's loveable parents (Peter Vaughan and Sheila Hancock) who said things like "you silly plum" and "you great buttock"; meanwhile Vince's daughter Sally was about to tie the knot with boyfriend Paul, a man who read Bridget Jones's Diary in bed and so couldn't be All Bad. Vince and Wendy resorted to seeing a marriage guidance counsellor, a character so feckless that he brought the entire profession into disrepute. The encounter did, however, allow Spall to reprise his Secrets And Lies turn, getting all articulate and revealing the pain within ("something's gone wrong somehow"). Vince and Wendy have two more episodes in which to work things out, and one would be a lot more hopeful of a happy ending if this had been scheduled for a Sunday night. This being a gritty Monday-night show, it could yet end in the divorce courts.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Radio
fields.body:
The very word "vitamin" conveys an impression of health, which is exactly what the Polish chemist Casimir Funk intended when he invented it in 1909. Unfortunately, as Claudia Hammond explains in The ABC Of Vitamins (9.30am, Radio 4), the reality is a little more depressing. Vitamin A, for example, is thought good for the skin, and one derivative is widely used in cosmetics. But the synthetic form of beta-carotene, which metabolises into Vitamin A, may increase cancer among smokers.

Men In Crisis (8.0pm, Radio 4), presented by Anthony Clare (pictured) is described as "provocative". Certainly it succeeded in provoking me. The opening programme abounds in unsourced claims, for example that "domestic violence accounts for 25 per cent of violent crime". That statistic could equally validly demonstrate that three-quarters of the people convicted of assault lead blameless home lives. Look out for a sudden increase in attacks on innocent radios.

fields.headline: A tale of two cities
fields.standfirst: The classic crime series, Taggart, and tonight's new drama, Glasgow Kiss, are both set in the same place. Or are they?  Jamie McCallum  on how television's portrayal of Scotland's biggest city is changing out of all recognition
fields.trailText: The classic crime series, Taggart, and tonight's new drama, Glasgow Kiss, are both set in the same place. Or are they? Jamie McCallum on how television's portrayal of Scotland's biggest city is changing out of all recognition
fields.body:
When the gravel-voiced chanteuse first sung the Taggart theme tune back in 1983 - "Well I know the city like a lover/ And you bet it's hard to love another/ This is no mean town/No mean city" - she couldn't have anticipated how much her lover would change over the years. The Glasgow of Glasgow Kiss, which starts tonight on BBC1, is a million miles away from the city of which she sings.

When the gruff, bluff DCI Jim Taggart first appeared, it was as an emblem of the city that spawned him. He was working-class, weathered and often harsh, but with a sense of justice and a sense of (black) humour. A rough diamond, he was Glasgow personified.

Then, the "no mean city" was still most famous for the razor gangs of the 60s, the serial killer Bible John, Red Clydeside, tenements and steamies.

Taking a lead from literature like the work of James Kelman and the city's demotic traditions, as well as its violent and poverty-stricken reputation, Peter MacDougall's gangster epics Down Among The Big Boys and Elephants' Graveyard set the tone for Taggart's Glasgow, the Glasgow instantly recognisable across Britain.

And, just as Taggart probed the city's underbelly and fed the notion that Glasgow was still awash with murderers, con merchants, wide boys and loose women, so John Byrne's Tutti Frutti and Your Cheatin' Heart were to suggest the same in later years, albeit in more lyrical, original ways. Their milieu too was on the seamy side of the street, among no-hopers, drop-outs and eccentrics.

But the Glasgow of now, the Glasgow of Glasgow Kiss, is another metropolis entirely, and in it, DCI Taggart, Eddie Clockerty and Vincent Driver would surely be lost. This Glasgow is hip, shiny, vibrant and above all, new. The new Glasgow - with its Year of Culture, its inner-city regeneration, trendification, gentrification and its "shopping mecca" and "most cosmopolitan city outside London" accolades - is so much a part of Glasgow Kiss, the city is virtually another character in the drama.

This means more than simply using the city's impressive vistas as establishing shots, though there is plenty of that and it's easy to see why.

Glasgow is a very visual, textured city, from post-industrial vistas - like the famous Finnieston Crane - to sweeping tenemented crescents and the Norman Foster-designed Armadillo concert hall. It has an awesome artistic and architectural tradition and a fondness for public art and democratic design.

Its people are very aware of how things should look (which may explain why they are so keen on the adorned, ornate glory of Versace). Hence, to use Glasgow so, instead of falling back on generic cityscapes and locations in London or completely fictional ones like Casualty's Holby, Glasgow Kiss deserves special mention. But more than that, it allows the writer, Stephen Greenhorn, to involve the city in the stories being played out.

The premise which initiates the drama - London-based management consultant returns to the city of her birth to sort out an ailing newspaper - could be read as a metaphor for New Labour attempting to kick the socialist Scots into touch, or for the west of Scotland letting go of its industrial/manufacturing past to look to a different future. Cara, the management consultant, has a run-in with the editor, a firebrand hewn on Red Clydeside (the last of his breed and probably a close personal friend of Jim Taggart), yet triumphs because in this brave new world, without her methods, his paper will "cease to be viable".

She meets Stuart, a sports writer, as different from the old breed of hack as you can imagine (instead of getting stuck in the pub, he gets held up at PTA meetings) and an on-off affair blossoms. Both Cara and Stuart are stuck in the past (he is yet to clear his wife's things out of the bathroom cabinet, years after her death, she because of emotional traumas linked to the city), but Glasgow itself becomes a lesson for them both. If the city can stop fetishising its past and look to the future, then so can they. With its streets of style bars, high-class shops and exquisite restaurants, Glasgow has made an uncertain leap, challenging Stuart and Cara to do the same. Its past has been transformed into its future, as the tenements in which both Stuart and Cara live demonstrate. Once, they were emblematic of the city's poverty, with their bed recesses and tin baths. Now, in the new Glasgow, they are des res, the domiciles of the middle-class. Today, candle-lit baths are taken out of choice, not out of necessity.

In the same way, the Finnieston Crane, once just a symbol of Glasgow's industrial past, now practically a work of art, takes on new meaning in Glasgow Kiss, and that meaning is of hope for the future.

Just as Taggart has repositioned itself in a more middle-class milieu since the death of Mark McManus in 1994, so too has the city itself. Not that there isn't terrible poverty on Glasgow's sinkhole estates, but there has genuinely been a renaissance in the city and that, more than anything, is what Glasgow Kiss conveys. Not a mean city any more.

 Glasgow Kiss, tonight, 9.30pm, BBC1

Once, they were emblematic of the city's poverty, with their bed recesses and tin baths. Now, in the new Glasgow, they are des res, the domiciles of the middle-class. Today, candle-lit baths are taken out of choice, not out of necessity. In the same way, the Finnieston Crane, once just a symbol of Glasgow's industrial past, now practically a work of art, takes on new meaning in Glasgow Kiss, and that meaning is of hope for the future. Just as Taggart has repositioned itself in a more middle-class milieu since the death of Mark McManus in 1994, so too has the city itself. Not that there isn't terrible poverty on Glasgow's sinkhole estates, but there has genuinely been a renaissance in the city and that, more than anything, is what Glasgow Kiss conveys. Not a mean city any more.  Glasgow Kiss, tonight, 9.30pm, BBC1

fields.headline: Bosnian minorities risk going home
fields.standfirst: Special report: war crimes in the former Yugoslavia
fields.trailText: Police backed by Nato troops moved into a tense village in central Bosnia yesterday to carry out the first eviction of the militant Islamic volunteers known as mojahedin, who fought on the Muslim side in the Bosnian war but refused to leave when peace came in 1995.
fields.body:
Police backed by Nato troops moved into a tense village in central Bosnia yesterday to carry out the first eviction of the militant Islamic volunteers known as mojahedin, who fought on the Muslim side in the Bosnian war but refused to leave when peace came in 1995.

The fundamentalists and their local supporters erected roadblocks last week to ward off the police after the first eviction orders were issued. In skirmishes 19 people were arrested.

Yesterday's operation in the village of Bocnija went smoothly, though bearded fighters filmed police officers descending on two houses.

The police found that the first two families due to be evicted had left of their own accord. "We anticipated obstruction and resistance. You never know with these guys," said Mehmed Bradaric, the mayor of Maglaj, himself a Muslim.

"I am extremely pleased that the process has begun without conflict. That is what we wanted. We didn't wish to begin in an uncivilised manner."

The 89 mojahedin families include about 65 men from Saudi Arabia, Jordan, Sudan, and other countries. The rest are Bosnian militants. They were welcomed during the war of 1992-95, when the United Nations had an embargo on weapons entering Bosnia and the government side was desperate for any kind of military assistance.

Under the Dayton peace agreement of 1995 all foreign forces were supposed to go home. But many Mojahedin settled in central Bosnia, often in houses once owned by Serbs. They have become active in the logging business.

The push to evict them is part of a new policy by Wolfgang Petritsch, the internationally appointed high representative for Bosnia, to enforce property laws throughout the country. This has helped to produce a surge in refugees, who have become confident enough to go home to their towns and villages despite the fact that a different ethnic majority now has power.

Hundreds of people who wanted to go back in the first years of peace found their homes burned down just before they arrived, or else they were greeted by angry mobs throwing stones.

In the last few months the tide has mysteriously begun to turn. About 12,580 people - four times as many as in the same period of 1999 - went back in the first four months of this year. Officials are baffled, but it seems to be partly that refugees of all ethnic groups are simply impatient five years after the end of the war.

It also helps that the average returnee is elderly, and therefore seen as little threat. Most have gone to remote and unoccupied homes damaged in the war. But people are also demanding the right to go back to flats where others are illegally squatting.

The eviction orders - now totalling several thousand and issued by local authorities at the high representative's instigation - are starting what officials describe as a virtuous circle, reversing ethnic cleansing. Mr Petritsch has been sacking officials who refuse to enforce the property laws.

In Bocinja the mojahedin were occupying houses that used to be Serb owned. The Serbs want to return. The first evictions in the village were deliberately aimed at local mojahedin who had homes to go to elsewhere. The hardest cases are those who are foreign and have no pre-war homes, though many have married locally.

The evictions have even been proceeding with some success in Republika Srpska, the Serb-run entity. In May, 163 took place there compared to 205 in the Muslim-Croat Federation, which is run from Sarajevo.

webTitle: All this - and Rolf Harris too

fields.headline: All this - and Rolf Harris too
fields.standfirst: Robin Denselow goes to Womad
fields.trailText: World music is now all-pervasive, with global styles appealing not just to fans of African, Latin, Asian or East European pop and folk music, but influencing everything from the contemporary dance and jazz scene to the MOR market. Faced with the competing problems of categorisation, musical correctness and success, the Womad team - Womad stands for World of Music Arts and Dance - have decided to broaden the definitions. Here, world music covers anything from the best-selling Senegalese pop of Youssou N'Dour and the bright new Malian songs of Rokia Traore to the soulful Australian ballads of Jimmy Little, the live techno of Eat Static, the Latin/dance sounds of Da Lata, and even family singalong from the ever-professional Rolf Harris, a man so desperately unhip that he's almost back in fashion.
fields.body:
World music is now all-pervasive, with global styles appealing not just to fans of African, Latin, Asian or East European pop and folk music, but influencing everything from the contemporary dance and jazz scene to the MOR market. Faced with the competing problems of categorisation, musical correctness and success, the Womad team - Womad stands for World of Music Arts and Dance - have decided to broaden the definitions. Here, world music covers anything from the best-selling Senegalese pop of Youssou N'Dour and the bright new Malian songs of Rokia Traore to the soulful Australian ballads of Jimmy Little, the live techno of Eat Static, the Latin/dance sounds of Da Lata, and even family singalong from the ever-professional Rolf Harris, a man so desperately unhip that he's almost back in fashion.

Wandering through Womad was a bit like musical channel-hopping in some Middle Eastern bazaar. Sold out, but not over-crowded, the best festival of the summer now featured live music at five different locations, presenting quite impossible choices. Should one be watching those moody, soulful Russians, the Terem Quartet, or be in another tent watching a mariachi band, Chavan, or over in the gymnasium, checking out The Master Musicians of Joujouka, the Moroccans who inspired Brian Jones, Ornette Coleman and more recently Talvin Singh? I chose the latter, though the current touring group are not a patch on the village band, whose thunderous drumming, when heard out in the Rif Mountains, is one of the most exhilarating noises in the world.

The best Womad moments are often the surprises, the lesser-known acts found playing in the smaller venues. This was a year for border-hopping guitarists. In the smallest venue, the Rough Guide Dome, the American blues and Hawaiian slide guitar exponent Bob Brozman was teamed up with Takashi Hirayasu, "the Django of the sanshin" (a three-stringed lute) from Okinawa, Japan. It was a strange, glorious collaboration, with Takashi mixing tuneful local nursery rhymes with his own songs about the effects of the US bases in Okinawa, and Brozman, a bearded global enthusiast in the Ry Cooder school, adding inspired embellishment.

Down in the Village Tent, there was an equally inventive set from Justin Adams, best known until now for his work with Sinead O'Connor and Jah Wobble. On his first solo album, Desert Road, he plays almost all the instruments himself, but for live work he has assembled a band, the Wayward Sheiks, in which he's joined by one-time member of the Beat, Andy Cox. Adams's best songs, like Out of the Woods, mixed the desert blues of Ali Farka Toure with the slinky, rhythmic style of JJ Cale, while switching between guitar and the African n'goni. His vocals (much influenced by Mark Knopfler) still needed attention, but he's made the right move in deciding to go solo at last.

African styles dominated much of Saturday night. Rokia Traore arrived late, missing her spot on the main stage, but gave a rousing performance in one of the smaller tents, repeating her success at the Barbican earlier this month by matching her own acoustic guitar with n'goni work from her band, and some frantic dancing. At this rate, she's set to become the leading young female singer on the continent. Veteran Congolese star Papa Wemba, appearing at the same time just a few hundred yards away, showed he is still in great voice but was let down by his songs and arrangements. Before he had finished, his audience were drifting off to watch the ever-reliable and energetic Youssou N'Dour. He played his international set (meaning he threw in a bit of soul, reggae and salsa along with his pop hit 7 Seconds) but was at his best adding extra, frantic percussion to the Senegalese songs from his new album Joko.

All that was missing so far was a nod to the current Latin boom. The strongest band on Sunday (though drawing a smaller crowd than Rolf Harris) were Da Lata, who mixed synth effects with strong percussion and guitar work and the cool vocals of Liliana Chachian. Their album may be remarkable for its blend of percussion and gentle atmospheric passages, but here they played an all-out dance set, just right for a classic Womad weekend.

fields.headline: Life in the big apple
fields.standfirst: Is this Antony Gormley? A piece of fruit? Both?  Adrian Searle  finds peace, stimulation and a high pollen count in an exhibition inspired by gardens
fields.trailText: Is this Antony Gormley? A piece of fruit? Both? Adrian Searle finds peace, stimulation and a high pollen count in an exhibition inspired by gardens
fields.body:
The exhibition Enclosed and Enchanted, at the Museum of Modern Art in Oxford, is neither the first nor the biggest contemporary exhibition devoted to art and the garden. As I write, a much larger international show, Le Jardin 2000, is currently on show in and around the Medici Villa in Rome. Enclosed and Enchanted - taking its title from a description of the gardens of Christchurch College in Oxford, in Evelyn Waugh's Brideshead Revisited - brings the garden indoors. Or rather, into the gallery and into our heads.

The garden of earthly delights, recreated pre-lapsarian Edens and geometric, symbol-laden metaphysical arbours, are a far cry from the perpetual Sunday afternoon-land of electric strimmers, mutant conifers and whimsical, pastel-painted decking.

So far, the Labyrinths and Pleasure Gardens of Belgian artist Jan Vercruysse exist purely as mental retreats, mapped-out and described in a series of reductive coloured plans and text. The text itself is almost enough: "A pond with black goldfish and some water plants... A very small basin with a fountain at the end of a lane... A conversation garden with two stone benches..."

In Vercruysse's gardens there are mazes, enclosures and plots planted with tall grasses, fields of artichokes, lawns with no flowers at all. The terse, clipped text is as plain - and as deceptive - as the apparent simplicities of the gardens he describes. Within the geometries of hedge, lawn and path are imaginary spaces for conversation and contemplation, places to walk, bounded views. Vercruysse doesn't expect more than a couple of his proposals to be planted in his lifetime, although work is afoot on two of his gardens.

Standing and looking and reading his plans, I feel that corners of his gardens are already flourishing in that unkempt weed-choked plot I like to call my brain. The harder one imagines what his gardens would be like, the more peculiar and disturbing they become. Gardens aren't always benign, as the lunatic fantasy gardens which Pirenesi drew and printed in the 18th century testify. Piranesi's prints punctuate the show, to remind us, if nothing else, of the artifice of the garden, its place in our mental geography, its distance from what we like to call the "natural".

What could be so unnatural as the 16th century garden of Ryoan-Ji, in Japan, the atoll of 15 weathered stones so precisely placed on the raked sea of white gravel, the bounded space within the garden's enclosing wall? Not a fleck of lichen is out of place. The stones disposed on the gravel appear, variously, as a closed fist, a seal, a hump-backed, low-browed mountain. Each stone, with its little encircling patch of greenery, rises from a plain of startling whiteness. Takahiko Iimura's film of the garden, with its tracking shots and long close-ups, which dwell on stone after stone, as though to follow the passage of the spectator's eye, is little more than an atmospheric documentary, with a soundtrack of percussive knocks, tinkling bells, a sonorous Japanese voice. There are brief interludes when the screen goes black and a short, contemplative text appears. Apart from the annoying pixelation of the DVD transposition of Iimura's original film, the work is extremely calming. This is a relief - much of Enclosed and Enchanted acts as a corrective to so much wham-bam, novelty-strewn anxious art of the moment.

The exhibition is unapologetically restful, in the way that gardens (apart from those gewgaw-strewn suburban fantasias inhabited by Charlie Dimmock and her straight-man accomplice, the unrelievedly wimpish Alan Titmarsh) are meant to be. It is also a highly accessible show. Where, you ask, is the challenge, the cutting edge, the shock of the new? Study to be quiet, wrote Isaac Walton, quoting the scripture. He may have been writing about angling, but its pleasures, at best, are similar to the pleasures of the garden, and of certain kinds of art which, at our peril, we might lose.

It has been a long time since I thought about Wolfgang Laib, the German artist who collects all kinds of unlikely pollen - in this case, the pale, soft Naples Yellow dust of the pine tree - and pours it into soft-edged rectangles on the floor. The oddly glowing, strongly scented pollen sits on a grey floor, attracting the local fauna. On my visit, a millipede was tracking its way around the pollen, till the gallery staff did a pet rescue of the creature. Laib, like the solitary bee, collects pollen. Unlike the bee, his art has no sting. But his entirely pleasurable rectangles of pollen do make your eyes sing, and there's nothing wrong with that. But is it enough? Is this more than Rothko for the New Age? Well, even Rothko can be pretty, and at least Laib doesn't sell us his angst.

Canadian artist Stan Douglas's photographs (Douglas is best known as a film-maker) of German gardens and allotments are another matter. I love the kinds of places he records - unkempt, fitfully cultivated zones down by the railway tracks and beside the pylons, with their sheds and greenhouses and compost heaps amongst the ivy, ramshackle fences, plots gone to seed. Between the neat rows of houses, in the hinterlands between industry and farmland, we both husband nature and leave space for the kinds of feral nature which persists in the face of the overdetermined. Douglas's images, shot on mild autumn days, almost smell of rotting apples in the damp grass, wet wood, leaf mould. I'll start sucking on an old briar pipe in a minute.

I stop and ask myself why it is that at least three Canadian artists I know of - Douglas himself, Jeff Wall and Peter Doig (a Scot brought up in Canada) - have expressed an interest in these hinterlands between town and country, wilderness and urbanism. Perhaps it has something to do with Canada's scale, the relative modernity of her cities, the absoluteness of the unclaimed tracts beyond. I offer this observation as a question. Yet, as much as we all (presumably) take pleasure in the garden - whether it is manicured, ordered by a surveyor's rule, severely landscaped, artfully arranged as a prettified wilderness - there is something about the ad hoc, organic development of the kinds of places Douglas has photographed which fascinates. Their persistance gives me as much pleasure as seeing foxes in Finsbury Park, sparrowhawks in Hackney.

Describing Gilbert & George's 1970 charcoal landscape drawings as "charming" is not to denegrate them. Charm is in short supply nowadays. The youthful artists maunder about in the countryside, rest under a mighty oak beside a stream, stand in a sloping field beside a wood, stroll a country lane. Are they taking the piss or what, you ask, these consumately urban figures who'd generally prefer to take their habitual daily constitutionals from Spitalfields to Dalston Junction? The drawings are great. The two artists look lost and fey and sad (as sad as can be, they write on one drawing), out of step and out of place. Which, of course, is their self-adopted role.

For all its evident weight, Antony Gormley's Fruit - an iron body-case which resembles a huge apple (look closely and one can see how the final form has the human body as its core) dangling from a heavy cable - is funkier than the general run of his work. It strikes me that there's more humour in Gormley's work than is generally noticed, and if ever his work has a light touch - easy to miss given the nature of his materials - it is evidenced here. There's something a bit macabre about Fruit, too, the idea that this angular, lofty man rolled himself up into a tight ball as though Joyce Grenfell were shouting, "Small as you can, Antony, that's it!" while his assistants did their thing with the clingfilm and the plaster. Fruit is an odd and pleasing shape, and leaves a nice puddle of shadow on the floor beneath it.

In Cristina Iglesias's Vegetation Room, you are the one who gets enclosed. A small entrance in a big white cube leads you into a cul de sac grotto of writhing, high relief, vine-like vegetation. It is, as I wrote elsewhere about her work, like sticking your head in a hedge. It is a work about enclosure and solitude, and enables the viewer to mentally step outside the gallery. The space is a kind of respite - the same is true of Jean-Marc Bustamante's installation of L-shaped concrete blocks and photographs of evergreen foliage ripe with cones. Both Iglesias and Bustamante want, I think, to perform a kind of quietly theatrical transformation of the physical space of the gallery, to take us elsewhere.

It strikes me that this is a rather unfashionable thing to do. Most artists want to take you somewhere horrible and nightmarish. In fact, everything about this show (even Diana Thater's garishly out-of-wack video projection, which turns Monet's garden at Giverny into nastily psychedelic smears of raw colour) asks us to take a break from the anxieties of modern art. Why not, for once, why not?

 Enclosed and Enchanted is at the Museum of Modern Art, Oxford, till October 8 (recorded information 01865 813830).
