Are they taking the piss or what, you ask, these consumately urban figures who'd generally prefer to take their habitual daily constitutionals from Spitalfields to Dalston Junction? The drawings are great. The two artists look lost and fey and sad (as sad as can be, they write on one drawing), out of step and out of place. Which, of course, is their self-adopted role. For all its evident weight, Antony Gormley's Fruit - an iron body-case which resembles a huge apple (look closely and one can see how the final form has the human body as its core) dangling from a heavy cable - is funkier than the general run of his work. It strikes me that there's more humour in Gormley's work than is generally noticed, and if ever his work has a light touch - easy to miss given the nature of his materials - it is evidenced here. There's something a bit macabre about Fruit, too, the idea that this angular, lofty man rolled himself up into a tight ball as though Joyce Grenfell were shouting, "Small as you can, Antony, that's it!" while his assistants did their thing with the clingfilm and the plaster. Fruit is an odd and pleasing shape, and leaves a nice puddle of shadow on the floor beneath it. In Cristina Iglesias's Vegetation Room, you are the one who gets enclosed. A small entrance in a big white cube leads you into a cul de sac grotto of writhing, high relief, vine-like vegetation. It is, as I wrote elsewhere about her work, like sticking your head in a hedge. It is a work about enclosure and solitude, and enables the viewer to mentally step outside the gallery. The space is a kind of respite - the same is true of Jean-Marc Bustamante's installation of L-shaped concrete blocks and photographs of evergreen foliage ripe with cones. Both Iglesias and Bustamante want, I think, to perform a kind of quietly theatrical transformation of the physical space of the gallery, to take us elsewhere. It strikes me that this is a rather unfashionable thing to do. Most artists want to take you somewhere horrible and nightmarish. In fact, everything about this show (even Diana Thater's garishly out-of-wack video projection, which turns Monet's garden at Giverny into nastily psychedelic smears of raw colour) asks us to take a break from the anxieties of modern art. Why not, for once, why not?  Enclosed and Enchanted is at the Museum of Modern Art, Oxford, till October 8 (recorded information 01865 813830).

fields.headline: It's hardly rock'n'roll
fields.standfirst: Almost overnight, Craig David and MJ Cole have risen from underground obscurity to top 10 stardom. But one of them still lives with his mum and the other thinks parties are boring.  Paul Lester meets UK garage's reluctant idols
fields.trailText: Almost overnight, Craig David and MJ Cole have risen from underground obscurity to top 10 stardom. But one of them still lives with his mum and the other thinks parties are boring. Paul Lester meets UK garage's reluctant idols
fields.body:
Take one classically trained 26-year-old, London-born son of an actor father and educationalist mother, and one impeccably mannered 19-year-old who still lives with his Osmonds fan mum in Southampton, and you have the unlikely focal points of garage/two-step, the latest sound to emerge from the British dance underground.

Every dance movement provides - indeed, needs - a charismatic focus as well as its own serious album artists with the promise of longevity, who help sell the music to a sceptical mainstream rock audience. Disco had Chic. Techno had Underworld. Trip hop had Tricky and jungle had Goldie. If anyone has eased garage's transition from pirate radio secrecy to shopping centre ubiquity, it is potential teen superstar Craig David (co-writer of, and singer on, Artful Dodger's Rewind and current top 10 hit Woman Trouble and his recent solo number one, Fill Me In). And if anyone is going to make two-step's first significant album, it is MJ Cole.

"We'll see what happens," says Cole (real name Matthew James Firth Coleman), inside London's Soho Studios complex, modestly assessing the chances of his debut LP, Sincere, being greeted as the genre's first major statement of intent. Not that the graduate of London's City University with grade 8 distinctions in piano, oboe and music theory has delusions of celebrity. "I never dreamed of being on Top of the Pops," he says, although he did appear on the programme when his single, Crazy Love, charted earlier this year.

"I'm not into red carpet and glitzy parties and blonde chicks coming up to you." Cole may have been recognised by the man behind the deli counter at his local health food shop last week, but it is as a producer, not a performer, that he wants to be acknowledged. "I want to be like Brian Eno, George Martin or Trevor Horn: a name on a record sleeve. A sign of quality."

Considering that DJs and mixmasters such as Cole are the new rock gods, with their own ready supply of groupies and drugs, and considering that garage has its roots partly in the ragga shouts of dancehall and "ruffneck" blasts of drum'n'bass (its smoother flavas come from American R&B), he has none of the bad boy about him. He learned his trade working the controls "for £20 a week" on a slew of drum'n'bass recordings, but a gangsta playa he is not.

Cole doesn't have the Moët/ Moschino-hungry appetites of this most aspirational of working-class music scenes, turning up to work the wheels of steel at clubs in T-shirt and jeans before disappearing with his girlfriend on his old Gilera scooter back to his newly acquired one-bedroom flat in London N19. He only moved there from his parents' Twickenham home last February.

He may be able to command five-figure sums for a remix ("half the annual wage of an average person my age," he sheepishly reveals when pressed) and be invited to play - either as a DJ or with his band - everywhere from Los Angeles to Singapore, yet "larging it", flaunting his fiscal, not to mention physical, pulling power, is not his business. "I like ladies, certainly," he grins, admitting that he is "having wrangles" with his significant other about the number of foreign trips on which she should accompany him (she wants to come on them all). "But I'm not into buying flash cars. I'm more sensible than that." For Cole, the "ultimate thrill" comes when "people ring me up and say, 'Great tune.' "

It was Craig David, femme-friendly in the flesh and on record, who won the most rapturous response from the young crowd at this summer's Party in the Park festival, and it is the nattily dressed boy with the mellifluous vocals who sports a near-£1,000 Marco Valentino watch. But you'd be wrong to presume he's only in it for the dough and devotion, the money-man to MJ Cole's muso. As he insists, he is motivated purely by the desire to write and perform.

"More than meeting people and going out with girls, I'm focused on my music," he says during a break from filming in the Balearic Islands for MTV's Ibiza 2000. "Everything around me is surreal. I get picked up in cars and go to celebrity bashes and I get sponsorship on clothes, and it's great and I really enjoy it. But you should remember where it all started: the music. That's the key. As much as money is important for security, for me it is worth nothing without music." It is only when pushed for a third time about the possibilities opened up by his new-found wealth that David gets vexed. "I'm a music man," he insists, and you can almost hear him wince. "It's just music."

He doesn't yet need the proceeds from his three hit singles anyway - he still shares a home with his British mother (who split with Craig's father, a Grenadian, years ago), where he stays whenever he's not in the capital, or wherever else he's in demand these days. For the singer-songwriter being touted as our first ever decent crossover pop/R&B export, that's most places.

He likes going home. "I lie in bed," he confides, recalling Paul Whitehouse's character in The Fast Show who thinks everything is "brilliant!", "and I try and step out of my body for a second and think, 'Craig, what have you actually achieved?' And I say to myself, 'Craig, you're number one!' It's the maddest feeling ever. I don't know if I'm still dreaming. Because it is a dream having a number one."

David's lyrics on his debut album, Born to Do It, express a similarly quaint worldview, with the accent on courtship rather than copulation. "I want to make sure what I'm doing is correct," says David, virtuous where everyone around him has succumbed to vice, convinced that performing is "better than sex, definitely". "I want to represent myself right, and then hopefully somewhere down the line I'll meet the right person. My morals," he adds, "are family morals."

If his words are old-fashioned, the music on David's LP, produced in collaboration with Artful Dodger's Mark Hill, another Southampton boy, has the crisp efficiency and precision-tooled feel of the finest modern dance. It builds a bridge between the hypersyncopated approach of US beat scientists Timbaland (Missy Elliott, TLC) and Rodney Jerkins (Mya, Michael Jackson) and the jerky rhythms of UK garage. For a record like Rewind, with its shifting tempos, shattering glass FX and cries of "Bo! Selecta", to have sold over 750,000 copies in Britain alone is testament both to the general public's stomach for strangeness, and to the accessible/ experimental balance of the David/Hill partnership.

Sincere, which MJ Cole produced, engineered, sequenced and programmed (the electronic bits) as well as arranged (the parts with real live musicians), also suffers from a surfeit of love-cliches (many of them penned by vocalist Elisabeth Troy, who runs the gamut of soul diva tricks, lyrically and vocally). Cole looks forward to coming up with words for his second longplayer, which should be more abstract and poetic, based on his own thought processes.

With any luck, he will also bring to his next project everything he studied at university - granular synthesis, Stockhausen's esoteric sound-collages, and what he describes as "hardcore classical electronic music" - because Sincere does tend towards noodling proficiency and glossy immaculacy.

Cole, so sensitive to criticism that he leaves the collation of his press cuttings to his mum, is better placed than anyone to record the first avant-garage LP. "I've had to hold myself back," he says by way of assurance, mentioning just a couple of the projects he has in mind for next year: scoring film soundtracks and writing for string quartets. (The pizzicato violins sampled by Cole for Crazy Love are a highlight of the year, let alone of his album.)

Craig David, too, has plans for the future: "A collaboration with Britney Spears, man." He almost expires with excitement at the prospect, before heading off to chill by the pool. "That would blow people's minds."

 Sincere by MJ Cole is released by Talkin' Loud on August 7. Born To Do It by Craig David is released by Wildstar on August 14.

webTitle: Save me a place in the birthing pool

fields.headline: Save me a place in the birthing pool
fields.trailText: Ultrasoundings: I have often wondered if there were a point in pregnancy at which the biological audacity of the whole enterprise finally hit home - if there would be a moment when I'd look down at the curve of my pregnant belly and realise that there was only one, rather narrrow, way out.
fields.body:
Week 34
I have often wondered if there were a point in pregnancy at which the biological audacity of the whole enterprise finally hit home - if there would be a moment when I'd look down at the curve of my pregnant belly and realise that there was only one, rather narrrow, way out.

If there is, I haven't got there yet, though my bump is the weight of a large, curled-up cat and juts out like the stern of an oil tanker. Maybe my brain is shrinking, or perhaps I am flooded with protective hormones, but I am tranquillised, withdrawn and think about the birth only as a pleasant, distant event. My blood pressure is positively sluggish and I'm as drowsy as the dormouse in the teapot. I sleep a solid 10 hours at night, then fall into deep naps during the day. How women with full-time jobs or little children manage this bit of pregnancy, I have no idea. For me, though, now that I've accepted that my working day is very limited, it's rather blissful - like being on morphine.

I've got to try to focus, though, because I'm supposed to be writing my Birth Plan. It's included in my file of NHS notes and, according to its list of time-prompts, I should actually have filled it in last week. I feel bad - not because I'm afraid of doctors but because I know that the open file and the Birth Plan and all the different choices now available to me in the delivery suite are the result of feminist pressure from outside the medical profession and vigorous reform and scientific progress from inside, and that the least I can do is cooperate. Just like you should always vote, if only in memory of Emmeline Pankhurst.

But, like voting, a lot of the exciting politics have gone out of Birth Plans. I no longer have to write "I want to be active during birth" because, far from being strapped down or in stirrups, women giving birth in my hospital seem expected to stand, squat and jog round the room, occasionally pursued by midwives with hand-held monitors. Nor do I have to say "I shall be bringing my own partner, beanbag and birthing pool" because there's a pool already, the delivery suites are full of beanbags and my partner is not just expected but scheduled into hospital care.

The heat has even gone out of the drugs debate. Both I and the hospital want me to have a short, comfortable first stage of labour, then to have as much feeling and control as possible in the second, when I actually push the baby out, so as to avoid forceps, cuts and tearing. We both favour relaxation, gas and air or very light epidurals in order to achieve this. Only unpredictable individual physiology stands in the way of perfection.

My Birth Plan, in fact, seems in danger of being very short, something along the lines of: "I want to be sensible and hope it all doesn't hurt too much. And that there's no one in the birthing pool if I want to get in. Put a towel on the lounger for me."

More to the point, really, would be a Pre- and Post-Birth Plan, since these are the areas that have suffered most under NHS cuts. My Pre-Birth Plan would include being able to get to know my midwife - the local team is so reduced and under pressure that I've only met her twice. I'd like her to be paid more and to have her workload halved - it took me six weeks to get one appointment. Then she might be able to remember my name.

My Post-Birth Plan would involve resting, eating and being shown how to breastfeed in a calm, supportive environment. This is not possible in our maternity ward, not because it doesn't have baby-friendly policies - it does, in spades - but because there isn't the money to pay for more than one midwife per 12 mothers, decent food or even enough cleaners.

The restrictions of an old-fashioned maternity ward - babies being taken away at night, timetabled days - have gone but so have the comforts these brought, particularly the prospect of a night's sleep. The ward is so crowded that the best you can expect is four mothers and four babies in one small, hot room, while the unlucky may have a woman with pre-eclampsia or one being induced, adding her particular groans.

Of course, I can write on my Birth Plan: "And afterwards I want to leave ASAP" but this may not be possible and anyway, individual action is hardly the point. When it comes to birth, I think it's time to abandon beanbags, doctor-berating and single issue politics, and start talking gross national product, the NHS and much better funding.

fields.headline: Sidelines
fields.trailText: The trouble with Big Brother | Justice for Women
fields.body:
Oh brother! I swear I was going to ignore it but I just happened to be walking past the TV set and... The trouble with Big Brother, C4's 24-hour voyeur-fest, is that one gets so involved. Is that lovely Irish farm boy mixing all right? Is there a way of liking the older blonde woman that doesn't involve approving of her laugh? And what's Mel B doing there?

Sidelines is much exercised by resident yogi Sada, whose book, The Babes' Bible, is enjoying a flurry of early publicity. It gives a guide to 25 types of men, from City Suit to Joy Junkie (yes, please), rating them on fidelity, social skills and sexual prowess. Sidelines is, of course, outraged at this reduction of men to the sum of their parts. Men are, like little flowers, individuals, unique. On the other hand, there are only two types of women: the ones who think that lovely Irish boy should take over his parents' farm when they retire and the ones who think it might be character-building for him to explore the world, strike out on his own, even for a couple of months, just to ... (cont'd p94).

 Nominations for the Emma Humphreys Memorial Prize 2000 have opened. Emma, who died in 1998, successfully appealed against a murder conviction in a case that helped change the law on provocation for battered women who kill. The prize, of £1,000, will go to a woman or group who has raised awareness of violence against women and children. Deadline for nominations is September 30 2000. For details, call Justice for Women, 020-8374 2948; email justiceforwomen@easynet.co.uk

A strapline across the top of our front page yesterday mentioned Long Kesh (the Maze) and then referred to "the last days of Britain's most notorious prison". The Maze is in Northern Ireland. fields.headline: Wordplay
fields.trailText: The prime minister did not use the words "easier" or "ride", despite your claim that "he declared that Labour would have an easier ride at the next election" (Blair sees easy win for Labour, July 24).
fields.body:
The prime minister did not use the words "easier" or "ride", despite your claim that "he declared that Labour would have an easier ride at the next election" (Blair sees easy win for Labour, July 24). His actual words (which refer to the government's successful management of the economy, and which you report accurately) were: "I think we are in a stronger position, because in 1997 we were having to say to people we are just going to have to be very cautious and very responsible. We can now say to people we have proved our responsibility."

Turning this into "Blair sees easy win" suggests that he is complacent about winning the next election, and taking the views of the electorate for granted. He does not.

Alastair Campbell
10 Downing Street

fields.headline: Jail house shock
fields.standfirst: A new survey shows the number of girls sent to prison is rocketing.  Diane Taylor  finds out why and reports on what life is like for young women within those walls
fields.trailText: A new survey shows the number of girls sent to prison is rocketing.  Diane Taylor  finds out why and reports on what life is like for young women within those walls
fields.body:
The road to Bullwood Hall Prison wouldn't look out of place in an ad for the English Tourist Board. Roses clamber up the sides of cottages, birds chirp contentedly. But a few hundred yards before the prison gates, the cottages peter out and everything becomes grey steel. Behind these gates is an increasing number of young women and while all yearn for a life beyond the prison walls, many believe their freedom won't last.

Angel Baker, 18, sits scrubbed and bright-eyed in the meeting room at Bullwood Hall. She is serving 18 months for supplying crack cocaine and is proud that she did her cluck (detox) without any support. She is hoping to stay crime-free but says she can't rule out a return. "It's so common now for girls like me to go to prison that it's like a fashion statement. It's not what clothes you're wearing but what prison you've been in."

According to a new survey by the Howard League for Penal Reform, the number of girls sent to prison rose by 382% between 1992 and 1998, despite the rate of offending by girls aged 15-17 falling by a quarter. In 1998, 302 girls were sent to prison compared with 79 in 1992, yet the number cautioned or found guilty fell from 2,183 girls per 100,000 of the population in 1992 to 1,632 in 1998.

The number of girls being imprisoned is rising despite a pledge from home secretary Jack Straw that from April, 15- and 16-year-old female offenders would no longer be sent to prison. The Howard League argued that placing girls in adult prisons, where drugs were widely available and bullying rife, breached the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child. But while the prison service has tried to improve provision for girls, with special facilities for them in most of the country's 10 women's prisons, some still end up in the adult system.

Clinical psychologist Kathleen Cox of Cox Associates, a firm of expert witnesses who make assessments of young offenders, believes more girls are getting sent to jail and for longer because judges and magistrates consider their behaviour "unladylike". "Have any of these people actually been to prison or seen what happens to girls after they come out?" Cox asks. "Some of these girls have physical problems such as poor eyesight or learning difficulties - it would be more useful to sentence them to wearing glasses or learning to read. The punishment should not fit the crime, it should fit the criminal. Let's face it, none of these girls is going to go into jail as a caterpillar and emerge as a butterfly. They don't call prison the university of crime for nothing."

Baker believes prison can damage teenagers because it normalises crime and punishment. "In prison you have to make yourself look big and be one step ahead. Sometimes the women look after the younger girls, but the way some of them talk about drugs and crime makes the younger ones think what they've done is OK. Something has gone really wrong with some of the girls in here. Some have babies but they don't talk about them or have photos - they'd rather talk about drugs. I don't want to go back to selling crack when I get out of here, but I would have a much better idea how to do it without getting caught. We compare notes on our crimes every day."

In prison, Baker has had a chance to reassess her upbringing and sort out her troubled relationship with her mother: "I grew up in a violent home and never used to get on with my mum, but since I've been in here, we have sorted a lot of things out." But not everyone reacts to incarceration in the same way. "One friend has already asked the gardener if she can have her old job back next time she comes in. Another was taught how to 'wash' cocaine to turn it into crack. She was really excited about getting out so she could practise her new skill."

Billy Simmonds, 18, who is serving 14 months for actual bodily harm, theft and arson, believes she'll continue to commit crime because that is what she has always done. "I'd like to get a good job but there's nothing out there. My family say they'll disown me if I reoffend, but I don't think that will stop me."

Perhaps most worrying of all is the lack of shame attached to being in prison. Mamalyn Gordon, 41, who is serving nine years for importing cocaine, acts as unofficial counsellor to some of the girls. "They have lost respect for themselves and for others," she says. "A lot lack a mother in their lives and they talk to me about their problems. The younger girls can be bullied by the older women, made to hand over cash sent by their parents or forced into lesbian relationships."

In the vacuum that Simmonds says is a feature of many of these girls' lives, being like the bad boys is one thing they have to aspire to. "If a boy can steal a car, there's no reason why we shouldn't. A crime with a lot of status would be something like armed robbery which is traditionally a male crime. That would be really daring."

Tara Fell, now 20, was 16 when she was sent to Holloway for killing her violent live-in boyfriend. She was freed on appeal but believes she and society would have been better served had she been given probation from the start. "Prison is definitely not the best place for a young girl. I saw so many 'good' girls who'd committed minor offences like stealing clothes, but by the time they left they felt big because they had served a sentence."

She believes a more sensible solution would be to tag girls and offer probation groups where they could talk things through. "A lot of these girls don't realise that if you throw a stone into the water, it makes ripples. They need to be made to see that."

Chris Tchaikovsky of campaigning group Women In Prison says it is up to policy-makers to change the system. "If they reduce the problems of the girls committing the crimes, they will reduce the crimes. These girls have had a hell of a life before they come to court. It's like taking a sledgehammer to crack not a nut but a piece of jelly. You can't have girls kicked and abused all through their young lives and not expect them to kick back."

Angel Baker remains hopeful that the positive bits of her experience of prison will outweigh the negative and stop her returning. "All I want when I get out is a place I can call my own, a hairdressing and beauty job, and to surround myself with friends. I just want a nice, bright life like everyone else gets the chance to live."

webTitle: London still takes the lion's share of arts funding

fields.headline: London still takes the lion's share of arts funding
fields.trailText: Your latest manifesto (Making money count in the arts and sport, July 24) showed the usual metropolitan outlook in diagnosing the problems in developing theatre and concert attendance.
fields.body:
Your latest manifesto (Making money count in the arts and sport, July 24) showed the usual metropolitan outlook in diagnosing the problems in developing theatre and concert attendance. A policy of selling off unsold seats cheaply to increase uptake from 70% might work in London, where there is a network of public transport, but attending any cultural event in the regions requires planning and almost always your own transport.

What regional theatre and concert halls there are exist in a few regional centres. Theatre in particular has almost completely lost its function of relating to and serving the needs of a community. A more imaginative and ultimately more workable initiative would be to look at ways of creating and sustaining a network of small-to-medium-scale professional theatre companies to work at a local level providing artistic and educational access.

Phil Hyde
Grimsby
phil.hyde@btinternet.com

 While I agree that the Lion King is a great piece of theatre, I cannot agree that paying for every child in the country to see it is a good idea.

The cost of a ticket to the Lion King would pay for two or three visits to a local theatre. Although 20 years of cuts and underfunding have ruined the network of regional producing theatres there is theatrical life outside the West End. Those that have survived are in greater need of support than a multinational media conglomerate. Any second-term arts policy should have at its heart the preservation and growth of regional producing theatre.

Ian Teague
London
mail@ianteague.free-online.co.uk

 Like Gordon Brown's spending review statement, your piece on arts spending confines its priorities for museums to the issue of free admission to the government-sponsored national museums.

It is to be hoped that this does not reflect a lack of interest in the other 1,400 or so public museums in England. These institutions, whether run by local authorities, charities or higher education institutions, have an important role in helping to deliver the government's agenda, particularly in the fields of education and social inclusion. However, the resources at their disposal are limited, and the only support network available to them - area museum councils - has had its government funding reduced by 20% over the past five years.

In most of the Department of Culture, Media and Sports sectors there is a balanced approach to funding between national, regional and local provision. In the museum sector, however, less than 10% of DCMS total expenditure on museums and galleries is directed towards support for regional museums.

Rosemary Ewles
Secretary Committee of Area Museums Councils
rjewles@pavilion.co.uk

fields.headline: Our remedies for health
fields.trailText: Madeleine Bunting's piece (Faith healing, July 24) is the most sensible commentary on the NHS I have read. We await, with a mixture of anticipation and trepidation, the details of the National Plan, but is all the effort really necessary or largely a distraction?
fields.body:
Madeleine Bunting's piece (Faith healing, July 24) is the most sensible commentary on the NHS I have read. We await, with a mixture of anticipation and trepidation, the details of the National Plan, but is all the effort really necessary or largely a distraction?

We are promised the most radical shakeup since 1948. But haven't we already got the answer to most of these problems in the belated recognition that for decades the service has been struggling with grossly inadequate staffing levels and funding that was slipping further and further behind other comparable countries?

Having guaranteed the funds, government should now stand back and let us get on and use them effectively for the benefit of patients. It has already put new monitoring systems in place to ensure that we do. Any more could be counter-productive.

Peter Fisher
President,
NHS Consultants' Association
nhsca@pop3.poptel.org.uk

 The new NHS plan may see patients as consumers, but we are all people first; we do not necessarily want to be patients at all. Promoting the health of the public requires action to improve employment, education and environment, and to redistribute wealth and income.

Prevention and cure, health and health services, all should be seen as public concerns, not private consumption.

John Nicholson
Chief executive,
UK Public Health Association
john@ukpha.org.uk

fields.headline: More bones to pick
fields.trailText: While I agree with what Larry Elliot says (Economics, July 24) about the state of the G8 and also recognise what an enormous service Marshall and Truman did for Europe, it should not be forgotten that their mistrust of communism has most of the old Warsaw pact countries still suffering terrible poverty today.
fields.body:
While I agree with what Larry Elliot says (Economics, July 24) about the state of the G8 and also recognise what an enormous service Marshall and Truman did for Europe, it should not be forgotten that their mistrust of communism has most of the old Warsaw pact countries still suffering terrible poverty today.

Simon Bailey
London

 If the G8 nations cannot bring themselves to cancel the debts of less-developed countries, perhaps they can use this debt-money - all of it - to benefit the countries paying it. It should go back to meet immediate needs (food, medicines) and medium-term investment (education, health).

George Hext
Addlestone, Surrey

 With respect to New Labour's "contaminated brand", I've done enough work in marketing to know that they need to add value and differentiate themselves from the opposition. "New (improved) Labour... now with added billions!" might prove effective. Sadly, as with a lot of products on the market, there is very little difference between the choices on offer other than the colour of the box.

Ellesmere Port
pauljamespalmer@netscapeonline.co.uk

 I was intrigued by the reference to herringbone corsets (The fine art of fashion, July 21). Were these designed for ladies requiring lighter control than the traditional whalebone corset or was this just another Guardian red herring?

Amersham, Bucks

 If the term "whip abuse" (Sport, July 24) were to be replaced by "horse abuse" then, at a stroke, "language abuse" would also be diminished.

Tiverton, Devon
ivora@totalise.co.uk

fields.headline: They're killing off asylum
fields.trailText: The additional money for the Home Office to clear the asylum decision backlog and vastly increase removals from the UK may do more than "kill off asylum as a politically damaging issue" for New Labour (£600m to end asylum backlog, July 24).
fields.body:
The additional money for the Home Office to clear the asylum decision backlog and vastly increase removals from the UK may do more than "kill off asylum as a politically damaging issue" for New Labour (£600m to end asylum backlog, July 24).

The government is doing more than its predecessors to kill off the right to asylum itself. In seeking to remove a staggering 30,000 people from the UK in 2001/2002, many more people will be sent back to regimes which carry out the most appalling abuses of human rights.

Sri Lanka is but one example. A new Medical Foundation report based on the examination of 49 Tamils found that "each had been kicked, punched and hit with heavy objects... two thirds had suffered cuts from knives, bayonets or burns. More than half had been suspended upside down, beaten or made to inhale noxious fumes. About a quarter were semi-suffocated with plastic bags and about a quarter suffered sexual abuse, including rape."

Home Offices figures show that in May some 760 decisions were made on Sri Lankan asylum applications. Of these 640 (84%) were refusals. Tony Blair thinks that the public see him as "soft" on asylum. Yet the only conclusion one can draw is that New Labour is prepared to deport thousands of vulnerable people and torture survivors providing it appeases the Daily Mail and gets votes in middle England.

Bill Bolloten
London
bb@elcamino.demon.co.uk

 At last the Home Office appears to be admitting that there can be "legitimate desires to migrate" to Britain (Migrants with skills may be welcomed, July 22). However, welcoming new migrants with specialist skills will make little sense while the government continues its punitive attitude towards refugees and asylum seekers who are already here. Many have skills and qualifications in areas of skills shortages - doctors, nurses, teachers, engineering and IT specialists to name a few.

Rather than being encouraged to use their skills, refugees and asylum seekers face barriers designed to exclude them from employment. Asylum seekers are forbidden to work for the first six months of their claim. Even after this it is difficult for them to get documentation that will convince an employer that they have the right to work.

In a spirit of "joined up thinking" it would be sensible if the government sorted these issues out so that Britain can benefit from the talents that are already here.

Andy Gregg
Director,
Refugee Education and Training Advisory Service

 The immigration minister, Barbara Roche, now accepts the great benefits which flow from human migration. Although this rather conflicts with the tough talk of "abuse" and "control" it is to be welcomed.

Given the new thinking it is time for the government to abandon the attacks on the 1951 Refugee Convention. This is a precise legal instrument which can aid refugee protection and accommodate the legitimate concerns of states. With political will and proper investment it can work.

The government should make sure that it does.

Dr Colin J Harvey
Human Rights Centre
Queen's University of Belfast
c.harvey@qub.ac.uk

 A change in government attitudes on asylum and immigration is certainly needed, but it seems to me that we would only further impoverish already desperately poor countries by poaching their skilled labour.

Noel Hannon
London
noel@hannon34.fsnet.co.uk

Yet the only conclusion one can draw is that New Labour is prepared to deport thousands of vulnerable people and torture survivors providing it appeases the Daily Mail and gets votes in middle England. However, welcoming new migrants with specialist skills will make little sense while the government continues its punitive attitude towards refugees and asylum seekers who are already here. Many have skills and qualifications in areas of skills shortages - doctors, nurses, teachers, engineering and IT specialists to name a few. Rather than being encouraged to use their skills, refugees and asylum seekers face barriers designed to exclude them from employment. Asylum seekers are forbidden to work for the first six months of their claim. Even after this it is difficult for them to get documentation that will convince an employer that they have the right to work. In a spirit of "joined up thinking" it would be sensible if the government sorted these issues out so that Britain can benefit from the talents that are already here. Although this rather conflicts with the tough talk of "abuse" and "control" it is to be welcomed. Given the new thinking it is time for the government to abandon the attacks on the 1951 Refugee Convention. This is a precise legal instrument which can aid refugee protection and accommodate the legitimate concerns of states. With political will and proper investment it can work. The government should make sure that it does. fields.headline: New names in the frame
fields.trailText: The naming by the News of the World of 49 convicted paedophiles (Tabloid's naming of paedophiles condemned by police chief, July 24), which was branded grossly irresponsible by Nacro, is in fact entirely the opposite.
fields.body:
The naming by the News of the World of 49 convicted paedophiles (Tabloid's naming of paedophiles condemned by police chief, July 24), which was branded grossly irresponsible by Nacro, is in fact entirely the opposite.

It is said that it drives sex offenders underground, making them harder to track and increasing the risk to children; but children are already at risk by unwittingly living alongside sex offenders without even knowing it. Children need to be protected, and their parents have a right to information which will enable them to protect them.

This whole problem comes about because we insist on seeing sex offenders as criminals to be punished rather than psychiatric patients to be treated - and the horror of that approach is that we have to release sex offenders back into the community at the end of their prison sentence despite what might be a catalogue of evidence asserting they will quickly reoffend.

Mark Leech
Chief executive, Unlock, the national association of ex-offenders

 Is the News of the World likely to name and shame the irresponsible drivers who have killed and seriously injured so many thousands of children each year? For there lies the greatest threat to children.

Ted Prangnell
Ashford, Kent
ted@tprangnell.freeserve.co.uk

 Will the Guardian publish photographs of irresponsible editors? Personally, I would be very distressed if the editor of the News of the World moved to Milton Keynes.

Richard Skellington
Milton Keynes
R.S.Skellington@open.ac.uk

webTitle: Leader: A vegetarian gets food for thought

fields.headline: When meat matters
fields.standfirst: A vegetarian gets food for thought
fields.trailText: For many she was less a politician than a punchline for a political joke. Like a foreign secretary without a passport or a transport minister unable to drive a car, Christine Gwyther was the Welsh agriculture secretary whose great misfortune was to be a vegetarian.
fields.body:
For many she was less a politician than a punchline for a political joke. Like a foreign secretary without a passport or a transport minister unable to drive a car, Christine Gwyther was the Welsh agriculture secretary whose great misfortune was to be a vegetarian. There are doubtless some countries where to be a non-meat-eating farming minister would present few problems. India, land of the lentil dahl, would probably be only too receptive to a herbivorous agriculture secretary. The trendier districts of California would surely warm to an abstainer from red-meat. But not Wales. There are too many rearers of livestock, too much reliance on lamb, for the Welsh to put their countryside in the hands of a woman who has not consumed so much as a morsel of meat in 20 years.

So they had it in for Ms Gwyther from the moment she took office last year, as part of Alun Michael's founding devolved Welsh administration. She had survived the departure of Mr Michael, but Wales's new boss, Rhodri Morgan, showed her the door. Now she can spend more time with her lettuce.

Perhaps she did not help her cause by dismissing so casually the producers of the vile, bloody flesh she so despised. Last month she told the Welsh assembly that farming's contribution to the nation's economy was "close to zero." Even if that's true, it was not quite the sentiment Wales's farmers were expecting to hear from their agriculture secretary. Stephen Byers does not often announce the demise of British trade and industry; Chris Smith does not boast of the irrelevance of culture, media and sport.

So the lesson for Ms Gwyther's successor, Carwyn Jones, is clear enough. He can say what he likes about the detail of policy, but first he ought to insist that agriculture - and therefore his own job - matters. Then he ought to tuck into a plate of prime, tender and, above all, Welsh lamb: with a side-order of beef, just to make sure.

webTitle: Leader: Wal-Mart opens first store in Britain

fields.headline: Wal-Mart stakes its claim
fields.standfirst: The consumer will be the last to complain
fields.trailText: It is, as critics are quick to point out, the biggest seller of guns in America, yet Hillary Clinton was on its board of directors for eight years. It is hailed everywhere as the consumer's friend yet attacked equally as a destroyer of local communities.
fields.body:
It is, as critics are quick to point out, the biggest seller of guns in America, yet Hillary Clinton was on its board of directors for eight years. It is hailed everywhere as the consumer's friend yet attacked equally as a destroyer of local communities. Wal-Mart, which opened its first new UK store in Bristol yesterday, is nothing if not a culture shock. It is difficult to recall any overseas company since McDonald's generating such a fierce debate about its impact on the British way of life. In the US criticism has centred not on its fiercely anti-union employment policies (it pays bargain basement wages) but on the way it is alleged to have forced the closure of local shops by luring consumers into gigantic out-of-town centres where its awesome buying power and grinding operational efficiency enable it to undercut all of the local competition. Shopkeepers have complained that Wal-Mart can sell goods at prices lower than small shops can buy wholesale. Hardly fair competition.

In Britain, the reaction is one of relief tinged with fear. There will be relief among consumers that the supermarkets and high street retailers will at last face serious competition to bring down the unacceptably high prices they have been charging relative to comparable prices in Europe. There could be macro-economic benefits as well: the government will be relieved that Wal-Mart will single-handedly exert a downward pressure on the retail prices index that could trigger ripple effects throughout the country. But there are also fears that a short-term fall in prices may bring longer term damage as the US giant - the biggest retailer in the world - uses its massive clout and legal nous to build more shopping centres out of town despite the change of policy against building on greenfield sites.

Wal-Mart probably won't engender quite the sort of opposition it did in the US among environmentalists - although not, of course, among consumers, who flocked to its stores. This is simply because Britain has already lost so many of its local butchers, bakers and speciality stores to the onward march of the supermarkets. It is those superstores which have most to lose. They will be forced to match the lower prices of Wal-Mart without having the global purchasing power it has to negotiate lower prices from suppliers. Critics claim that once Wal-Mart has seen the competition off it will raise prices, like most monopolies. If there is a danger from that direction, it is some way into the future and beyond the time-horizons of most politicians. What the UK's supermarkets and sellers of consumer goods (not to mention car showrooms) ought to be asking themselves is why they allowed such a market opportunity to happen. If they hadn't kept their prices so high then the UK wouldn't have been quite such an attractive market for Wal-Mart to target. They have no one but themselves to blame.

What must be resisted strongly is any move by Wal-Mart to pressurise governments or local authorities to bend the rules in favour of building more out-of-town centres that despoil the countryside and encourage the unnecessary use of cars and fuel. That argument has been won and must stay won. Wal-Mart may not need to - it has been testing "neighbourhood stores" in the US of 50,000 square feet or less which are barely a quarter of the size of its out-of-town stores. This approach marches in step with the new planning zeitgeist in the UK. Meanwhile, the Office of Fair Trading should be asking itself a serious question: why has it taken the arrival of an American corporation to bring about the competition it was supposed to engineer?

webTitle: Loss of duty-free takes toll on Eurotunnel

fields.headline: Loss of duty-free takes toll on Eurotunnel
fields.trailText: Abolition of duty-free yesterday helped push Eurotunnel, operator of the Channel tunnel, into a £78m net loss for the first half of this year.
fields.body:
Abolition of duty-free yesterday helped push Eurotunnel, operator of the Channel tunnel, into a £78m net loss for the first half of this year.

A 72% fall in retail sales to £26m and declining passenger numbers lay at the heart of the group loss. However, the £51m net profit posted last time was flattered by one-off gains from financial restructuring.

Passenger numbers on Le Shuttle, the service for motorists, fell by a fifth in the six months to June and vehicle numbers were down by more than 300,000.

Eurotunnel offset some of the impact by increasing fares. Revenue from the Shuttle service was up by 29% through growth of freight traffic and higher average prices for cars and buses.

In the first half, 540,000 lorries used the Shuttle service, 42% up on the same period last year. Eurotunnel's share of the cross-Channel freight vehicle market rose from 37% to 47%.

Revenue from Eurostar and freight companies rose by 2% to £104m and Eurotunnel's overall operating revenues were down only 10% from £309m to £277m.

The chairman, Patrick Ponsolle, insisted the overall financial performance was in line with expectations. Eurotunnel would still meet its objectives of covering all interest and investment costs from operating cash flow by 2002.

In a letter to shareholders accompanying the results statement he said the stock price would "sooner or later reflect the scale and speed of our recovery and our ability to bring lasting growth to our profitability".

Falling traffic level has led to legal action by the tunnel's retail operator, BAA. A spokesman for Eurotunnel said this case would be strongly defended.

Eurotunnel has improved its overall financial position by increasing the operating profit and stabilising interest payments. There was an 18% reduction in the underlying loss to £75m from £92m last time.

Financial operations in the first half were restricted to a small debt repurchase and a leasing operation in Britain which led to an exceptional profit of £4m.

Mr Ponsolle said: "A year ago I told you we expected that the cross-Channel market would go through a 12- to 18-month period of adjustment following the abolition of duty-free. Against that difficult background the success of our strategy to compensate for the loss of duty-free has been very encouraging."

Analysts said the company still needed to repair weaknesses in its balance sheet to revive the share price.

webTitle: BP rebrands on a global scale

fields.headline: BP rebrands on a global scale
fields.standfirst: Oil group seeks to go green
fields.trailText: BP Amoco yesterday sought to ditch its image as an old-fashioned oil group and rebrand itself as an environmentally-aware energy and general services company.
fields.body:
BP Amoco yesterday sought to ditch its image as an old-fashioned oil group and rebrand itself as an environmentally-aware energy and general services company.

Chairman Sir John Browne said the new so-called sunburst label would be used to launch a range of new BP Connect convenience stores on all major petrol forecourts in an attempt to increase retail sales by more than 10% per annum.

The BP Amoco name will be shortened to BP as the group moves to a single brand after the $120bn (£79bn) series of acquisitions over the last two years that took in Amoco, Arco and Burmah Castrol.

The brand change has cost $7m and BP plans to spend a further $100m a year developing it. Sir John said BP would in future stand for "beyond pe troleum" rather than British Petroleum. Its 28,000 petrol stations around the world will be modernised over four years, but 3,000 jobs will be lost as overlapping BP and Amoco sites are shut down.

Named the Helios mark after the Greek sun god, the new logo signifies dynamic energy in all its forms from oil to gas and solar, said Sir John.

But he admitted it would allow BP to expand its brand into other retail areas beyond its traditional energy fields. The company will start with its general shops, which will sell everything from baked beans to washing powder.

"We are not an oil company. 40% of our hydrocarbon production comes from natural gas. We are aware the world wants less carbon-intensive fuels. What we want to do is create options," he explained.

But the relaunch was met with cynicism by green cam paigners. Rob Gueterbock, a climate energy speciliast at Greenpeace, said the company's move was a triumph of style over substance.

"They spent more on the logo this year than they did on renewable energy last year. Given they spend $8bn a year on oil exploration, BP stands less for beyond petroleum and more for burning the planet," he said.

The first of the new retail sites will be opened in London later this year. BP Connect stores will feature in-store e-kiosks where customers can check weather and traffic conditions, pay and call up directions to local destinations.

While filling their tanks, motorists will be able to use a touch-screen monitor to order sandwiches, pastries and snacks. The screens will also be used to offer sports scores and latest news.

BP also plans to underline its new renewable energy commitment by using solar energy to power the new sites, with panels forming the transparent canopy above the pumps.

Sir John added: "We expect the move to a global brand and introduction of state of the art retailing sites to bring a significant increase in sales."

He said it was important to strengthen the sense of identity and common purpose of the company's 100,000 employees who work in more than 100 countries around the world. He added that BP was having no problem recruiting staff, despite falling unemployment levels in the United States and Britain.

fields.headline: Biotech chief in hasty exit
fields.standfirst: Move raises fears of boardroom clash
fields.trailText: The finance director of Oxford Glycosciences, Paul Triniman, has abruptly quit after five years with the high-flying biotechnology company.
fields.body:
The finance director of Oxford Glycosciences, Paul Triniman, has abruptly quit after five years with the high-flying biotechnology company.

Mr Triniman, 39, who was on holiday in France yesterday, is likely to leave without serving his 12-month notice period. He will take with him share options worth more than £3m and is likely to receive about £170,000 in compensation for loss of office.

Mr Triniman's departure created fears of a boardroom battle with the group's autocratic chief executive, Michael Kranda.

However, a spokesman said: "Paul thinks he's at his best when he's working for businesses which are about to float or have just floated on the stock market. There are a number of biotech companies out there which are just limbering up for a a flotation. He's decided to progress his career elsewhere."

Oxford Glycosciences develops drugs based on proteins. It has benefited from enthusiasm about the mapping of the human genome, which has led to advances in knowledge about the way genes govern protein production in the body. Its shares have risen 19-fold in the last two years and the group is valued at £750m.

Mr Kranda is considered the driving force behind the company and is known to domi nate the boardroom. The company has just one other executive director, research chief Raj Parekh.

Mr Triniman does not have another job lined up. A qualified accountant, he joined Oxford Glycosciences after a spell with another drugs company, Life Sciences International.

 Evotec Biosys is in talks to buy Oxford Assymetry in what would be the first purchase of a British firm by a German biotechnology company, industry sources said yesterday.

Oxford Assymetry announced last week it was in talks with an unnamed party which could lead to an offer. The suitor is said to be Evotec, listed on Germany's Neuer Markt.

fields.headline: First buyer for super-airbus
fields.standfirst: British aero-industry stands to gain 22,000 jobs in constructing new plane
fields.trailText: British aero-industry stands to gain 22,000 jobs in constructing new plane
fields.body:
A fabulously wealthy sheikh yesterday pledged £1bn of his fortune to a new 575-passenger superjumbo aircraft which will create 22,000 jobs in Britain.

Ahmed bin Saeed Al-Maktoum signed a firm commitment at Farnborough air show for five passenger versions and two freighter versions of the double-decker Airbus A3XX. The sheikh, a member of the ruling clan of the United Arab Emirates, chairs the Dubai-based Emirates - which is to take delivery of the passenger versions in February 2006.

Heathrow has been earmarked as the first airport to receive the inaugural flight of the A3XX - pencilled in to be be a six-and-a-half hour jaunt between Dubai and London.

Yesterday's deal was signed at Farnborough by Sheikh Al-Maktoum, and Airbus's chief executive, Noel Forgeard.

Minutes after the announcement, Air France said that it had signed a letter of intent with Airbus for 10 3XXs. The airline's president, Jean-Cyril Spinetta, said that the projected growth in air traffic and the "extremely environmentally friendly" potential of the aircraft convinced Air France that the A3XX was "ideally suited to the evolving needs of the 21st century".

Stunned by the Airbus initiative, the rival Boeing plane builder retorted that the A3XX concept would not work. Randy Baseler, a senior marketing director, said that big airports like Heathrow did not need large aircraft. They wanted improved frequencies, new non-stop markets and smaller aircraft.

Boeing will produce a stretched version of its 747 jumbo to accommodate up to 522 passengers, but that is its limit. In a clear move to outshine Airbus, it said that it had obtained orders for 180 commercial jets valued at £7bn.

However experts say the size of the A3XX gives it an added versatility over other jumbos. Emirates is expected to equip the A3XX with a crèche and a sleeping area for travellers.

Other airlines, notably Virgin Atlantic, chaired by Sir Richard Branson, are considering bigger plans. Virgin has taken options on six 3XXs, and its eye-catching options include Jacuzzis and cinemas. Sir Richard has indicated that he might install double beds on long-distance flights to Asia and the west coast of the US.

The development of the A3XX could create about 22,000 direct and indirect jobs for workers in North Wales, Bristol and Scotland. BaE Systems, formerly British Aerospace, one of the four European partners in Airbus, has a 20% share in the business and will build the wings - despite a quarrel between the British company and Airbus shareholders.

webTitle: Smart missiles to replace RAF's dumb bombs

fields.headline: Smart missiles to replace RAF's dumb bombs
fields.trailText: The RAF is to invest in "smart" weapons to replace the cluster bombs used in the Kosovo war, Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, announced yesterday.
fields.body:
The RAF is to invest in "smart" weapons to replace the cluster bombs used in the Kosovo war, Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, announced yesterday.

In a statement to the Commons which left unanswered many questions about the inadequacy of defence equipment, he told MPs that the government would equip the RAF's Harrier jets with the more accurate US Maverick missile.

All-weather satellite-guided weapons would be fitted to Tornados to replace "dumb" bombs, whose use was limited in the Kosovo war because of cloud cover. However, the ministry has yet to decide whether the replacement will be a British or US weapon.

It is unclear whether the MoD still intends to buy a new British-designed bomb, codenamed Brimstone, which is nearly 10 years late and on which the ministry has spent more than £600m in development costs.

A ministry spokesman said yesterday that Brimstone was designed to attack "mass armoured targets".

Unexploded "bomblets" from cluster weapons dropped from British and US aircraft have subsequently killed a number of people in Kosovo, including two British soldiers, and maimed others.

The new bombs, and a more secure air-to-air communication system, will be paid for out of a one-off £200m the ministry extracted from the Treasury this year.

The ministry has already announced that it will spend £80m modifying 200,000 of the army's standard SA80 rifles and machine guns.

It was disclosed yesterday that Brigadier Seymour Monro, the most senior infantry officer, had demanded the immediate replacement of the light machine gun version of the SA80 after criticism of its performance in Kosovo; he asked that units serving in Kosovo should be given a new gun as an "urgent operational requirement".

Ever since the 1991 Gulf war, soldiers have complained of the SA80's tendency to jam and the constant need to reload. The army would like to replace the gun with belt-fed weapons of the kind used by the US army as well as the SAS.

Mr Hoon yesterday also confirmed that, despite strong opposition from government scientists, the bulk of ministry's defence evaluation and research agency would be privatised.

The ministry has been promised £250m from the proceeds, with the Treasury taking the rest of the profit from the sale.

Some 9,000 scientists will work for a new private company, with about 3,000 retained in a ministry-owned rump that will include the chemical and biological research establishment at Porton Down.

The split is designed to appease the US, which is concerned about passing secret research to a private company.

The ministry yesterday conceded that military research scientists in the US remained concerned, though it said the US government was satisfied with the new arrangement.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.body:
Universities rethink urged

Universities could become "playgrounds for the children of the rich" unless the government takes preventive action, the Association of University Teachers warned yesterday.

Ministers should invest in training for admissions tutors and research admissions policy, the AUT told the Commons education sub-committee.

Two held over Cyprus stabbing

Two Britons were remanded in custody by a Cyprus court yesterday on suspicion of attempted murder after a British tourist, Andrew Gray, 35, was stabbed during a beach party in the resort of Ayia Napa on Saturday. The two men, Jason Pinder, 29, and Cofi Achah, 21, both from London, were arrested at Larnaca airport.

Boy, 10, died at dentist

A 10-year-old boy suffered a cardiac arrest during routine dental surgery to have a tooth removed, a General Dental Council disciplinary hearing was told yesterday.

Darren Denholm, of Armadale, West Lothian, could not be resuscitated, the hearing was told.

Child porn 'downloaded'

The head of a police force's communications department secretly downloaded hundreds of pornographic images of children from the internet on to his office computer, Newcastle crown court heard yesterday.

Alan Coates, 52, manager at Cleveland police headquarters, was allegedly caught after a routine check when he was out of the country. He denied 15 charges of making indecent photographs of a child.

webTitle: US style 'shock jocks' turn off radio listeners in Britain, say watchdogs

fields.headline: US style 'shock jocks' turn off radio listeners in Britain, say watchdogs
fields.trailText: Radio shock jocks have become an institution in the United States, but their confrontational style is proving a turn-off for British listeners.
fields.body:
Radio shock jocks have become an institution in the United States, but their confrontational style is proving a turn-off for British listeners.

Research conducted by radio watchdogs has found mounting concern about the treatment meted out to unsuspecting callers by over-zealous presenters.

Listeners are annoyed by phone-in hosts who appear to encourage controversy simply to boost ratings, and two-thirds told researchers that they switch off or re-tune if they hear something offensive.

The report, published yesterday by the broadcasting standards commission and the radio authority, will raise concerns in the industry, which has become increasingly reliant on phone-ins to fill airtime as the number of stations has shot up. Speech-based broadcasters such as Radio 5 Live and Talksport encourage listener participation.

The radio authority warned programme-makers to take note of the research: yesterday, Nicky Campbell, one of Britain's foremost phone-in presenters, apologised on his Radio 5 Live show for appearing to suggest, during a discussion last year, that Sky News programmes were inaccurate and biased.

Of almost 2,000 people who returned a detailed questionnaire, 40% said they had been offended by something they had heard on the radio. Of these, two-thirds said they had either switched off or tuned to another station. Poor treatment of callers, foul language and racism were the principal concerns.

Martin Campbell, director of programming and advertising at the radio authority, said: "The thread of the research is that people do not want to see radio abused by its presenters."

The researchers asked a sample group to listen to examples of phone-ins, including two discussions which re sulted in heavy fines from the radio authority last year. The participants were surprised that a discussion about rape on London-based Xfm and another about bestiality on Hallam FM in Sheffield had ever made it to air. Both stations were fined the maximum £50,000 for serious breaches of the Broadcasting Act and warned that any repeat of the offence could result in removal of their licences.

Listeners did not object to difficult subjects being discussed, but were concerned about how they were handled. A woman said of the Hallam clip: "If someone was raped and wants to talk about how it affected them and they're taking it seriously, the presenters are taking it seriously, that's fair enough. But in that context... it is totally unacceptable."

There were also concerns about bad language, following recent controversies surrounding high profile radio DJs such as Chris Evans and Zoe Ball. In November 1998, Ball was disciplined by the BBC for using a four-letter word. She was later criticised for reciting a version of Mary Had a Little Lamb incorporating sexual innuendo.

Parents were particularly concerned about what children may hear on the radio - more than half were worried about their children hearing swear words or sexual comments during the "school run". Most believe more should be done to stop adult subjects being covered at times when children are likely to be listening, and 85% say swearing should be banned during the day.

A youth from Southampton, quoted in the report, said: "One of the little kids at play school was saying 'bitch, bitch, bitch' and he called his mum a bitch, which he has never ever done again. Kids do pick up these words even if they don't know what they mean."

A mother from London, said she had faced the embarrassment of explaining a sexual term to her child after it was mentioned on the radio. "I have questions about all sorts of things - 'what's a prostitute, what's a madam?' etc - because they have heard it on the radio."

webTitle: Five fined for streaking at Open golf championship

fields.headline: Five fined for streaking at Open golf championship
fields.trailText: Five streakers have been fined and given a dressing down by a sheriff for stripping off during the British Open golf championship at St Andrews.
fields.body:
Five streakers have been fined and given a dressing down by a sheriff for stripping off during the British Open golf championship at St Andrews.

The five, three women and two men, were arrested after shedding their clothes and cavorting on the links during the millennium championship.

The highest profile incident, seen by millions around the world, involved Jacqui Salmond, a lap dancer, who danced round the 18th flag on Sunday seconds after Tiger Woods had teed off.

Woods said later that her actions had spoiled the final hole of his championship winning round.

At Cupar sheriff court, Fife, yesterday, Sheriff Patrick Davies told the streakers that their behaviour ruined the concentration of golfers under extreme pressure and also had the potential to trigger off serious public disorder. He said a mischief-maker who is alleged to have offered £10,000 to anyone who streaked at the competition should also be facing charges.

Salmond, 33, from Kirkcaldy, had told police she hoped to receive money for her impromptu strip. She was fined £100 for breach of the peace, as were Carol Limond, 37, from Inverurie, Grampian; Julie Methven, 23, from Cupar; and Michael Duncan, 22, from Dundee. Barrie Dorman, 28, from Tyne and Wear, who turned naked somersaults on the 18th fairway and perched on top of the Swilken bridge, was fined £200.

Officials at the Royal and Ancient golf club are to review security in light of the number of streakers who managed to make it on to the course. Peter Dawson, secretary of the R&A, said: "It is mindless, and the way I think to get rid of it is to ignore it."

webTitle: US store giant puts Mammon on wheels

fields.headline: US store giant puts Mammon on wheels
fields.standfirst: Asda Wal-Mart opens first British supercentre with promise of bargains but amid fears for small retailers
fields.trailText: Depending on your view of skate-powered sales staff, it marked either the dawn of easy shopping or the triumph of Mammon.
fields.body:
Depending on your view of skate-powered sales staff, it marked either the dawn of easy shopping or the triumph of Mammon.

The UK's first Asda Wal-Mart 24-hour supercentre opened in Bristol yesterday with cheerleaders waving pompoms around a 1,000-space car park, "price-checkers" on scooters, and an ecstatic squad of "happy-to-help" greeters cracking jokes via microphone.

One year after US giant Wal-Mart's £6.7bn takeover of Asda, the revamped US-style store at Cribb's Causeway is bigger than a football pitch, with 45 varieties of baked beans, 60 check-outs and some 93,000sq ft of bargain items - some 60% cheaper than rivals.

The store - including an optician's, a DIY centre, and clothes and electronics departments - sells 40,000 products from takeaway curry and 42 varieties of toilet roll to own brand Posh and Becks prams.

Shoppers entering one of the two "food" and "non-food" entrances are met within seconds by singing "welcomers" who hum tunes and tell gags to add "personality" to the dullest of chores.

The familiar sight of a half-strangled dog winding its lead round a lamp-post while waiting for its owner has been replaced by Wal-Mart "pet stops" - with food, water and shelter for waiting animals.

A "brolley patrol" shields shoppers from rain and in the "bobby lobby", a police constable sits on duty.

Nick Agarwol from Asda Wal-Mart said the store anticipates 60,000 shoppers in the first week.

The £15m makeover of the Bristol Asda store created 200 jobs and is the first of 10 warehouse-style UK Wal-Marts opening over the next five years, creating 750 jobs.

Its aim, the company says, is to create 10% to 15% better value than competitors on food and other items. At the store yesterday, RayBan sunglasses were £50 cheaper than at Boots and a child's quad bike was £16 less than at Toys R Us.

In an attempt to shed Wal-Mart's bargain bin image, price cuts also targeted the dinner party set. There were 250 varieties of organic food, quails eggs for £5 less than high street prices, and balsamic vinegar at half the cost of Sainsbury's.

Mr Agarwol said: "This is new to the UK in terms of value and range. About 50,000 customers stopped at the store last week before it was fully opened.

"The number of caravans in our car park shows that holidaymakers are treating our cafe and restaurant as an equivalent to service stations."

But as some people had trav elled over an hour to get to the store, fears will be raised that the megastore will bleed customers from small local businesses.

Last week, Curry's became the first retail chain in Britain to issue a direct challenge to Wal-Mart, saying it would undercut the store by at least £10 on some items in its own shops around Bristol.

Billy Shaw, manager of rival store Big W in Bristol, said the store would not damage large competitors. "There is a dan ger that Asda may alienate their value-led customers by selling more up-market products. If customers are expecting a typical Wal-Mart store they will be surprised, maybe even disappointed."

Some shoppers at the open ing seemed to find the experience bewildering. Edna O'Dell, 82, from Bristol, who was at Asda to compare prices of groceries, said it was good for young families but she could get what she needed from her local shop.

The happiest people at the store yesterday were the shop assistants on scooters.

Sandie Dalton, 44, said: "Normally at the end of the day I was tired and had blisters all over my feet, but not any more."

webTitle: Finance may hold key to family murders

fields.headline: Finance may hold key to family murders
fields.standfirst: Police check on dead husband's business affairs after wife and children bludgeoned to death
fields.trailText: Police have begun investigating the financial affairs of a former civil servant to see if they could hold the key to the killing of his wife and four children and his own apparent suicide.
fields.body:
Police have begun investigating the financial affairs of a former civil servant to see if they could hold the key to the killing of his wife and four children and his own apparent suicide.

Robert Mochrie, a 49-year- old property owner, was found hanging on the landing of his five bedroom home in a suburb of Barry, Vale of Glamorgan, after police officers forced their way into the property on Sunday evening.

The bodies of Mr Mochrie's wife, Catherine, 45, and his children, Bethan, 10, Luke, 14, Sian, 16, and James, 18, were found in separate rooms .

All had been bludgeoned to death with what investigators say appears to have been a blunt weapon. It is thought the bodies could have been on the property for up to 11 days.

Police were called to the house at the end of a cul-de-sac on the Highlight Lane estate after being contacted by a worried family friend who said the family had not been seen for some time. Neighbours thought the family was away on holiday.

Three officers sent to the house in Rutland Close found the first signs of the carnage after climbing a ladder to look in through a first floor bedroom window.

Superintendent Colin Jones, divisional commander for the Barry area, said the officers had been horrified by what they found in the house and had been offered counselling.

"Their reaction was one of disbelief. It denies logic. They were devastated. It's not very often you come across a household like that with six bodies in it."

Officers said the reasons for the tragedy were a mystery. But an examination of Mr Mochrie's business affairs would form one line of inquiry. They said they were not looking for anyone else in connection with the investigation.

After leaving his job at the Welsh Office in Cardiff five years ago Mr Mochrie became involved in property and is believed to have owned licensed premises in the Barry area which closed last year. He is said to have invested in the run-down Barry Hotel successfully turning it round and selling it as a "going concern" about three years ago.

But a further investment in another hotel, the Pembroke House in Haverfordwest, Pembrokeshire, was set back after a fire last year which forced a halt to business.

The Mochries moved to their home at the end of the close 15 years ago and were well liked by neighbours and by teachers at the Roman Catholic school the three eldest children attended.

Their youngest child, Bethan, attended a special needs school.

Sue White, a school secretary who has known the family for 15 years, said she was horrified by what had happened.

She had assumed the family must have gone away on holiday when she did not see Bethan playing outside.

"They were a nice family with four lovely children. The two parents seemed to be very private, but the kids mixed with the other children around here. They seemed to be such a nice, close-knit family. I can't believe we are not going to see them again, especially little Bethan. She was a little poppet. Everybody used to be very protective of her."

Mike Glinch, headteacher at the Sir Richard Gwyn school where the three older children were pupils, said the Mochries were a strong Roman Catholic family who were supportive of the school.

Mrs Mochrie, sister of the former Wales and British Lions rugby scrum half, Terry Holmes, was secretary of the PTA and both parents regularly atended parents' meetings together.

Mr Glinch said the the children were pleasant, from a normal, caring family. There had never been a hint of anything sinister behind the scenes. He said the tragedy would affect everybody at the 500 pupil school.

According to Mr Glinch, both James and Luke were big, healthy boys - bigger than their father - who were placid and good natured.

fields.headline: Living it up on the farm
fields.standfirst: Stowell, Somerset
fields.trailText: Stowell, Somerset
fields.body:
Stowell, Somerset

Long and narrow, with sloping bars down each side just wide enough apart for a cow to push her head through, the trailer was designed to be hauled to a suitable feeding point at times when there was not enough grass.

But it served very well to carry 20 of us, young and old (the youngest giggling, bouncing up and down and spilling melted ice cream), on a bumpy ride across the fields. We took the route of the tractor shuttle between the car park at the top end of the village and the terminus at the bottom.

We sat back to back on bales of straw laid down the middle, bumping companionably into each other and peering out between the bars at views only farmers usually see. Our young farmer steered us expertly, with only an inch or two to spare on either side, over baked and pitted mud at the narrow gateways of sloping fields.

It was open day at Stowell, a village of some 80 inhabitants. Side by side, the church and ancient manor (now Stowell Farm) make a picturesque formation on the bend half-way up the hill. From that point the other dwellings straggle down the winding lane on to the flat land below.

Outside one house, a notice said "26 rabbits in 2 weeks". At the back, a network of sheds and hutches, paved paths, water troughs and enclosures made a sanctuary for hurt, lost or rejected animals. The latest admission was a baby hedgehog. It had been carried aloft by a magpie, which held it by one leg and then dropped it.

At Clare Farm, a few yards away, you could meet the dairy herd whose photographs and CVs were displayed outside. And you could see the art exhibition at the dairy house, the history exhibition at the church, the bookstall at the barns or the sculpture workshop at Stowell House (once the rectory).

After a ploughman's lunch at Stowell Farm you might have had a pony ride, heard Wincanton town band, watched the falconry display and taken part in the skittles competition ("Play-off 4.30") and still had time for a cream tea at Clare Cottage.
