webTitle: Comment: Mark Hollingsworth  on  MI5's strategy for dealing with David Shayler

fields.headline: Opening the floodgates
fields.standfirst:
When Jestyn Thirkell-White broke cover, he ruined MI5's strategy for dealing with David Shayler
Special report: David Shayler
fields.trailText: Comment : When Jestyn Thirkell-White broke cover, he ruined MI5's strategy for dealing with David Shayler
fields.body:
There is one individual so embarrassing and infuriating that Sir Stephen Lander, the head of MI5, must pray nightly for the earth to open up and swallow him.

That man is David Shayler, the portly Middlesbrough fan and MI5 officer, who so notoriously departed from the intelligence agency in 1996 with a sheaf of secret documents allegedly under his arm, to blow the whistle on numerous malpractices and talk to the press.

Despite the existence of a recent and draconian piece of legislation - the 1989 Official Secrets Act - MI5's bosses have since been forced to fume helplessly, first as the French refused to extradite him; next as a copy of a highly secret intelligence report detailing British complicity in a Libyan assassination plot was posted on the internet; and finally as, last week, the courts ringingly refused to order the Guardian and Observer to hand over correspondence and notes about their dealings with the fugitive.

But until now, Lander and his frustrated intelligence colleagues have had one single - but highly important consolation. Shayler has been, apparently, alone in his complaints.

So MI5 have repeatedly said that he is disgruntled and bitter - a solitary voice in the wilderness and not credible. The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, taking his cue from Whitehall, claimed Shayler's Libya allegations were "pure fantasy".

However, that fundamental strategy has now been destroyed. Jestyn Thirkell-White, a former colleague of Shayler's in the secret world of MI5, has broken cover in the Guardian. In last week's interview, he backed many of Shayler's allegations of mismanagement, excessive secrecy, lack of accountability and unwillingness to reform. He denounced the Special Branch harassment of Shayler's British supporters as "acting like the police state from which they are supposed to be protecting us".

When I recently travelled to western Europe to meet Thirkell-White (who now works for a prominent merchant bank), I did not find a wild man. A quiet and carefully spoken 32-year-old who lives with his family, he is no attention-seeker.

Educated at a public school and Christ's College, Cambridge (a 2.1 degree in philosophy), Thirkell-White joined MI5 in 1991 after noticing a cryptic advertisement in the Independent on Sunday. Headlined "Godot Isn't Com ing", it was the same one that enticed Shayler. He holds moderate liberal views and was a CND activist for many years. But his grandparents had served in the colonial service in Burma: joining the secret world was not an alien concept.

Thirkell-White left MI5 a disillusioned man. He was not angry, but disappointed. When Shayler revealed a series of blunders and cover-ups, he knew from inside that many of them could be true.

He had always agreed with Shayler's analysis of MI5's failings (both resigned from the organisation in 1996) but was originally deterred, as well as appalled, by the harassment and the imprisonment of his former colleague. (Shayler spent four months in a French jail fighting the UK extradition attempt).

When I met him, he had been thinking about going public for several months. It was a considered and measured decision. However, he was determined to say nothing that was harmful to the nation. (In this he was successful. Security experts have confirmed that he has made no disclosures about MI5 that are genuinely damaging to national security.) He never sought money.

It was MI5 management's unwillingness to reform that eventually wore down Thirkell-White. Like Shayler, he believed that targeting terrorists meant that MI5's internal procedures needed radical modernisation. But there was institutional resistance. MI5's endless committees were cumbersome. Security always seemed to be the excuse to do nothing.

Thirkell-White knew Shayler reasonably well and was part of the same intake. He understands why his former colleague went public: there was no mechanism for internal dissent within the closed organisation.

Thirkell-White too, seems to have had no confidence in the so-called staff counsellor. As a former permanent secretary and a Whitehall insider, no one ever went to see him. Staff were expected to tell the personnel department they had seen the counsellor so there was little trust. Thirkell-White's generation clearly felt any complainant would be reported back to the director-general.

Jestyn Thirkell-White has no plans to make any further statements. And MI5, although deeply dismayed, are not intending to make the foolish mistake of attempting another prosecution.

But he may have opened the floodgates for other former intelligence officers to tell their story in a similarly moderate and measured fashion. And the Official Secrets Act now appears unable to prevent them from speaking out.

In achieving this, Mr Thirkell-White has performed a public service.

The author wrote, with Nick Fielding, Defending the Realm - MI5 and the Shayler Affair, Andre Deutsch

webTitle: Britain 'will not be left' in slow lane of Europe

fields.headline: Britain 'will not be left' in slow lane of Europe
fields.trailText: Britain will not tolerate a "two-speed Europe" in which France and Germany forge ahead and leave other EU member states behind in the slow lane, the government warned yesterday.
fields.body:
Britain will not tolerate a "two-speed Europe" in which France and Germany forge ahead and leave other EU member states behind in the slow lane, the government warned yesterday.

Keith Vaz, the minister for Europe, delivered a strongly-worded message to EU foreign ministers in Brussels as they began debating controversial French plans for "reinforced cooperation" or flexibility.

"We won't allow a situation where a group of countries go ahead at top speed on a particular issue and undermine the credibility of the single market or stop all countries acting together," Mr Vaz said. "We do not believe there should be a super league of a few countries and another league for everyone else. The whole basis of the EU is that you join because you want to do things together."

London's fear is that if closer cooperation is made easier, the 11 eurozone countries may move to harmonise taxation and budgetary policies, making a British decision on the single currency even tougher than it is. Mr Vaz's intervention came as Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, prepared to tell eastern European candidate countries that they should be given a clear date for ending their negotiations on joining the EU - a position opposed by both Paris and Berlin. Mr Cook is in the Hungarian capital Budapest today to underline Britain's strong commitment to enlarging the 15-member union, and its opposition to abstract debates about future institutional structures.

Opinion polls shows public support for enlargement slipping as concerns mount in Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic that the political will to end the division of Europe is waning. With member states worrying about subsidising poor Polish farmers, accepting poor environmental standards and facing an influx of cheap labour, France has made clear that it does not want to give the newcomers a date for joining at the Nice summit in December. The EU has said membership can start from 2003, but 2004 or 2005 now seem more realistic. France is overseeing the reforms necessary to prepare the bloc for expansion, though talks have registered little progress since starting in February.

President Chirac fuelled the debate over closer political and economic ties in the EU when he suggested that France and Germany could lead deeper EU integration among a "pioneering group" core of member states. Mr Chirac's speech followed an even more controversial blueprint by the German foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, for a federal Europe.

Britain also faces tough talks over the size of the European commission; how to extend majority voting in the EU and how to redistribute voting in the decision-making council of ministers.

fields.headline: Yesterday
fields.body:
Good day

Welsh assembly first secretary Rhodri Morgan, who has been made a privy councillor. As well as entitling him to some top table cabinet information about Wales it means he will know be known as the Right Honourable Rhodri.

Bill of the day

The costs of running home secretary Jack Straw's office have soared to £1.6m, mainly to accommodate growing ranks of press officers to fend off the media. The home secretary was robust in his defence that he was not engaged in funding spinning. He told MPs: "The only spinning that I'm ever involved in is a spinning class in the House of Commons gymnasium every Monday morning and I was there this morning."

Today

Scottish questions. Criminal justice (mode of trial) bill, remaining stages. Learning and skills bill, Lords amendments. Westminster Hall: Backbench debates on hospital services in Worcestershire; administrative burdens on teachers; access to justice and civil procedure; maintenance of rural roads. Lords: Football (disorder) bill, report and third reading. Countryside and rights of way bill, committee.

webTitle: Setting quantitative targets to reduce TB

fields.headline: Setting quantitative targets to reduce TB
fields.standfirst: Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: Tony Blair returned to the Commons from the G8 summit in Japan, looking pretty well for a man who has just discovered that some of the press would rather watch Ellen Brockovitch on the in-flight movie than be briefed by him.
fields.body:
Tony Blair returned to the Commons from the G8 summit in Japan, looking pretty well for a man who has just discovered that some of the press would rather watch Ellen Brockovitch on the in-flight movie than be briefed by him. The comparison is easy: Ellen Brockovitch features (a) taut, exciting plot in which the goodies win and (b) daringly low-cut necklines. Tony Blair features (a) long, rambling plot in which nobody wins and (b) uptight business suits.

He started yesterday on the size of the problem: "a debilitating and self-reinforcing cycle of politics, poverty and weak governance". Ha! He had finally grasped the scale of the situation in Downing Street, we thought, but it turned out he meant Africa.

"The need to set quantitative targets to reduce TB," he went on, "TB" being the code used for the prime minister himself in Downing Street. It looks as if that mole is not only thieving the documents: he is writing them as well.

A torrent of intitials and acronyms poured out. OAU, the Nam and Asean were joined by the HIPC scheme and the WTO round.

There was talk of "decision points" and "conflict diamonds". Prime ministers love this stuff: it's the jargon of their trade. The unspoken message to the other side is "You don't get it. I'll bet you don't even know what the HIPC scheme is!"

Moments later he was burbling about the "certification scheme for rough diamonds". I didn't realise that John Prescott needed a certificate, like the ones on a dentist's wall.

What really bothered the prime minister about Africa was not the weak governance, the Aids or the TB, but the lack of access to the internet. "We agreed a series of measures to close the digital divide." Thank heavens. At last, after years of deprivation, millions of barefoot children will be able to rush back from lessons in their open air, mud-floored schools, and immediately log onto www.nude-celebs.com and www.hot-babes.com.

There was not a lot William Hague could say in reply, without sounding as if he was against ending poverty, disease and the digital divide. Instead he quoted Jubilee 2000, the end-world- debt organisation, which had called Okinawa "the squandered summit" and claimed "world leaders have blown it". Silly boys; only President Clinton has done that. Mr Hague then went on to attack the Japanese prime minister, for spending half a billion pounds on mounting the summit.

"It's hard to believe. They even built a replica of President Clinton's boyhood home!" (It is hard to believe. For much less they could have built a replica of the Oval Office, including the original built-in hallway where he first blew it.)

Mr Blair replied that the Japanese had spent even more on aid to poor countries than they had on the summit. And, it turns out, the "Japanese investors" he met entirely agreed with Labour's wait-and-see policy on the euro!

That's pretty amazing, since every position on the single currency can claim a host of Japanese investors, who believe we should join tomorrow, never join, become part of a trade pact with Tierra del Fuego and the planet Mars, or whatever you want. I'm going to make a fortune setting up as head of Shimo Hokate Industries. "You want me to endorse Plaid Cymru policy on the euro? Sure thing. That will be two million yen, obrigato."

My favourite moment came when Mr Blair said that it was incredible for the Tories to pose as friends of the developed world. "Well, excuse me!" shouted several Tories, like a gaggle of schoolgirls, or Dale Winton.

They even built a replica of President Clinton's boyhood home!" (It is hard to believe. For much less they could have built a replica of the Oval Office, including the original built-in hallway where he first blew it.) Mr Blair replied that the Japanese had spent even more on aid to poor countries than they had on the summit. And, it turns out, the "Japanese investors" he met entirely agreed with Labour's wait-and-see policy on the euro! That's pretty amazing, since every position on the single currency can claim a host of Japanese investors, who believe we should join tomorrow, never join, become part of a trade pact with Tierra del Fuego and the planet Mars, or whatever you want. I'm going to make a fortune setting up as head of Shimo Hokate Industries. "You want me to endorse Plaid Cymru policy on the euro? Sure thing. That will be two million yen, obrigato." My favourite moment came when Mr Blair said that it was incredible for the Tories to pose as friends of the developed world. "Well, excuse me!" shouted several Tories, like a gaggle of schoolgirls, or Dale Winton.

fields.headline: Civil servant's £500,000 fraud went unnoticed
fields.trailText: Controls on a government legal agency were so weak that a £500,000 fraud by a civil service lawyer went unnoticed for nine years, according to a report yesterday.
fields.body:
Controls on a government legal agency were so weak that a £500,000 fraud by a civil service lawyer went unnoticed for nine years, according to a report yesterday.

The report by the comptroller and auditor general, Sir John Bourn, is embarrassing for the Treasury solicitor's department which carries out much of the government's legal work, and which oversaw the now defunct government property lawyers agency.

Richard Lillystone, a solicitor in the agency, which handled the conveyancing for government departments and public agencies, defrauded it of £542,000 from 1989 to 1998. He was discovered when a client, who had sent one too many cheques by mistake, asked for the extra cheque back and officials were unable to find it.

When confronted, Lillystone confessed. He was prosecuted and sentenced to two concurrent jail terms of 30 months.

Sir John said: "Fraud on public expenditure must not be tolerated. Weaknesses in the way the agency's financial procedures were operated enabled a substantial sum of public money to be lost. More widely, the agency's experience serves to emphasise the importance of having in place sound internal financial controls to safeguard taxpayers' money."

A spokesman for the Treasury solicitor's department admitted: "There was absence of control and lack of separation of duties. We are taking legal action to recover the money."

Sir John said the agency and the department had taken a number of steps in response to the fraud: reviewing a large random sample of cases to check for any similar frauds; requiring two signatories for all payment authorisations; and obtaining written bank account details from the solicitors of all property sellers to make sure any money was paid into the right account.

The fraud started in 1989 when a public agency for which Lillystone was acting in buying property mistakenly issued a duplicate cheque in favour of the property seller's solicitor.

Lillystone opened a building society account in the name of the solicitor but under his own control, and stole £70,000.

He later opened other accounts in the names of other solicitors, depositing more than £1.2m and pocketing the interest.

The Treasury solicitor's department won a judgment for damages against Lillystone and a court order freezing assets totalling £250,000.

A further investigation found an extra £137,000 had been paid into his false building society account.

Sir John's report said that, although there was no immediate evidence to prove this was part of the fraud, the possibility could not be ruled out.

As part of a general review, a decision was taken in November 1998 to close down the agency and it was wound up last September.

webTitle: Gang rapists encouraged by women in canal attack

fields.headline: Gang rapists encouraged by women in canal attack
fields.trailText: A 37-year-old woman was thrown into a canal and then gang raped by a group of youths who were being encouraged by their girlfriends, Scotland Yard revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
A 37-year-old woman was thrown into a canal and then gang raped by a group of youths who were being encouraged by their girlfriends, Scotland Yard revealed yesterday.

The victim was left naked on the towpath of the Grand Union Canal between Ladbroke Grove and north Kensington, west London, following the attack at 12.45am on Saturday.

"She managed to pick herself up and she ran home without any clothes on," said Detective Inspector Mike Christensen, who is leading the hunt for the attackers.

"She has been through a terrible ordeal. Everyone who has heard about it is very shocked.

"This was an unprovoked and savage attack on a defenceless woman. We need to find the people who did this."

Scotland Yard said she was raped by three different men and then subjected to a serious sexual assault by a fourth.

It appears that the woman was set upon as she walked home after a night out in the neighbourhood.

When she reached the tow path from the Harrow Road, she was approached by a group of black, white and mixed race youths aged between about 16 and 22.

Police do not believe she knew any of them.

"They befriended her and she walked with them for about 150 yards," said Det Insp Christensen, who is based at Notting Hill police station.

The gang then turned on her for no apparent reason.

She was pushed in the canal and when she climbed out of the water, she was attacked.

The men tore off her clothes, forced her to the ground and raped her.

"It appears there were four women in the group who were standing around and encouraging the men as this was going on," said Mr Christensen. "They threw her clothes back in the water and left her."

The woman struggled home and the police were called immediately.

"We have no idea why they did this to her. We don't think there is any link between them. The victim is extremely badly shaken and is getting the medical attention and emotional support that she needs."

So far the woman has been too distressed to give descriptions of the attackers, but she has told officers she believes there were between eight and 12 in the group.

Detectives are checking CCTV coverage of the area and are hoping witnesses will come forward.

Anyone with information can call the incident room at Notting Hill, 0208 246 0124, or Crimestoppers, 0800 555 111.

This stretch of the Grand Union Canal in west London has been a favoured haunt of muggers and drug users in recent years.

The incident comes nearly four years after the gang rape of an Austrian tourist who was also thrown into a London canal. The 33-year-old victim was attacked by eight youths near to the Regent's Canal in King's Cross. The youths were caught and sentenced to lengthy custodial sentences.

webTitle: Drinks industry calls for morning kick-offs

fields.headline: Drinks industry calls for morning kick-offs
fields.trailText: The British tradition of Saturday afternoon football, already undermined by the demands of television and European competition, is under threat again - from the drinks industry.
fields.body:
The British tradition of Saturday afternoon football, already undermined by the demands of television and European competition, is under threat again - from the drinks industry.

Big alcohol manufacturers say fixtures which could pose a risk of public disorder and violence should be given morning kick-offs rather than attract widespread liquor bans as proposed by the Home Office.

The Portman Group of leading companies, formed to promote sensible drinking, said huge areas of towns and cities would need to be included in no drink zones to be effective in curbing pre-match drunkenness.

This would "unacceptably disrupt the harmless routine of non-football fans". Morning matches would be a better way of reducing the potential for fans to drink excessively.

The group was worried by government licensing proposals which would give senior police officers powers to ask magistrates to ban the sale of alcohol in pubs, off-licences and supermarkets for up to 24 hours before a big game if they feared public order problems could be fuelled or exacerbated by drink. It argued publicans and shop keepers could face severe financial losses, while local people and well-behaved football fans would be deprived of the right to enjoy a drink.

The police already have considerable influence over local landlords, many of whom already close or arrange strict stewarding at pubs near grounds on matchdays. The group is against further measures, because it does not think drink is a cause of football violence.

The Home Office said morning kick-offs, which sometimes already take place, were an operational matter for the police.

The FA Premier League said it would need to be convinced more were necessary. There had to be "fairly compelling reasons" to change kick-off times. These usually were linked to television.

"One of the reasons the majority of football matches are still played at 3pm, on a Saturday, is it is convenient for fans and works in terms of travelling," said a spokesman.

Kevin Miles, of the Football Supporters Association, said the "genuine travelling, match-going football supporter always plays second fiddle to the needs of broadcasters or supposed law and order measures." He said a blanket alcohol ban in Lens in France when England played there during the 1998 World Cup had not worked since some fans saw it as a challenge "and people arrived with lorries laden with lager."

If such bans were applied in Britain they would "send a message to football fans saying 'we don't trust you to enjoy yourselves'," he added.

The Portman Group also suggested that the goverment should adapt new smart cards, with which school leavers "buy" further study, as "proof of age" identity cards.

webTitle: Britons' icy challenge on kilometre-high sea cliff

fields.headline: Britons' icy challenge on kilometre-high sea cliff
fields.trailText: Four British climbers set off yesterday for the bleak Greenland coast, where they hope to become the first to scale the world's highest sea cliff.
fields.body:
Four British climbers set off yesterday for the bleak Greenland coast, where they hope to become the first to scale the world's highest sea cliff.

An engineering student, a part-time mountain guide, a photographer, and a sales executive hope to break the world sea-cliff climbing record by reaching the summit of the diminutive sounding Thumbnail cliff, a sheer, jagged face of black granite which is actually a kilometre high.

Weather permitting, one of the party, Ian Parnell, 31, from Wanborough, Wiltshire, will leap from an inflatable motor boat on to the vertical rock face on Thursday, followed by Ben Bransby, 20, Matt Dickinson, 28, and Gareth Parry, 27.

The Greenland authorities have told the team not to worry about the many killer whales and hungry polar bears which swim in the fjords around the southern tip of Greenland; the sub-zero waters - should they slip in - can kill in under two minutes.

Once established on the cliff, which has never before been scaled, the team will haul themselves, and two 75kg bags of equipment and supplies, up the granite face for up to eight hours a day. They hope to reach the top on the 10th day.

At night the team will assemble 7ft by 3ft aluminium pole tents suspended from the rock face in which to eat and rest. In good weather they will be able to cook packet noodles on camping stoves.

Speaking from a car on the way to the airport yesterday, Mr Parry said the climbers were "extremely excited" to be finally on their way.

"We had heard rumours about this large sea cliff two years ago and when Matt came back from Greenland and told us about it we decided we had to climb it," he said. "I couldn't exactly tell you why we're doing it. Climbing is just something we've been doing for a long time.

"When you experience the thrill of reaching the top of a climb, you are full of adrenaline. But you have to keep upping the challenge to experience that same excitement next time round. And that's why we're going to Greenland."

While the expedition will enjoy the many daylight hours of a sub-arctic summer, the climbers are unlikely to feel much of the sun's warmth as they hug the icy north-facing cliff. As the snow on top of Thumbnail melts away the team will also face the added risk of rock falls which could knock them from their perch. Should anyone be injured during the ascent an air rescue has already been ruled out as helicopters will not be able to get close enough to the cliff.

Yesterday the Meteorological Office forecast dry weather and broken clouds over south Greenland on Thursday morning with light to moderate winds. But the afternoon and rest of the week is likely to bring a turn for the worse, with a high chance of rain and snow at higher altitudes, a spokesman said.

webTitle: Timing of sacking raises assembly questions

fields.headline: Timing of sacking raises assembly questions
fields.standfirst: Special report: devolution in Wales
fields.trailText: It was Wales's worst kept secret. But the manner of its confirmation took everyone by surprise. Living up to his reputation as something of a maverick the first secretary Rhodri Morgan chose the eve of the biggest event in the Welsh agricultural calendar to announce that he was putting a new person in charge of this sensitive portfolio.
fields.body:
It was Wales's worst kept secret. But the manner of its confirmation took everyone by surprise. Living up to his reputation as something of a maverick the first secretary Rhodri Morgan chose the eve of the biggest event in the Welsh agricultural calendar to announce that he was putting a new person in charge of this sensitive portfolio.

Out, without ceremony, went the much vilified Christine Gwyther. In came her deputy, Carwyn Jones, the assembly member for Bridgend.

It has left major uncertainties about how Mr Morgan will handle other changes in the Welsh executive in order to stamp his own mark on what in the main has been a cabinet inherited five months ago from former first secretary Alun Michael.

Although Mr Morgan had originally been expected to announce a reshuffle before the summer recess, recent briefings in Cardiff suggested he would wait until the autumn. Education secretaries Rosemary Butler and Tom Middlehurst, both said to be facing the axe, are likely to have a less than relaxing summer break while they wait to learn their fate. It has been rumoured that both will go should Mr Morgan decide to bring pre-16 and post-16 education together under one brief.

The manner of Ms Gwyther's sacking - in a weekend phone call from the first secretary - rounds off what has been a torrid 15 months for the former Pembrokeshire county council development officer since she was plucked from relative obscurity to take charge of the crisis-torn agriculture sector in Wales.

The appointment of a vegetarian to represent the industry at what was then the height of the beef crisis was more than many farmers could stomach and there were immediate demands for her resignation. But some officials who have worked closely with Ms Gwyther believe antipathy towards her was sparked as much by misogyny as by dislike of her eating habits.

In the assembly Ms Gwyther became an easy target for opposition parties keen to flex their muscles against the minority Labour regime. She was censured by assembly members over her failure to deliver on a promised calf processing scheme for Wales but remained in her post. Although she survived two other Tory inspired censure motions her reputation was dealt a further blow when the Department of the Environment in London gave the go ahead for the planting of a GM trial crop in Flintshire in the face of assembly determination to keep Wales a GM free zone.

Mr Jones, a barrister, was appointed by Morgan as deputy secretary for agriculture, environment and local government five months ago and is felt to have done a sound job.

He takes over at a time of falling farmers' incomes and particular concern over a renegotiation of compensation paid to farmers in less favoured areas.

There was concern in some quarters about the timing of the announcement which came less than 24 hours after officials had sent out press notices detailing Ms Gwyther's engagements on the opening day of the Royal Welsh Show at Builth Wells, Powys.

Mike German, Liberal Democrat leader in the assembly, said: "The show is geared around the agriculture secretary, and suddenly with only a few hours' notice everything has got to change. There is a feeling that this could have been handled a bit better."

Plaid Cymru's agriculture spokesman, Rhodri Glyn Thomas, said such a sudden reshuffle could only mean that the Welsh cabinet was in panic and had no strategy in important areas such as agriculture and rural development.

fields.headline: 'We seem to know you...'
fields.standfirst:
News of eight-year-old Sarah Payne's death has caused a new, Diana-style outpouring of grief. Helene Mulholland asks well-wishers why they are paying tribute to a stranger
More about the Sarah Payne case
fields.trailText: News of eight-year-old Sarah Payne's death has caused a new, Diana-style outpouring of grief.  Helene Mulholland asks well-wishers why they are paying tribute to a stranger
fields.body:
It is a perfect late summer evening, in a quintessentially English setting outside the village of Pulborough in West Sussex. Green, flat countryside, with clusters of expensive houses, trimmed hedges and neat gardens. A small rabbit lies face down in the middle of the road, dead, while traffic coasts by.

Families, couples, single men and single women are making their way to a grass verge which has been transformed from the ordinary to the extraordinary, from the unknown to the famous, in less than a week. Flowers, large bears, small bears, rabbits, beetles, pandas, alligators, monkeys, hedgehogs, piglets, rhinos, elephants and letters, so many letters, have consumed this once unremarkable space. Behind the thicket, no more than 5m back from the A29, a three-dimensional, brilliant-white triangle stands remote in a farmer's field. It marks the death of a girl, and the nation is grieving in the most spectacular fashion.

On Friday evening, a teacher from a special school down the road from where Sarah Payne lost her life joined the stream of people showing their respects to the eight-year-old girl who went off for a quick sulk after the kind of tiff we can all remember having with our siblings, never to be seen alive again.

A young, childless couple have come from Portsmouth, 40 minutes down the road, to bring flowers and a message for Sarah. Donna Moakes didn't come with flowers, nor did she, unlike many who have visited the site over the past seven days, bring a poem or letter for Sarah or her grieving family. Her offering was for the guilty. A simple plank of wood held a bold, dark message stuck on in the form of a cross: "Give yourself up."

That night no one knew what to say. Today they still don't. Platitudes and cliches swill in the crowd. Emotion has long overtaken the lexicon of grief. People weep silently, but openly. A message in the mass of tributes reads: "We seem to know you, yet we don't, we have all hoped to see you, now we won't."

Moakes hadn't given much thought as to why this particular child's murder had provoked such a strong reaction in her, but the thoughts suddenly tripped off her tongue: "It has a lot to do with the high profile of the family and what kind of family they represent; a very strong, caring, loving family, and anybody with any normality within them recognises that in themselves. The mother was so strong and believed Sarah would be found alive and we accepted it. I didn't think for a moment that she wouldn't be.

"On the Monday when they found the body I was diverted from my route and I thought 'they found her!' I got home and was so excited. Then my legs were kicked from under me. I just didn't think they would find a dead body." A letter from Turkey, another from South Africa, join local voices of grief. One letter reads: "Not since Diana are a nation's hurt so true, the feelings of why? for this beautiful little princess." No child since the Moors victims or perhaps James Bulger seems to have prompted such a powerful response. So why this, and why now?

Most admit that the continuous media coverage has made them feel closer to this child, and certainly to the grieving family, a fact clearly mirrored in the tributes. The courage and unity of the Payne family has become a key signifier of the whole ordeal. "It is incredible how strong the family has been," someone mutters in the crowd. Others nod their agreement.

The family's relaxed consent has allowed us into a truly private sphere: the home of the bereaved. A strong couple, a loving family has affected everyone. A woman who in her darkest hour mothered the public by reassuring everyone that Sarah was out there, alive, was powerful reassurance indeed. She was wrong, but she was strong, the kind of ideal mother image that many aspire to, others belatedly yearn for.

The empathy that such a public tragedy allows the public is a bit like a real-life soap. We attach our personal to the mast of the public, on to a real subject, a live situation, but without the resolution promised in the written script. Next thing you know, we give ourselves a part.

We can do nothing. A child is already dead, but we wish we could do more. We make the journey, we take the trouble, we think the effort worth it.

His wife Leslie has fewer doubts, though she has no more facts at her disposal than her husband: "They deserve everything. Just kill them, for all our sakes."

webTitle: My war is over, says loyalist killer

fields.headline: My war is over, says loyalist killer
fields.standfirst:
Freed gunman calls on UDA to decommission its weapons
Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: At the Avenue One bar, the teetotal Michael Stone sipped orangeade while staring at television footage capturing his gun and grenade attack on an IRA funeral, which left three dead. Asked how he felt about what had happened back then, he replied: "I have had better days."
fields.body:
At the Avenue One bar, the teetotal Michael Stone sipped orangeade while staring at television footage capturing his gun and grenade attack on an IRA funeral, which left three dead. Asked how he felt about what had happened back then, he replied: "I have had better days."

It had taken Stone, now 45 and more notorious even than his loyalist rival Johnny Adair, just 10 minutes to revisit Milltown cemetery, the scene of his murderous attack.

Earlier yesterday he had become the 340th terrorist to leave the Maze prison early, under the Good Friday agreement. A lone RUC jeep was parked at the spot where police officers saved him from a republican lynching 12 years ago.

His people-carrier swept up the M1 in presidential style to east Belfast. He saw his face, wild-eyed and framed with a shock of black hair, adorning a gable wall close to the pub. The slogan on the freshly painted mural reads: "His only crime was loyalty."

Stone had already killed three Roman Catholics when he attacked the funeral of three IRA terrorists whom the SAS shot dead in Gibraltar in March 1988, before they could mount a bombing mission. His six life terms and convictions on a host of other offences brought him jail terms totalling 684 years.

Stone, who spent 28 years as a volunteer in the Ulster Defence Association, was back home yesterday after just 12 years, one of the more controversial beneficiaries of the peace process. Had there been no agreement, prison sources say he would have served 15 more years.

Painful

The early release scheme, which is seen as the most painful element of the agreement, reaches its cut-off point on Friday, two years after its introduction.

The doors of the Maze will open, spewing another 80-odd terrorists on to Northern Ireland's streets, among them the most hardened of the Troubles.

Stone inspired loyalist hero worship for his solo attack at Milltown, in which he shot Thomas McErlean, 20, John Murray, 26, and an IRA member, Caoimhin MacBradaigh, 30, as they gave chase after he tossed grenades at the gravesides.

RUC officers raced in and pulled him from certain death. When they told him how many he had killed, Stone replied: "Brilliant. I would have shot more if the gun hadn't jammed."

But Stone, who has nine children, said yesterday he had been trying to kill Martin McGuinness, who he believed sanctioned the Gibraltar operation as head of the IRA's northern command. He also suggested Mr McGuinness gave the go-ahead for the November 1987 massacre at Enniskillen, which killed 11 people.

He said he had tried to kill Mr McGuinness before, but had pulled out because he was walking one of his young daughters to school and holding her hand. He mused that it was ironic that his one-time target was now responsible for the education of his three grandchildren.

But, though he said he would never be able ever to sit down with a Sinn Fein politician, Stone claimed he still supported the agreement which led to Mr McGuinness becoming minister of education. He said he would continue to work towards its success, and sent out an unprecedented call within the UDA for loyalists to decommission their weapons.

Stone walked free from the Maze just before 11am, with speculation raging over whether republicans or loyalists would win the race to assassinate him. He is locked in an unexplained feud with Adair, and took to carrying scissors into the showers while in the jail.

Frankie Gallagher, of the Prisoners Aid Post-conflict Resettlement Group, had briefed journalists that there would be no triumphalism for fear of upsetting any of his victims' families. Stone, much slimmer than when he went into prison, said nothing and remained expressionless as he emerged through the rickety turnstile into the car-park.

But 50 loyalists cheered and clapped. They gathered around him for the cameras, many wearing sunglasses despite the gloom, brandishing the standard of the Ulster Freedom Fighters' east Belfast brigade.

Just as his murderous exploits ensured devotion among many loyalists, so they have made him particularly feared within the Catholic community. But his wild eyes were much calmer yesterday, and he looked less Yorkshire Ripper and more aspiring sculptor.

Stone, nicknamed The Purist inside the Maze because he had no truck with drugs, spoke softly more than two hours after he was freed at a prisoners' centre, where a Welcome Home sign hung above the door. He had few apologies. He was, though, guilty of inconsistency, failing to offer an explanation of how his grenade attack could have singled out McGuinness; suggesting at one stage he did not regret the deaths of his own victims; and even unsure if yesterday was a day of celebration for him. He finally declared it a new phase of his life.

"Today is a day of celebration for myself, friends and family, but I recognise there will be those within the nationalist and republican community who view my release with sadness and anger, just as the release of high-profile republican prisoners on Friday will anger the unionist and loyalist community. I understand that. There are no words I can say to take away the hurt of the loss of their loved ones."

Stone's previous victims included Patrick Brady, 36, who was shot in November 1984 as he arrived for work at a dairy in south Belfast. He shot dead Kevin McPolin, 26, from Katesbridge, in Co Aramgh in November 1985 as he arrived for work, at Lisburn, Co Down. He killed Dermot Hackett, 37, from Castlederg, in May 1987 - shooting him 15 times as he sat in his bread van.

Stone said yesterday: "I was a volunteer in the UDA involved in a 30-year war. It was not of my doing. It was down to republican rebellion. This is my 29th year as a member of the UDA. I have no regrets about defending my community and my family. I am proud of that fact."

But he regretted all deaths, including those of republicans, and vowed that his war was over. He would be doing all he could to take a constructive approach to the agreement, he said, and, if he found he was unable to do so, he would quickly disappear from view.

He believed Tony Blair could be trusted. So was he planning a life in politics? "No. I would not even vote for me. I am a soldier. I am not a politician. Politicians start the wars. Soldiers fight it, and they die or go to prison."

Murderers who will walk free

On Friday a number of other prisoners are due to be released from the Maze. They include:

Sean Kelly , 26, an IRA volunteer from Ardoyne, north Belfast, serving life for killing nine Protestants, including a pregnant woman and a seven-year-old girl, in a bomb attack on Frizell's fish shop on the Shankill Road in Belfast in October 1993.

Kelly was injured in the blast, which killed his accomplice, Thomas Begley, 23. Their intended target was the Ulster Freedom Fighter Johnny Adair, who had his headquarters above the fish shop. He will have served nine months for each murder.

Torrens Knight , 30, an Ulster Freedom Fighter, is serving life for murdering four workmen, including one IRA member, in Castlerock, Co Londonderry, in March, 1993, and eight people at the Rising Sun pub in Greysteel, Co Londonderry on Halloween, 1993.

Knight, like many loyalists, is now said to be a born-again Christian.

Michael Caraher , 32, the IRA's sniper in south Armagh, is believed to be responsible for shooting dead a dozen members of the security services. He is only 16 months into a sentence totalling 105 years after being jailed for murdering Lance Bombardier Stephen Restorick in February 1997, the last soldier to be shot dead in Northern Ireland.

Along with his three co-accused, Caraher laughed as he was sentenced. They realised the Good Friday agreement meant that they would be freed.

Bernard McGinn , 43, another member of the IRA's sniper unit, was jailed for Restorick's murder and the shooting dead of two other soldiers. He built the bombs that blew up the Baltic Exchange eight years ago and Canary Wharf in February 1996, the attack that marked the end of the IRA's first ceasefire.

He was also found guilty of supplying Semtex used in the 1996 attack on Hammersmith bridge in west London.

Glen "Titch" Cunningham , 32, of the Ulster Freedom Fighters, was jailed for 25 years for the attempted murder of a Catholic in 1992.

He was a key member of the Ulster Defence Association and Ulster Freedom Fighters delegation who met in January 1997 with Mo Mowlam, then Northern Ireland secretary, when she persuaded them to stick to their ceasefire after the assassination at the Maze of Billy Wright, 37, a close friend of Adair.

Norman Coopey , 29, Loyalist Volunteer Force. He was jailed for the sectarian murder of James Morgan, 16, in July 1997. Morgan, abducted when hitchhiking home, was tortured and beaten to death with a hammer.

Coopey, who has an IQ of 74, was not a member of any paramilitary organisation at the time of the attack but he was accepted on to the LVF block at the Maze, and so, under the rules, will walk free on Friday.

fields.headline: No: 1684 Princess Michael of Kent
fields.body:
Full name (please curtsy as you say it): Baroness Marie-Christine Agnes Hedwig Ida von Reibnitz.

Age: 55 if we're counting years; about 1,200 if we're counting dynasties.

Appearance: Brünnhilde after a visit to a beautician.

Nickname: Princess Pushy.

Who dislikes her? The Queen calls her Val (as in Valkyrie); Woodrow Wyatt branded her "an uncontrollable ass"; and the News of the World's genealogist traced her pedigree back to Vlad the Impaler.

Ouch! Why the hostility? She called Princess Diana that "silly girl next door", the Duchess of York "common", and declared her background "better than anyone else who's married into the royal family since the war, except Prince Philip".

That famed bloodline to Vlad? To Charlemagne actually.

So why is she in the mews, sorry news? She's just given an interview in an American magazine rounding on her critics, who she says attack her because she's "foreign and Catholic".

Not because she's an unbearable snob and social climber? Of course not: it's all to do with centuries of British religious bigotry.

Brief biog: Father was a Silesian aristocrat and keen Nazi; mother fled to Australia after the war and worked as a hairdresser; the princess moved to London and got a job as a secretary ("typing and shorthand were not her forte", said her boss), before marrying an old Etonian businessman and then her prince.

Sounds rather selective and unfair: It's all to do with centuries of British religious bigotry.

Not to be confused with: The tennis-loving Duchess of Kent, who is married to HRH the Duke of Kent, whereas Princess Michael of Kent is married to HRH Prince Michael of Kent.

Do any of them actually live in Kent? Don't be silly.

Most likely to say: "Call me madam."

Least likely to say: "Don't worry about the washing-up, I'll do that."

webTitle: One lifebelt, two crew and a less than perfect end

fields.headline: One lifebelt, two crew and a less than perfect end
fields.trailText: When the sea gets rough in the new Hollywood blockbuster The Perfect Storm, the crew of the threatened fishing boat stand shoulder to shoulder as the hurricane closes in.
fields.body:
When the sea gets rough in the new Hollywood blockbuster The Perfect Storm, the crew of the threatened fishing boat stand shoulder to shoulder as the hurricane closes in.

In real life, things go rather differently from the way they do in the movies. The crew fight one another to the death.

Raymond Leiker and Alvin Latham were the only two on board the Bandit, a Louisiana shrimp boat, a week ago when it was hit by a severe storm in the Gulf of Mexico 30 miles south-east of New Orleans.

The night was dark, the sea was high, and the radio was out. When the storm struck, the Bandit began to ship water and sink. Inside the cabin, Captain Leiker grabbed the only lifejacket, fought off Latham's attempt to grab it from him, and prepared to jump.

As he did so, a wave hit the Bandit with such force that Leiker was swept overboard and lost the lifejacket, which he had failed to tie up properly.

If this were Hollywood, Latham would have plunged in after the skipper and tried to rescue him, as in The Perfect Storm. But as a desperate Leiker tried to clamber back on board, Latham went for him with a knife and a piece of piping, knocking Leiker back into the waves.

When Latham was rescued, he told authorities that he and the captain had knelt together on deck and prayed for salvation as the Bandit began sinking. As the boat went down, Latham told them, Leiker's foot got entangled in a net. Latham tried to save him, but to no avail. After the ship sank, Latham kept swimming, and was rescued by another fishing boat.

Then Leiker's body was found, floating at sea, full of stab wounds and bruises. "Until we found the body, there was no indication that anything illegal had gone on out there," said John Marie of the local sheriff's office in Plaquemines.

Confronted with the evidence, Latham confessed to inflicting the wounds. Yesterday he was due to appear in court in Venice, Louisiana, to answer second-degree murder charges.

"He said he thought the captain was going to come back at him," Plaquemines police chief Curtis Bowers said yesterday. "I think things just went way out of hand, with the weather so bad and the boat sinking, they were just fighting for their lives."

When Latham was rescued, he told authorities that he and the captain had knelt together on deck and prayed for salvation as the Bandit began sinking. As the boat went down, Latham told them, Leiker's foot got entangled in a net. Latham tried to save him, but to no avail. After the ship sank, Latham kept swimming, and was rescued by another fishing boat. Then Leiker's body was found, floating at sea, full of stab wounds and bruises. "Until we found the body, there was no indication that anything illegal had gone on out there," said John Marie of the local sheriff's office in Plaquemines. Confronted with the evidence, Latham confessed to inflicting the wounds. Yesterday he was due to appear in court in Venice, Louisiana, to answer second-degree murder charges. "He said he thought the captain was going to come back at him," Plaquemines police chief Curtis Bowers said yesterday. "I think things just went way out of hand, with the weather so bad and the boat sinking, they were just fighting for their lives."

webTitle: England's tormentor Figo in world-record transfer

fields.headline: England's tormentor Figo in world-record transfer
fields.standfirst: World's most expensive footballers
fields.trailText: The money-go-round that is modern football took another turn yesterday when Luis Figo, above, became the world's most expensive player as he moved from Barcelona to Real Madrid in a deal worth £43m.
fields.body:
The money-go-round that is modern football took another turn yesterday when Luis Figo, above, became the world's most expensive player as he moved from Barcelona to Real Madrid in a deal worth £43m.

The 27-year-old, who signed a six-year contract, will double his wages to £71,000 a week after tax.

The deal eclipses the £36m Lazio paid fellow Italian club Parma for the services of the Argentine striker Hernan Crespo barely two weeks ago.

The signing of the Portuguese international, whose spectacular goal against England in Euro 2000 marked the beginning of the end for Kevin Keegan's team, was the main campaign promise of Florentino Perez, who was elected the new president of the European champions last week.

The fee dwarfs the £15m Chelsea paid Atletico Madrid for Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink, the top price paid by an English club this summer.

fields.headline: Deadlock in Hillsborough case
fields.standfirst: Victims' relatives may seek retrial of police chief after jury fails to reach decision
fields.trailText: The families of 96 people who died in the Hillsborough disaster will meet today to decide whether to seek a retrial after a jury failed to reach a verdict on manslaughter charges against the police match commander.
fields.body:
The families of 96 people who died in the Hillsborough disaster will meet today to decide whether to seek a retrial after a jury failed to reach a verdict on manslaughter charges against the police match commander.

After deliberating for 24 hours, the jury at Leeds crown court was unable to reach a verdict against the former South Yorkshire police chief superintendent David Duckenfield. The jury was discharged yesterday by the trial judge, Mr Justice Hooper.

Mr Duckenfield, 55, of Bournemouth, Dorset, who was in charge of crowd control at Sheffield Wednesday's ground, denied the specimen manslaughter charges against two fans, John Anderson, 62, and James Aspinall, 18. They were among 96 Liverpool supporters crushed to death on the terraces during an FA Cup semi-final against Nottingham Forest in April 1989.

The charges were brought by the Hillsborough Family Support Group in a private prosecution. The group will meet today and announce its decision about a retrial tomorrow.

Mr Duckenfield's deputy, former superintendent Bernard Murray, 58, of Pontefract, West Yorkshire, was cleared of the same charges on Friday.

Mr Justice Hooper told the jury: "Notwithstanding your very best efforts I understand you are not going to be able to reach a verdict in this case. In these circumstances I will discharge you from so doing. That will be the end of your involvement in the matter."

He thanked the jurors for the great care and attention they had given to considering the case. "Sadly you have not been able to reach a verdict - but these things happen," he said.

The families had said in the private prosecution that the two police officers were responsible for the fans' deaths.

They were said to have ordered the opening of an exit gate to relieve the crush of supporters outside the turnstiles without taking steps to block off a tunnel leading to the already overcrowded Leppings Lane terraces.

The judge had told the jurors that they had to consider whether there were failings on the part of the officers that led to the disaster, and whether any failings amounted to a serious criminal offence.

Alun Jones QC, prosecuting, said the two men should have blocked off a tunnel leading to central pens of the terrace, diverting fans to uncrowded pens on either side.

"The entry of dozens of spectators into a tunnel, with a slope down to the terraces, over a period of eight minutes, forced hundreds of people down the terrace [to] the pens into a hideous crush," he said.

Mr Duckenfield chose not to give evidence but from the dock Mr Murray said he was worried by the pile-up of fans at the entrance to the ground and had been forced to make an emergency decision.

Mr Duckenfield's counsel, William Clegg, said: "The disaster was a conglomeration of many unique, unforeseen events. It was a tragedy but it was not David Duckenfield's fault."

Mr Murray said in a statement yesterday: "I have suffered deeply over the past 11 years and particularly over the last two years. However, I know that this cannot compare with the suffering of people who lost sons, daughters, fathers or brothers and my thoughts will always be with them.

"I can only hope that the passage of time can help everyone to understand each other's feelings and try, and I appreciate how difficult this will be, to look to the future."

Relatives of the victims filled the public gallery throughout the trial. They left the court building without comment. The case is estimated to have cost at least £4m.

fields.headline: Russia's best brains for sale
fields.standfirst:
The second in our three-part series on the decline and rebirth of Russian science finds pure research in the doldrums as institutes are forced to work at bargain prices on western commercial projects
Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: The second in our three-part series on the decline and rebirth of Russian science finds pure research in the doldrums as institutes are forced to work at bargain prices on western commercial projects
fields.body:
One of Russia's most successful exports in the past 10 years has been its brains. Highly educated and available at bargain prices, this human commodity has been in feverish demand throughout the developed world since the end of the 1980s.

Russian scientists, with a combination of enthusiasm and sadness, have been packing their suitcases and leaving for the west - lured by seductive salaries and research facilities unavailable at home.

The flow to the west reduced in the last years of the 1990s, but in its place new forms of brain drain have emerged.

For example, scientists are moving to jobs which are more secure or more lucrative, according to figures issued by the ministry of science and technology.

In 1990 1.6m people were working in science; since then 800,000 have abandoned their careers, some to go into business, others to scrape a living in any field that will feed them - as market traders, say, or taxi-drivers.

The newest, subtlest form of the phenomenon is the virtual brain drain - represented by those scientists who stay in their old institutes but work exclusively on contract to foreign firms.

Trade in intellect

Vladimir Vaschenko, one of Russia's young software tycoons, is one of those entrepreneurs who have been accused of promoting this trade in intellect - selling Russian brain power to the west at discount prices.

Novosoft, the company Mr Vaschenko owns with an American partner, employs hundreds of Russian scientists and mathematicians who work on programming contracts for international clients. A cluster of similar firms exploiting the local concentration of highly educated scientists has led to the region of southern Siberia around Novosibirsk being labelled Cyberia or the Silicon Taiga.

When Novosoft began it charged western firms w$1 an hour for each Russian programmer working on their project. It recently raised the rate of about $25 (£16) an hour. In the United States an experienced software consultant can demand up to $200 for the same work.

Mr Vaschenko's venture is part of a global trend. With good phone and internet links, firms in the west are now in a position to employ skilled people overseas - in India, the Philippines, or Russia, to name just three - without the cost of moving them.

Near Novosoft's offices in Novosibirsk, the Siberian Institute of Catalysis, once Russia's leading chemical reaction research centre, is touted by the local authorities as a model of how academic institutes can transform themselves into profit-making enterprises. This can mean relegating pure research to the back burner to do paid work for western firms.

The institute went commercial in the early 90s when state funding almost vanished. It now does research almost entirely for the likes of DuPont and Monsanto.

"We used to focus mainly on pure science," said the institute's vice-director, Vladimir Likholobov. "Now we have a business section and a marketing department that directs which lines of research we pursue."

To Professor Likholobov this has come as a bit of a shock; to many western academics it has long been a familiar trend. And there are Russian academics who regard the change with resigned pragmatism: in the absence of state support, they argue, anything is better than closure.

Prof Likholobova said that most of his colleagues were fairly satisfied with the new regime: a proportion of the money coming in from the commercial contracts was set aside every month to finance their own research and buy new equipment. But Valery Ermikov, a professor at the local university who has seen some of his best students leave, is angry about the actual and virtual brain drains.

Big void in universities

The state was educating specialists "for free", he said, then companies like Microsoft came and stole them. "A lot of western firms come here and exploit our talents and intellectual capacities and give nothing back. We would like them to treat us with more respect."

Ultimately, though, it is still the physical departures that prove the most devastating. The departure of so many scientists aged between 30 and 45 - the age group that ought to be passing on its knowledge to students - has left a void in the universities. The education system has always been at the heart of Russia's scientific achievements.

Since 1990 approximately 16,000 scientists have left the country permanently to work abroad. At the height of Russia's painful economic reforms in the early 90s, more than 2,000 were leaving every year; now the annual figure has levelled off at around a thousand. "When you examine the figures they don't look so bad, just a few thousand in a country the size of Russia," Michael Kirpichnikov, the science minister, said in an interview in Moscow.

"But the reality is that these were often the most talented, energetic people. In science new ideas are born in the head of an individual, so even the loss of one person - a Newton or an Einstein - can be disastrous. Pure science is an international phenomenon, but it is very painful to see our former colleagues making ground-breaking, world-leading discoveries as citizens of other countries."

Russia's aim now was to transfer the economy to the high-technology road, he said, yet "one of the basic preconditions for this is a strong pure science base".

Among the chaotic stacks of scientific journals in Valentin Vlassov's study are piles of photos of his old students, standing in sunshine waving happily.

From the backdrops of expensive restaurants and gleaming cars, it is obvious that they are not Russia. These are the ones who have left the tutelage of Professor Vlassov, one of the country's leading biochemists, to seek new lives abroad. There are government schemes to halt such departures, focusing on giving young scientists flats and equipping labs with modern equipment. But with funds scarce, the impact has so far been minimal.

Shuffling through the pictures with arthritic fingers, Prof Vlassov listed the most talented to have gone. Among them is his son, now a research fellow in the US.

"You can't blame them for leaving. When there's no money, it's impossible to do research," he said. "But if the process goes on, Russian science will die."

Tomorrow: Rebirth.

webTitle: Boom in house price rises at end

fields.headline: Boom in house price rises at end
fields.trailText: The boom in house prices across the UK has finally come to an end, according to a report issued by the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors yesterday.
fields.body:
The boom in house prices across the UK has finally come to an end, according to a report issued by the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors yesterday.

The institution said that in the three months to the end of June house price rises were at their lowest since 1998.

The percentage of surveyors reporting a rise in house prices over those who saw a fall was only 5%. This figure represented a drop of 25% on the previous month.

The report said that this finding showed a continued slowing of house price inflation and that it signalled the end of the boom in UK prices which had lasted since early last year.

However, the institution added that with good economic and employment prospects, further price rises were likely, though at a much more moderate pace than had occurred in previous months.

A spokesman for the institution said: "With a plentiful supply of properties on most chartered surveyor estate agents' books, and the real prospect of house price reductions, the next few months should be a good time to consider buying.

"Stability in the market and realistic pricing should also help the first time buyers who have been put off by recent market conditions."

The slowdown in price inflation at national level has, however, disguised wide regional variations. In London, prices fell for the first time since 1998, with 14% of chartered surveyors reporting falls.

But in the north of England the trend is still upwards, with 39% of surveyors reporting rises - up from 23% in May.

Estate agents in Yorkshire, Humberside, and the West Midlands also reported rises, although the East Midlands, East Anglia, the south-east, south-west, and north-west reported a downturn in the rate of price inflation.

The number of transactions in the period covered dropped, with the average number of house sales for each surveyor at 30 - down 12% from the previous survey and representing the lowest level since December last year.

 Press Association

webTitle: Mugabe to quit in 2002, report says

fields.headline: Mugabe to quit in 2002, report says
fields.standfirst:
Kingmakers to groom Zimbabwe's next president
Special report: Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: President Robert Mugabe is ready to step down at the 2002 presidential election, and to let a group of kingmakers groom a successor, according to Zimbabwe's state news agency, Ziana. But the agency says the ruling Zanu-PF party leadership is deeply divided over who should succeed the 76-year-old president.
fields.body:
President Robert Mugabe is ready to step down at the 2002 presidential election, and to let a group of kingmakers groom a successor, according to Zimbabwe's state news agency, Ziana. But the agency says the ruling Zanu-PF party leadership is deeply divided over who should succeed the 76-year-old president.

Mr Mugabe, who has ruled Zimbabwe since independence in 1980, has clearly been shaken by his party's near defeat in last month's parliamentary election. Zanu-PF won just five seats more than the fledgling opposition party, the Movement for Democratic Change.

Ziana quotes "well-placed Zanu-PF sources" as saying that shortly after the election a "secretive group" was formed in the party to press for Mr Mugabe's resignation because he was considered more of a liability than an asset at the presidential ballot in two years' time.

Mr Mugabe's spokesman, George Charamba, denied that any such group had been formed. "The kingmakers' club is nothing but a phantom," he said.

But on Saturday Mr Mugabe acknowledged at Zanu-PF's first central committee meeting since the election that its results reflected general disillusionment with his party and the country.

"This amounted to a major political disaster that came our way as a party," Ziana quoted him saying.

"This could very easily translate into a deep chasm between such disgruntled supporters and the party."

The central committee meeting was described as "explosive". Ziana said a split had developed in the party between younger, more reformist members who favour the finance minister, Simba Makoni, as Mr Mugabe's replacement and the old guard, which backs the party chairman, John Nkomo, or its finance secretary, Emmerson Mnangagwa.

Meanwhile, the opposition is pressing for constitutional reform to abolish Mr Mugabe's office immediately and transfer power to a prime minister and parliament.

The party is trying to overturn Zanu-PF's majority in parliament by making legal challenges to the election results in more than 20 constituencies before tomorrow's deadline for the ballots to be reviewed.

It will tell the high court in Harare that intimidation, ballot stuffing and bribing of voters cost it victory in those seats. Zanu-PF rejected the legal challenges as "childish". The high court can order elections to be rerun if it finds evidence of irregularities.

Some white farmers have added to the pressure on the government by declaring a strike at the beginning of the planting season in protest at the failure of the police to enforce court orders requiring the removal of war veterans from their land, even after the government also ordered the squatters to leave.

"A week has gone by since the government told the war veterans to get off. We're seeing no action, so more widespread shutdowns are a possibility," said the director of the Commercial Farmers Union, David Hasluck.

The union said it believed an elderly white caretaker found murdered on a farm 90 miles south of Harare yesterday was the victim of a criminal rather than a political attack.

webTitle: Mayor's wife fails to answer judge

fields.headline: Mayor's wife fails to answer judge
fields.trailText: The wife of the French capital's embattled mayor appeared before examining magistrates yesterday accused of an election fraud which has sent former associates of the husband and wife team, including the president, Jacques Chirac, scuttling for political cover.
fields.body:
The wife of the French capital's embattled mayor appeared before examining magistrates yesterday accused of an election fraud which has sent former associates of the husband and wife team, including the president, Jacques Chirac, scuttling for political cover.

Xavière Tiberi refused to answer as she was formally questioned on charges of rigging an election in 1997 in which her husband won by 2,725 votes.

Investigators claim that 7,228 "suspect voters" were added to the electoral roll of Paris's fifth district, of which 3,315 cast their vote. Dozens of voters have come forward saying they were offered jobs or council flats in return for their inscription on the electoral roll.

The mayor, a member of the conservative Rally for the Republic party (RPR), was forced to step down in March as head of his party's local branch in the light of the scandal.

Raymond Nentien, general secretary of the municipal corporation of the fifth district, who is himself accused of fraud in the case, which has been running for two years, wrote to the court accusing the Tiberis of being the brains behind the scheme.

Mr Nentien claimed that in two meetings with the mayor, Mr Tiberi told him: "For every 10 electors who have been crossed out, eight must be inscribed."

But Mr Tiberi denies doing anything wrong. "I have always said that I was completely unaware of anything that was going on. Those who say the opposite are lying."

Mr Tiberi, deputy for the fifth district since 1968, succeeded Jacques Chirac as mayor of Paris in 1995.

The lawyer for Mr Tiberi's political confidante Anne-Marie Affret, another official indicted in the proceedings, said his client would not spill the beans on anyone.

fields.headline: Paedophile watch
fields.standfirst: Analysis
fields.trailText: The Home Office estimated that in 1993 there were at least 260,000 men aged 20 or over who had been convicted of a sexual offence of some kind, of whom 210,000 had convictions for a "sexual offence with a victim" (ie excluding offences involving only consenting adults). fields.body:
The Home Office estimated that in 1993 there were at least 260,000 men aged 20 or over who had been convicted of a sexual offence of some kind, of whom 210,000 had convictions for a "sexual offence with a victim" (ie excluding offences involving only consenting adults). About one in 60 of a sample of men born in 1953 had a conviction by the age of 40 for some type of sexual offence. Some 10% of these offenders had a further such conviction within five years of their first conviction for a sexual offence.

The same 1993 Home Office study estimated that at least 110,000 men aged 20 or over had a conviction for an offence against a child. Despite popular paranoia about predatory paedophiles kidnapping children off the street, only a handful of children - between five and 10 - are kidnapped and murdered every year by strangers.

Another popular fear - that all sex offenders will reoffend again and again - is also not borne out by the facts. One study that followed up some 4,000 offenders against children over a period of 21 years found that 16% were reconvicted of a child sex offence. A range of international studies have put re-offending rates for sexual offenders at between 15% and 43%. This is some way short of the 64% reoffending rate for child sex offenders presented by the News of the World to justify their ill- conceived "campaign".

Though the majority of abused children do not go on to become abusers, most child sexual abusers were themselves abused as children (70% according to a recent Home Office study of participants in sex-offender treatment programmes). This means that reducing the risk of sex offenders abusing children should help to reduce the prevalence of sex offending in the future.

The sex-offender register is probably the best-known recent initiative for managing sex offenders in the community. It came into force on September 1, 1997 and requires sex offenders who, after that date, were convicted or cautioned, were serving a custodial or community sentence, or were being supervised to notify the police of their names and addresses and of any subsequent changes. This requirement lasts for periods of time that vary according to the seriousness of the offence but it is a lifetime requirement for anyone imprisoned for 30 months or more.

The sex-offenders register is a useful, though limited, power. It can help the police apprehend a suspect if an offence takes place, but it does little to reduce the risk of offending. Though there have been some concerns about how few sex offenders are coming forward to register, this problem will be made immeasurably worse if paedophiles fear reprisals. Perhaps the single greatest loophole in the current legislation is that those who kill a child with a sexual motivation are not covered by the register, as their crime is deemed to be violent, rather than sexual. This means that, when caught, Sarah Payne's killer may not be required to register, if he or she were to be released from prison.

The 1998 Crime and Disorder Act enables courts to order the post-release supervision of such offenders for periods of up to 10 years. This should improve public protection and the prospects for rehabilitating offenders. Post-release supervision can include conditions requiring, for example, offenders to live in supervised accommodation, to stay away from specified places or people, or to take part in treatment programmes. Failure to cooperate can result in recall to prison.

A recent survey by the probation inspectorate found that 93% of sex offenders, and 96% of those in probation hostels, did not reoffend while under probation service supervision. If there is a problem, it is that courts are not using their powers for extended supervision as regularly as they could.

If community supervision is to be fully effective, more treatment programmes for sex offenders are needed. Treatment programmes aim to counter sex offenders' distorted beliefs; increase their awareness of the impact of their crimes on victims; make offenders accept responsibility for the results of their actions; and help them to control their deviant behaviour and avoid relapse. Recent Home Office research on sex offenders on probation orders found that 5% of those participating in treatment programmes were reconvicted within two years, around half the figure for offenders under probation supervision without a treatment programme (9%). Both the prison service and the probation service have greatly increased the number of programmes in recent years, but more than half the sex offenders supervised by the probation service and two-thirds of those discharged from prison have not been through a sex-offender treatment programme.

A second key requirement for effective supervision is stable accommodation for released sex offenders. If offenders constantly move from place to place, their supervision and treatment is disrupted. The issue was highlighted in March 1998 by the court of appeal in R v the chief constable of north Wales police. The appellants, two paedophiles, had gone to ground after being made homeless by a police decision to reveal details of their offences to a caravan site owner. While upholding the lawfulness of the police's actions, Lord Woolf's judgment stressed the importance of efforts to find appropriate accommodation for offenders when they are released from prison.

A missing piece in the current legislative jigsaw is an indeterminate sentence for dangerous offenders, which would mean that sex offenders could be held in custody for as long as they pose a risk, rather than being released when their sentence ends, regardless of the danger they pose. This is being considered by the government in the case of those with a dangerous personality disorder.

The laws for dealing with child sex offenders are not perfect, but creating a vigilante culture is no way to solve the problem of child abuse.

Richard Garside is head of communications for Nacro, the crime-reduction charity

webTitle: French town stung by mosquito report

fields.headline: French town stung by mosquito report
fields.trailText: It is the ambition of most French leaders to bequeath a monument worthy of their rule: Georges Pompidou left Paris his ill-fated tubular museum - so hi-tech it had to be almost dismantled before it could be repainted last year; François Mitterrand placed three controversial glass pyramids in the forecourt of the Louvre.
fields.body:
It is the ambition of most French leaders to bequeath a monument worthy of their rule: Georges Pompidou left Paris his ill-fated tubular museum - so hi-tech it had to be almost dismantled before it could be repainted last year; François Mitterrand placed three controversial glass pyramids in the forecourt of the Louvre.

Claude Barral, the mayor of Lunel in the south of France, wanted to go down in history as the man who freed the Camargue of its resident pest - the mosquito.

So he spent £32,000 on a 12-page report, and it has been plaguing him ever since.

The report found the obvious: that the mosquito "is characterised by a spindly body, diaphanous wings and an apparatus which injects and sucks"; in other words, it revealed that mosquitoes bite.

Mr Barral now admits that the report, which he both commissioned and wrote 13 years ago, was "bullshit". He told Libération: "At the time we didn't know; if we knew we were making a cock-up, we would not have done it."

But his honesty failed to stop lengthy litigation by one of the municipalities whose money paid for the mayor's crashing statements of the obvious.

Its case has been bolstered by a local audit commission who found it odd that an organisation of which Mr Barral was administrative secretary should have made a report to a tourist association of which Mr Barral was also the official representative. It found the cost of study "disproportionate to the work carried out".

Mr Barral claims that the current proceedings are all a plot to discredit him, but admits: "Effectively, one could consider this report to be insufficient."
