fields.headline: Season speaks volumes
fields.trailText: One day soon, a City analyst will confirm the link between the six-week summer break for Britain's schoolchildren and the level of activity in the equity market.
fields.body:
One day soon, a City analyst will confirm the link between the six-week summer break for Britain's schoolchildren and the level of activity in the equity market.

By the official close of trading yesterday - day one of the holiday - turnover in London had struggled to 930m, the lowest level since mid-June, as traders deserted the dealing rooms and headed for the sun.

"Tedious" was one broker's description of the session, noting that without the contribution of Vodafone AirTouch, London's biggest and most liquid stock, turnover would have been a paltry 810m.

Those left behind had to find other ways to brighten up their lives, such as trying to guess the next move in the ITV consolidation saga or rehashing weekend newspapers tips. So Lord Hollick's United News & Media marched up 32p to 990p as dealers looked for ward to a carve-up of the group's television assets, while Emap rose 53p to £11.80 after a weekend paper labelled the magazine publisher "undervalued".

Amid the torpor, the FTSE 100 managed to close fractionally higher, up 2.9 points at 6,381.3, with Wall Street providing little in the way of leadership following Friday's sharp sell-off.

There were pockets of interest. A rumour did the rounds late in the session that executives from internet group Freeserve had been dispatched to Germany to reopen talks with T-Online. The talks broke down in late June but the two sides are said to have remained in close contact.

However, the shares remained depressed, ending the session down 11.25p at 328.75p. It was not that dealers dismissed the tale - most believe Freeserve will eventually fall to a better capitalised rival - rather that many had their fingers burnt when the talks ended last time and are not prepared to repeat the experience.

News and information group Reuters , down 52p to £12.58, also caught the eye as it jolted lower towards the end of the session. It seems some of the City's shrewder players sold the stock short in expectation of weak first half figures today.

Analysts, by contrast, were confident Reuters will turn in sound figures. Deutsche Bank's Patrick Kirby expects to see continuation of the trends evident in the first quarter of the year: gradual acceleration in revenues within Reuters Information; buoyant volume growth at Instinet.

Bookham Technology , which manufactures integrated components for optical telecoms, benefited from some dubious lateral thinking. Somehow, the fact that Nortel Networks might sell its optical parts business to US group Corning in deal worth $100bn is good news for Bookham.

According to dealers, the deal would help justify Bookham's sky-high valuation. Floated in April, Bookham has a market capitalisation of around £6.5bn.

On a firmer footing, telecoms equipment manufacturer Marconi advanced 49p to £10.25 as it secured a £2bn contract to supply British Telecoms with equipment for its new European broadband network.

Meanwhile, a sigh of relief was heard at Tesco , up 2.25p to 216.25p, as the Metro take-over rumour was finally put to bed. Despite recent speculation, the German supermarkets group's three main shareholders have no plans to sell their stakes to Tesco or anyone else.

Market strategists are struggling to see what will pull the FTSE 100 out of the 6,200-6,600 trading range it has held for most of this year. One answer put forward yesterday is a resurgence of interest in telecom stocks, which have been out of favour since the correction on the Nasdaq in March.

Schroder Salomon Smith Barney, expects equity markets to break out of their narrow trading range soon and for telecoms to lead the way.

Nevertheless, Vodafone AirTouch was the only such stock to make real headway yesterday. It closed up 6p to 302p, helped by an upgrade from JP Morgan, which has set a target price of 448p for the stock.

 Petchey's Plan

Property tycoon Jack Petchey is at it again. Yesterday the multi-millionaire investor, who specialises in building stakes in high-yielding, low-rated stocks, increased his holding in real estate group Town Centre Securities to 11.8%.

Recently, Trefick, Mr Petchey's investment vehicle, has been busy building stakes in petrol retailer Save (currently in bid talks), Bourne End Properties (where he holds more than 25%) and car retailer European Motor Holdings.

Mr Petchey has built something of a following among small-cap investors, and his appearance on a share register is usually a prelude to some sort of corporate action.

Town Centre Securities meanwhile has all the hallmarks of a classic Petchey investment. It shares, which closed yesterday at 93.5p, trade at a discount to net asset value.

Town Centre shares are expected to move higher today and the possibility of Mr Petchey buying more should not be discounted.

fields.headline: At this price?  BSkyB
fields.trailText: Shares in BSkyB have been caught up in the market's wild swings in sentiment towards hi-tech stocks.
fields.body:
Shares in BSkyB have been caught up in the market's wild swings in sentiment towards hi-tech stocks.

Like many stocks in the media/internet sector, BSkyB peaked in March at £22.75, a breathtaking rise for anyone holding the shares since the end of last year when they were labouring for some time at around £6. The slide in net stocks between April and June brought the share back below the £10 mark.

BSkyB must partly blame itself for being caught in the volatility after announcing plans at the start of the year to spend £250m building a web-based business, although it still remains unclear where that cash will go.

Tomorrow investors will be focusing on the fundamentals and grubby facts such as subscriber numbers when the company reports its year- end results - and that should be a good thing. Analysts forecast revenues of around £1.8bn, an improvement of 16% or so, and pre-tax losses halved to between £150m and £160m. BSkyB is expected to return to profitability next year after the cost of its digital set-top box giveaway begins to subside.

Early on it identified digital as the next driver of growth in pay television and the company is expected to report net additions of 450,000 for the fourth quarter. That will bring its total digital subscribers to 3.2m and keeps it on target for 5m by the end of the calendar year.

The time spent in the red clearly has been worthwhile for the company which has stolen a march on its rivals in the spread of digital services. Telewest and NTL, its cable rivals, have likewise missed a significant opportunity by their repeated delays.

In the past 12 months BSkyB has demonstrated its determination to stay ahead. A joint venture with Kingston Communications is experimenting with broadcast via telephone wires and the company recently took control of the impressive home shopping business Open.

At £13.08, up 4p yesterday, the shares look as though they have fallen too far.

fields.headline: Michel Droit
fields.standfirst: Gaullist journalist who helped the general back to power in France
fields.trailText: Michel Droit, who has died aged 77, was a French journalist and television presenter, whose championing of General de Gaulle led to him being criticised by colleagues as "a caricature of complacency". Both highly praised and deeply despised during a long and distinguised career, he was always courageous and determined.
fields.body:
Michel Droit, who has died aged 77, was a French journalist and television presenter, whose championing of General de Gaulle led to him being criticised by colleagues as "a caricature of complacency". Both highly praised and deeply despised during a long and distinguised career, he was always courageous and determined.

Born in Vincennes, Droit was a student at the École Libre des Sciences Politiques in Paris, which he left to join the wartime resistance and to establish an independent radio service to broadcast news of German defeats. He followed the Free French first army and described the liberation of Paris.

After the war, he reported from all round the world for French radio. In 1949, he joined a young team preparing to produce television news, and began making short films and writing novels. In 1956, he started presenting the evening television news, and thus became a well-known national figure.

Apart from those who were simply jealous, there was a real split in the world of journalists and critics towards Droit's work. The French Ministry of the Interior kept a tight hold on television news; neither presenters nor producers enjoyed freedom. But it was noticed that the man who had written Le Monde's television criticism (a column he had to give up in 1956) accepted these controls only too readily.

Droit made no attempt to conceal his enthusiasm for Gaullism and de Gaulle, who returned to power in 1958, and he saw nothing abnormal in refusing to give time to those opposed to the Algerian war.

In the presidential election of December 1965, there was no winner in the first ballot, and de Gaulle faced the humiliation of having to fight François Mitterrand in the second round. Totally discouraged, he considered resignation. His advisers recommended that he show himself to the French people as he was. Michel Droit was considered the television interviewer who would display the general to best advantage, and indeed the three resulting programmes softened the leader's Olympian image, presenting him instead as a smiling, thigh-slapping politician.

When de Gaulle won the second ballot with 54.5% of the votes, it was said that without the Droit interviews, he would not have succeeded. Droit was praised, although there were protests about television manipulating politics. In 1968 and 1969 he made two more programmes with de Gaulle, in the second of which the general announced that he would resign if defeated in the constitutional referendum (he was, and he did).

In 1960, Droit became edi tor of Figaro-Littéraire, a post he occupied for 11 years. But it was increasingly being said, particularly after 1965, that television was the enemy of culture - so Droit found himself constantly criticised. fields.headline: Barrage 'is drowning meadows'
fields.trailText: Hay meadows along the Derwent were becoming permanently waterlogged after being sacrificed to pleasure boating interests, the high court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
Hay meadows along the Derwent were becoming permanently waterlogged after being sacrificed to pleasure boating interests, the high court heard yesterday.

Known locally as "Ings", the meadows constitute a tenth of the UK's dwindling wetlands and are home to rare flora and wildfowl. Five local farmers claimed in court that the Barmby tidal barrage in East Yorkshire, operated by the environment agency, was transforming the area's ecology, driving out typical species, and leaving the hay meadows waterlogged.

The farmers, with the backing of the Yorkshire Wildlife Trust and the World Wide Fund for Nature, were asking Mr Justice Newman to order the agency to make a full assessment of the barrage's environmental impact.

Their counsel, Stephen Trumans, alleged that the agency was maintaining the river's depth at a four feet minimum for the benefit of pleasure boats which would otherwise have to wait for the tide to turn before passing upstream.

The case continues.

 Strand News Service

fields.headline: A D Hope
fields.standfirst: Australian poet whose erotic work outraged local opinion but drew international acclaim
fields.trailText: When the man who became Australia's most distinguished poet, AD Hope, published his first volume of work, The Wandering Islands, in 1955, it created the kind of scandal that most writers can only dream of. Even as its phrases - such as the "closer and closer apart" of the title poem - pass into the language, the volume has not lost its power to shock.
fields.body:
When the man who became Australia's most distinguished poet, AD Hope, published his first volume of work, The Wandering Islands, in 1955, it created the kind of scandal that most writers can only dream of. Even as its phrases - such as the "closer and closer apart" of the title poem - pass into the language, the volume has not lost its power to shock.

Hope, who has died aged 92, wrote poetry that was always explicit about sexual desire. Local outrage against it was soon overtaken by international recognition, although Hope was criticised in his own country for favouring the classical and European, rather than the local vernacular, in both his style and subject matter. Latterly, he acquired the reputation of a conservative, in poetry as in culture more generally, and although he continues to be widely anthologised and translated, much of his work has been allowed to go out of print.

Born a child of the manse, Hope spent his early years in Tasmania, where his father was a Presbyterian minister. He won scholarships to the selective Fort St high school and Sydney University, where his science results were not high enough to enable him to study medicine, though he retained a lifelong interest in both subjects. He came top of his year in English and philosophy, and won a scholarship to University College, Oxford, to read English.

In 1928 that meant the highly philological course of medieval languages; he got a third, and returned to depression-ridden Australia with no prospects. Not a doctor, not a scholar, briefly an unsuccessful schoolmaster, in those less diploma-haunted days he worked as a vocational psychologist and then as a school counsellor.

Nonetheless, a sense of being not quite good enough co-existed with great intellectual assurance. Hope made his name as a reviewer with no time for the puffery of the local product which was then the norm, and published a few poems in little magazines. In 1937, he married Penelope Robinson, a civil servant, with whom he had two sons and a daughter, and lectured in literature, first at the Sydney Teachers' College, and from 1945 as senior lecturer at the University of Melbourne. He read constantly and widely, taught himself more languages - including Russian and some Arabic - wrote, and talked.

In postwar Australia the radio played a crucial role in education, and Hope both lectured for distance learning and played the role of "Anthony Inkwell" in a children's programme, The Argonauts, which encouraged young Australians to write, and to hear their writing discussed. His friendships with other writers and talented students, were convivial, often bibulous, but also intense.

In 1951 Hope became the first professor of English at the fledgling Canberra University College (now the Australian National University), where he lectured on European literature, although he also became instrumental in establishing the teaching of Australian literature in Australian universities.

He nonetheless excoriated what he viewed as the pretentious styles of Patrick White's The Tree Of Man and Max Harris's The Vegetative Eye, and ridiculed the "Jindyworobaks", who made the first attempt to appropriate Aboriginal culture for their poems. White never forgave him, and Harris's vengeful review of The Wandering Islands managed to characterise it as both sensuous and boring. It won the Grace Levin Prize in 1956.

Hope only wrote formal verse, and often returned to the traditional themes of western poetry. Opposing the Vietnam war, he wrote a variation on the Greek inscription at Thermopylae. His writing is allusive, learned, often erotic, sometimes very funny. And he wrote with a ferocious intelligence. Imperial Adam, one of his most anthologised poems, looks again at paradise, and, like Dali's God's-eye crucifixion, makes it new. This is the puzzled father of mankind looking at Eve:

The gravid elephant, the calving hind,

The breeding bitch, the she-ape big with young

Were the first gentle midwives of mankind;

The teeming lioness rasped her with her tongue;

The proud vicuña nuzzled her as she slept

Lax on the grass; and Adam watching too

Saw how her dumb breasts at their ripening wept,

The great pod of her belly swelled and grew,

And saw its water break, and saw, in fear,

Its quaking muscles in the act of birth,

Between her legs a pigmy face appear,

And the first murderer lay upon the earth.

He published a dozen volumes of poetry, as well as an imitation of Pope's Dunciad, and his talent was recognised by a steady series of awards and prizes, from the Arts Council of Great Britain Award (1965) to the Ingram Merrill Award (1969) and the Robert Frost Award (1976). He was elected to the American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters, and became a foundation fellow of the Australian Academy of the Humanities. He read and lectured all over the world.

Since he was 48 when his first volume of poems appeared, it is perhaps not surprising that much of what Hope subsequently published came after he took early retirement to concentrate on writing. His critical essays made three books, and he wrote a strange meditation on a long medieval dream poem, as well as a book about the reading and the writing of poetry. Eventually, inevitably, he became a set author in Australian schools.

He and Penelope were wonderfully hospitable and encouraging to younger writers, and their house was filled with the sense of things being made. She and their daughter predeceased him; he is survived by his twin sons, Andrew and Geoffrey.

Ruth Morse

fields.headline: Anna Sosenko
fields.trailText: The formidable Manhattan figure, Anna Sosenko, who has died aged 90, wrote the hit song Darling, Je Vous Aime Beaucoup, and was the longtime manager of the legendary cabaret singer, Hildegarde.
fields.body:
The formidable Manhattan figure, Anna Sosenko, who has died aged 90, wrote the hit song Darling, Je Vous Aime Beaucoup, and was the longtime manager of the legendary cabaret singer, Hildegarde.

The two met when Hildegarde, touring as a pianist in scratch bands, lodged at Sosenko's parents' boarding house in New Jersey. Young Anna, then a music student, persuaded the entertainer to let her accompany her to New York, in a bid to become a songwriter. In the event, she went on to oversee Hildegarde's own career as a cabaret performer, in an act which was, according to singer Bobby Short, "produced down to the last sigh, even to the blue spotlight that brought out the colour in the red roses that invariably sat by her piano".

Sosenko had realised that cabaret is an art into which an audience has to be tastefully seduced. She and Hildegarde went to Paris to see how it should be done. It was a tough time; at one point, a hotel owner took pity on them and gave them free food and lodgings for a year. That changed when Hildegarde began to attract admirers, such as King Gustaf of Sweden.

In 1935, Sosenko wrote the million-selling Darling, Je Vous Aime Beaucoup after a bicyle ride in France when she and Hildegarde mixed up their French and English while asking for directions. Recorded with Carroll Gibbons and his Boy Friends, it features such lines as "Je ne sais pas what to do/ Vous avez completely stolen my heart". Other Sosenko songs included I'll Be Yours, Ask Your Heart and Why Don't They Leave Us Alone?

Back in America, Sosenko began to build on the act's European success. She advised Hildegarde on a new cabaret act - play piano in gloves, she urged, tell mildly risqué jokes and greet cele- brities by name. Her philosophy was summarised thus: "You have to play phoney to get along". Together, their success was phenomenal. Stout and freckled, Sosenko was a tough cookie on behalf of her svelte charge.

For 23 years, she and Hildegarde worked together as equal partners. In New York, they shared a 10-room apartment and built up an art collection - chosen by Sosenko - that included Renoir, Manet and 40 Rowlandsons. The partnership never had anything so formal as a contract and exactly why it broke up in 1956 is not clear. As Hildegarde once said: "These things do happen after 20 years".

A fter it was over, Sosenko continued to produce radio shows, and developed her interest in manuscripts and memorabilia, in which she traded at a small shop near New York's Lincoln Center until a few years ago. She was a familiar figure on the theatrical scene, a force behind the theatre collection at the city museum, for which she prevailed upon the eminent to perform at benefits.

She lived by palpably energetic lights, always happy to reminisce - she was "in Philadelphia for the original opening of Girl Crazy, with Ethel Merman and Ginger Rogers, and George Gershwin conducting in the pit; now that's what you call thrilling" - but was never locked into the past.

She continued to write songs in her 80s. One, On The Outside Looking In, was given its premiere a few years ago by Hildegarde, with whom she was now reconciled - "It would be absurd not to at our age," the singer told me. They even performed together. One could tell that there must always have been a certain badinage between them. Always described as formidable, Sosenko was at heart kindly and dignified.

Christopher Hawtree

fields.headline: Teenage killers can be named
fields.trailText: An Old Bailey judge's ruling allowing the naming of three juvenile members of the gang which murdered student Timothy Baxter by throwing him into the Thames, was yesterday upheld in the high court, London.
fields.body:
An Old Bailey judge's ruling allowing the naming of three juvenile members of the gang which murdered student Timothy Baxter by throwing him into the Thames, was yesterday upheld in the high court, London.

Lawyers for Alan West, now 17, Shaun Copeland, 15, and Toni Blankson, 17, failed in their attempt to quash Judge Ann Goddard's decision to lift an order preventing disclosure of their identities in the media.

The three, with three adults, were sentenced on May 19 for murdering Mr Baxter, 24, and attempting to murder his friend, Gabriel Cornish, 25. The two students were thrown into the river after being robbed on Hungerford Bridge in central London a year ago. Mr Baxter drowned.

Judge Goddard sentenced the three adults to life imprisonment and ordered the juveniles to be detained at Her Majesty's pleasure.

She said the juveniles should be identified because it was important that the public should know as much as possible about the case.

Peter Clarke QC, appearing for West, argued that "naming and shaming" was not in the public interest and was an improper use of of deterrence, which would result in families of notorious young criminals being hounded.

But Lord Justice Rose, sitting with Mrs Justice Rafferty, said of Judge Goddard's decision: "It is quite impossible to say she exercised her discretion in a flawed or inappropriate way."

He lifted the anonymity order, which had remained in place pending yesterday's hearing.

 Press Association

webTitle: Police form squad to cut gang killings

fields.headline: Police form squad to cut gang killings
fields.trailText: An elite squad of more than 160 police officers has been set up to focus on black gunmen with the aim of cutting the number of gang-related murders, it was announced yesterday.
fields.body:
An elite squad of more than 160 police officers has been set up to focus on black gunmen with the aim of cutting the number of gang-related murders, it was announced yesterday.

Among the team will be a detective who will be posted to Jamaica to gather intelligence on contract killers who regularly travel to England to carry out shootings.

The Metropolitan police revealed the measures as part of an attempt to step up Operation Trident, a strategy against gun crime in London.

There have been seven murders and more than 21 attempted murders this year. Last year there were 29 gun murders involving the black community.

Commander Michael Fuller said innocent people were often caught up in the gang warfare, which was often triggered by disputes over crack cocaine dealing.

Anthony Brightley, the owner of Chimes night club in east London, and a member of the Trident independent advisory group, said: "We have known what the problem has been. Operation Trident is the solution."

 Press Association

fields.headline: In brief
fields.body:
UN soldier killed in East Timor

A New Zealand soldier became the first UN peacekeeper killed in East Timor yesterday, during a battle in the former Indonesian province where pro-Jakarta militias still attack independence supporters.

Private Leonard Manning, 24, was patrolling along the border with West Timor when he was shot in the head, according to a UN official, who said it was the third serious attack on UN peacekeeping troops in the region. AP, Bangkok

Two journalists taken by rebels

Two local journalists covering the hostage crisis on Jolo island in the southern Philippines for a local television network were seized yesterday by Islamic rebels.

The journalists, who work for the ABS-CBN network, were travelling to an Abu Sayyaf rebel hideout to interview seven European hostages when three armed men stopped their vehicle and led them off into the jungle, according to their driver. AP, Jolo

Chinese bears saved by pact

The Chinese authorities signed an unprecedented agreement with an animal welfare group in Hong Kong yesterday to release 500 endangered Asiatic black bears which are being used to yield ingredients for Chinese medicine.

The agreement between the China Wildlife Conservation Association, Sichuan forestry department and the Animals Asia Foundation means the bears can be released from the farms in Sichuan where many lie sick and injured in metal cages with dirty catheters, used to extract gallbladder bile, protruding from their stomachs. AP, Hong Kong

Mass grave may hold 200 bodies

An excavation team has found a suspected mass grave that may hold more than 200 North Vietnamese soldiers killed and bulldozed into a pit by US forces during the Vietnam war.

Four sets of arm and leg bones have been recovered from a 3,000 sq-metre area being excavated by 40 soldiers in the central province of Quang Tri. The recovery of the remains is expected to take them a month. AP, Hanoi

Court orders tallship freed

A French court yesterday ordered the release of the Russian sailing vessel which was detained in the north-western port of Brest as part of a legal battle about unpaid Russian debts.

The county court in Brest also ordered the Swiss trading company Noga, which requested the seizure of the Sedov to recoup the money it says it is owed by the Russian government, to pay compensation to the tallship's owners. AP, Brest

Ten feared dead in bus explosion

As many as 10 people were killed when a bomb ripped through a bus in the northern Indian state of Punjab yesterday.

The bus was on its way to Jalandhar from Pathankot, near the Kashmiri border. Reuters, Chandigarh

Private Leonard Manning, 24, was patrolling along the border with West Timor when he was shot in the head, according to a UN official, who said it was the third serious attack on UN peacekeeping troops in the region. AP, Bangkok Two journalists taken by rebels Two local journalists covering the hostage crisis on Jolo island in the southern Philippines for a local television network were seized yesterday by Islamic rebels. The journalists, who work for the ABS-CBN network, were travelling to an Abu Sayyaf rebel hideout to interview seven European hostages when three armed men stopped their vehicle and led them off into the jungle, according to their driver. AP, Jolo Chinese bears saved by pact The Chinese authorities signed an unprecedented agreement with an animal welfare group in Hong Kong yesterday to release 500 endangered Asiatic black bears which are being used to yield ingredients for Chinese medicine. The agreement between the China Wildlife Conservation Association, Sichuan forestry department and the Animals Asia Foundation means the bears can be released from the farms in Sichuan where many lie sick and injured in metal cages with dirty catheters, used to extract gallbladder bile, protruding from their stomachs. webTitle: Giuliani orders spraying for killer virus

fields.headline: Giuliani orders spraying for killer virus
fields.trailText: Insecticide-spraying helicopters will return to New York this week for the first time since the West Nile virus killed seven people last year.
fields.body:
Insecticide-spraying helicopters will return to New York this week for the first time since the West Nile virus killed seven people last year.

The city's mayor, Rudi Giuliani, decided to use aerial spraying after the discovery of four dead birds infected with the virus. The helicopters were expected to spray large areas of Queens, Staten Island and Brooklyn, the three boroughs next to Manhattan.

Seven infected birds, crows and a merlin, have been found in New York so far this year. There have also been reports of the disease in Connecticut and New Jersey.

The disease spreads from birds to humans through mosquitoes. A particularly virulent outbreak killed seven people in New York state last year and seriously affected 55 others.

So far this year the intensive surveillance system set up by the city has prevented the disease spreading to humans. A helpline to inform people about the disease said yesterday that the spraying was designed "to prevent the spread of West Nile virus to humans".

Mr Giuliani, seeking to reduce concern about another outbreak, said the spraying was a precautionary measure.

"People should not be alarmed, they should not be concerned," he said. "These are all things that we assumed we would have to do."

He added that the outbreak was not as bad as last year's.

In the spring, the city authorities used larvicide in storm drains and other waterways to kill as many larval mosquitoes as possible.

Public health officials advised residents to clean roof drains, unchlorinated pools and piles of old tyres which might serve as a mosquito breeding ground.

Most mosquitoes do not fly very far from where they are born. The helicopters are expected to cover a 2-mile radius from the site of the dead birds' discovery.

Concern about the impact of the insecticide on wildlife in Staten Island, where there are large areas of marshland, caused some friction between the mayor and the federal and state environmental officials.

Nevertheless, Dr Neal Cohen, the city health commissioner, said the state had allowed the use of the pesticide "in the face of a public health threat".

Several public helplines advised people to stay indoors during the spraying, which usually takes place after 10pm.

webTitle: Colorado bush fire threatens ancient site

fields.headline: Colorado bush fire threatens ancient site
fields.standfirst: Heatwave conditions allow blaze to create its own weather
fields.trailText: A fire in the Colorado Rockies which has doubled in size in the past 24 hours is threatening to engulf some of North America's most important pre-Columbian archaeological sites, but it has also exposed several new sites as it roars through the tinder-dry brush.
fields.body:
A fire in the Colorado Rockies which has doubled in size in the past 24 hours is threatening to engulf some of North America's most important pre-Columbian archaeological sites, but it has also exposed several new sites as it roars through the tinder-dry brush.

Last night the fire in the Mesa Verde national park in south-west Colorado covered 17,000 acres (6,900 hectares) and was within miles of the park's priceless and spectacular native American cliff dwellings, which mainly date from the 13th century.

"The fire is doing what it wants, and everything is imperilled," a spokesman for the fire-fighting operation, Justin Dombrowski, said.

"It's a big powerful fire. Right now it's moving so fast and so far that it puts everything in that park at a greater threat."

With temperatures in the western United States continuing at record levels, the hot dry weather offers little immediate hope that the blaze will be brought under control. Firefighters again bombarded it from the air with retardant chemicals and thousands of gallons of water yesterday, but the rough terrain and deep valleys of the Mesa Verde hamper all efforts from land and air.

None of the main historical sites in the Mesa Verde - the only wholly archaeological national park in the United States - has yet been struck by the fire, but the flames are less than three miles from the unique and evocative ruins known as Cliff Palace, a 13th century village consisting of more than 200 rooms wedged in the overhang of a sandstone rock face.

More than a thousand tourists were evacuated from the park when the fire started last Thursday, probably from a lightning strike.

"As long as the fire continues to create its own weather inside and around it, it's going to grow," said Chuck Maxwell, the fire team weather adviser.

A second fire 25 miles to the north of the Mesa Verde has further stretched the emergency services.

"We're running short on resources," a fire service coordinator in nearby Durango said.

Archaeologists remain hopeful that the cliff dwellings and other buried sites will survive whatever the fire has in store, but the sandstone from which the buildings are made is vulnerable to extreme heat, which can cause it to explode.

The impending disaster has a silver lining for archaeology, however, since the fire has revealed at least a dozen previously unknown sites on the flat-top mountains of the area, which are normally covered in the green juniper, pinyon and oak brush. A fire in 1996 led to the discovery of more than a hundred new sites.

"It's a bit of a trade-off," said Jane Anderson, a National Park Service archaeologist. "It's exciting to see the new ruins and get that information, but at the same time, fire can destroy these sites."

The beautiful ruins, which nestle high in the cliff alcoves of the remote mountains near the New Mexico border, were mostly built between 1190 and 1270, and are believed to have housed several thousand Pueblo Indians before they were mysteriously evacuated around 1300.

Since the ruins were discovered a century ago, they have become a major tourist attraction, a cradle of New Age cultural activity. and a source of intensive academic dispute.

Although some historians have tried to portray Pueblo life as a native American idyll which was destroyed by the arrival of the Spaniards, a University of Utah study last year argued that the inhabitants of Mesa Verde may have been cannibals.

webTitle: Model girl pupil on trial as gang boss

fields.headline: Model girl pupil on trial as gang boss
fields.trailText: A teenager who was a star student at her exclusive Pretoria girls' school may be jailed for up to 25 years for allegedly masterminding a gang of armed robbers.
fields.body:
A teenager who was a star student at her exclusive Pretoria girls' school may be jailed for up to 25 years for allegedly masterminding a gang of armed robbers.

Tanya Oosthuizen, 19, is accused of using sex to induce young men to steal in order to raise money for the defence of her boyfriend, who is facing trial for the attempted murder of a policeman.

All four male members of the gang were convicted earlier this month. Their theft at gunpoint of cars, jewellery and other valuables raised more than 150,000 rand (£15,000).

Miss Oosthuizen, the daughter of a millionaire businessman from Warmbaths, north of Johannesburg, appeared in court in leg irons on six charges of armed robbery.

The court ordered her to be detained at Pretoria's maximum security prison while psychiatric tests are made.

The prosecution told the court that one gang member William Prinsloo, 18, with whom Ms Oosthuizen had sex, made just 1,000 rand from the crimes, half of which he spent on a tattoo.

Miss Oosthuizen was a straight-A student and head of her house at Pretoria high school for girls, but was described as "going off the rails" after she became a waitress in a strip club, where she met Andre Venter, 23. The police said he was "very dominating".

webTitle: Sell-off plans test Indian PM's mettle

fields.headline: Sell-off plans test Indian PM's mettle
fields.standfirst: Nationalists and ministers threaten privatisation
fields.trailText: India's ambitious privatisation programme is in danger of being blown off course by the powerful Hindu right and disgruntled ministers unwilling to give up their lavish perks.
fields.body:
India's ambitious privatisation programme is in danger of being blown off course by the powerful Hindu right and disgruntled ministers unwilling to give up their lavish perks.

The prime minister, Atal Bihari Vajpayee, showed his determination to face down his critics - many of them among his natural supporters - by appointing a new hardline minister for privatisation yesterday, the ex-journalist Arun Shourie.

Since he was returned to power in October, Mr Vajpayee's plans to transform India's vast and notoriously inefficient public sector have run into trouble. So far only one state business, Modern Foods, an ancient bread factory on the outskirts of Delhi, has been privatised.

Earlier this year Mr Shourie's predecessor, Arun Jaitley, announced plans to sell off at least 10 state companies, including airlines, telecommunications businesses, and car manufacturers.

But the proposal was immediately opposed by the Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh (RSS), the militant ideological wing of Mr Vajpayee's Bharatiya Janata party (BJP). The RSS's new chief, KS Sudarshan, has made it clear that he is against foreign investment in India. He advocates a policy of swadeshi (economic self-sufficiency).

Since most BJP members are also members of the RSS, Mr Sudarshan's views carry some weight. Earlier this month Mr Vajpayee postponed a crucial meeting on privatisation to allow his finance minister, Yashwant Sinha, to reach agreement with his RSS critics.

India's public sector is not in good shape. Lunchtime visitors to the New Delhi office of Air India, for example, may be surprised to find that only one of the 37 counters is open.

"The staff have gone off to play cards or take a nap," a passenger said wearily. "They don't have to bother with the customer because they get money from the government in any case."

Since 1995, Air India's losses have grown to £3.7m.

But not everyone accepts the wisdom of privatisation, even in Mr Vajpayee's government. Several coalition partners who hold important ministerial portfolios have dug in their heels. They include the civil aviation minister, Sharad Yadav, who argued against the sale of Air India.

After a cabinet meeting last month, plans to sell MTNL and VSNL, the state telephone and internet companies, were postponed. So was the sale of Maruti, India's biggest car manufacturer, whose family saloons adorn every middle-class Indian driveway. Nineteen less contentious sell-offs were approved.

"The big decisions have yet to be taken," Dr S Bhide, the chief economist at the National Council for Applied Economic Research, said.

As things stand, ministers who oversee large state industries enjoy free accommodation at five-star hotels and foreign travel. Some are reluctant to give up these perks up. "I'm all for privatisation, as long as it's not my ministry," one said.

The communists, and many of the unions, are also against a large-scale sell-off.

Those responsible for the "disinvestment" policy remain bullish.

"There is bound to be opposition. You in Britain had a miners' strike for a year," Pradip Baijal, the secretary of the newly formed department for disinvestment, said.

webTitle: Filipino maids burned by Hong Kong employers

fields.headline: Filipino maids burned by Hong Kong employers
fields.trailText: Branding with an iron has acquired an ugly contemporary meaning in Hong Kong where there have been two cases reported recently of employers using a hot domestic iron to punish their foreign servants.
fields.body:
Branding with an iron has acquired an ugly contemporary meaning in Hong Kong where there have been two cases reported recently of employers using a hot domestic iron to punish their foreign servants.

Imelda Cacatian, a 40-year-old Filipino, was treated for burns last week after her taitai (madam) ran a hot iron over her forearm.

A police spokesman said her employer had called for her several times without response while she was ironing clothes.

"She was scalded on her right forearm with the iron by her employer," the spokesman said. "Her arm swelled up and part of the skin was peeling off."

The 74-year-old employer was arrested.

In May another taitai was jailed for 18 months for inflicting grievous bodily harm on her maid with an iron.

Liu Man-kuan was enraged by her Filipino maid, Achacoso Cabaneros, scorching her camisole, the court was told. Ms Liu made her put her hands flat on the ironing board and pressed on them with the iron, telling her: "This is payment for what you have done."

The magistrate who sentenced Ms Liu, Colin Mackintosh, commented: "Domestic helpers are vulnerable to abuse within the confinement and privacy of a home".

Last week a well-known Hong Kong lawyer, Dixon Tang, was convicted of raping and indecently assaulting one of his family's Filipino servants. The servant told the court that she had earlier allowed Mr Tang to indecently assault her because she feared she would be sacked.

In another incident reported last week a Filipino maid claimed that her employer had poured boiling water over her hand. She said her employer had reprimanded her for not washing up kitchen utensils properly.

"She didn't believe I had washed them with hot water because the bowls were dry. I told her the bowls were dry because the air-conditioner was on," she said.

The employer was questioned by the police and released on bail.

Support groups for foreign servants say that the law is tilted in favour of the employer. A sacked servant who does not find another job promptly will be deported.

Unscrupulous Hong Kong Chinese employers and the employment agencies which bring in the servants are known to hold on to their passport to keep them under control.

Last year the government yielded to pressure from local employers and cut the minimum salary of foreign servants from HK$3,860 (£320) to HK$3,670 (£305) a month. There have been complaints of employers paying below the minimum wage, particularly to Indonesian migrants, who are willing to work for less.

The number of foreign servants, mostly women who do household chores and look after children, rose to 201,000 in April, of whom 140,000 come from the Philippines.

Adrian Bernie Canbolada, an official at the Philippine consulate, says the victims in these cases are being encouraged to seek civil damages. He hoped other domestic servants would be encouraged by the publicity to speak out.

webTitle: Minister pledges £250m home aid for key workers

fields.headline: Minister pledges £250m home aid for key workers
fields.trailText: Nurses, teachers and other essential workers priced out of property "hot spots" such as London and the booming south east could soon be offered government subsidies in order to qualify for a mortgage.
fields.body:
Nurses, teachers and other essential workers priced out of property "hot spots" such as London and the booming south east could soon be offered government subsidies in order to qualify for a mortgage.

Ministers yesterday announced the creation of a £250m fund under which key staff, as well as workers in shops, catering and other services, would be given a first step on the housing ladder - partly at public expense.

The housing minister, Nick Raynsford, said this could involve interest-free top-up loans, cash for deposits, and help with shared ownership schemes, under which a government funded housing association might own half the equity of a home. But the so-called "starter homes initiative" could depend on employers chipping in with half the extra cost in targeted areas of high demand, such as the south east where house prices rose by 23% last year.

Unveiling a package of measures to help people find accommodation in the south, where there is also a growing shortage of homes to rent, Mr Raynsford said: "We think there is a lot of scope for innovative new thinking and particularly want to hear from employers who would make a contribution themselves - but that would be matched by funding from us."

When John Prescott, Mr Raynsford's boss, first floated the idea three months ago, government sources indicated that the deputy prime minister was considering an interest-free scheme of top-up mortgages of up to £50,000 on homes at the lower end of the market costing £125,000 or less. Employers were not mentioned.

Sources said that potential buyers would still have to find a commercial lender to give a £75,000 mortgage for a £125,000 home but the government would top this up with £50,000 interest-free - potentially saving buyers almost £2,000 a year.

The aim is to run the scheme with local councils and housing associations. Yesterday Mr Raynsford said it would be "utterly catastrophic" to give an indication of how many people might be helped in a particular area because it could lead to house prices going through the roof. "It is essentially about helping people who are priced out of the market and doing so in a way that does not have an undesirable knock-on effect on house price inflation which would clearly undermine the whole purpose."

Recent research by the National Housing Federation shows that in nearly three quarters of English counties people now need to be earning more than £20,000 annually to qualify for a mortgage. Yet a teacher with three years experience is often earning only £18,303 annually while a nurse with similar service is on just £16,000.

In eight English counties, the federation says an income of £40,000 is needed to buy a home with a 95% mortgage, although in parts of inner London the income qualification jumps to over £70,000.

Mr Raynsford also announced yesterday that the government planned to double the budget of its housing corporation to over £1.2bn by 2003-4. This could eventually lead to the building of 56,000 new affordable homes for low paid workers, mainly in London, the south east and East Anglia.

Unveiling a package of measures to help people find accommodation in the south, where there is also a growing shortage of homes to rent, Mr Raynsford said: "We think there is a lot of scope for innovative new thinking and particularly want to hear from employers who would make a contribution themselves - but that would be matched by funding from us." When John Prescott, Mr Raynsford's boss, first floated the idea three months ago, government sources indicated that the deputy prime minister was considering an interest-free scheme of top-up mortgages of up to £50,000 on homes at the lower end of the market costing £125,000 or less. Employers were not mentioned. Sources said that potential buyers would still have to find a commercial lender to give a £75,000 mortgage for a £125,000 home but the government would top this up with £50,000 interest-free - potentially saving buyers almost £2,000 a year. The aim is to run the scheme with local councils and housing associations. Yesterday Mr Raynsford said it would be "utterly catastrophic" to give an indication of how many people might be helped in a particular area because it could lead to house prices going through the roof. "It is essentially about helping people who are priced out of the market and doing so in a way that does not have an undesirable knock-on effect on house price inflation which would clearly undermine the whole purpose." Recent research by the National Housing Federation shows that in nearly three quarters of English counties people now need to be earning more than £20,000 annually to qualify for a mortgage. Yet a teacher with three years experience is often earning only £18,303 annually while a nurse with similar service is on just £16,000. In eight English counties, the federation says an income of £40,000 is needed to buy a home with a 95% mortgage, although in parts of inner London the income qualification jumps to over £70,000. Mr Raynsford also announced yesterday that the government planned to double the budget of its housing corporation to over £1.2bn by 2003-4. This could eventually lead to the building of 56,000 new affordable homes for low paid workers, mainly in London, the south east and East Anglia.

fields.headline: University, eh?
fields.standfirst: Changing the aspirations of children from poorer backgrounds has not proved easy, but universities are now embarking on some novel schemes to attract them.  John Beckett, Helen Carter and Martin Wainwright  find out more
fields.trailText: Changing the aspirations of children from poorer backgrounds has not proved easy, but universities are now embarking on some novel schemes to attract them. John Beckett, Helen Carter and Martin Wainwright find out more.
fields.byline: John Beckett, Helen Carter and Martin Wainwright
fields.body:
Years of rhetoric about opening up universities to the children of low-income families have so far failed to alter the present imbalance. In fact the position is actually getting worse.

However, exciting schemes to reach out to these youngsters are happening at universities around the country this summer, though they will take years to make an impact. As a report by Sir David Watson, vice-chancellor of Brighton University, and Rachel Bowden makes clear, the proportion of students from blue-collar backgrounds has remained virtually the same since Lord Dearing's report on higher education was compiled in 1996.

A taste of campus life for inner city kids

Over the past few weeks universities have been working to change their future student population. Excellence in Cities summer schools, involving Year 11 and 12 students from 24 inner urban boroughs, have been taking place in 70 universities with more to follow over the next two months.

The government is funding the summer schools, this year involving 5,000 students, with the aim of helping students who have the academic ability to benefit from higher education, but may be prevented from looking at the full range of courses, or even looking at all, by their educational and social background.

The aims of the universities involved centred on raising the aspirations of students and opening their eyes to possibilities. Harinder Lawley, Head of Access Development at North London, saw the summer school as "a new way of working with the local community", offering a chance to show local students "a realistic glimpse of what it will be like to be a student in higher education".

The summer schools have been a mixture of residential and non-residential. Leicester's 55 students 'in residence' came from Birmingham and London, whilst LSE's 200 travelled in each day from two nearby London boroughs, Waltham Forest and Hammersmith and Fulham. Students attended for a week of lectures, talks, visits and project work, which they presented at the end, and also had social activities laid on. A variety of university staff were involved, ranging from academics delivering talks to postgraduates acting as mentors or "buddies".

Judging by the comments from all those involved, some remarkable things have been achieved in a short space of time. Rosie Gosling, Director Higher Education Summer Schools at LSE remarked that "the enthusiasm has been tremendous and infectious." East Anglia found their summer school students to be "very lively, contributive and quick to learn." Bruce Lyons, Dean of Social Sciences, said that at the final session it was clear that "they had really enjoyed the intellectual, as well as the social, experience. As I sat and watched a tingle went up my neck and I felt genuinely moved."

Student comments are just as positive - words like "brilliant", "great", "marvellous", "excellent", "exciting" crop up with regularity in the feedback sheets, with many wishing it had been two weeks rather than one and wanting to return next year! Many talked of being less intimidated by the idea of going to university: "it has made me more confident about applying to university despite the costs;" others of becoming aware of "the opportunities university opens up for you and how you need to learn to adapt to new experiences."

The true test of the summer schools' success is the entry into higher education of these students. Leicester plan to track their students over the next two or three years in terms of applications to Leicester and success in being made offers, starting a course and progressing through their degree. Hopefully other universities will follow this approach. We must not disappoint students whose expectations have been transformed over the past few weeks.

Strathclyde targets a critical age group

A summer academy developed by the University of Strathclyde and aimed at encouraging teenagers to achieve their full potential is underway again, after the phenomenal success of its inaugural year in 1999.

The Summer Academy at Strathclyde - known as S@S - will involve hundreds of pupils from eight local authorities in the west of Scotland. It consists of a series of two-week courses based on a number of challenges, team building and sport activities. Everything from volleyball, relaxation techniques, creating web pages and dramatic improvisation will be covered in the curriculum.

The university has targeted 14-year-olds, whose level of motivation is crucial to their success in Standard and Higher Grade exams. Fourteen has been identified as a key age at which pupils lose interest in academic progression. The academic content of the academy covers the core subject areas of the curriculum within a series of challenges involving manipulative and design skills, maths, creative writing and problem solving.

Of the 650 pupils who took part last year, 98% said they thought classmates who had not gone had missed out; 86% said this was because it was good fun and 56% because they tried out new interests and activities.

A key component in the success of the programme was the contribution of 50 Student Teacher Assistant Role Models (Stars), all of whom were students at the university. They were credited with motivating, stimulating, guiding, facilitating learning and fostering reflection in the students.

Cambridge Policy Consultants, who evaluated the 1999 academy, said: "This was clearly picked up on by pupils, many of whom comment on how much they liked looking up to the Stars and how well they thought they had been supported. Often differences between their school teachers and the Stars were mentioned, such as the fact that Stars talked to them as equals, did not shout and were fun to be with."

The consultants concluded that S@S has had a positive impact on almost all participants in terms of confidence and communication. Even where it has not been able push pupils over boundaries, it has given them a boost. The full impact will only become apparent over time.

Hull keeps its bright sparks glowing

Robert Bourne was virtually swallowed up by his academic gown on graduation day at Hull - not surprisingly, because the billowing folds aren't usually tailored for people aged only 13.

Togged out in the Hull University robes, plus a cap and a scroll from the chancellor and senate, Robert was one of 350 schoolchildren from the city invited to the bunfight, in one of the latest - and youngest-targeted -moves to widen access to universities.

Alongside Hull City Tigers mementos, his mantelpiece at home in Hedon now has a formal offer of a place at the city university in five years' time, provided he can jump the appropriate hurdles at GCSE and A-level. It isn't preferential, because Hull and its partner in the scheme, the University of Lincolnshire and Humberside, have no intention of lowering standards. But it is intended to keep a bright spark glowing through sometimes difficult years.

"Robert's been asking questions ever since he learned to speak," said his mother, Diane Bourne, a Hull school dinner lady, who was proudly at the city's Guildhall for the ceremony, which turned out all the local great and good, including the playwright John Godber. "He seems to be interested in everything - it can get quite exhausting at home."

Targeting Robert, and the top 10% of new arrivals in the first year at each of Hull's 16 secondary schools, was the project's initial strategy, which required the children to enrol in and carry out a six-month course of weekend extra lessons, pairing with student mentors and visiting the universities, to earn their scrolls - each a written offer of a degree course - from Lord Dearing. Using Sats, teacher reports and interviews with the children, the programme set out to locate and raise the sights of families where university had simply not been considered an option.

"There are plenty of children in Hull who haven't any idea that they even can get to university," said Hilary Jones, schools liaison officer at Hull University, which has fielded professors alongside the student mentors for the mini-students' taster course. "The scheme says to them: you've been identified as an achiever; now we're going to help you carry on that way, to become an effective learner who can and will go on to get the necessary grades." It also creates a bright cohort, with its own peer group pressure to treat learning as "cool".

Robert positively bounces with the accolade, like most children given an encouraging pat; and his counterparts appear to spreading the message to classrooms that the more formal ways of UCAS seldom reach. The key feature of the Hull scheme is that 10% are taken from each and every high school in the city, giving those at the bottom of the exam league table an equal chance.

Since Hull had the worst league table results in the country last year, for the second year running, this is crucial stuff. The city council, which is also investing £35m in school repairs from its telecom bonanza (the hugely successful float of the municipally-owned local phone company with its famous white kiosks) backs the scheme with vim. Hand-picked "inspirational teachers" have been seconded to the students' three-hour Saturday sessions at the two universities.

Dr Andy Swallow, assistant director of education for Hull, says: "Just over 96% of pupils picked for the pilot scheme have stayed the course, many more than originally expected. We had good reason for optimism, though, after research at local schools and the Hull Children's University" (a council innovation which tempts children as young as seven with even smaller academic gowns than Robert's, plus courses such as "Literacy and ice skating").

"It's been really good," said Robert, whose only regret was that his dad, also Robert, had to watch the ceremony on a camcorder video because it clashed with his late shift at a Hull chemical plant. That work has been a bonus too , however. Robert says: "My dad got me interested in science through telling me about his job. I like setting challenges for myself and having someone to explain stuff, and the teachers at the university are fantastic, almost as good as dad."

Achievers in Excellence has been singled out for praise by the Department for Education , as a successful way of firing pupils' imagination and ambition. David Blunkett calls it: "an exciting initiative which should really make a difference, giving young people a taste of what higher education has to offer." Hilary Jones of Hull University bears him out: "We had a big do at the Guildhall when we launched the scheme in January, with the whole family coming along with each student, and there was a real feelgood factor. Mums and dads were coming out afterwards and saying: 'Well then - a place at university, eh?' It definitely looks to be raising expectations."

 After Dearing: a mid-term report by David Watson and Rachel Bowden. £4 from Education Research Centre, University of Brighton, Bevendean House, Falmer, East Sussex BN1 9PH

fields.headline: The big spree
fields.standfirst: Will Woodward on the chancellor's new-found generosity
fields.trailText: Will Woodward on the chancellor's new-found generosity.
fields.body:
You might call it the Laura Spence dividend. For if it wasn't for the Tyneside sixth-former, and whatever propelled Gordon Brown to make her a Hillary Clinton-like symbol of British higher education - strong, noble, wronged - one doubts quite so much as £20m would have been devoted in the chancellor's comprehensive spending review last week to attracting working-class and state-school pupils to university.

Brown's decision to put some of his money where a lot of his mouth is some compensation for David Blunkett, the education secretary, who wasn't over-thrilled by the Spence controversy. Mr Blunkett has also signed up the millionaire educational philanthropist Peter Lampl to be an unpaid adviser to the Higher Education Funding Council for England.

The elitism row threw up a lot of comparisons between the UK and the US, where Spence is due to begin a course at Harvard in the autumn and where research funding dwarfs that over here. In the spending review the government won't solve the problem, though it might have ensured it doesn't get any worse. A 5.8% real- terms increase in science funding has delighted scientists, and though an extra £50m for academic pay is a drop in the ocean - about a tenth of the amount the Bett inquiry's recommendations last year would cost - it is a welcome drop, nonetheless.

Funding beyond April 2002 has not yet been set for higher education. Will that mean a radical shake-up of higher education funding in Labour's manifesto, along the lines of the recent report for the Russell Group, with top-up fees and massive injections of capital into research? Not if Blunkett has anything to do with it.

The table shows how slow the Labour government has been to reach the levels of education spending, measured as a proportion of gross domestic product (GDP), during John Major's government. Only in this year will Labour's spending rise above Major's lowest year, and then only by 0.1%.

Fortuitously for the government Major's worst performance was in the year before the general election, so Labour will strictly speaking fulfill its manifesto commitment if and when it goes to the polls next year. But measured against Major's performance through the last parliament, the Blair government will fall behind.

If Labour win the election, on the current plans only in the penultimate year of the comprehensive spending review will the government match Major's best year.

The GDP figures have to be taken with a pinch of salt, mainly because Major was prime minister during a recession, while under Blair the economy has grown steadily.

Labour is, according to Treasury figures, increasing education spending in real terms, taking inflation into account. As a real-terms figure spending during the last parliament, from 1992-1997, ran as £36.9bn, £37.9bn, £39.1bn, £39bn, £38.3bn. So far this parliament (1997-2000) it is running at £38.4bn, £38.4bn and £40.1bn and is set to continue on an upward trend.

In that context, the £11.9bn real- terms increase in education spending across the UK by 2003 still looks impressive. The devolved parliaments may decide to spend more and push that figure up still further. In England, which the Department of Education and Employment has direct responsibility for, education spending is planned to increase from £38.8bn in 2000-1 to £49.2bn in 2003-4, some £10.4bn.

fields.headline: A slide to ashes
fields.standfirst: Schools are more likely to be set alight than any buildings except barns. So how can heads protect their premises, and spot the signs that they are at risk, asks  Karen Gold
fields.trailText: Schools are more likely to be set alight than any buildings except barns. So how can heads protect their premises, and spot the signs that they are at risk, asks Karen Gold.
fields.body:
It was the call that every headteacher dreads. Half past two on a Saturday morning, Peter Laurence woke to the sound of the ringing phone. He picked it up and his deputy head told him that his school was on fire. He threw on some clothes and drove to Brigshaw High, a 1,150-pupil 11-18 comprehensive on the semi-rural eastern edge of Leeds.

"I arrived to find the school in flames," he recalls. "For the next few hours we watched the destruction of the whole building."

Almost two thirds of the school was burnt out in the fire, which took place on April 1 this year. The damage is estimated at £8m. The English department, the art department, the science labs, the technology workshops were all destroyed. Teachers' lesson plans and records, some of them built up over entire teaching careers, went up in smoke. So did most of the GCSE coursework. Two youths have been charged with arson. Brigshaw High will not be fully rebuilt until 2002.

Going by the law of averages, Brigshaw High was not the only school to go up in flames that night. Every day, in England, three schools are set on fire. Only 15% of these fires are believed to be accidental: the other 85% are malicious. Insurance figures show that schools are at a higher risk of arson than any other buildings used by people. Only sheds and barns fare worse.

Arson in schools has cost £45m so far this year. That figure is predicted to reach £85m by Christmas, which would make this year the worst since records began. Much of that sum is taken up by a few big fires, like Brigshaw's, but there are hundreds more small ones that do not get out of hand- a survey in 1995 showed the fire brigade was only called to 45% of school fires.

So what are the causes of this epidemic of school arson, and can anything be done to prevent it?

Going by the people who are caught, we think we know who sets schools on fire. It is children, and most of them are boys. Some are mini-arsonists, as young as eight or nine, and below the age of criminal responsibility. Some are not much older: 65% of all offenders cautioned for arson are aged 10 to 14. At any age they are likely to have a connection with the school: to be pupils, former pupils, friends of pupils.

We also know when they set schools on fire - and the season is well under way. According to the Arson Prevention Bureau, malicious school fires peak in May and in July, during school holidays and at weekends. By far the worst time is between 6 and 10pm, although there is small surge between 1 and 3pm too.

There is a clear pattern, says the bureau's school arson expert, Larry Stokes: "Most schools which experience fires, first find they have more graffiti, smashed windows, a small fire in a bin, perhaps a fire in a portable unit, and then a big fire. It's what we call a slide to ashes."

But why do children set schools on fire? At this point we need a caveat. The clear-up rate for arson is terrible: only 10% of arsonists are ever caught. The clear-up rate for school arsonists is even worse. Only 2% of school fires result in a caution or conviction. So any information we have about who sets schools on fire, and what their motives are, is heavily undermined by the fact that we know nothing whatsoever about the nature and motives involved in 98% of them.

Nevertheless, from the few who are caught we can draw some tentative conclusions. Many small children play with matches. Many slightly older ones experiment with fire. Some of them bring their experiments to school without any intention of burning the place down, says Andrew Muckley, a psychologist who used to work with fire-setting children at Aycliffe young offenders' institution.

"People who set fire to schools usually have an interest in fire; they have poor communication skills, they get angry and they act out their feelings. There's always one teacher they get really angry about - most of us get really cross with one teacher, but we can handle it. These people can't.

"The teacher punishes them; now they are going to punish the teacher. They probably come from a family that is all mixed up and doesn't set limits and says things like 'boys will be boys'. "They go in, probably set fire to the classroom of the teacher they are angry with, and run away."

As individual schools gain in power and local authorities decline, some authorities are giving way to pressure from schools in low-risk areas to pay lower premiums than their inner-city, high-risk neighbours.

After this year's fire at Brigshaw High no child missed more than eight days' schooling, and GCSE classes missed only three. Everyone was reinstalled in a mobile school made up of 40 portakabins - making Brigshaw the ironic beneficiary of yet another school fire. I think the school is still suffering from it, because so much effort is devoted first of all to surviving, and then to rebuilding. Take the buildings, says Larry Stokes. School design in the past 30 years has undoubtedly favoured the arsonist over the firefighter.

Architects and school premises committees need to address fire prevention, he says.

"The difference between a £1m fire and a £10m fire may be an inadequate partition between two rooms."

"Schools don't see fire-setting as part of their agenda until the school has gone. They don't talk about it. They see pupil behaviour as the problem: so they exclude the pupil and now he is really angry and he has time to think about the fire he is going to set. If a child comes into school with a bruise on their arm, there's a panic. If a child comes in with a box of matches, the head confiscates them and says 'Don't do that again.' But the most dangerous situation is the one with the box of matches."

Of course schools cannot necessarily then stop the child setting a fire. But there are plenty of people who say they can. Many local fire services now have education programmes, directed particularly at young children who play with matches. They will visit the child and family in their home, talk to them about how scarily fire spreads, encourage them to fit smoke alarms and take responsibility for fire and its consequences, instead of seeing it as an exciting game. Schools can recommend families for these programmes.

For children who have already been caught setting fires, local youth offending teams, sometimes in conjunction with the fire service, run extended versions of the same programme: taking children to the fire station, showing them what happened after they had set a fire and fled the scene, showing them videos of conflagration, encouraging them to see fire as something to treat with respect.

A novel preventative version of this has just been launched in Nottingham, where the city council, Zurich Municipal insurance company, the Arson Prevention Bureau, police and fire services are sending a theatre workshop and curriculum materials into schools, to encourage teenagers to think about the consequences of fire and to carry out fire risk assessments of their own schools.

There is a risk that such a programme might give a determined fire-setter ideas, admits Larry Stokes; no one has tried prevention on this scale before so no one knows. But sooner or later they would probably have set a fire anyway, and - with the proviso again that most arsonists are not caught - such schemes suggest that reoffending rates among their "graduates" are very low.

Andrew Muckley, who ran one among serious arson offenders at Aycliffe, says this is partly because fire-setting is a relatively unrewarding crime. It does not bring the material rewards or excitement of burglary or car theft. Only one of the children who went through his fire-setters' programme was ever sent back to Aycliffe while he was there.

"He was 14; he came back two years later and I thought: 'Oh no, where did we go wrong?' I went to see him and he said 'I'm back here because I've taken about another 80 cars and done another 100 burglaries. But I didn't set any more fires.' "

2 Deter entry with perimeter fencing, security lighting, staff living on site, CCTV.

4 Investigate fitting sprinkler or fire detection systems.

fields.headline: Nobody's baby
fields.standfirst: How much longer can the only Welsh school in England survive? By  Will Woodward
fields.trailText: How much longer can the only Welsh school in England survive?
fields.body:
In a corner of north London, they spent the last day of term at the Ysgol Gymraeg Llundain, the only Welsh language school outside Wales, packing boxes. And then the staff and pupils went away for a week together.

When the pupils said goodbye 10 days ago to the school's home for 38 of its 48 years, in two rooms attached to the former Willesden Green Welsh chapel, they did not know for certain where - or even if - they would be going to the school next term. The chapel, which closed when the congregation fell to just five people, has been bought by Chinese Buddhist monks who, after allowing the school a year's grace, have asked it to leave.

That decision plunged the school into crisis and began a spat between the Welsh Assembly and the Department for Education. Nobody wants it to close, but but nobody with sufficient power has yet come forward to safeguard its future. English ministers and Welsh assembly members have made polite noises and played pass the buck.

With most of the 16 full-time and 16 part-time pupils away at a summer camp in Cardiganshire, the school's trustees are still negotiating for a new home. Stonebridge school in Harlesden has agreed in principle to let the Welsh school move to rooms there for a year; but Stonebridge has not yet put its plans before Brent council. Gymraeg Llundain is, strictly speaking, an independent primary school, but no pupil is ever turned away and those who can't afford the £500-a-term fees come to an agreement with the school. The head teacher, Sian Edwards, is half the permanent staff. The year groups fizzle out at about age 10, as parents move their children into bigger primary schools, to prepare them for the bustle of secondary education.

Part-time pupils of all ages and from across the south-east come from other primaries for one day a week, Friday. They go to schools elsewhere for the rest of the week and have tolerant head teachers.

"It would be disastrous if all this finished," said Alison Garrard, a parent of two children at the school. "I went to a village school in west Wales and I knew everyone in the school and their parents. It's a very supportive village atmosphere."

Hannah, Mrs Garrard's daughter, is aged seven and there is only one other child, a girl, in her year group. "They get on well," says Mrs Garrard.

The Welsh assembly gave £23,500 to tide the school over last year, funnelled through the Welsh Language Board. The assembly is spending £130,000 over three years to support Welsh language among the descendants of the 1865 settlers in Patagonia.

But the assembly's view is that the school is in England and should therefore be funded by the Department for Education. The school is keen on that, too, and has been looking at acquiring voluntary aided status.

Which would be fine except the Department for Education isn't prepared to fund schools which don't use follow the national curriculum in English. Up to the end of key stage 1, aged seven, the school follows the Welsh national curriculum. To do otherwise, says Ms Edwards, "would undermine the whole purpose of the school - there would be no point in carrying on". Beyond key stage 1, the curriculum is in English, but that is still not good enough for the Department for Education.

If Brent and Stonebridge can agree, the school may be saved in the short term. But what it really needs is someone in government to take up its cause. Or failing that, a nice wealthy Welsh benefactor.

fields.headline: Ferguson reopens Beckham rift
fields.trailText: Sir Alex Ferguson has gone public on his bust-up with David Beckham and why he dramatically dropped him last season. It threatens to reopen the rift with Manchester United's highest-profile player with the new season approaching.
fields.body:
Sir Alex Ferguson has gone public on his bust-up with David Beckham and why he dramatically dropped him last season. It threatens to reopen the rift with Manchester United's highest-profile player with the new season approaching.

United's manager reveals how he "blew up" at Beckham and why he banished him from the team for a crucial Premiership match at Leeds in February, in an updated version of his autobiography Managing My Life, serialised in the Sun and the Times.

Although Ferguson writes that the row proved beneficial in that Beckham agreed to spend more time in the north-west and less at his Hertfordshire home - which had been a major irritation to the manager - Ferguson's decision to rehash the dispute in print may provoke further rancour between the two men.

Many will question the timing and the wisdom of the disclosures, not least because they follow hard on renewed speculation about the widely coveted England player's future. And immediately after the February incident the manager reportedly said the matter would not be brought up again.

Only last week Milan, anxious to make a headline signing, claimed they had made a second, improved offer for Beckham - believed to be £40m - to take him to Italy. But United's incoming chief executive Peter Kenyon denied that they had made a bid and said that in any case the player was effectively untouchable.

Beckham, Ferguson writes in the book, "made me lose my temper badly" by missing a Friday training session before the Sunday game at Leeds and then refused to apologise when reporting back on Saturday.

The player claimed he had missed training because he had to look after his son Brooklyn, who was unwell. Ferguson writes that the explanation "would normally have made me totally sympathetic. But when it was well known that Victoria [Beckham's wife] was out in London that Friday I had to think David wasn't being fair to his team-mates."

The manager continues: "It doesn't matter to me how high a player's profile is. At first he simply refused to accept that he had anything to answer for, and that made me blow up... from time to time somebody in my job is confronted with the situation which must be handled in a manner that signifies control."
